in another play variant all the transparent cards are open in the table and the shadow cards are shuffled and open one at a time. The fastest player to find the correspondent transparent card wins a point.

name: Dansbandsspelet
description: Dansbandsspelet is a quiz game, with questions about Dansband music and artists. The questions is in five categories: "Continue the song", "Compititions", "Profiles", "Albums", and "Chanse". One player after another gets one question in one of the categories. If he/she answer right he/she gets one point. The player with most points in the end of the game is the winner.

name: Ryska Postenspelet
description: Ryska Postenspelet ("The Post Office Game") is a quiz game. One player rolls the die, that determines which of the six category to read from a drawn card. The categories are: "Charades", "challenge", "truth", "whispers", "I have never", and "Post Office". If a player finish the challenge on the card he/she gets one point. The player with most points at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Unholy Upheaval
description:
Unholy Upheaval is a game that takes place in the Kingdom of Axios. Four sages, drawn by a mysterious power, accidentally disrupt the harmony of the forces behind the manifest world. Unwittingly they freed a great and terrible power, Orono. The sages recognized their mistake, but were hastily locked away by the knights of the Kingdom. With no one left to stop Orono, the Ancient Forces who formed Axios, must now gain back the loyalty of their creation and return harmony to the kingdom.

In Unholy Upheaval players take the role of one of the 4 Ancient Forces of Axios. Using what limited resources they have, players must gain back the loyalty of their creation and take the power back from Orono. Whoever can acquire the most of Orono’s fragments will take the place as the dominant force once harmony is returned to Axios.

The playstyle of Unholy Upheaval is deck-building with minor PvP elements. Each player starts with a starter set of 10 cards and 0 fragments. They utilize their starter cards to build a more powerful deck from a common pool of available cards, the Aether.

The playing take turns playing and purchasing cards. Each turn follows the followng structure:
1. Check for any relic effects in your battlefield and perform their actions.
2. Play cards from your hand. Each card will provide either resources (Loyalty, Rage, Fragments)or provide powerful effects. Play Minions to your battlefield face up, and Relics into your opponent’s battlefields face up. Resolve all text on each card before playing another card.
3. Use loyalty to acquire Minions and Relics from the Aether. Defeat Shards from the Aether with rage, and gather Fragments from the supply as indicated on each card.
4. Once you have finished acquiring and defeating cards, place all Minion cards played this turn (that are not haunted) face up in your Discard Pile and draw 5 new cards from your deck (if you need to draw a card and cannot, simply shuffle your discard pile to create a new deck.)

Unholy Upheaval ends when the last Fragment is taken from the pool and the round is complete. This way every player has the same number of turns. Players can still earn Fragments after the last one is taken.

Each player counts the Fragments in their pool then adds that to fragment value of the cards in their deck. This number is represented by the fragment symbol in the upper right hand corner of Minions. Relics and Shards do not count towards your score at the end of the game. The player with the most total Fragments is the winner. In case of ties the player with the most relics in their deck is the winner

name: Carpathia
description:
From the publisher:

Carpathia is a table top skirmish game for two or more players set in a dark fantasy world with steam-punk elements. Players take control of a party of heroes and adventurers on a common quest. The core game is designed to be played in around an hour depending on how large of a party you choose to hire. Before the start of the game, players agree on the amount of gold they will each spend on hiring and equipping their party.

You must first choose a hero to lead your party. Heroes are persons of great renown throughout Carpathia and the rest of the world. They are natural born leaders and usually excel at fighting, magic, or even crafting. Once you have hired your hero you can then recruit the rest of your party, purchase additional equipment for your adventurers, magic spells, or other items. The hero you choose will determine the alignment of your party. There are three alignments in Carpathia, good, neutral and evil. You may have guessed that if you hire a hero of the good alignment, you will not be able to hire adventurers that are evil. Neutral heroes can hire either good, neutral, or evil adventurers; although you cannot have both good and evil in the same party. Each of the 14 available factions in Carpathia is of one of the three alignments. Hiring your party entirely from the same faction gives you small stat bonuses. However, each faction also has a specific style of play. Some factions excel at magic, while others are expert warriors. Some are masters of deceit, while others are master tacticians and strategists. The ability to hire your party from multiple factions gives you the option to customize your play style.

Each character in Carpathia comes with his or her own stats, equipment, spells, and other items. All of this information will be found in the rulebook, as well as all the additional equipment you can purchase. Supplied with the rulebook, you will also receive a blank character sheet. This is what you will use to record your heroes and adventurer’s statistics, equipment, spells, items and abilities. Not only will it make it easier to quickly look up character attributes during a game, but will also make it easier to change them, as they can often change during a game, or especially if you are playing a Quest.

Quests in Carpathia are a series of games. During each game your adventurers gain experience, acquire loot, and gatherer resources. However you must be careful because heroes and adventurers can also be hurt or even killed. In between games you will be able to apply gained experience towards new abilities, skills or to increase statistics. You will also be able to attempt to heal any hurt or wounded characters as long as your party possesses the necessary spells or potions required to do so. The loot, whether in the form of gold or items, can be used amongst your party, sold, or even traded to other players. Finally the resources found can also be sold or used to craft weapons, armor, or items if your adventurers possess the required skill sets. Our hope is that these features will add a level of emersion into the world of Carpathia and make the games more rewarding and fun. The Carpathia rulebook will have a number of Quests, but we also encourage players to develop their own.

Those who have played table top war games before will find the core rules of Carpathia familiar, while those new to war gaming should have no problem quickly picking them up. Each player will take their turn, in which he or she can move his or her adventurers, use items, cast spells, engage in combat, or hunt for treasure and resources. The game turn is divided into four Phases. First is The Action Phase, followed by The Movement Phase, then The Combat Phase, and finally The Magic Phase.

During The Action Phase you can activate certain items such as food or magic weapons, attempt to claim resources, or attempt to recover adventurers who have been knocked down or unconscious. During The Movement Phase you may move your adventurers, attempt to climb, jump, swim, or take cover. The Combat Phase is when both shooting and hand-to-hand combat is resolved. Finally The Magic Phase is where characters with any ability in manipulating the winds of magic can attempt to cast their spells. During phases in which you come in direct contact with your opponent, he or she will have the opportunity to retaliate if not otherwise incapacitated. For instance after you charge an enemy adventurer during your combat phase, but fail to either knock down, out, or kill him or her, your opponent will have an opportunity to retaliate with an attack of their own.

Our goal is to make individual games of Carpathia fast paced but also fun and engaging. The Quests are meant to provide further emersion and give players the ability to play out epic stories as they journey across Carpathia in search of honor, glory, treasure, knowledge, power, or the dark energies that inhabit it.

The Carpathia rules are based on a D6 system, and we recommend playing on a 4 foot by 4 foot playing surface. The main rulebook will include the complete rules, 6 quests, full rosters of heroes and adventurers for each of the 14 factions, lots of additional spells, items, weapons and equipment; resource counters, as well as blank character stat sheets. Also in the rulebook will be the full history of the world, as well as the background and history of each faction. Carpathia itself is only a portion of the greater game world. So far we have planned three expansions providing the success of Carpathia, which will explore other portions of the world, offer additional quests, characters, items, and content.

Our goal is to continuously release new miniatures to represent various heroes and adventurers, as well as introduce a guide for building your own characters in one of the planned expansions.

name: TRUMPshit crazy
description:
TRUMPsh*t crazy, is a card game in the vein of Cards Against Humanity. Or in this case Cards Against Politics, Civility, Decency, Political Correctness, Feminism, Human Rights, Civil Rights, Peace and whatever else he spouts forth, generally the complete opposite of what is socially acceptable.

We have taken a wide, varied and often horrifying selection of quotes from the great pumpkin candidate and you get to use them to postulate views in his dulcet and sometimes vitriolic verbal tone.

Players draw 8 red "quote" cards and a player draws and reads out a blue "ask" card. The other players pick their funniest or inappropriate or topical card and hand it to the reader whoc picks the winner. The person with the most blue "ask" cards wins. Play to a timer or till all the cards are gone.

120 "ask" cards and 240 "quote" cards.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Political

name: Détective Mathéo (Second Edition)
description:
Détective Mathéo is a Mathematics card game. This second edition of the game contains five games: additions, subtractions, simple multiplications, all multiplications and divisions. (The first edition contained only the additions, subtractions, and all multiplications.)

Cards are displaying calculations on one side and results on the other side.

Players choose a card set, shuffle the cards, and put the pile between them with the calculations visible. They flip over the topmost card which now shows results and place this card next to the pile. The aim is to be the first to find the only calculations whose result is on the result card.

The player who first finds the right pair gives the result aloud and then the associated calculation. If they are correct, he then wins the "Results" card which is worth one point. If they are wrong, the are out for the rest of that round.

At the end of the game, one card will be left on the table, the player who has won the most card is the winner of the game.

name: Kiyoshikenga抜 Kenai
description:
聖剣ガ抜ケナイ (a.k.a. Kiyoshikenga抜 Kenai) is a semi-cooperative battling game in which players simultaneously reveal a card from their hand to collectively try to pull a sword from a stone. You don't want to waste your strength, though! If the total strength is within the winning range, then whoever played the lowest card wins — unless more than one person played a card of the same value in which case the next lowest person wins.

If you pulled too hard, then the player who played the highest number wins the round — unless, of course, more than one person did the same.

Whoever wins the most rounds wins the game!

name: Charybdis
description:
As part of the Galactic Sciences Coalition fleet, several vessels—including your ship—have been experimenting on a mysterious black hole, NGC 7841, nicknamed Charybdis, for the last several weeks. It was a routine mission until those fools on the GSCV Narwhal miscalculated their hyperjump and disappeared into the event horizon!

Your ship’s alarms scream danger: your instruments register a sudden and violent increase in the black hole’s diameter. The black hole is relentlessly growing larger, and you are dangerously close!

You know you must leave before being gobbled up by the black hole, but your hyperjump drive is useless now that the event horizon is so close, and the gravity waves make your sub-light drive slow and unreliable. If you are to survive, you must escape using every means available to you. Think!

An idea springs to mind: Could you use your ship’s powerful tractor beams to help pull yourself to safety? But what could you target with enough mass and momentum to make a difference?

As the inescapable answer washes over you, you set your jaw in resignation at what you must do. For years you’ve worked closely with the crews on the other ships, and some of them are even close friends. But now, you order your crew to warm up the tractor beam emitters and target the ship ahead… It’s everyone for themselves at the edge of forever.

Gameplay

In Charybdis, you captain a ship and crew trying to escape from the orbit of a black hole that is relentlessly expanding. Your engines are affected by the singularity, so there is only one way to guarantee survival: by targeting other ships with your tractor beam to pull yourself to safety, while dragging them closer to their ultimate doom.

On each turn, you roll your Crew Dice, choosing which to keep and which to re-roll. Your goal is to create combos that allow you to assign your Crew to the various tasks aboard your Ship: manning the Helm (movement), maintaining the Fusion Generators (energy), or upgrading your Navigational Computer, Tractor Beam, or Shields.

You can use your Tractor Beam to steal dice from your opponents, which you roll on your turn in addition to your Crew Dice. These extra dice give you a boost while slowing down your unfortunate targets. You can even lock a Tractor Beam on nearby Asteroids, but watch out--Asteroids can trap you with their gravity and drag you closer to your doom.

After each player has a turn, Asteroids trapped in the Black Hole's gravity fall inward, and then the Event Horizon expands, potentially devouring your Ship and Crew.

Charybdis took 1st place for Best Artwork & Graphic Design, 1st place for Best Written Rules, and 2nd place for Best Overall Design in the 2016 One-Page PNP Contest (see contest results).
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: The Agency
description:
This game is a solo or co-op game depending on if you have any friends who would like to play.

Movement is on a grid based system which is turn based. Each character has a number of Life Points which equal to abilities within the game as well. When they are wounded their life goes down which also reduces their abilities within the game.

Players complete their mission by surviving the game map (which is random apart from a few key elements that will always appear) and completing their mission objective by returning to their starting vehicle.

It maybe to retrieve something, destroy something or any manner of events. These events are decided by the roll before gameplay beings of the Dice of Destiny which give a primary, secondary and bonus mission.

Equipment is varied and unique in some cases. Players start with an amount of points that they can purchase equipment which they can carry and keep in the starting vehicle as this has capacity to store extra equipment.

The characters available are classic type heroes who range from spies to thieves. The single player can control two of these while co-op each player can only control one each.

The scene and era is pulp fiction / cult era and general classic caper / 70's film type scenario!!!

The missions are random generated and can include such types as:


Stop a doomsday device.
Save the husband of the bride.
Kill the undead allied zombies.
Replace the Six Million Pound's man bionic parts with lesser quality items.
Save Schrödinger's cat.
Rob the safe.
Collect evidence.


Everything you need to play the game apart from the dice will be included within the Print and Play rules that are free.

This game can be supplemented with additional furnishings and miniatures. The system allows for very easy expansion and 3rd party supplemental material.

The game also offers basic characters’ progression and surviving characters can be moved from one adventure to another. This in essence means that you may benefit from equipment from a prior mission if you play wisely.
categories: Dice, Exploration, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Liebes Spiel
description:
A journey into the world of feelings
With exciting and erotic game instructions

It turns throwing and advanced on a path the corresponding number of spaces . Then, the instructions on the destination field will be followed. The goal is to get to know each other and may be the first to reach the 'Love Nest'.

name: Pocket Dungeon Thief
description:
Play the role of a thief Searching Dungeons, lock picking treasure chests, pickpocket other players, battle monsters and dungeon bosses for gold and loot!

Pocket Dungeon Thief is a 1 to 3 player card and dice game. Each player draws cards from the search, treasure and loot decks to collect items, gold and loot. Treasure chests are lock picked with the thief dice and monsters or dungeon bosses are confronted with the battle dice.

Combinations of sneaky tactics can be performed to outwit your opponents to gain an edge, for shiny coins!

But gathering gold does come at a price... A treasure chest can be cursed and spawn one of four dungeon bosses that every thief player must unite and battle

name: The Reward Game
description:
Starting with $1.2 million in cash, players (or teams) buy and sell stocks, bonds, real estate, and gold. First player to $10 million wins.

Players start on any square on the board and move clockwise by rolling the dice. Some squares allow you to optionally buy or sell various assets, other squares require you to buy or sell assets. Asset value can change during play when a player lands on one of the "Change In Interest Rate" squares, causing the "Inflation Rate Indicator" (a plastic spinner) to move up or down, indicating a new value for everyone's assets. After the rate change, the player who landed on the square is required to sell from half to all of one of his assets.

The Inflation Rate Indicator starts at "5-10%" and during play will move up and down to "0-5%" or "10-15%". Players may borrow from the bank, but it must be paid back before someone reaches the $10 million goal.

name: Segeln
description: Each player is trying to reach the goal as quickly as possible. The route takes around two turning points. But beware , there are many places where it is temporarily completely windless.

name: Scrambled Slogans
description:
Subtitled "The New Adult Game that Peps up the Party - Smart - Saucy - Sophisticated", Scrambled Slogans consists of six pads (labeled A-F) of perforated and gummed labels. Each pad contains 48 phrases or sayings, such as "Red-headed woman suspected", "Down on the farm", "No metal can touch you", and "What a Young Girl Ought to Know".

The game also includes a pad of blank sheets. Each player or team then takes one or more of the gummed sheets and attempts to write a funny story, using as many as possible of the gummed phrases. The players are allowed to bridge gaps by hand writing any names of people or places, pronouns, prepositions such as in, at, of, on, for, to, etc. as well as a dozen common verbs: be, do, go, can, say, have, see, meet, give, think, know, hear.

After the stories have been completed, each is read aloud and a winner is chosen either by the hostess or by a vote of the players.

name: Diminutives Opposing Civilization
description:
Rude, rambunctious, and raunchy. Diminutives hate civilization and they are on a one-way trip to end it all! Equipping themselves with unique and powerful gear (such as Yo Dong Wang’s Doom Frisbee and the Dreaded Unitard of the Old One) they fight while assembling their ultimate weapon of destruction. Will your diminutive be victorious and be the one to destroy it all?!

Diminutives Opposing Civilization is a card game for 3-5 players. Each player uses quality and gear cards to outfit their diminutive, defeat other diminutives, gather pieces for their ultimate weapon, and destroy civilization! There are literally millions of hilarious combinations in DOC.

If you think that Diminutives Opposing Civilization is just a straight-forward, predictable game, well… think again! DOC also has both “Twist of Fate” and “Quirk” cards. Twist of Fate cards create situations and effects that no can predict. Quirk cards shift the fate of battle in unpredictable ways.

Spontaneous and unpredictable, with just enough strategy, means that Diminutives Opposing Civilization will keep things hilariously interesting!
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Humor, Party Game

name: Tip the Scales
description:
Tip the Scales tests your knowledge and luck against your opponent to tip the scales in your favour.

Your superior knowledge about diet, exercise and other lifestyle issues will get your scales tipping quickly.

Game consists of general knowledge about diet and exercise, activities or positive and negative actions that increase or reduce the weight on your scales.

name: Jippijaja Quiz: Resor & äventyr
description: Jippijaja Quiz: Resor & Äventyr is a party game with 550 questions about travelling, restaurants, museums, and world-famous attractions.

name: Davy Crockett and the Alamo
description:
From the publisher:

Remember the Alamo is a card game where players are trying to keep the Mexican Army from storming the Alamo and breaching the walls. Players are the defenders of the Alamo and will try to stop the onslaught of the Mexican Army.

Players will use their hand of cards to fight back even though they are severely outnumbered. The defenders can position cards to use set collection to utilize the powers on the card or can pass the cards to the player on the left. The players win the game by defeating Santa Anna and his army. The Mexican Army wins by breaching the walls of the Alamo.
categories: American West, Card Game, Dice, Math, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Number, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: På reise i Norge
description:
Make the fastest route from one place to another in Norway .

For example: You are in Svolvaer and may only travel further by car or boat . Do you find a destination that suits ?

Travel by plane, boat , train, bus or car to seven sites in Norway . Put your cards together for the fastest itinerary , complete the journey first and win the game.

name: Wait Up, Grandpa!
description:
From the designer:

Grandpa is visiting, and you and a sibling are going out with him. Your delicious destination: the ice cream stand in the park. Your walk will take you through eight friendly neighborhoods, and there are plenty of interesting objects to explore and collect along the way: stones, insects, bottlecaps and such—pretty much anything you can stuff into your pockets. Stay out of the mud puddles, though, or your mom won’t be happy with you when you get home.

For each round, one player rolls all the dice. Grandpa moves along the path automatically, then each player will have a choice of moves. It's good to maneuver yourself into going first, since that player will have first crack at snapping up objects, but he will also have to deduce what his opponent might do. Other considerations for both players include getting more different objects than their opponent, when to re-roll their dice, and the need to stay close to Grandpa. If you lag too far behind you'll have to entreat Grandpa to "wait up!"-- which will yield negative victory points at the end of the game.

Light fun for kids and semi-serious gamers, Wait Up, Grandpa! provides 30 minutes of game time well-spent.

Components:
1 Game Board
5 Dice in three colors (2 blue, 2 red, 1 gray)
24 Object cubes in eight colors
10 “Wait Up/Hurry Up, Grandpa!” markers, double-sided
3 Mud puddle markers
2 Player tokens (1 blue, 1 red)
1 Grandpa token (gray)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: xChess
description:
Description from the publisher:

xChess is based on a Hexagonal Chess Game invented in Canberra Australia, in 1973 by Wolfgang Flatow. The Flatow Chess Board is a 65 hexagon 8 x 4 x 4 hexagonal matrix, one more hexagon than the traditional 64 square matrix. The chess piece moves are intuitively and logically mapped by closely correlating adjacent and diagonal moves used by the traditional square Chess game. xChess has 2 openings, the Flatow opening can be played using a traditional set of pieces, having 2 bishops (all on the same diagonal grid) and the Fortress opening having 3 bishops (one for each diagonal grid) per side. The Game was refined over 2 years of intensive exploratory play by Canberra Chess enthusiasts and was self-published in 1976 in Australia.

The Flatow Chess Board and openings present the neatest and most compact form of Hexagonal Chess and xChess is the combination of the best openings and pawn variations discovered over the years.

The X in xChess stands for HeXagon, eXtra dimension, eXtra power, eXtra possibilities, eXtra fun and X Factor.

name: Supremacía
description:
Supremacy expansion
It Contains 4 additional cards that help fight the battle front.

Expansión Supremacía
Contiene 4 cartas adicionales que ayudaran a combatir en el frente de batalla.

name: Hermandad
description:
Brotherhood Expansion
Contains 21 cards, 18 German soldiers, 18 French soldiers, 15 ammunition chips, 1 destruction card and one additional trench card.

With this expansion you can play with up to 4 players in a game, semi-cooperative 2 vs 2.

Expansión Hermandad
Contiene 21 cartas de abastecimiento + 18 soldados alemanes + 18 soldados franceses + 15 fichas de munición 1 cartas de destrucción y 1 carta de trinchera adicional, con esta expansión se podrá jugar hasta 4 jugadores en una partida
semi-cooperativa 2 vs 2.

name: Corporate Shadows
description:
Corporate Shadows by Mike Haverty is a Two or Four Player action based card game where players manipulate corporate assets and initiate covert operations against opposing criminal organizations. Support from one of the two major solar system wide governments, research and military actions bolster the players' stance and eventual outcome of the shadowy maneuvers between the players.

Gameplay is based on the Action Rummy Concept with the use of Oversight Cards allowing the player to score points during a Hand at the risk of bringing down the High Court on the player (Player scores no points) if too many are played.

Players may also play Alliance cards to form temporary teams during the course of a hand in order to score points jointly with that Alliance member.

Corporate Asset Cards are collected by the players during each hand in order to score points. The game is played to 150 Points.

name: Big Money Baseball
description:
A card and dicing game for two players.

Big Money Baseball is divided into two phases.

Phase One - The draft. Each player gets 100 dollars to spend on drafting a team of players. The player card deck is shuffled and the first five cards are laid out. Each player card is assigned a position, a set of statistics and a minimum bid amount. The players draft a team of baseball players (at least nine, to fill every position, but bench players are encouraged) by bidding against each other.

Phase Two - The game. Players field their teams and roll dice to determine the outcome of each at bat. Play begins with a pitcher's roll, which is checked against a results chart. Play then continues with a batter's roll and a fielder's roll (if necessary). Play follows normal professional baseball rules. The game can continue for either 3 or 9 innings.

name: Und Hase weiß von nichts!
description: Each player gets the same number of newsstands, one lottery ticket, a pawn and 18 game token (money). The newsstands may be placed on any space in the color of the players pawn. The remaining newsstands can be bought by the players. The players move the pawns around the board according to the results of their dice rolls. Whenever a pawn lands on a space with the newsstand of another player, the owner of the pawn has to pay 3 token to the other player. If a pawn lands on a space with a circled number, the player has to take an (often humorous) event card and follow the printed instructions. The lottery tickets have value for one lap around the board. At the beginning of each round the Player may renew his ticket for 2 token. Lottery winnings are distributed by event cards. After an agreed on number of laps the player with the most money wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Storm the Bridge
description:
In Storm the Bridge, you play as both a leader in charge of a party of crew members and, sometimes, as writer able to change the narrative. You will recruit crew members (some better than others), sabotage other players (all in the name of peace, of course), and fight for control of ship sections (sorry, no holodeck). Action is cut-throat, a well-played card can change the direction of the game, and in the end, only one leader will arise as the new captain of the FSS Polemus.

Storm the Bridge is completely card-based, with 14 oversized cards (nine leaders and five ship sections) and 140 poker-size cards (35 crew members and 105 action cards). Players use their leaders to recruit crew members, and then use the leaders and crew members to recruit better crew and attack ship sections, while using action cards to add bonuses, sabotage the other player, modify crew members, and more. The goal is to control the Bridge ship section card and two other ship sections, then use the Bridge's unique ability - Victory!
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That

name: Koffer zu und ab die Reise
description:
This game contains 3 Ravensburger games:
Koffer packen
Deck zu
Wohin geht die Reise?
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Memory, Travel
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting

name: Strudel
description: The game consists of two decks of cards and, for each player, a timer that acts like a chess or Scrabble clock. One deck is of five letter words, the other of seven letter words. The active player looks at the word at the top of a card that is drawn from the deck of his choice. The rest of the card is hidden. He then either (i) begins naming the word's anagrams that may be hidden on the card, or (ii) says "Strudel" if he believes the word has no anagrams. He tips his timer to its side when he is finished naming anagrams or when he says Strudel and then re-starts it on his next turn. Players advance on a score track for each anagram they name and for each correct Strudel. They are penalized for incorrect Strudels. The winner is the first to the end of the score track or the furthest along when the timers all have run out.

name: To Make a Dollar
description: To Make a Dollar is an economic game that is meant to teach kids about managing their money, making a profit, and the concept of supply and demand. The player is tasked with buying fruit when the price is low and selling when the price is high. Each fruit only has a shelf life of 7 days before it expires so they must decide if they are willing to risk waiting for the perfect selling price or if they need to settle for a smaller profit margin. The player with the most money at the end of the game is the winner.
categories: Children's Game, Economic, Educational, Math, Number

name: NHL All About Trivia Card Game
description: NHL All About Trivia Card Game is a travel-sized edition of the board game by the same name. It includes cards with 250 trivia questions and is officially endorsed by the NHL.

name: TACTX
description: Each sheet of a pad shows a 15X15 grid in which some square have been blacked out. The location of the black squares differs from grid to grid. Players take turns marking non-black squares, with the objective to get three in a row diagonally or orthogonally and thereby scoring three points. Subsequently adding a square to the row means scoring the entire row again. play until all the squares are filled in.

name: VERBA: Español Expansion 1 – Novice Sentence Pack
description: Expansion 1 - Novice Sentence Pack: This 52 card expansion pack extends VERBA: Español in the elementary classroom byproviding an additional 52 sentences, all containing high frequency verbs and novice constructions -perfect for scaffolding language acquisition among beginning learners.The Español Core set is required for play.

name: VERBA: Español Expansion 2 – Additional Nouns
description: Expansion 2 - Additional Nouns: This 72 noun card expansion pack for the Español version of VERBA adds additional nouns to the core set for expanded gameplay. The Español Core set is required for play.

name: VERBA: Latin Expansion 1 – Ablative Absolute & Indirect Statement
description: Expansion 1 - Ablative Absolute and Indirect Statements: This 50 sentence card expansion pack extends VERBA: Latin into the advanced classroom by providing an additional 50 sentences all containing ablative absolutes and indirect statements. Perfect for scaffolding the advanced clauses found in Caesar and Vergil. The Latin Core set is required for play.

name: VERBA: Latin Expansion 2 – Subjunctive Clauses
description: Expansion 2 - Subjunctive Clauses I: This 50 sentence card expansion pack extends VERBA: Latin into the advanced classroom by providing an additional 50 sentences all containing subjunctive clauses; cum clauses, indirect commands, result clauses, and purpose clauses. Perfect for intermediate learners. The Latin Core set is required for play.

name: VERBA: Latin Expansion 3 – Additional Noun Pack
description: Expansion 3 - Additional Nouns: This 50 noun card expansion pack for the Latin version of VERBA adds additional nouns to the core set for expanded gameplay. The Latin Core set is required for play.

name: VERBA: Latin Expansion 4 – Latinitas Recens
description: Expansion 4 - Latinitas Recens: This 72 noun card expansion pack for the Latin version of VERBA adds additional nouns to the core set for expanded gameplay. These nouns are all centered around objects fromthe modern world. The Latin Core set is required for play.

name: VERBA: 中文 – Zhōngwén
description:
VERBA is the new language learning card game developed by The Pericles Group. The concept is incredibly simple -- one player (acting as a judge) draws a random card containing a fill in the blank sentence in the target language and the other players play a card containing a noun from their hand. The player who has played the sentence card then chooses the best card played and that player scores a point. Play continues with that player as the new judge.

All VERBA players benefit from seeing high frequency words, with many repetitions, in a context that fosters authentic learning and comprehensible input. As with all of The Pericles Group's educational games, the play objectives and the learning objectives are one in the same. Players win by making comprehensible sentences, scaffolded by the cards, the images, and the helpful hints included on the sentence cards. We always want to ensure that the learners are seeing correct forms and those forms are continually reinforced by the mechanics.

This is a core set specially tailored for novice level Chinese learners and works great in or out of the classroom!

name: Kändis!
description: Kändis is a quiz game about scandals and television tabs, b-celebrities and superstars. A player get points by giving right answers, and first player to a certain amount is the winner.

name: VWLS Craze
description:
Object: Accumulate the most points by spelling words of 3 or more letters using the VWLS Craze cubes during three timed rolls.

Play: Each player in-turn rolls the five VWLS Craze cubes. Using the consonants rolled, the player mentally adds vowels to form words. Words are spoken and spelled aloud. Another player writes down each word as it is spelled. Score is calculated after the time runs out (using a sand timer).

Score: words with 3-letters, one point each
words with 4-letters, two points each
words with 5-letters, three points each
words with 6-letters, five points each
words with 7-letters (or more), ten points each

name: Quadtriple
description:
Quadtriple Word Game (Two Games in One)

Triple: Each player simultaneously and secretly forms words using 3 randomly selected letter tiles. Words can be any length but must contain all three letters. After the time is up, players in-turn read their word lists aloud. Players cross off words from their lists that match the words being read aloud. Each player scores points for words only he or she wrote down on their word pads. After playing nine rounds, the game is over and the player with the highest score wins.

Quad: Same game as "Triple" only 4 letter tiles are randomly selected instead of three.

name: Five Round Revolver
description:
This new, fast paced, Russian roulette themed card game puts players in control of their own fates. This deadly game of chance will not only test your luck, but your nerves as well.

Each round, the dealer deals face-up a card to each player from the deck. If the card is a Click, the player will stay alive and continue in the round, but if it is a Bang!, the player has gotten shot and must leave the round with no points. Each Click card will also contain the number of points won by the player who posses it. The play continues in a clockwise fashion with each player deciding whether they will like to collect their points and exit the round, or risk their lives with a new card for the possibility of getting more points. Once all the players have either chosen to leave or have been shot, the points are tallied, the deck is shuffled, and the next round begins. The first player to 50 points is the winner.

name: WOSOM
description:
Earth in the year 3200 is devastated and destroyed in post-apocaliptic environment, erosion and pollution have caused tectonic plates come together creating a single continent called "WOSOM".
4 clans of warriors have survived and have to rebuild their empires, metallurgy is the basis of development but resources are limited and must fight for being the biggest.

Wosom is a card game, where you use resources to build and earn points.
Each clan is led by an emperor (CARD), owners of large golden domes. which you can block a hacker attack.

There are also skilled warriors soldiers to ravage silver and copper mines. You can block with H3 virus.

And finally are androids, robots programmed servers to obtain iron and aluminum. which can be locked with an electrical failure.
there is an interactive card that has a QR code, reading this code with your phone will get immunity in any of your armies.

The game is won by whoever gets in the end the most points in resources (iron, gold, silver, aluminum, or bronze)

Wosom is a fast game of interactive cards, based on competition and strategy.

From the publisher:
La tierra en el año 3200 se encuentra devastada y destruida en un ambiente post_apocaliptico, la erosión y contaminación han provocado que las placas tectónicas se junten creando un solo continente llamado “WOSOM”.
4 clanes de guerreros han sobrevivido y se disponen a reconstruir sus imperios, la metalurgia es la base del desarrollo pero los recursos son limitados y deben pelear por ser los mas grandes.
Cada clan está dirigido por un emperador, dueños de las grandes bóvedas de oro.
También hay soldados guerreros hábiles para devastar minas de plata y cobre.
Y por último se encuentran los androides, robots servidores programados para la obtención de Hierro y Aluminio.
Ganará quien al final obtenga la mayor cantidad de recursos.

Wosom es un juego rápido de cartas interactivo, basado en competencia y estrategia.

name: To D Island
description:
To D Island is a stick-men survival game, where the players (the stick-men) have to face the dangers of the island and escape. It can be played cooperatively, with all the players working together, or competitively, where it’s each player for himself and until the last man standing.

The dangers the players must face are the devious traps meant to hinder them on the way, the Monster trying to devour them and the volcano which will eventually envelop the island. But most importantly, the players have to deal with the Flip, an event which will change the perspective of the island, and move the play to an entirely different map, one where is it a lot more difficult to survive and get away from the Monster.

To help them, the players search through the island looking for items that boost their abilities, movement and overall make their job easier. However, the traps are hidden amongst the same treasures that they need to find items, so event this is a perilous task.

Welcome To D Island!
mechanics: Area Movement, Area-Impulse, Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Evil & Good
description:
Evil & Good is a two players game where each player represent a divinity ancient God.
In the game the players can see the progress of a civilization from prehistoric to modern times.
This civilization evolutions by automatic system (know by players) and the Gods (players) interact with the fate and future of this civilization using cards.
Each player has a secret objective for humanity's destination. The player who is the first to reach his objective wins! But beware! Playing with the humanity destination could have fatally consecuences and if the civilization collapses both players lose.


Evil & Good es un juego para dos jugadores en el que cada jugador representa un dios divino de la antiguedad.
En el juego los jugadores iran viendo el progreso realizado por una civilizacion desde la epoca prehistorica hasta tiempos modernos.
Esta civilizacion evoluciona mediante un sistema automatico (conocido por los jugadores) y los Dioses (jugadores) interacturan con esta civilizacion para influir en su futuro y destino mediante la utilizacion de cartas.
Cada jugador tiene un objetivo oculto sobre el destino de la humanidad, el primer jugador en completar sus objetivos ganara! Pero cuidado! Tensar demasiado la cuerda puede llegar a hacer que esta se rompa y si la civilizacion collapse ambos jugadores perderan la partida.
categories: Card Game, Civilization, Print & Play, Religious

name: Warrior Clash
description:
The greatest warriors of history have been assembled for the ultimate battle to determine their legacy.

Warrior Clash is a capture and elimination strategy game that pits greatest warriors in history against each other. Players will draft teams of warriors, defend their land, collect resources with the goal of conquering their enemies. These battles are played atop modular gameboards which create hundreds of possible areas.

Each warrior has a different arrangement of trait scores between the categories of Grit, Agility, Ingenuity and Strength. As warriors are moved throughout the gameboard, the players will attempt to rely on relative strengths and exploit weaknesses of their enemies. When matching sides of two opponent warriors are aligned, they can do battle. The trait scores determine the handicap of the fight, but rolls of the dice determine the victor.

Will your team be the last one standing?
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Player Elimination

name: Eat or Eaten
description:
User summary
Eat or Eaten is a two-player abstract game with a theme of hares struggling for feeding ground. On a 5x6 square grid board, players have five hare tiles each. Their goal is to capture four of their opponent's hares or to occupy their opponent's burrow for one turn. There are three types of hares, which determine their movement directions allowed, and each type has a flip side that alters its direction. You may flip your tile by consuming one turn, or moving into a special square.

This intellectual game is suitable for those who began to enjoy thinking.

There are two editions of the game. The original Version was produced for the Spring 2015 Tokyo Game Market (TGM). Each TGM, designers are invited to face a challenge, to design a game under certain conditions. This is where the ¥500 microgames came from, which included Love Letter. The Spring 2015 TGM challenge was '2種カードゲー企画' which was to bring games using only two types of cards. The first edition of Eat Or Eaten was produced to satisfy the 2種カードゲー企画 challenge. The components were only cards and the field was only 3 x 4 square. The Hares behaved differently between editions too. In the first edition, when a Hare was flipped over, it changed the power relationship with opponents' Hares, leading to a fourway stand-off. In the second edition, produced for the Autumn 2015 TGM, the Hares have equal power, but flipping a Hare changes the way it moves. In both Versions, the Hares are competing for food.

Publisher's summary
うさぎの餌場争いをテーマにした、二人用のアブストラクトゲームです。５匹のうさぎを使って争い、相手の巣穴マスに１ターン留まるか、相手のうさぎを１匹にすると勝利します。駒は裏返すことによって、動き方が変化します。頭をしっかりと使うゲームで、考えることが楽しくなってきた方におすすめです。

name: Describe: Perspective Exploration
description: The game is a deck of cards, each with an adjective and three questions related to that adjective. The instructions include i) a Headbanz-style game in which a player tries to guess the word that is pasted to his forehead as the other players act it out, ii) an Apples to Apples-style game in which a player guesses which of the other players played which adjectives that describe him, and iii) a Balderdash-style game in which the guesser guesses which players wrote which answers to one of the questions on the card.

name: Caviar: The Elegant Challenge
description:
Caviar is an abstract strategy game played on 8x8 grid with each of the corner spaces missing. This results in the first and last rows having only 6 spaces instead of the usual 8. Each player has 6 tiles numbered 1-6 which are placed on the first and last row in numbered order.

On a player's turn, he rolls 6 dice to determine which pieces may move and by how many spaces. To begin with, pieces may only move sideways, forward, or forward diagonally, but may not move backwards.

If a piece is adjacent to an opponent's piece, it can be jumped in a Checkers fashion and removed from the game. Once a piece reaches the opponent's starting row, it becomes a king and can now move backwards.

The first player to eliminate all of his opponent's pieces from the game is the Winner.

name: Give Me 5!
description:
Similar to Rummy 500, you are trying to complete a goal and get rid of the cards in your hand to end the round. The game consists of five cards that must be completed in order.

Once you complete a goal, during the next round you work on your next goal while the other players are still trying to complete the previous one.

Goals:
1. Set of any 3 strawberries plus any 2 spinach
2. Set of any 3 tomatoes plus any 2 kiwi
3. Run of 5 in any suit (fruit or vegetable)
4. 2 runs of 3 in any 2 suits
5. Any 5 of one suit plus two 3's

Winner of the game is the first to complete all five goals in order.

name: New Jack City
description:
Welcome to the fastest growing suburb in the country. You and your opponents are cast as very irresponsible real-estate developers charged with the task of building houses, shops and factories to make quick money before larger interests notice the community.

New Jack City is a city-building game where players place tiles that contain residential, commercial, or industrial properties. Players must place tiles by matching the roads and construct them using workers known as builders. Builders start counting down when the property is connected to the electric grid. Constructing large properties offers bonuses which allow you to outpace all other players. To win a player must earn more money than all other players by constructing buildings before the city's’ electricity grid becomes maxed out.

name: OfficeDungeon: The Quest for Promotion
description:
OfficeDungeon is a card RPG for 2 to 4 players taking a humorous poke at the stereotypical office environment. Choose one of four Heroes and collect Promotion Points to crawl your way to the promotion you've always wanted. But be careful! Your co-workers and Bosses will want to knock you down a peg.

The main goal of the game is to have the most Promotion Points (PP) after either the defeat of the required number of Bosses or when the deck has been played through once. PP has another purpose, however: it is also player's currency, allowing them to purchase equipment, items, and companion creatures to boost their stats and stand a chance against whatever stands in their way.

Players choose their Hero Card at the beginning of the game, each representing an entry level position in the Office. From there, they encounter creatures, loot, and the dreaded Instant cards as they work their way through the 90-card deck. A simple, stat-based combat system and the ability to make your own shady backroom deals between players facilitate quick, competitive play.

name: Big Time Tennis
description:
Introduction


It’s the Wimbledon finals, and you’re facing off against an opponent that’s every bit your equal. Will you play your best, smartest game? Know when to play aggressively? Keep momentum and use your entire bag of tricks to win the match? Big Time Tennis is the only board game that plays like real tennis. You’ll experience long volleys, dribblers off the net, service aces, fatigue-- and hit great lobs and other strokes. You’ll even be able to challenge the referee’s calls!

Object of the Game


======Use your skills, wits and a little luck to win the match and become the champion of Wimbledon!

Components


1 Game Board
1 7-Point Tiebreaker board
1 Scoreboard
1 10-sided Die
16 Action cards (2 sets)
48 Momentum cards
8 Player markers (4 gold, 4 silver)
1 Tennis Ball token
1 Momentum marker (double-sided)
1 Advantage marker
1 At-the-Net token

(I only rate my own games so they'll appear in user searches.)

name: Retro Rocket Rally
description:
Players race their vintage rocket ships through a random and mostly unexplored galaxy, encountering asteroids, UFOs, wormholes and more as they collect Star bucks to buy fuel and rocket parts. The first one to collect 3 Flags is the winner.

A deck of space cards is drawn dealt out in a conveyor belt system that creates the board as you play. Players must ration their money and fuel cards to avoid calamity. Ship upgrades can be purchased to give them an edge over their opponents. The game is random enough to be challenging without being dependent on the whim of dice.

A light racing and hand management game intended to fill a sweet spot between Sorry! and Merchants of Venus.
mechanics: Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Trading

name: I See What You Did There
description:
I See What You Did There is a game about convincing your friends that you're clever. Convince them by relating the cards using any means of interpretation necessary.

Every card has a word on the top half and a game instruction on the bottom half. Players either use the abilities detailed on the bottom half card (ex: While this card is in play, players must repeat the last word of their sentence sentence) or try to connect 3 of their cards together (ex: Penis, Kindness, STD). Successfully convincing your fellow players that 3 of your cards are connected earns you a stack; first player to 3 stacks wins.

I See What You Did There is NOT responsible for any shenanigans you and your friends get into. (Including prank calls or murder)

name: War Torn
description:
In a war torn land, you find yourself trying to start over, but war seems to follow you.

The world has been all but destroyed by war. You are the leader of your people, looking for untouched land that hasn't been destroyed by war. After a long journey you find this new land and you start to build a new home for your people. Other Leaders have the same idea, and the new land breaks out in war.

War Torn is a resource management game with Drafting and Building of your new city. Each player starts with a limited amount of resources to start their new home. Craft your City to match your play style, and be the first player to gain enough Victory Points to claim the land as your own.

Play as unique characters like a Lava Ape - The Fire King, or a Necromancer Crow that raises the dead. In this 2-4 player game you will find yourself building, fighting and deceiving other players to claim the victory.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: Who am I in Wonderland?
description:
From the publisher´s website:

Which fairy tale hero would you like to be? The Dragon or the Princess? Lets make it a surprise instead!
Pick a card and let the magic begin! Only the others can see who you have become, don't even try to look into the mirror! Your task is to ask clever questions and guess who you are based on the answers of the other players.

In order to guess who or what he/she turned into (what creature the card depicts) the first player has to ask questions from the other players but they can only answer with “Yes” or “No”.
For example:
- Am I human? Boy? Girl? Etc... The well known fairy tales can help you in coming up with the questions. If the first player successfully guesses who or what he/she has been turned into, he/she can look at the card and keep it and it is the next players turn. If the first player is unable to guess the card, you should set it aside. Before you start the game you should agree upon how many times you want to change (how many cards one player can pick during the game) and the player with the most cards at the end of the game wins!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Deduction, Fantasy

name: Arthur et la Vengeance de Maltazard: le Jeu de Course
description:
Help Arthur, Betameche, Selenia and Max reach the passage room as fast as possible ! The future of the Minimoys is in your hands !

Playing in turns, roll a direction and a speed dice to move your vehicle as fast as possible while avoiding Maltazard's soldiers and collecting bonus cards to help you be the first to reach the end of the race.

name: Poleis: Ancient Cities
description:
The poleis were the city-states of ancient Greece. Each state was like a political entity ruled by their own citizens. Your goal is to form the greatest Greek alliance, build wonders and be favored by deities.

COMPONENTS:

There are three types of cards:

POLIS CARDS, the backbone of the game, which provide resources, some abilities, Victory Points, trade routes, deity worshiping.

WONDERS CARDS, which give Victory Points. These require certain resources and once build they belong to that player.

DEITIES CARDS, give Victory Points. These require faith, they belong to the player that worships a certain deity the most - during turns these can switch among players.

GOAL:

The goal of the game is to win the most victory points.

SETUP:
The deities and wonders cards are placed face up in the middle of the table. The starting player will get two polis cards, the rest will form the draw deck.

GAMEPLAY:

During a round, a player, must draw until he has three cards in his hand. Then must choose one card and place it in front of him - once doing that he will acquire faith and resources symbols.

He then checks if he meets any deity or wonder requirements.

The round ends with the cards passed to the next player.

END OF GAME:

The game ends when all players have five polis cards in front of them, in a row.

SCORING:

Players add the Victory Points from Wonder Cards, Deities Cards, the longest trade route and any extra victory points from the polis cards.

name: Funedco
description:
According to the publisher, this educational card game is "designed to improve vocabularies, improve spelling and provide profitable entertainment". The game consists of a pack of 72 cards, each of which bears a single letter of the alphabet in large print. The deck has between one and six cards of any given letter.

Six cards are dealt to each player. The dealer begins by playing one of his cards and announcing a word starting with that letter. Subsequent players must play the next letter in a word on the board if they can, or start a new word if they cannot. They then draw a card from the deck to replace the one played.

After each player has had a chance to play on a word that has been announced, subsequent players may change the announced word to any other that word that includes in order the letters already played.

Players get points for completing words, ranging from 5 points for a 2-letter word to a maximum of 1,000 points for a 10-letter word. Each time a player takes a trick by completing a word, he may also "declare" another word for which he has all the necessary letters in his hand. He scores for that word as well, and then ends his turn as usual by drawing a card. Winner is first to 2,000 points.

name: Classified
description:
How well do you really know your friends? Find out in the ultimate party game of opinions... Classified!

Each round, one player is assigned a number 1-11, but isn't told what it is. Then, the rest of the group has to try to get that player to guess what the number is by giving a clue based on a shared prompt -- for example, "the beverage you drink on a hot day" -- in the "manner" of the number, where 1 is the worst, and 11 is the best.

For example, if it were a 1, one might say, "warm cobra venom." An good clue for 11 might be, "a smoothie made from fruits found in the Garden of Eden."

If the guessed gets it right, they get to keep the card. If they're wrong, they award the card to whomever they feel gave them the best clue.

First person to five cards wins!

name: Würfel-Tennis/Pfui Spinne
description:
Würfel-Tennis (2 players)
This game simulates a tennis match by spinning a top (or rolling a die) and moving the ball (game piece) accordingly. The ball moves from one half of the game board to the other and back. Generally two sets with up to 10 fault points are played. Only if the two sets are a draw, a third set is played to determine the winner.

Pfui Spinne (backside of the board, 2-4 players)
The players start at space 1. Movement is determined by the spinning top (or a die). If the players get on space 21 (the spider) they lose the game. The last player in the game is the winner.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Deckvilization
description:
A very straightforward yet strategic deckbuilding campaign game with Civilization theme.

Players start with the same set of 12 cards representing their Stoneage tribe and keep developing their society, card after card. The game can be played in two modes:

Campaign mode: After the first game (Era I) players score their points and set their decks aside. The next time they'll play, each player is going to start with his own old deck and new cards will be available in the market (cards from Era II). After 5 games (5 eras), the player with the highest sum of points is the winner.

Fast mode: Use less copies of each card; players play a one-shot game purchasing cards from the market and refilling it with cards of the next eras. The player with the highest sum of points at the end of this single game is the winner.

The game mechanics are both similar and different from the original Dominion; basically, players can play a card and purchase a card from the market, as in Dominion. However, the market is a row of cards instead of different deck containing the same card in multiple copies. Moreover, there aren't the usual coins or victory point cards. Each card has a point value, an effect, a cost, a colour, and can be discarded from hand together with other cards of the same colour to purchase a new card from the market. There are Leaders and Wonders too; Leaders are multicolour and have powerful effects while Wonders can be purchased at any time and they provide more ways to score extra points or other bonuses. Keep them separated from your deck.

In the campaign mode: players choose and obtain a Leader at the end of each game, with the player with the highest score being the first to choose. Wonders can be purchased at any time (max. 1 per Era) in place of a card of the market, and players keep all their Wonders until the end of the 5 eras.

name: What of It?
description:
Subtitled in the rules as "A Game of Family Supplies", this 1889 card game is based on the familiar mechanics of Happy Families, where players try to assemble sets of cards by asking each other for cards related to ones they already hold.

In this case, the 40-card deck is divided into 10 sets (called orders) comprised of a variety of household ingredients. Order 8, for instance, includes Prunes, Oatmeal, Cloves, Chicago Yeast Powder and Mustard.

This game has two distinct features. First, the order sets vary both in size and point value. The ten orders include four of 3 cards worth 5 points if completed, three of 4 cards worth 10 points, two of 5 cards worth 15 points, and one of 6 cards worth 20 points.

More importantly, the game has an educational focus. Each card lists three facts about the title ingredient, and three key words related to the facts on each other ingredient card in the order. If player A asks player B for the card "Citron" and B holds it, B says "What of It?" and A must then provide one of the three facts about Citron before taking the card.

name: College
description:
This 1908 card game published in Philadelphia is based on the rivalry between Cornell, Princeton, Yale and University of Pennsylvania. The 60-card deck is divided into four suits of 15, each representing one of the four colleges. In addition to being numbered from 1 to 15, each suit contains cards with letters spelling out the name of its college. The object of the game is to complete the name of one of the four colleges using only the letters from its suit.

Players are dealt five cards each, and five more go face-up on the field between them. Each player on his turn has the opportunity to capture cards on the field by playing a card that adds up to the same number (e.g. a 13 can be played to capture a 9 and 4). He plays until unable to capture any more, and then adds one of the cards from his hand to the field. When a player exhausts his hand, he gets a new hand of five cards.

Players must declare which college they are playing for, and if there is competition for one, the first player to get the 15 of that suit takes over and the other player must go after a different college.

Letter cards of the desired college are placed in front of the player as successfully used or captured, and the remaining cards go into a discard stack which becomes the replacement deck when needed. While two colleges have only four letters (PENN and YALE), the values of the letter cards ensure that each college is as hard to complete as the others (e.g. PENN has letter cards of 12, 13, 14 and 15, while PRINCETON includes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9 and 15).

name: Climbing Path
description: A traditional dexterity game, Climbing Path involves carefully moving a ball up the face of a sloped wall full of holes, trying to avoid the holes in order to reach the destination, by means of pulling on two strings attached to a ball carrier. Suggested paths printed on the board can be followed for varied difficulty, or you can attempt your own path. This is similar to the dexterity game Labyrinth, but this one is vertical, and uses strings to move the ball, instead of tilting the board.

name: Cats & Caverns
description:
Cats & Caverns is a cooperative game for 2-6 players where you play the role of a house cat–ahem–feline hero.

You and your team are working to rid the realm–your home–of a Big Cheese, along with his villainous rats, that has taken up residence in a nearby network of caverns under the house.

Traps have been laid and henchmen lie in wait for you. Defeat them for treasure–things around the house, really–and continue to until you find and defeat the Big Cheese!

While adventuring in the caverns:

A lineup is created based on the number of players
Villains and traps are ordered by speed.
Heroes each roll a D20, adding their speed bonuses, and join the battle lineup in order. Heroes can, at the start of battle, choose to be later in the lineup for strategic purposes.
Once ordered, heroes will take their turns, attacking or disarming traps as desired.
When each cavern is cleared, they will then roll on potential loot based on the Cavern Card and the battle mode (cat or beast) chosen.

name: Under Construction
description:
Under Construction is a 2-6 player worker placement game that puts players in the role of general contractor.

You need to win contracts (lowest hidden bid wins), collect the necessary resources, and then build them in order to get cash and increase your reputation.

With a modest amount of bluffing, resource management, worker placement and Development Cards—that can help you or harm others—there’s a little something for everyone.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Turn Order: Time Track, Worker Placement
publishers: Cray Cray Games, Print & Play Productions

name: Orinpikku nekkyō yūgiban
description:
オリンピック熱狂遊戯盤 [= Olympic frenzy board game]
Board game issued August 1932 as a supplement to volume 19, no. 8 of the monthly magazine "Shonen Club".
The game was produced at the time of the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics. Four players represent the USA, France, Japan and the UK. Each has 4 starting counters (athletes), who must move to the centre of the circular board (bypassing the unplayable spaces representing Finnish, Norwegian, German and Canadian competitors), collect a 'laurel wreath' and return to the goal behind the player's 4 starting spots.
Paper-scissors-rock is used to determine which player is able to move one of his athletes to an adjacent space. If a player's athlete lands on another player's, the two play paper-scissors-rock again: the winner can move to an adjacent space, the loser's is eliminated.
The reverse side of the board features name and photographs of all the Japanese athletes who competed at the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics.

name: The Federation Game
description:
A version of 'snakes and ladders' themed around the federation of the Australian colonies. The numbered board spaces from 1841 to 1901 represent years. Players roll the die and move towards 1901, moving up ladders and down snakes if they land on these. In addition, some spaces require a player to answer a trivia card on some topic of Australian constitutional history. A correct or wrong answer moves the player forward or back 2 spaces respectively .
Comes with folding board with rules printed on it, and deck of 34 cards. The die and player tokens required for play do not seem to have been included.
Produced by the Departments of the Senate and of the House of Representatives, of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

name: Tramid
description:
"The fascinating boardgame"

Abstract race game played with tetrahedral pieces on a hexagonal board divided into six large equilateral triangle regions, each of which is subdivided into 25 equilateral triangles which are the movement spaces. The centre triangle in each of the 6 larger triangles regions is marked with a letter of the alphabet (A through F), each of which is the starting and finishing space for one of the players.

The six playing pieces are tetrahedrons, each with one face in each of the colours; red, blue, white and orange. All 6 pieces have the same colour sequence, but are distinguished by each face being marked with the letter (A to E) corresponding to the start/finishing space to which it pertains

In each game, 3 of the spaces (except the start/finish space) in each region are marked with one of the colours; red, blue or orange. The players must move from their own starting spaces, to tag all the spaces of a particular colour and return to their own starting space to finish.

The game can be played with each player required to make three laps of the boar,d once tagging ll the red spaces, then all the blue then all the orange. Alternatively players race the same coloured track as their opponent opposite in each round (e.g. players A & D race the red track, B & E the blue, and C & F the orange; then in rounds 2 & 3, swap colours).

Pieces are moved by either
a)rotating 120 degrees in place through a vertical axis (i.e. the face-down side remains face down), or
b)by pivoting the piece along one of the three edges touching the board, so that it 'rolls' into one of the 3 spaces adjacent along one of the sides of the current space.

To enter (and tag) a coloured space, the colour of the face-down side must match that of the coloured space.

Each turn a player rotates his piece in place or moves to an adjoining triangular space. First player to complete the race around the predetermined course wins.

The game does not appear to have been published in a commercial version. Rather, an 18-page manual with hand-drawn line illustrations was produced in 1986 suggesting players make their own copy of the game for tabletop play, or even construct a giant set for outdoor use.

A 3-page supplement (Modified Tramid) was produced in 1987, with proposals to improve the quality of a manufactured board, and slight changes to the rules..

name: 骸骨王VSボドゲ探偵 (Skeleton King vs Boardgame Detective)
description:
User summary
骸骨王VSボドゲ探偵 (Gaikotuou tai Bodogetantei) means Skeleton King vs Boardgame Detective in English. This is a 12 card expansion deck for the game Criminal 're In Detective. In this extension of the rules, it is possible that the culprit can kill the detective.

Publisher's summary
Criminal 're In Detective の拡張カードセットです。この拡張ルールでは、犯人が探偵を殺すことが可能です。

name: Peekaboom
description:
Peekaboom is a fast and outrageously fun strategy game where you work with your partner to assemble and detonate your explosive device before your opponents can detonate theirs.

Sounds easy? Not so fast! You need to use secret signals to let your partner know when your device is ready to explode. Don’t make it too obvious or you’ll get caught. But if it’s not obvious enough, your partner won’t notice it… And don’t forget to watch your opponents or you’ll miss their secret signals!

At the start of the game, each player gets a secret signal card, 3 explosives cards (the player's hand) and a stack of unknown explosives cards. To start a round, each player takes a card from the top of their stack and places it face up in the center of the table. Then the player tries to collect 3 of a kind by discarding a card from their hand and collecting one from the center of the table. There are no turns - players collect cards simultaneously. As soon as a player has 3 of a kind, he or she performs the secret signal described on the secret signal card (e.g. touch your nose, tap the table, etc...). If the player's partner sees the signal and shouts 'BOOM!' that team wins the round. If an opponent sees the signal and shouts 'SNIP!' the opponent's team wins the round. The first team to reach 10 points wins (7 points for a 6 player game).


Bluff! Send fake signals to make your opponents mistakenly say ‘SNIP!’.
Watch what explosives your opponents are collecting. Enjoy the look of surprise on their faces when you say ‘SNIP!’ before they have even made their signal.
Alternatively, if you see an opponent collecting a particular explosive, grab it when it appears on the table before they manage to grab it themselves.
Even better, if you already have an opponent’s card in your hand, play it and say ‘SNIP!’ as soon as he or she picks it up.
You should also watch what your partner is collecting, maybe you have a card he or she can use.
Watch for players who aren’t collecting any cards, they probably have collected 3 of a kind already.
Confuse your opponent by constantly dropping and collecting extra cards so that they can’t see what explosives you are really collecting.
There are blank signal cards in the Signals deck. Make up your own signals.
For more advanced players - don’t use the Signals deck at all! Each team makes up 3 Signals before the game and uses them from start to finish.

name: Circle of Democracy
description:
วงเวียนประชาธิปไตย = Wongwian Prachathippatai

A simple roll-and-move race game, derived from the traditional European game of the goose, to which has been added a theme of Thailand's evolution towards democracy. Players roll a die and move their tokens around a spiral race track of 145 numbered spaces to end at the Democracy Monument in Bangkok in the centre. Various spaces contain thematic bonuses or penalties. The board is surrounded by a chronology of Thai democracy from the Siamese revolution of BE 24 June 2475 (AD 1932) to the ‘Black May’ protests of BE 17 May 2535 (AD 1992).

The game, and the Thai Institute that published it, were sponsored by the German Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung (Konrad Adenauer Foundation).

Entirely in Thai, except that the title is also given in English on the outside and inside of the folding board.

name: Spider-Man vs Doc Octopus
description:
Spider-Man and his team of superheroes vs. Doc Octopus; Who will win this tension-filled race? With a lot of luck and daring play you can help Spider-Man and the superheroes overcome their foe. Be careful - risky play isn't always rewarded!

Spider-Man vs Doc Octopus is a roll-and-move game where the players each have to reach the finish before Doc Octopus does. Each turn, a player decides how often they want to roll the die (up to four times). However, if they roll an "X" in any of their attempts, they do not get to move. Instead, Doc Octopus advances a number of squares equal to the number chosen at the beginning of the turn.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Toulavá Kamera
description: A Trivia game with 494 questions and answers about attractions of the Czech Republic, which appeared in the program "Toulavá Kamera" from Czech Television divided into thirteen categories by regions. Win a Stamp for each region, head to Capital city Prague and answer the final questions to win the game.

name: One Piece Board Game: Dream Sea Tribe Dan Battle Royale
description: The players uses a spinner to be able to walk 1-6 steps on the board. On the board player can be able to pick crew cards, and can place them on there 3x3 player board. The crew gives abilities to use during the game. The winner is the player that first reach with end of the board.

name: Magically Cute Creatures
description:
In the game of “Magically Cute Creatures”, players will use a set of creature cards to defeat one another in a turn based game. The game play is very similar to “Rock, Paper, Scissors”, where one type of creature and/or element beats a different creature or element type. In this deck series, however, all cards have BOTH a creature and element attached to them. This means that every card is individually unique, and players can use each card differently depending on the type of game they wish to play. The elements covered in this game are: Fire, Water, and Nature. The creatures introduced in this game are: Dragons, Phoenixes, and Unicorns.
Remember!
Dragons beat Unicorns – Unicorns beat Phoenixes – Phoenixes beat Dragons
AND
Fire beats Nature - Nature beats Water - Water beats Fire
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Charity: The Generous Game
description:
"You have earned a fortune, and you want to give it away to charity, but you can't help acquiring more money. don't give it all away though, or you are back where you started!"

Game components: box, board, 1 die, 8 playing pieces, 50 charity cards, 50 income cards, 88 silly cards, 100 quiz cards, play-money

Simple roll-and-move race game on a 64-space track, which includes a loop in the middle. Players start with $10,000,000 and have to give as much away as possible. The player with the *least* amount of money when one player reaches the finish space wins.

The main types of spaces are:
- Charity space: draw a 'charity' card and give away (to the bank) the amount of money indicated.
- Income space; draw an 'income' card and collect the amount indicated from the bank.
- Quiz space: answer the charity-related trivia question on a 'quiz' card correctly and move to the next charity space, answer incorrectly and move to the next income space.
- Silly space: follow the instructions on a 'silly' card correctly (or not) to gain a bonus/penalty.
Other spaces include Black Hole, Insurance, Miss a turn, Throw again, Move forward, and Go back.

The game was endorsed by 10 high-profile Australian charities, whose logos feature on the board and box: MS Australia, National Stroke Foundation, Asthma Foundation, Make-a-Wish Foundation, Royal Blind Society, Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute, Lifeline, Legacy, Barnardos Australia, and the RSPCA.
$7.50 from each game sold was given to these charities.

name: Patented Zone & King Flower
description:
The essential element is the game board, constituted by a pliable tablecloth in PVC (80x80), with two sides, which let the use of the board in the front and in the back, so that each box contains two games.

Protected Zone, a role game with two characters. It consists in the virtual simulation of the surviving fight against terrorism. The pieces who live in a district, must cross it, enter the high attacks risk area and, after they have gone out of it, reach the protected area of the opposite district, which grants the physical safety.

King Flower, a card game with four characters. The aim of the game is to realize some series by using figures that in the past represented the icons of the hierarchical historical scale.

name: Eine Reise ins Gebirge
description: The players start at space 1, the lake shore and have to reach the summit at space 50. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces, events hinder or benefit the players. The first player to reach space 50 wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Viktoria Gesellschaftsspiel
description:
The players have to move their three pawns (one black, one red, one gold) from the starting spaces, marked with their letters (A-H) to the coat of arms in the center of the game board. Movement is determined by a die. Numbered spaces hinder or benefit the players. If a pawn reaches a space with an opponent pawn on it, the later has to go back to the space, the other pawn has come from.
