After completing a circle around the game board, the pawns advance to the inner circle and lastly the coat of arms.

This game was likely published about 1930.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Impact and Melee: Roman Wars against Macedonia 280-148 BC
description:
From the publisher:

A very simple game of Pikes vs Pilum. Two pages of rules, simple map, and easy combat mechanisms combine to provide a quick play game with two very different armies represented. Balanced yet different, this is the classic ancient warfare competitors locked in battle.

Can the Roman infantry destroy the Pikemen, before the Macedonia Heavy cavalry caves in their flanks

name: Impact and Melee: Gallic Fury
description:
From the publisher:

A simple game of ancient warfare between the early Roman City State and the Northern Italian Gallic tribes. Simple and easy rules (3-pages) and quick playing time, combine to make this game a good lunch hour game.

name: Chief Inspector
description:
Master criminals are freely walking the cobbled streets of London town. The scuffers are clueless, but the reliable old Chief Inspector is on the case and making good progress. That is, until he turns up dead in a ditch.

Any of you desk jockeys want to be the new Chief Inspector?

Chief Inspector is set in the Gaslight Empire and follows the events of Ruse and Skyway Robbery. In Chief Inspector, each player takes on the role of a junior inspector walking the streets of 1800's London, hot on the trail of a Master Criminal. The King wants results, and the player to make the biggest arrest will become the new Chief Inspector.

To set up the game 5 suspects are placed in a line up and beneath each of them face down clue cards of four types: Intelligence, Reputation, Status and Prior Arrests. Hidden on the other side of these clues are truths about the suspects and related numbers.

Players must use their hand of three Inspector cards to uncover clues about the five key suspects, procure the necessary evidence, and arrest the suspect with the highest total value (the most notorious criminal). But beware, certain actions corrupt, and the player with the most corruption automatically loses!

name: Bonsai
description:
A game of thought and artistry. Players are bonsai tree gardeners competing for the title of "Master Gardener."

Bonsai is a beautiful pattern matching tile-laying game where players use tiles to grow their tree and compete for the best overall submission.

Components:
24 Branch Tiles
12 Trunk Tiles
6 Large Trunk Tiles
20 Pattern Cards
7 Community Goal cards ("Ribbons")
5 Foliage "chits" of each player color
Turn Track
3 Bonsai Pots.

Players take turns selecting and adding a branch tile to their flower pot. Each tile has a color: red, green, or yellow. When players have created a pattern that corresponds to a pattern card in play, they obtain that pattern card. As the game progresses players are given the opportunity to add foliage to their tree, but only to certain branches. This foliage can also count towards color patterns.

Trunk tiles and Large trunk tiles are placed on top of branch tiles. Trunks are worth VP, and build your tree "up" visually, which is very satisfying.

This game is played over the course of 12 turns depicted on the turn track.

In the basic rules, players have a one-time use special power to trim their tree, or change the position of 1 tile. This happens more often in Advanced Play.

Scoring:
Scoring happens at the end of the game, when players easily count points for every pattern card completed, the number of visible points on tiles, and community goal cards. But watch out! If your tree has any spare branches, you're going to lose 1 point for each one!

name: Gem Hunter
description:
Gem Hunter is played on a 10x11 board but only the squares forming what looks like a capital E with 4 horizontal bars are used. Each part of the E is 2 squares wide and the horizontal bars are connected by pairs of "Crossing" squares. The other squares are Start, Barren, Miner/Prospector, Opal, Sapphire, Ruby, Emerald and Diamond.

There are 50 cards of each gem type with values 100-500 and 3 special decks -Prospector, Miner and Questions. Players start as a Propector and can graduate to a Miner by drawing the appropriate card from the Prospector deck and this increases their options - at a cost.

It is essentially a "throw die, move, follow instructions" game and even movement is restricted to a single path that winds all round the E.

The winner is the first to collect one of a number of specified gem sets.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Skyways
description:
This two-player game says on the board that it was "approved by United Airlines" and appears to have been developed as marketing tool. The back of the board features a large picture of a United Airlines two-engine "Mainliner". The front of the board features a UAL logo. And the playing surface - a map of the United States overlaid with a grid of squares 13 wide and 9 deep, seems to include UAL's entire route map in red lines - even though these lines have nothing to do with the game.

Each player has five planes and starts from either New York or San Francisco. Each player must also pick up 10 pieces of baggage en route to the opposite base city. At the start of the game, each player puts the other player's baggage in the most inconvenient pattern possible, since the goal is to be the first player to reach the destination city with all five planes having picked up all 10 bags.

A player may move each plane only one square, either directly or diagonally ahead. Moves North and South are only allowed in the home airport bands on either coast, and planes may never move backward toward their starting airport. If a plane of either player is adjacent in a legal direction, the moving player may jump over the other plane as in checkers but without removing it. Jumps are free moves, and multiple jumps are allowed, followed by a final square forward as usual.

Success depends on artful placing of the opponent's bags, careful planning of a five-plane route that will both reach all bags and enable as many jumps as possible.

name: Hurry Home
description:
According to the rules, Hurry Home was designed by J. W. Patterson, whose most famous game was the 1939 hit Contack. Described as "72 miles of hilarious enjoyment", this race game has three twists.

First, the circular course from Home to Town and back again is laid out in three lanes: Red (inner), Yellow (middle) and Green (outer). Second, the game uses a very large 12-sided die with color-coded numbers: 1-4 are red; 5-8 are yellow; and 9-12 are green. Finally, players may only move counter-clockwise on the yellow and red tracks, and must move the opposite direction on green.

Players choose one of seven vehicles: train, plane, bus, car, scooter, bicycle and horse-drawn buggy, but their mode has no bearing on their speed. Each player roles the die and must move on that color track in the direction indicated. If this requires moving sideways to get to the right track, each such move counts against the total: so a player on the red track who rolls green 9 must first spend two points to go sideways to green and then 7 points clockwise.

Player counters block movement by other players, whether sideways or around the track. First player to pass town and then home wins. A variant allows each player three rolls per turn, with the first two being optional and the final one compulsory (even if one or two previous were accepted and moved).

name: New York World's Fair Children's Card Game
description:
This very simple children's card game was published as a souvenir sold at the 1964/65 World's Fair in New York.

The 36-card deck features photographs of some of the fair's pavilions and exhibits. Players deal out the deck face down on the table and take turns turning over two cards. Cards that match are captured; those that don't are turned face down again. Winner is the player to capture the most cards.

name: Election
description:
This U.S. election game is played with two decks of cards. The Rollcall deck, backed with stars on blue, contains a card for each state, showing an outline of the state, the cost of campaigning for the state, the number of electoral votes it provides, and one of eight symbols representing different power blocs. The Campaign Deck, with red and white striped backs, consists of five types of cards used to capture states: Campaign contributions (money), Splinter Party, Favorite Sun, Endorsement and Party in Power.

The state card deck is shuffled, and the first six states are laid on the table. Each player receives a hand of seven Campaign cards. On each turn, he uses his hand to take states either from the table or from other players. Once he has made as many moves as he desires and can afford, he ends his turn by drawing two more Campaign cards from the deck.

States on the table can be obtained by discarding campaign contributions greater than or equal to the campaign cost of the state. No change is provided. States can be taken from other players by using the other cards. Using Endorsement, a player must pay 1.5 times the normal cost to take a state from another player; using Favorite Son, he pays only the normal cost; and using Splinter Party, he pays only half the normal cost. The most powerful card is the Party in Power, which allows the taking of one state from each opponent for half their normal costs - but the player must take and pay for a state from each player.

The final element to strategy is the assembly of power blocs. When a player manages to assemble three or more states with the same symbol, he pays $1M per state and places them in front of him as a group. After that, only the top card is vulnerable to attack, and the attacker must pay double the normal cost.

Once the last state has been taken, electoral college votes are tallied and the player with the most votes wins.

name: Fanorona Dimy
description:
Played by the same rules as Fanorona but on a 5x5 grid of an Alquerque board instead of the 5x9 grid used by Fanorona. On this smaller board Fanorona Dimy is played with 12 black pieces and 12 white pieces.

Capturing is compulsory and a series of captures may be made by the same piece on a turn. Unique aspects of the game include its method of capture (either approaching or withdrawing your piece from a line of enemy pieces), and the "vela partie" (debt game) after winning a decisive game (the winner must let the loser "eat" one man each turn for 9 consecutive moves). Because of the density of the board (only one open spot at the games beginning) and the unique method of capture, strategy is complex and enigmatic, with fewer pieces often beating more pieces.

name: Rhyminitions
description: Rhyminitions is a party game. Players get questions about words that sound alike such as "Rabbit" and "Habit". If the player can correct can identify the answer the player gets one point. The player with most points at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Are You Ready For The 4th Grade?
description: Are You Ready For The 4th Grade? is a educational children's game. The players gets questions about math and language, and also gets "challenges". There is three levels of difficulty, giving the player $50, $100 or $200 in-game money. The player with the most money at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Back to the Future: An Adventure Through Time – Einstein promo card
description:
Promo card that was included with pre-orders of the Back to the Future: OUTATIME dice game from the IDW Games webstore.

The card, featuring Doc Brown's dog Einstein, is awarded at the end of the game to the player who has the most Doc character cards in their ripple pile. (In case of a tie, Einstein is lost in time and awarded to no one.)

name: Der König der Schafe
description:
The games aim is to gather his sheep on a hill or a pasture.

The sheep are looking for a new king for their new home.
Each player starts with 30 sheep and 6 crowns.

Who 's on turn , rolls all dice :
The number of diced sheep come to graze .
A sheep per arrow (according to number of dice ) migrates to the next pasture .
The first player to 5 sheep in a pasture , places one of his crowns in the cloud . Are all the sheep to the plan , so that the player per round 3 sheep can move one square . Are then eventually all the clouds covered with crowns , so the one who had been elected king , who has the most crowns in the clouds .

The game is designs to be completly in wood.

name: Game of Funny Conversation Cards
description:
While this 1906 question-and-answer game from Milton Bradley might seem to be a response to Parker Brothers' 1893 Komikal Konversation Kards, it actually owes more to the much earlier 1784 Comic Conversation Cards (unknown publisher).

While the former provided questions and answers to be distributed randomly amongst a mixed group, the 18th century game specified that answers must be given by someone of the opposite sex from the questioner. Comic Conversation Cards is even more specific: the Gentleman asks the questions and the Lady provides the answers.

There are 24 Question cards in black and 24 Answer cards in red. Here is one example. One question: "Has mamma bought you a rubber dollie yet?" One answer: "I'll ask mamma, and let you know next Sunday afternoon". A bit forward for a first date, wot?

name: Chitty Chitty Bang Bang Switcheroo Card Game
description:
This 1968 card game is visually a spin-off from the hit movie, but the mechanism is essentially the same as Crazy Eights. This deck has 44 cards in four suits, each numbering 1 to 11. Each number has an illustration of a character, with the 8s being Chitty Chitty Bang Bang the car.

Each player is dealt a hand of five cards. The rest are face down as a draw deck, and the top of the draw deck becomes the card to match. Each player in turn must play a card from hand that matches either the number or the suit. Chitty Chitty Bang Bang cards are wild, can be played on any card, and allow the player to specify the suit that must be matched by the next player. First player to empty his hand wins.

There are no other special or "pick-up" cards that usually figure in Crazy Eight games.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Maranatha
description:
"A uniquely edifying game" where 2 - 6 players move around a Monopoly-style board collecting Word, Revival and Treasure cards and trying to avoid being under Attack.

Players take turns to roll dice and collect cards depending on the space that is landed on:

Word: Collect a Word card which has a Biblical verse on it.
Treasure: Collect a Treasure card
Revival: Collect a Revival card, once you have collected a full set, you are in "Revival" and can collect two cards when you land on a Treasure space.
Attack: Draw an Attack card and play the matching Word card to counter it.
Jesus: You can "Minister" to another player under "Attack" by drawing a Word card for them.

The winner is the person with the most Treasure when the Maranatha card is drawn. The Maranatha card is in the Treasure deck.

The box promises "a game of spiritual insight for all the family."
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: My Friends Are Weird
description: My Friends are Weird is a meta party game. When friends come by for a picnic, movie night, party, game night, or just general hanging out, they each pick a card and keep it secret. Each card has an action detailed on it that is out of the ordinary. The players’ goal is to perform that action without anyone catching on that it is being done for the game. People must notice you are doing the action (unless the card says otherwise). The trick is to try to incorporate it into the context of whatever it is you happen to be doing at the time. If, at the end of the night, you’ve pulled it off, you get points based on how tricky the action is to get away with. If you get caught (if someone guesses that you did something weird for the game), you lose any points that you have acquired from that card. You cannot take another card until (1) you are successful with the first one or (2) you get caught doing the first one. If there is debate over whether or not you accomplished something, the group as a whole decides at the end of the night if you pulled it off; partial credit is permitted at the group’s discretion. If the action is something that you would do anyways; congratulations, you are a natural at this game and you are weird.

name: Green Thumbs
description: Green Thumbs is a tile placement and deck building game. Build a competitive deck of resource cards to purchase plant tiles to add to your vegetable garden. Points are earned based on the difficulty of growing that particular vegetable and where it is placed within the garden.

name: From Rage to Reason
description:
A psychological teaching game that teaches how to deal with Rage and properly Reason.

From one of the rules sheets:

"Randy is in his late teenage years. He goes to school and also has a job. In the game, we will follow Randy through challenging situations that make Randy very angry. Randy's anger is not unusual, because these situations would make most people angry. It is the job of the players to give him advice on how to deal with these problems and achieve his goals. Players earn lots of play money for giving good advice.

The object of the game is to earn the most money. Play until the last Spark card is used or the instructor says that time is up, whichever comes first. Players choose a banker to give out the money. The banker receives no extra pay period

Nature of the game

This game is different from most board games. Players do not go around the board with their pawns. In fact, there are no pawns or dice. It is played more like a card game than a board game. Players play certain of their cards on each round, and the player who has played the best cards wins the "pot" (all the money on that round). The board serves as a playing surface and a presentation of the skills used in the game."

2-6 Players (More with team play)

name: Stygian
description:
You're trapped down here and the only hope is to escape! The gates are the way out, if only you could remember where they are in this twisting maze of moldered passageways. You'll need the Silver Key to get through them as well; it must be here somewhere, waiting to be found.

Suddenly there is an inhuman screech, a yowling, ululating expectation of madness that paralyses your body and frays your psyche... from somewhere, out there in the dark. You pant as your breath returns and you stagger to your feet; you must escape before they can find you!

Game Pieces:

23 Hex Tiles
1 Hex Rift Tile
12 Horror Cards
12 Lost Cards
24 Item Cards
4 Player Tokens

How to play:

The game is played between 2-4 players, the ultimate goal being to escape. This is done by finding two things; the tile of the gates, and the card of the silver key which opens them.

Each player starts with a random character card and three item cards - maybe even the silver key, which makes the game much more cut-throat, much more quickly.

The players explore, revealing new hexes as they do so, expanding the board out, revealing the unknown. Sooner or later a player will succumb to a trap, or an attack from another player, or just the bad luck of finding the brain parasite item card.

When this happens, that player is removed from play. They will come back on their next turn with a Horror card. They are now an eldritch beast from another dimension, and the only way to recover their humanity is to devour one of the human players - reversing their fates.

The game is heavy on strategy; all the cards affect each other in one way or another,depending on the situation and positioning of the tiles themselves. Despite this, the rules are simple enough to pick up and play in five minutes. Games can be over quickly, but the more experienced the players, the more devious and complex their strategies become.
mechanics: Area Movement, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: NYC IQ: The Trivia Game For New Yorkers
description: The ultimate test of city smarts for the Big Apple! This trivia game allows diehard natives, new arrivals, and nostalgic transplants to prove they know the city better than anyone. The game comes with 400 multiple-choice questions spanning all five boroughs; correct answers are counted as IQ points, and the winner is granted NYC insider status. From Harlem to Hell’s Kitchen, the Guggenheim to the Gowanus Canal, Fashion Week to Yankees-speak to Knickerbocker lore and more, this game rewards those truly in the know, while revealing hidden secrets that will surprise even the most knowledgeable New Yorkers. Sleek graphics and game components ensure that this simple but sophisticated package will be displayed on the cityphile’s coffee table, seized at dinner parties, and lingered over for serious fun.

name: The Wyne Tasting Game
description:
From the publisher:

The game comes in a cloth bag and includes:

1) A game board, silk screened on heavy fabric
2) 4 packets each with fifteen game tokens
3) Instructions and rules of the game

The object of the game is to capture five squares in a row, horizontal, vertical or diagonal!

You can play with more than four people by having people play in teams sharing a marker set.

Each turn, the player (or team) marks a square. Then, he drinks a sample of wine (as indicated on the square) or eats a sample of food (as indicated on the square). Each player starts by placing a marker on a white wine space, and from then on, he has to alternate wine and food space. You can either stay with white wine or change to blush/rose and after that to red. At a minimum, it is recommended to bring at least 3 kinds of wine, with at least one white, one blush/rose, and one red. Think of this as similar to a Pente' wine party.

There are several different wines listed on the game board:

White, Blush, and Red Wine
Riesling, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, White Zinfandel, Merlot, and


Port

Sweet, Dry, Fruit, and Dessert Wine


Take as little or as much wine as you want to drink on each turn.
Drink responsibly.

name: Unidentified SPY
description:
User summary
未確認スパイ (Mikakunin SPY) is Unidentified SPY. Part of the artwork in this game comes from public domain sources.

In the game of Unidentified SPY, players try to identify a spy, a player who belongs to a group with the least members.

Someone raises a topic, and each player secretly writes down an answer to the topic. Spies are the players whose answers are shared with the least players, but no one knows if they are actually a spy or not. After 3-minute discussion, each player votes a player who they think to be a spy. A player who gets the most votes is executed. When all answers are revealed, the spies win if the executed is not a spy, otherwise the non-spies win.

At the beginning of a game, each player looks at the answer of the player to their right. Deduce a spy from what you saw and what you heard.

Publisher's summary
お題に対して各自自由に回答を書いて伏せます。そこで少数派回答になった人がスパイ（いわゆる人狼）になります。3分間の相談時間の後、ゲームの終わりに一斉で投票し、最多票を集めた人が処刑されます。全員の回答を公開し、処刑された人が少数派回答者（人狼）であれば多数派（村人）の勝ち、そうでなければ少数派回答者（人狼）の勝ちです。ゲーム開始時に全員右隣りの回答は見れるので、それをヒントに互いの回答模様を推測しましょう。

name: Game of Fractions
description:
This is one of a series of educational games published in the early 20th century by Cincinnati Game Co. They were intended to be used for group play and class exercises in ways that would be fun for children as well as sound in terms of pedagogy.

The deck is made up of 56 cards, each featuring a fraction with a denominator between 2 and 12. On 15 of the cards, the numerator is a "?", which can stand for any number less than the denominator.

The rules booklet describes four group games and 13 class exercises. In the first game, for instance, the cards are dealt equally among the players, with any odd cards placed face up on the table. Play proceeds with each player turning over one card and by combining it with any other face-up cards, achieve a whole number. If successful, all the cards used are gathered up, and the player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

name: Addition and Subtraction
description:
This is one of a series of educational games published early in the 20th Century by Cincinnati Game Co. The 52-card deck is made up of two each of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5; three each 6 and 7; four each 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13; and two each 14, 15, 16, 17, 18 and 19.

The rules booklet describes two group games and a class exercise for Addition; three group games for Subtraction; and a game and additional exercise for Addition and Subtraction.

In the first game, two cards each of 1-9 form a table deck, with three cards laid out and a fourth face up on top of the deck. The rest of the cards are dealt to the players. Each player in turn must try to use two or more of the table cards to equal a card held in hand. The player takes all of the cards in the set, new cards from the deck are turned over to fill any gaps, and play continues until the deck is exhausted. The player collecting the most cards through sets wins.

name: Word Game
description:
Word Game is one of a series of educational card games published at the turn of the 20th Century by Cincinnati Game Co.

The game consists of a deck of 111 half-size cards, each bearing a single letter, with the number of each letter varying from 1 (j, k, q, v, x, y, z) to 12 (e). The rules booklet describes a Primary Exercise for first-year students, three Group Games and four Class Exercises.

In Group Game 2, for instance, one of each vowel is placed face up on the table, and the rest of the vowel cards are distributed randomly to the players and also placed face up. The rest of the cards are distributed face down as equally as possible. Each player draws a hand of five consonants, and then in turn try to form words using cards in hand and vowels on table. Players may also play cards from hand that add to existing words and make new, longer ones. The first player to empty his hand wins.

The rule booklet concludes with rules for using this deck to play Niloe, a word game published separately by Cincinnati predecessor Fireside Game Co. in 1896.

name: Stack Tactics
description:
Stack Tactics is a abstract strategy game for 2 or 4 players where the goal is to capture the other opponents chips. This is done by stacking more chips than your opponent on a square.

Using 4 dice per turn, you execute your strategy by choosing what chips to move, where to move them and how big to make your stacks. 4-player allows unique co-operative attacking.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Elevator
description:
The idea of Elevator is to get rid of all your cards. All the cards are dealt out at the start. You start with five cards and take cards from your own stack as you play.
Save your wilds for when you need them, try and stop your neighbor from going out by sacrificing and taking the pile, or change the elevator to "going down" if you know your neighbor has high cards.

What is in the game:
A sturdy box with 3 decks of cards, (marked for easy separation when playing with less players).
Instructions for gameplay

name: Kerää kansallispuku!
description:
A simple roll-and-move game about Finnish folk costumes. The goal of the game is to collect a set of five cards from the same folk costume. One card may be replaced with a wild "trader" card.

On their turn, players roll a D6 and move along a board. Depending on the square landed, player may either take a card from the deck, trade cards with another player or take a wild card. The first player to collect a complete five-card set of the same folk costume wins the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Game of Thrones: Intrigue at King's Landing
description:
Game of Thones: Intrigue at King's Landing is a print & play card game for 3-4 players based on the hit TV series Game of Thrones, where each player represents one of the great houses of Westeros struggling for dominance and to ultimately claim the Iron Throne.

Each round, each player chooses one scheme that they are trying to fulfil. Players then make deals, conspire and back-stab to either support or oppose these schemes. Helping another player with their scheme may be easier, though if they are successful that player will gain a powerful ability that may be used against you later in the game! Players must also be careful of opening up support of their schemes to the wrong house, as a well-timed betrayal can leave you losing everything to an adversary.

Schemes also award armies, gold and power to those who are most successful in carrying them out or preventing them from coming to fruition, all of which contribute towards the award of four prestigious titles as well as your claim to be ruler of Westeros!
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Kimenmura e Youkoso!
description:
User summary
奇面村へようこそ! (Kimenmura e Youkoso!) means "Welcome to the funny face village!" in English. Artwork in the game comes from public doamin works.

A player give a question by expressing two randomly determined feelings in one facial expression. The other players answer the combination of feelings simultaneously. They gain one point if correct. The questioner gains one point if at least one player was correct. Play several times and the highest scorer wins the game.

Publisher's summary
毎回１人が出題者になります。それ以外の人は回答者になります。出題者はランダムで決定された２つの気持ちを１回の表情で表現してください。回答者はそれを見て、どの気持ちの組合せか一斉に回答します。組合せに正解した人と、正解者が１人でもいれば出題者にも点数が入ります。誰かが７点に到達するか、４ラウンド過ぎるとゲームが終了し、最も点数の高い人が勝者として奇面村に取材に行きます。

name: Pizza Pronto
description:
Due to a telecommunication snafu, all of the pizza places in town are receiving the same orders from the same customers! The first delivery person to the house gets the tip, but did you remember the order correctly? Which pizza did the zoo order? Mushrooms? Pepperoni?!? You have to race your opponents to get customer’s tips first, but make sure you complete the order accurately or you get nothing!

In Pizza Pronto, 3-5 players compete to deliver pizzas to locations around the table by flicking discs and tossing tokens. Each round, an order is read aloud. “Hello! I need a pineapple and pepperoni pizza at the zoo and a mushroom and pineapple pizza to the firehouse, please.” Players flick their delivery disc in real time, racing to each location. Once there, you can pick up a pizza and try to toss it into the fenced area. When a player has delivered both pizzas, they place their disc in the highest spot on the garage board. Players score points for delivering the correct pizzas to the correct locations, with bonus points awarded for speed and throwing accuracy. Once the deck of cards runs out, the player with the most points wins!

name: Australia puzzle map
description:
A simple roll-and-move race game along a 30-space track circumscribing a map of Australia. Starting from any space, players roll a die and move that many spaces clockwise around the track. Each space contains a hand-painted image of a location on the map in the centre of the board. When a player lands on a space, another player identifies the location, "googles the location on a smart phone" and asks the moving player three questions about that location. If all three questions are answered correctly, the moving player gets to remain at the new location, otherwise he returns to his previous space.
The first player to return to his starting space wins.

name: Guest's Treasure Chest Biscuit Game
description:
A snakes-and-ladders like game, using palm trees as snakes and packets of Guest's biscuits as ladders, to promote the products of the publisher's Melbourne-based biscuit factory. A metal spinner is built into the board. Counters were provided at the side of the board ready to be cut out, and were differentiated by colour and the name of one of Guest's biscuit products.
The back of the board featured a pirate galleon to be coloured in with paints or crayons.
A player spinning a 6 got a second spin (presumably adding the results together). It was necessary to land on the final square on an exact spin; otherwise the player moved backwards a number of spaces equal to the number spun.
publishers: T. B. Guest & Co. PTY. LTD.

name: Verkade's Melbourne-race spel
description:
Simple roll-and-move race game themed for the 1934 MacRobertson International Air Race from from Mildenhall, England, to Essendon airport in Melbourne, Australia. The race was sponsored by confectionary magnate Sir MacPherson Robertson as part of the Melbourne Centenary celebrations. This game published as a promotion for Dutch biscuit company Verkade, is based on the heroic efforts of the Dutch team, flying a KLM Royal Dutch Airlines DC-2, who came second in the race overall but won the handicap prize.
The board is a map of the eastern hemisphere from England to Australia, with 63 numbered circles (unusually, they are not contiguous nor connected by lines) marking cities both on and off (Peking, Algiers) the official race route. 12 of the circles are blue, and have penalties or bonuses described in the lower left of the board.
The game is described as for "een onbeperkt aantal personnen worden deelgenomen" (an unlimited number of participants), and players much pay an ante of five collector cards from packets of Verkade biscuits. Some of the penalty spaces require payment of more cards into the pool. Although not specified, presumably the winner takes the pool of cards.

name: Jeu de la Marine
description:
French 19th century roll-and-move board game, similar to the Game of Goose, with 63 numbered spaces spiraling into the centre of the board. Players roll 2 dice and move that total number of spaces. Bonuses and penalties are incurred on some spaces, as detailed by text in the middle of the board. The theme of the game is a naval expedition. Spaces represent various French admirals, sea battles, and other naval and nautical themes.
Landing one one of three lighthouse spaces (every 9th space) gives you a double move (i.e. if you land on a lighthouse with a move of 5, move on another 5).

name: Catch that bunyip
description:
From Box: Alexander the pink bunyip is hungry again. He decides to visit his four favorite shops. But the Bunyip Catchers have other ideas and set out to catch The Bunyip before he returns to the safety of the billabong. Watch Out Bunyip - don't get caught!
[note: a Bunyip is a mythical Australian Aboriginal creature].

Object of the game: The winner is the player who finally catches The Bunyip OR the Bunyip who has visited all four shops and returns safely to the billabong.

One player is the Bunyip, the others are Bunyip Catchers. If 6 play, the 6th is a second Bunyip. The Bunyip(s) starts in the Billabong in the centre of the board, the catchers in the corners of the board. Each player spins a spinner (mounted in the box) and moves that many spaces (1-2-2-3-3-4-5-6).
The Bunyip(s) must pass over (they don't have to stop on) each of the 4 shops in the centre edges of the board. The shops and the pink spaces either side of the shops are prohibited to the catchers. The catchers attempt to land on the Bunyip when he is not in a safe area. If they do so, they spin the Bunyip Escape spinner (a second spinner mounted inside the box): either the Bunyip is moved automatically to another named space, or he is caught (and the catcher wins). If the Bunyip visits all 4 shops and returns to his starting space (the Billabong) he wins. Catchers landing on another catcher send the latter is sent back to his starting space.

The same game system, with different artwork and creatures was used in "Watch out wombat" and the New Zealand version "Catch that kiwi" both issued the following year.

name: Digit Dick's walkabout on the Barrier Reef
description:
"A game based on the story by Leslie Rees" - box cover.

Published between 1945 and 1954, and based on the best-selling Australian children's book "Digit Dick on the Barrier Reef" by Leslie Rees (1905-2000) illustrated by Walter Cunningham, published by John Sands, Melbourne, in 1942. Set in Queensland, the book details the adventures of Digit Dick , a "little boy only as big as his mother's big toe", who smuggles himself on holiday with his parents in his father's coat pocket.

The game is a simple roll-and-move race game using marbles as pawns on a board mounted in the game box. The track is a connected sequence of 45 holes. Most holes are small enough to hold the marble in place, but 9 of the holes are large enough to swallow the marble (and represent the adventures Dick has in the book).

Players must throw 1 or 6 on a six-sided die to being, then get to roll again for a proper move. If the player's marble lands on a big hole, it rolls down the box and he must start again. If he lands on an already-occupied small hole, he places hi own marble one space behind (which might be a big hole). He must throw an exact number to finish, otherwise he moves backwards the excess amount.

A second version "for older children and grown-ups". In this version, a big hole causes you marble to move backwards 5 spaces (instead of starting again). If the countback takes you past the start space, you must start again.

The rules sheet summarizes the story of Digit Dick on the back, and advertises two other Digit Dick book titles; Digit Dick and the Tasmanian Devil (set in Tasmania), and Digit Dick in Black Swanland (set in Western Australia).

name: Bulwark: A Few Wounds More
description:
From the publisher's blurb:

This product provides 6 extra wound cards you can use together with Extra Wounds from Blood-Soaked Plains and the wounds from the base set. With these extra wounds, you can make a 30-card wound deck consisting of 2 copies of each type of wound. With two copies of this product, you can make two such decks.

Useful for just that bit more variety in your wound deck.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Variable Player Powers

name: The One True Goblin King
description:
In The One True Goblin King 2-4 players play as a Goblin family vying for the Goblin throne. Players use a press your luck dice mechanic to buy oil, water, sticks, and stones with which to craft tools of murder to kill the Goblin King. Kings have four specific weaknesses that must be taken advantage of. The player that scores the coup de gras becomes the new King according to Goblin law.

The goal of each player is to have the greatest legacy or be the first to seat three of their family members on the throne.

The One True Goblin King uses a modular naming mechanic to humorous effect, and increases the game's replayability with hundreds of combinations.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Push Your Luck

name: French Conversation Cards
description:
This 1897 educational card game consists of a deck of 48 plain undersized cards, each printed with either a question or an answer in French. The 24 questions and 24 answers are divided equally among the players.

The first player calls out a question, and the player to his left must offer a suitable reply. If he cannot, the next player has an opportunity and so on round the table. When a question is answered, both the questioner and the answerer get to discard those cards, and the player providing a correct answer gets to ask the next question.

The winner is the first to empty his hand unless a question is called out that no one can answer, in which case the game ends immediately and the player with the fewest cards in hand wins.

The rule card says the cards include a vocabulary of more than 200 words and introduce "the various changes of the Articles, Adverbs, Pronouns and Verbs. It can be used with success as a novel and pleasing way of studying the French language."

name: The Reaper Game
description:
The Grim Reaper is calling it quits! Humans are dying at alarming rates, and he just can't keep up. He's challenged a few individuals to take the burden from his bony shoulders, promising that the most efficient reaper will take a place beside him to become the next big boss. To test themselves, the reapers — each with their own powers and secret missions — embark on six different locations and times to capture dying victims, but these potential victims will put up a fight, then bargain for their life, offering valuable help in exchange for mercy. The reapers must decide which victims deserve to die and which are indispensable sidekicks — well, indispensable until plans change since in the end the Grim Reaper will accept only corpses as proof of your work, so the clock, as always, is ticking.

The Reaper Game is a dice-rolling game with strong set collection and press-your-luck elements. During the game, players roll their dice, then try to fulfill the requirements of the available victims to capture them. In turn, those victims will grant the players unique abilities, such as extra dice or dice manipulation, to help them capture even better victims.

Each victim belongs to a specific location, and at the start of the game players receive three secret objectives that require specific victims in order to grant extra victory points. During the game, the Grim Reaper itself tries to sabotage the tasks of these chosen souls by taking one location out of play, and once a location has been visited three times, it's removed from play completely. After the second location has been removed, the game ends. The Grim Reaper also has special powers, one of each triggers at the start of each round, causing chaos and heartache to the players.

The Reaper Game features an introductory mode suited for new players and for those looking for an easier and even faster experience.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Lost Star
description:
Lost Star is a cooperative/competitive hybrid card game about the internal power struggle of a star ship crew adrift in the galaxy.

The Lost Star's captain is dead, and her crew is lightyears from home. One player in command and up to four other players acting as the crew must cooperate to return home safely. However, the Commander is untrustworthy as he will take credit for the success of the mission.

Play proceeds with drawn encounters of various difficulty. Four decks of cards feed the players' hands based on the their role. The commander takes cards from each of these decks, and plays orders based on his exclusive knowledge of the encounter's potential effects.

In the following phase players are encouraged to dissent and replace their given orders for ones they prefer. Orders affect how the encounter resolves, and successful orders increase the players trust. With which they can use on challenging encounters, boost their fellow crewmembers, or mutiny and take command.

If the crew makes it through all of the encounters the Commander takes credit for the success of the mission and is declared the winner. There is only one winner, but no one wins unless the Lost Star makes it home.
categories: Card Game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Regions
description:
Regions is a game about territory fight, using the same board game set as Go. It has one basic concept: region. The players increase their territory by making regions:

The rule of the Regions is very simple: If the player's current stone and the other 3 stones on the board form a 4-side region (which is formed by vertical lines, horizontal lines and lines of 45°), and the region contains no enemy stones (including edges), then the whole region belongs to the player and will be filled by the player's stones.

When one player has occupied more than half of the territory, then game ends, i.e., whoever takes 181 points wins.

Notes:
* If there is no restriction to the 4-side region, the shape can be weird and against the common sense. So the region cannot be concave, and any 2 sides of the region cannot be crossing or overlapping, which means, only regular quadrilateral are valid. Actually the shape can only be rectangle, rhombus, parallelogram, trapezoid, and a kind of right-angled quadrilateral.
* In some special situations, one played stone can form multiple regions
* Since black moves first and has advantage, so it is ruled that the first move of black cannot be in the center, because center also has advantage. At the end, maybe black needs to pay back some points to white. Currently we assume handicap of 4.

name: The Orchestra
description:
In The Orchestra players take upon roles of a starting conductor. The aim of the game is evolving to the best one there is. You complete your musical works and control as many musicians as you possibly can.
You have to collect musicians for you to play (music) your music pieces.
You gather your musicians by combining cards, place them on the right spot in the Orchestra and collect extra bonuses by placing them on important places.
So, who wil be there first on the right spot?

There are many more possibilities to gain extra points, block your opponent and steel points. There is also the possibility to gain points (or to lose them) on the timeline.

The artwork for this fantastic game is designed by Joris van Beusekom and will be crowdfunded august 2016.

name: Mists of War
description:
A fictional wargame (WW2 themed) for two players in which quite a few things are foggy at the start of the game. To have a better chance of winning you will try to find out what kind of units the enemy has, how many are fielded and where they are located. And hopefully, you will find out your opponent’s objective before it is too late.

The hearth of Mists of War is a true double-blind game system without using an extra player as an umpire. You might call it a block wargame because of the cubes, but it goes much further into hiding information than the standard games in this genre. The cubes in Mists of war are not just hidden units, but are used as a system of fog of war which comes and goes according to what your units can actually see. Besides the cubes, Mists of War also gives the players a secret objective to win the game. Furthermore, a player receives a number of force points unknown to the other player which he can spend on buying troops. The more force points you get, the harder your objective will be.
Activation of units is done by selecting zones. Selecting more zones gives your opponent more benefits.
It uses a randomless (no dice) combat outcome in which all the units in the selected zone can act together and add their strength.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Crash, The New Airplane Game
description:
A simple spin and move game similar to Pachisi. The game has a four color spinner, and used 3 small metal airplanes for each player's pieces to note position on the circular track on the playing board.

There was only one version of the game and it has an mostly orange cover with an airplane in the center over the game name Crash.

Contents:

12 metal airplanes in 4 colors
Game board
4 color spinner
Instruction booklet

name: A Game of the World
description:
This game is comprised of a deck of 100 cards, each of which bears the name of a country, colony, region or body of water along with 10 questions about its subject.

Each player is dealt a hand of three cards. The first player asks the player to his left one of the questions on one of his cards. If the second player answers the question correctly, he takes the card and puts it face down in front of him. If not, the next player in line gets a chance and so on. Whoever answers takes the card. If no one answers, it is placed into an Ignorance Pile on the table. The asking player then replenishes his hand to three, and the turn to ask moves to the left.

Every four cards collected by correct answers make up a "book" and victory goes to the first player to collect an agreed number of books. The rules recommend four books for 2-3 players, three books for 4-5 players and two or even one book for larger numbers.

The rules suggest two ways for adapting the game to classroom use, either by forming teams or by spelling-bee style elimination.

name: IBETCHA: Extended Play Pack
description:
The first official expansion pack for IBETCHA. Includes 100 completely new cards ranked by explicitness (37 '1-point cards'; 33 '2-points cards'; 30 '3-points cards').



From the Original GameOverview

IBETCHA is a highly interactive mix of Cards Against Humanity and Never Have I Ever. Guess what your friends have done, hear their stories, then laugh your face off. You're gonna love IBETCHA, we guarantee it. The game is basically truth serum for people that aren't in the CIA (and some that are). See which of your friends can read people, dazzle them with your past mistakes, then crush them.

Game Rules

To start the game, each player draws eight random Betcha Cards that say things your friends may have done or are willing to do. All the cards are ranked by explicitness (1 to 3 points).

Each round has a different Victim. Everyone puts down a card (face-down) they think the Victim has done. Then, the Victim has to respond "yes" or "no" to each one. The group then screams which story they want the Victim to tell. Whoever submitted the chosen card, gets to keep it and receives the number of points on it. The first person to reach 10 points, wins!*


You can also play forever.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game

name: Rocca Card Blocks
description:
Rocca Card Blocks distills the hexagonal-cards-as-cubes concept down to simply that: Each card represents a building block of one color or another (with intentional variations in the "finish" on the blocks, in order to add that visual authenticity). The backs of the cards are unpainted blocks, and the fronts are either white, blue, yellow, or red (15 of each), and one of each of those colors depicts the Rocca logo.

In addition to the "construction puzzles" offered in the game, the game also come with rules for Rocca Match, which is a derivative of a standard memory game. In Rocca Match, each player can only claim pairs that match and match her player color (a starting card). When you claim a pair of cards, "stack" them like blocks. An optional rule provides a twist: If two Rocca logos are revealed, everyone passes their claimed cards (and thus player color) to the left.

name: Keeping Up With The Joneses Card Game
description:
Keeping Up With The Joneses is a light, fast paced, print and play card game, with an ever changing goal.

The top card of the Goal deck is turned face up for all players to see; this representing The Joneses latest purchase and the current object of desire for the players!

On their turn players either play a card (or a sequence of cards) from their hand, or they draw a card.

The aim is to collect a set of cards which matches the current Goal card. You will then score the value of the item purchased, and a new Goal card is revealed.

However cards can be played to steal cards from other players, switch cards, force players to discard cards and even change the current Goal for a new one!

When they year ends (the deck runs out) the player with the highest score wins.
Keeping Up With The Joneses won’t be easy…

name: Bigwig
description:
This game is subtitled The Great Game of Politics ... For the People. There is an octagonal game board with five concentric tracks (each moving closer to the center of power), along with money, Vote cards, Political Backing cards and Media cards.

Players choose one of eight factions (Military, Wealth, Education, Ecology, Women, Labor, Industry, Farm) and take the corresponding Information Card (cheat sheet) and colored plastic token. They also start with $7,800, two Vote cards and four Political Backing cards. They put their tokens on the corresponding spaces in the outer (dark blue) Local Level ring.

Players roll dice and move, winning and losing Political Backing, Money and Votes along the way. They may spend Political Backing cards to change their own die roll by one space, or to change another player's roll, by one if in the same ring or more if in a higher (closer to the center) ring. Media cards provide random rewards and penalties.

Players need to accumulate both money and Vote cards to move up the rings to State, Federal, Convention and finally Campaign Trail. The winner is the first to land by exact roll on the Bigwig space in the innermost ring.

name: Mc.V's Magic Jaffa Game
description:
A simple race game included free on the inside of boxes of McVitie's Jaffa Cakes in the UK in 1979 (my copy purchased 15 Aug 79). When opened out carefully, the board could be found printed on three sides of the inner surface of the box. The fourth side bore the punchable teetotum spinner, along with 4 counters (yellow one side, white the other).
It is very similar to Snakes & Ladders [US: Chutes & Ladders], but with only 50 squares, and with a "Miss a go" square.
No rules are included - they are not necessary as it is self-explanatory. A game of pure luck, although I added a sticker with an additional rule to my copy, allowing a little skill to creep in to a two-player game.

name: Classic Coins of the 20th Century
description:
Classic Coins of the 20th Century is a card game for two or four players. Four players may play as individuals or in teams of two. The deck consists of 36 cards; there are four suits, or coin denominations. Each suit consists of ranks one through nine, representing the years the coins were minted: 1911 through 1919. During this period the designs of US coins changed. The nickel was redesigned in 1913. The dime, quarter and half dollars were all redesigned in 1916. These coins are considered great examples of the coining art. On a turn, a player must play one card to the table to try to capture one or more cards that sum to that card's value; if a player can't or doesn't want to do this, he or she must lay one card on the table. Your goal is to capture as many cards, especially those valuable first year designs, as you can.

Similar game play as seen in Casino and Scopa
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Team-Based Game

name: GreenFrogRedFox Game
description:
The GreenFrogRedFox Game is not available for purchase. To play for free, simply go to www.greenfrogredfox.com and follow instructions on the "GAME" and "RULES" link in the top navigation bar.

This is an education roll-and-move game. Each turn, a player (or team) rolls the dice, and moves their pawn the indicated number of spaces. After moving, they will usually have to answer a question, which depends on the space they have landed on. If answered correctly, they score points.

Each time they pass go, the player collects an animal card. These cards are also worth points. However, when a player lands on an Animal Spot, (StrangerBear, BobCat, BuzzFly, AllieGator) they are stuck on that spot until they can discard a matching card. In the meantime, they may draw one new card or trade with another player for a matching card.

The game ends after all players have answered ten questions correctly. This is tracked by coloring in a drawing. Now, the points from the questions and held animal cards are added up. The player with the most points wins the game!
categories: Animals, Book, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Todos contra a Dengue!: Expansão Zika Vírus
description:
The Zika virus was discovered recently and many problems have caused for Public Administrators and the general population. In Game based game "Todos contra a Dengue", we Dengue, Chikungunya and Leptospirosis as population to disease-causing and with this expansion, add the Zika virus. The Zika virus is also caused by the same transmitter of dengue and Chikungunya, which is the mosquito Aedes aegypti. Mosquito combat this is an efficient way to end these diseases.

Placing the Zica Virus in the game is a good way to put on the table an issue of great importance to all! For those who played Todos contra a Dengue there are few changes to the rules as described in the basic game. Only a disease that is Zica is added. The Zica virus comes into play only in one city and different from the other cities where there is a Dice D6 scroll to determine the number of people with disease, this town with Zica virus already has 12 people diseases that need to be addressed. The final rule score takes into consideration if this city with Zica virus were all treated patients or not, thereby altering the final score of the players.
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: 9 Years to Yesterday
description:
Leverage the past, present and future to gain your freedom.

You are a Shifter. A rare breed of human that has the ability to slip through time at will. But this ability does not come without a cost. Your kind has drawn the interest of an untouchable crime boss known only as Gary. He wishes to not only control the city, but the city today, tomorrow, and yesterday. That’s where you come in; an indentured servant, forced into a life of non-linear crime. You can’t claim to dislike the rewards of your efforts, but the risks involved have you looking for an exit strategy - a normal life. Not to seem unreasonable, Gary has proposed a game; he is willing to release one of his loyal Shifters upon completion of one last job.

You assume the role of one of four Shifters; your job is to fulfill Contracts for your boss, Gary. There are two types of Contracts: standard and release. Standard Contracts are general smuggling jobs and are worth one Contract Point. Release Contracts are tailored to each Shifter’s unique skills, but as such, are more challenging. The reward for completion of a Release Contract is that the Shifter named on the Contract receives 5 Contract Points required to win Gary’s competition. The first Shifter to collect 10 Contract Points wins Gary’s competition and their freedom.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Player Powers

name: Regatta
description:
This 1946 game appears to have been privately developed and produced and predates the somewhat similar games published by 3M, Avalon Hill and Klee by more than two decades. There is a yacht club in one corner of the 24.5 x 19 inch map, and the courses are complicated by three islands and four banks of shoals.

While the basic mechanic is simple (roll two dice), the rules and subtleties do a good job of recreating the tensions of a sailboat race. A red die determines the basic movement amount, but this is modified by matching the red-white combination against a Help and Hindrance card that evens out the results. Net moves range from 0 (6-6=blown out a sail) to 5. Lower red rolls get help and higher ones get penalized.

Unlike later games, the wind is assumed to blow constantly from the top of the board, and courses are laid out accordingly. The rules and realities of sailing apply: a boat on starboard tack has right of way over port; close-hauled over reaching or running; getting to windward of another boat hurts its movement, and so on.

There are rules for tacking, luffing and setting spinnakers. There are shoals that players can try to get over but if their turn ends on a shoal they ground. There is an advanced start process too: instead of rolling for position with highest first, players can spend three turns manoeuvering for position as in a real race.

The rulebook has extensive diagrams of various potential situations, and is designed to make the game instructive as well as fun for players who are not sailors.

name: Birds
description:
Birds was a promotional game distributed by the Woolson Spice Company for mailing in "Lions head cutouts" from Lions Coffee.

In a turn, you draw the top card and give the top clue to the next player. If he knows the correct answer, he claims the card. If he gives the wrong answer or passes, the next clue is given to the player on his left, who will claim the card if they get the answer right. And so on, around the group, until the card is won.

Most cards, wins.

The publisher, a coffee supplier, claims that this is one of 60 games they have published!

name: Robin: The Boy Wonder
description:
Unlike the 1978 Whitman trick-taking card game of the same title, this 1977 Russell game is more like rummy, with players aiming for three or more of a kind or in sequence. The deck has only 40 cards, four each of ten different illustrations numbered 1-10.

The English rules are printed on the back of the box, but a card with French rules is enclosed, suggesting Canadian distribution as well as American.

name: Sippa Fish
description:
This 1936 party game consists of four sparkly blue straws and a box full of tissue-paper fish in two shapes (fish and sharks) and six colors (red, orange, yellow, green, blue and violet). There are rules for three versions on the inside of the game box.

In the Shark! Shark! game, a mix of 20 fish and two sharks go in a bowl, and everyone tries to use the straws to suck fish out of the bowl and into one in front of them. Anyone caught with a shark on their straw is penalized three fish, and the accuser gets three extra in his bowl. If falsely accused, the penalty and bonus goes the other way. The player with the most fish wins.

In the Relay Race, teams of two run a course across a room or porch, and the first player has to hand off the fish to the second player straw-to-straw. In Rainbow Sippa, players compete for the most points from a mixed bowl with each color counting a different number of points from 1-6.

While the game included only four straws, there is a health note at the bottom of the rules: "For sanitary reasons, see that each Sippa is used by only one person and then destroyed."

name: Prize Fighter Ultra
description:
The 2nd Timensional Tournament of Earth has Begun!
Can you prove you are the toughest fighter in both Time and Space?

Prize Fighter Ultra is the ultimate head-to-head mixed martial arts card game. Don the role of one of Earth's greatest brawlers, chosen from infinite alternate dimensions and timelines. Forced to fight in a tournament for fame and glory, battle your way through the rankings and become the undisputed champion!

In combat, you and your opponent simultaneously play moves to try and win the match with a knockout. Use attack cards to score points, generator cards to gain adrenaline to boost your attacks, or counter cards try and counter your opponent's killer combo. Between matches, unlock one of 63 unique moves at the gym to customize your hand and augment your characters passive abilities. Effectively utilizing strategy, hand building, resource management and reading your opponents will be the keys to victory.

Do you have what it takes to become the champion?
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That

name: Maiden Island
description:
'User Summary:'

In "Maiden Island", players are tasked with keeping up the spirits of several love struck young ladies, while working to escape the island you're all trapped on. Survive for one week and everyone escapes via a raft. If any of the young ladies become too upset before then, they'll violently lash out at others or even themselves.

The game consists of three phases that repeated over the course of (at most) 7 rounds.

Event Phase - Shuffle the eight tiles and place them in a 3x3 grid. The last space in the bottom right is left open. Tiles are then moved around like a slide puzzle and activate various effects. Some provide food, but most only lead to members of the group becoming upset. Get the three components of the raft in either one row or column and the phase ends.

Dinner Phase - Three food are consumed by the entire group. If you come up short, all of the available food is still consumed and every young lady becomes dissatisfied.

Date & Kill Phase - Players may choose to go on a date with one of the young ladies. Her dissatisfaction is then spread to the other members of the group. Finally, a check is made to see if any one in the group has become emotionally overwhelmed. If so, they kill another member of the group or take their own life.
publishers: 哀愁旅館きたぐに (Aisyu Ryokan Kitaguni)

name: A Trip Through Europe
description:
This educational board game was one of a trio of games published around 1900 by The Educational Game Company, headed by Elmer E. Johnson, also president of The Regents Institute, a school for boys and girls in Brooklyn, NYC.

The square paper game board features five maps, one in the middle showing Europe as a whole, and the rest showing parts of the continent. It has a perimeter track of 13 squares per side, and six square tracks leading to the middle map from the center of each side.

The corners and middle squares are blank red. The rest bear the name of a European city with a number suggesting where it may be found on the board. Each player has four tokens and a "clock" spinner that enables moves of 1-12 spaces. When moving, the player must announce the name of the city to which he is moving and the country in which that city is located. He may look at the maps for help, but if he can immediately name the city and country without looking, he gets another turn to a maximum of three.

Landing on another token sends it back to the nearest red square, and first player to complete a full circuit and then move to the centre with all four tokens wins.

name: Dino Addition Bingo
description:
A fun and exciting way to learn addition - the prehistoric way! Spin the spinner, solve the associated addition problem, and then place a colorful dinosaur counter on any spaces that match the answer. Be the first to get three dinosaurs in a row, and you win!

The ability to add is an important math skill. Dino Addition Bingo is a great way for children to learn - and practice - this skill.

name: Potato Land
description:
Potato Land is a very fun collectible strategy game like "Gwent" from "The Witcher". There are from two to eight players. You choose one of four opposition parties. You win if you have more points than your friends. Some cards have special effects: control of the weather, double of points, draw of additional cards, steal of cards of opponent.

The game becomes tense with every card which you put on the table. After all if you have fewer cards in the hand, you can absurdly lose this game.

name: SAPOS Y CENTELLAS (SPARKS AND TOADS)
description:
In SAPOS Y CENTELLAS (for the moment will be only available in Spanish), from 2 to 8 players shall compete to achieve victory trough casting powerful spells and throwing magic artefacts and toads at their rivals. Also, it is crucial to accumulate valuable cards and to try to keep them until the end of every game to win.

CONTENTS
SAPOS Y CENTELLAS includes 92 game cards, 20 cardboard “orbs”, 1 cardboard coin, and one manual inside the game box.

CARDS
The game features 4 different kinds of playing cards: special, passive, toad and unique cards.

-Special cards: These cards hold various magical properties. Using them can result in the user discarding some of his worst cards in order to obtain better ones, in each player being obliged to hand one card to the person at his right, and in some other outcomes.

-Passive cards: These cards cannot be used but only discarded if desired. Among them we find the Spark Cards, which grant points to a player if he keeps some of them until the end of a game. Other passive cards will allow its holder to duplicate a Sparks Card or may reveal someone’s hand to every other player.

-Toad cards: There are Green Toads, Blue Toads, Red Toads, Yellow Toads and Poisonous Toads. These cards may be exchanged for other cards, randomly chosen from any rival’s hand. They may also be kept by a player to gather an “all coloured toad combination”, which yields 100 points at the end of a game, or an “all five toad combination”, which yields 200 points.

-Unique cards: There is only one type of card in the entire game under this category, the HOURGLASS. Both in the front and the back, HOURGLASS cards display the picture of an hourglass. There are six units of this type of card, and all of them are randomly located among the second half of the draw deck in every game. When an HOURGLASS is uncovered, the game ends.

name: Cubecar Racing
description:
In the Cubic World, cube men get their excitement from racing their Cubecars around the track. But it is a dirty and deadly sport and sometimes not all the cars survive to finish the race and win the coveted trophy! Players take actions to change gears and move their cars to avoid dangerous bends and hazards in the hope of reaching the finish!

Each player selects one of 8 different cars to use in the race each with their own special powers on one of two different tracks. Then in turn order they select one of the 8 actions on the four action cards and flip the card over revealing two different actions. Players must ensure that their movement is not too fast for their current gear selection (spin off) or too slow (stall) and if they do so they will miss their next turn. Corners have gear limits and if a car attempts a corner in a higher gear the car will take damage. Too much damage to a car and they will be out of the race permanently! The first over the finish line is the winner.

name: Limericks
description:
This rare McLoughlin Brothers card game is undated, but the style of the box (fancy embossed gold lettering and borders on a pebbled maroon cardboard box) is very similar to that of an 1890s Logomachy.

The game consists of a deck of 54 cards, divided into 18 books of three. Each book has cards labelled A, B and C. The A cards bear the first two lines of a limerick. The B cards have the last line of the limerick. And the C cards bear the middle two lines of the limerick.

Each player is dealt an equal number of cards, and immediately set aside any complete books. On their turn, players may either try to force a card on another player or obtain a card. To force a card, a player must hold and A or B card or both, but not the C. He calls out the letter and number of his card(s), reads the line(s) on them, and the player with the C card must respond. The first player then hands his card(s) to the C player. To obtain a card, a player with a C card asks a particular player for the name and number of another card in that book. If successful, he receives it and gets another turn; if not his turn ends.

Complete books are set aside as they are formed, and the first player to get rid of all his cards wins.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: SWAT Command
description:
From the publisher:

SWAT Command is a cooperative board game for 1 - 5 players set in modern time. The players are controlling a SWAT team attempting to bring a hostage situation to a successful resolution. The game uses resource management, press-your-luck, and grid-based combat mechanics. Six situation variables allow for the game to have a high replay value. Players must work together to use the time that is given to them by the Hostage Negotiator to purchase Team members and equipment, gather intelligence on the situation, and prepare a rescue plan. The longer players wait, the better equipment and personnel they will have, but the more chances that negotiations will go south. Once players choose to rescue the hostages, grid-based combat begins that resolves in about 15 minutes.

The game is based on a hostage situation inside a bank. The situation cards are unknown at the beginning of the game (Hostage and Suspect #, Hostage and Suspect Positions, Equipment and, Motivation) Each game begins with an Arrival Situation that determines how much Time the players begin the game, and whether or not someone is injured and needs immediate rescue. In a multi-player game, one player is the Incident Commander and the other players control dedicated sides of the building.

The first phase of the game is the Containment Phase. A round begins with the Incident Commander rolling a die to simulate negotiations. The result of the roll is how much Time the negotiator has "bought" for the other players. Each player then begins their turn buy using their Time to buy SWAT personnel from the stack to their staging area, moving SWAT from their staging area to the board, purchasing equipment, using SWAT personnel skills, moving, or gathering intelligence. Players can buy everything from a Medic to the Bomb Squad (once revealed) and Flash Bangs to Plastic Explosives. If players begin their turn with no Time, A card is drawn that has a negative effect for that player or the entire team to simulate the suspects doing something. Certain actions require the player to draw a reaction from the suspects that range from a gunshot heard inside with an unknown result to a hostage crawling out the window.

At any time, or when the team is ready, the Incident Commander may initiate the Rescue Phase. All players move their squads to their breach points (windows/doors), breach doors and determine amount of surprise, reveal any unknown information, Snipers then shoot, Squads begin movement, squads then mark their shots simultaneously, once all shots are marked the shots are taken. Repeat the Snipers to shooting steps until surprise is over and then the suspects react by moving, shooting or surrendering until all the suspects have been neutralized or arrested.

A quick-play version is comprised of scenarios that tell the players how to set up SWAT team members, equipment, and scenario cards. The players then skip the first phase of the game and go straight to the second phase, the Rescue Phase, to attempt to rescue the hostages. All scenarios can be played at various levels of difficulty by adding or subtracting equipment items that give the players bonuses.

name: The Game of Traits
description:
This early-1930s game from Wilder Manufacturing Co. of St. Louis hearkens back to the Victorian era with its focus on moral rectitude. The game consists of a deck of 48 cars, 24 of which illustrate Faults and 24 illustrate matching Virtues. There also are four cards with a list of all the Faults and the Virtues that cancel their effects, and a set of four wooden racks.

Each player is dealt six blue-backed Faults and six red-backed Virtues. He puts his Faults upright in the racks facing away from him, so that others can see his Faults but he cannot. By looking at his opponents' Faults, a player must work out which Faults he has, and on his turn puts a Virtue from his hand on the table that will match one of his Faults. If this Fault is in his rack, it is removed and discarded along with the Virtue from his hand.

If a player feels that he does not have a needed Virtue in his hand, he may draw a card from the player on his right. If it matches one of his Faults, he discards both cards. If not, he must take one of the Faults from that player as a penalty. The first player to dispose of all his Faults wins the game.

name: Sneak, Steal & Squabble
description: A family fun, mischievous game of goblins stealing treasure from the kings castle. Players take on the roles of 3 goblins belonging to four different factions. Use your actions wisely to move around the castle and steal the treasure, when the alarm sounds, the castle will lock down and all players will need to race to the exit and escape with their treasure. the goblin faction with the most treasure wins the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Take That, Tile Placement

name: Mystery Solitaire
description:
Mystery Solitaire integrates classic cases of murder and mayhem into a mix-and-match multi-deck twist on the classic game of Klondike/Patience. Take on the role of a sleuth and choose which case you will solve. Shuffle your deck of 52 cards together and you are ready to play!

Use the abilities on Sleuth cards to help with the investigation while negotiating the obstacles presented on Crime cards.

Win by playing all cards from your deck and tableau.

A single deck provides hours of single player enjoyment. However, multiple decks allow players to mix-and-match characters as well as unlocking the ability to play a two-player variant.

Will you alone find the clues?

name: Going to Market
description:
This children's game from Corey Games is a very simple roll and move race. Players each get two tokens and must move them along a path that includes four circles and rectangle. They must spin the exact number needed to reach the exit (red dot) square of each of these.

The only element of judgment is over which token to move with a given spin so as to make it through the exit points. Movement is eased by a "move ahead seven" space in each circle that just happens to put a token on the exit dot.

name: Clown Capers
description:
This children's game combines a deck of 54 small cards and a playing board. The board has outlines of four large clown faces, each containing 12 spaces for cards. There also are six green spaces for individual cards. Each of the cards has a number and either a piece of clown face or an animal.

Players are dealt eight cards each, with the remainder forming a draw pile. In turn each must try to play a card on one of the spaces. The first player must play either a 1 card on one of the clown noses or an animal card on a green space. If he can do neither, he draws a card.

Each clown face must be built up in number order, from 1 (nose) to 2 (eyes), 3 (mouth) 4 (eyebrows), 5-6 (ears) and finally 7 (hair). There are two spaces for eyebrows, eyes, mouth, and upper and lower ears, and the right and left numbered spaces must have precisely matching parts on each face.

Each player either plays a card or draws until one player managers to win by being the first to empty his hand. The rules recommend continuing the game until all the clown faces are filled out.

name: BANDITS!
description:
User summary
In the game of BANDITS!, players are bosses of bandit bands, and try to steal unearthed treasures. The player with the most treasures wins the game.

Each round, a treasure is unearthed from each of four sites. Treasure value ranges from 1 to 10. Then each player plays a thief and reveals them simultaneously.

A thief card has a specific color that indicates which site to go to. If you go into a site alone, you steal all the treasures there.

If two or more players chose the same site, they can negotiate to split the treasures there, or fight to grab all the treasures. Treasures not taken are held over to next round, heating up the game. Players hire thieves using treasures they have stolen.

The base set has special cards: Knights and Golems. And there is an expansion that has Dragons, Princesses, and Witches, adding more excitement to the game.

Publisher's summary
プレイヤーは盗賊団の親分です。プレイヤーが雇っている盗賊で発掘された宝を盗みます。
盗賊団を強くするために盗んだ宝で盗賊を雇います。
勝利者はゲーム終了時に宝を多く持っていたプレイヤーです。
発掘場所では毎ターン１つずつ宝が発掘されます。その価値は１〜１０点のランダムです。
宝を見た各プレイヤーは盗賊を1人選び、同時に公開します。
発掘場所と盗賊はそれぞれ4色あります。盗賊は自分と同じ色の発掘場所の宝を盗みに入ることが出来ます。
同じ発掘場所に盗賊が集まった場合、交渉によって宝を分配する事が出来ます。
もしくは、戦争して勝つ事で、全ての宝を入手出来ます。
発掘場所に残された宝はキャリーオーバーします。ゲームはヒートアップします。
基本セットには騎士、ゴーレムが含まれます。さらに、拡張セットもあります。ドラゴン、姫、魔女、が登場し更にゲームが盛り上がります！
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Hero Lab
description:
This game requires good skills!
