Every player in his turn play as a mad scientist who'll try to create some heroes by a mix of potions while the other players will try to steal them creating the best super heroes team.

The Scientest player is the master who has got in his hand some cards to mix in groups of three cards matching with the three components useful to realize every Super Hero.

Some component cards are covered and other ones are discovered, so everybody can use the discovered informations to understand if the superhero has been created or not.

The Master must realize more super hero as possible for receiving award to delete his malus at the end of the game.

Every other player must block (with the hand), before the other players, the super heroes realized, receiving victory points.

If you block a not realized super hero you'll receive the same points as malus.

The winner is the player with more victory points at the end of the game.

name: Hyakumannin Shinda Busho
description:
User summary
100万人死んだ部署 (Hyakumannin Shinda Busho) in English would be "The Department That Claimed a Million Lives". (In Japan, there is a picture book named "Hyakumankai Ikita Neko" (The Cat That Lived a Million Times), and the game title is derived from that).

Welcome to the department that claimed a million lives!

You are assigned to a department that is said to have killed a million workers, and have four job cards to work on.

You cannot finish your jobs without the part-time worker Miya-chan's help, so everyone competes to get her. When a player finishes all their jobs, her working time runs out and everyone else has to work over-time to finish their remaining jobs by themselves. Add up the face values of cards in their hand, and that's the over-time hours this week.

If a player's total over-time exceeds 300 hours, that player suffers Karoshi (death from overwork) and loses the game. All other players win because the department gets investigated and all survivors are liberated from overworking.

If all players survive four weeks without exceeding 300 hours, all players win the game.

There are four types of cards in the game.
(1) paperwork: Playable while you have control of Miya-chan to finish a job
(2) snack: Playable in response to paperwork to gain control of Miya-chan
(3) toy: Playable while you have control of Miya-chan to make others discard snacks
(4) paperwork with candy: Playable while a toy is active to gain control of Miya-chan

Use them wisely and finish all jobs with Miya-chan.

Publisher's summary
100万人死んだ部署へようこそ！
あなたたち社員（プレイヤー）は『100万人死んだ部署』と呼ばれる部署に配属され、仕事（4枚の手札）を渡されることになります。
手札は、アルバイトの『ミヤちゃん』に手伝ってもらうことで減らすことができます。
社員同士で「ミヤちゃんに手伝ってもらう権利」を奪い合い、誰よりも早く自分の仕事（手札）をゼロにしましょう！
手札が残ってしまった人は、カードの数字を合計して「残業時間」として記録していきます。
勝利条件は2つあり、①誰かの残業時間が累計300時間を超えて『過労死（負け）』した際に生きていること、　または　②全員で4週間生き残ること、です。
ゲームのフェイズは4段階あり、それぞれ「準備」「スタートプレイヤーの決定」「権利を奪い合うメインのゲーム」「残業時間の計算と勝利判定」になります。
この準備～勝利判定までの流れを1週間と呼び、誰も死んでいなければ手札を配りなおして再開します（1週間を終えるのには3分もかかりません！）。
メインのゲームでは、権利を持っているプレイヤーが手札から場にカードをプレイしていきます。カードに描かれた4種類の絵柄で権利を奪い合います。
権利を持っているときにプレイできる書類、書類が出た時に出せて権利を奪える「おやつ」、権利を持つときに他全プレイヤーのおやつを捨てさせる「おもちゃ」、おもちゃが出た時におやつの代わりに出せて権利をうばえる「おまけつき書類」の4種類があります。
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Delving!
description:
Delving! is a fantasy themed family style card game.

Take on the role of both dungeon crafter and seasoned adventurer. Explore the dungeon, slay the monsters, grab the treasure all while trying to thwart the efforts of your rivals.

The game is playable with one to five players. Play time is about 30 minutes.

name: "That's Me!"
description:
This Depression-era party game is really a gambling game, but green wooden disks are provided as a game currency. The board has a central pot with a buff corridor from each of the four sides. In between are three concentric octagonal rings (Green outer, Grey middle, Orange inner). On these rings are spaces with 8 Up elevators, 8 Down elevators and 16 black circles.

There are 16 numbered wooden tokens and matching cardboard disks. Each player takes one of the tokens randomly from the cup and keeps it secret. The cardboard disks are distributed randomly onto the black circles on the board. The goal of the game is to land on and "collect" one's own disk number.

Each player antes one chip and moves onto the board via one of four Entrance Elevators. Players roll a red and a white die and may choose which to use (red goes left, white goes right). Elevators, dots and the buff corridors must be reached by exact throw. In a buff corridor, a player immediately tries to reach the pot by exact count (1,2 or 3 depending on ring); if successful, he collects the pot, and everyone antes again. In either case goes back outside the building.

When a player lands on and captures a numbered disk other than his own, the owner (if in play)must say "That's Me" and pay his captor five chips. Landing on another player "bumps" them and requires a fine of one chip to the pot and another to the bumper. The winner is the first to land on and collect his own numbered disk. The winner collects the pot plus 10 chips from each player.

name: Royal Gambit
description:
From the instruction manual:

Royal Gambit is the exciting new game of skill that combines the color of medieval pageantry with the thrills and fascination of ancient warfare.

Designed for two, three or four players, Royal Gambit is played on a board representing four ancient mountain kingdoms joined in the center by lowland meadows. Combat takes place among the kingdoms for possession of the entire area.

Each kingdom consists of a castle and an army of 10 mobile pieces: A King, four Nobles and five soldiers. Royal colors for the kingdoms are orange, black, white and yellow.

During the course of battle a King may be elevated to Emperor by capturing a rival kingdom whose forces have not been severely reduced. Title of Grand Emperor is bestowed on the winner of the game.

name: Entour Travel Game
description:
Entour is a roll and move travel game with an educational objective. The board is a linear track of 38 destinations starting from a Port of Departure and ending in a Port of Arrival. There is no rhyme or reason to the order of the destinations, which are literally all over the map.

One player or non-player acts as the Tour Director, and holds the pack of Destination Cards (which list a variety of information about each destination. There are three piles of Itinerary Cards labelled Day 1, Day 3, and Day 6. Each player starts with $3,430. Each destination has a landing fee, starting at $300 for the first destination, Antigua, and rising to $1,000 by the final one, Tokyo.

Each player rolls two dice and advances that many destinations. First he pays the landing fee to the bank. Second, the Tour Director asks him what he knows about that destination. If the player supplies any of the information on the destination cards, he gets rewards. Third, he may buy the destinations Investment Certificate, which pays dividends each time a player lands there. Finally, he then takes an Itinerary Card, from the Day 1 pile on turn 1, Day 3 on turn 2, Day 6 on turn 3 and rotating from there.

When they reach the Port of Arrival, players must pay $500 and start over. The game ends as soon as one player runs out of money, and the winner is the one with the most money left.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Fly-In
description:
The brightly colored board makes this game look simple, but it is not. There are one red and one white dice, and a single 47-space track spiralling counter-clockwise and inward from the Start. The track includes 10 spaces where players draw Situation Cards that provide benefits or penalties. But the key to the game are the 21 spaces labelled Log Book and numbered 1, 2 or 3.

When landing on a Log Book space, the player rolls the dice twice more. The first red-white combination determines the section of the Log Book to consult (e.g. a 5 red, 2 white = section 52). A second roll, adding the two dice, gives the question number to be asked (e.g. a red 4 and white 3 = question # 7)

These are not simple questions. The easier ones are True/False or multiple choice, but some ask for detailed knowledge of flying rules (e.g. "What is wrong with a pilot flying a heading of 200 degrees at an altitude of 3,500 feet?", aeronautics ("Vfc/Mfc means ?") and even history ("What date did the airforce take delivery of the first P47D?").

To win, the player must make it to the second-last square and answer two questions correctly, then roll doubles and answer two final questions. The rules say that Fly-In "can be a learning tool to help the aspiring pilot be more aware of the world of flying".

name: The Game of Planting
description:
This early American card game is a festival of puns for gardeners. It consists of an 8-page rule booklet and 72 small (3.25" x 1") yellow cards, each of which has a number, a phrase "Plant ....." and the question: "What will come up?"

The rules say it is best played by "a large and mixed company", with one person chosen as Keeper of the Pool, or more precisely holder of the answer book. The cards are distributed equally among the players along with an equal number of tokens. Players take turns asking the player to their left the question on one of their cards, the answer to which is always some kind of plant or flower. The Keeper of the Pool judges the answer against the book and if the answer is wrong, the responder pays the asker one of his tokens.

Some examples from the book:
Plant a shepherd. What will come up? Phlox.
Plant a river. What will come up? A Currant.
Plant a man who won't pay his debts. What will come up? Willow.

There is one exceptional rule. "7. By vote of a majority of the players, rewards shall be paid from the pool for unusual brilliancy, and fines imposed for ludicrously erroneous answers. For example, when this game was first played, a young lady drawled out, in answer to the question 'Plant a menagerie. What will come up?' the single word 'Grapes'. Upon being made to realize that she intended to suggest the idea of 'Gray apes', the Keeper of the Pool voluntarily paid to her the sum of ten counters." Yes, that entire passage is in the rule booklet.

name: Jungle Fun
description:
A combination memory and race game. Make sure you find the path through the jungle the fastest.

The 36 tiles are randomly placer face down on the board, and the 4 playing pieces are placed in each their own corner. Players take turns trying to find pairs. If no pair is found the tiles are turned back face down, otherwise the tiles are removed and a path through the jungle is formed. After each turn a player may move his playing piece as far as possible through the cleared paths. First to reach to opposite corner wins the game.

There is also an advanced game where snakes on the tiles can be place to block opponents from moving.

name: Voennaya Taina
description:
User Summary

Voennaya Taina ("The Military Secret") is a Soviet-era game for children aged 7-9 that is pure propaganda. It combines a snakes-and-ladders type track with a story in the rule book that plays out through the illustrations along the track.

It has its roots in a Russian fairy-tale, and shows strapping young lad starting life placidly farming with his father, seeing his father go off to war on horseback and come back wounded, and then following in his footsteps.

He goes off to war, has his comrades in the lines betrayed to the fascists, survives capture and prison and eventually triumphs over both the fascist trio and the cigar-smoking capitalist giving orders behind the scenes.

name: Braves to Warriors: American Indian Rite of Passage
description:
INTRODUCTION
In America’s “Old West,” the young male braves of many Indian tribes faced difficult trials in order to become warriors. In Braves to Warriors, you and a friend will compete to win five such tests and gain the coveted feather of success in each. At day’s end, only the best brave in the tribe will henceforth be called: “Warrior”!

OBJECT OF THE GAME
Win the most Victory Points (VPs) during the five trials – swimming, tracking, riding, hunting and fighting – and finish the game with a higher score than your opponent.

COMPONENTS
36 cards (7 cards in five suits + one “Big Chief” card)
10 Feather tiles (2 tiles in five suits)

THE CARDS
There are five suits, each reflecting one of the five trials in the game—swimming, tracking, riding, hunting and fighting. Each suit has seven cards valued 1 to 7, which is used during trials. Your goal is to obtain 7 or more of the 13 Success Points (SPs) available during the trial. One SP is scored for each card in the trial suit you take, plus one SP for each value 7 card, during a round of quasi-trick taking.
categories: Abstract Strategy, American West, Card Game, Print & Play

name: Sheep Fold
description:
This Australian game is an early example of asymmetric warfare, pitting two Dingoes against a herd of 28 Sheep that are fleeing from their Paddock across a Wild Belt to the safety of their Sheep Fold.

Movement is akin to checkers, with a cross-shaped grid of orthogonal and diagonal lines. Sheep may move forwards or sideways, but may not move backwards or into a previously occupied position. The goal of the Sheep player is to fully occupy the Sheep Fold square across from him with nine Sheep - or to completely block movement by the Dingoes.

The two Dingoes can move in any direction and can capture a Sheep by jumping over it into an unoccupied square. The Dingo player wins if he can prevent the Sheep from making any further moves or if he captures 20 Sheep.

name: Rat Race: The Card Game
description: Rat Race is a fun, fast, easy card game for all ages (10+) that combines single-step gameplay with memory and process of elimination to create an experience that everyone can enjoy. Each player is assigned a rat card with a rule on it that you—and only you—have to follow. The object is to win either by collecting in your hand all the game cards featuring your rat, lining up 3 of your rat on the board, or eliminating all the other players by correctly guessing which rat card they were dealt—or getting them to incorrectly guess yours! Pay attention, watch for tells, and don’t run out of cards as you work to outlast the others! The action is quick, the cards are plenty, and the race is on!

name: Bolster
description:
Bolster is a turn-based, abstract strategy game where two lords meet on the battlefield; both maneuvering to eliminate the other's most powerful units. Players move their units of various strengths to constantly improve their own position, while weakening their opponent. All units share the strength of adjacent allied units when resolving attacks/defense, and charge movements allow long chains of units to be moved to trap, manipulate, and eliminate their opponent’s units.

Each player takes one move per turn, and based on positions of allied and enemy pieces, attack and defense scores may be bolstered by adjacent units. Players may choose to have any number of allied units follow behind the piece moved.

The object of the game is to eliminate each of the opponents 3 most powerful units; when only one of the 3 most powerful units is left, that player must choose one of his remaining pieces to remove from play at the end of each turn.

name: The Racing Line
description:
In The Racing Line you steer a car token around a course in a succession of straight lines. The length of those lines is determined by your current speed as measured on a special ruler.

You're limited in how much you can change your speed between turns so approaching corners can be very tricky unless you get them just right.
The game also encourages you to pick-up various "Power-up" tokens scattered through the course: Missiles, oil, nitro gas, emp bombs and more!Use these against your enemies, or just bump them off the track in your quest for victory!

name: LOGS
description:
User summary
ログズ (LOGS) is an abstract game for two players. Each turn, you may place your pin on a 9x9 grid of intersections, or make a special move using your large pin. You can play two types of game with it. The game was originally published in 2015, then revised and re-issued in 2016 with the "bloom" rules also added.

(1)LOGS connect
The goal is to build a complete route on the board from your end to your opponent's end by only your own pins. You may place your pin adjacent to any of your existing pin, or remove your opponent's pin by placing your large pin if adjacent to any of your existing pins.

(2)LOGS bloom
You score victory points by orthogonally surrounding an intersection with your pins, then placing your large pin on that intersection. You may place your pin on any vacant intersection.

Publisher's summary
"LOGS"はアブストラクトゲームで、2つのゲームが遊べます。
1つは"LOGS connect"。プレイヤーはお互いの対辺を先に繋げることを目指します。大きなコマと相手の普通のコマを取りかえることができるルールが特徴です。
もう一つは"LOGS bloom"。陣取りした場所に、多くの点数を得ることが目的です。普通のコマで囲まれた場所の中心に大きなコマを置けば得点になります。
mechanics: Enclosure, Network and Route Building, Pattern Building

name: Backstab: Danse Macabre expansion
description:
This is the first expansion for Backstab.

The Danse Macabre expansion include 4 completely new characters with unique abilities and introduce the new "events" card mechanism to push the plots and double dealing at a whole new level!
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Murder/Mystery, Political, Print & Play
mechanics: Acting, Betting and Bluffing, Negotiation, Real-Time, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Trading, Voting

name: Kiddie Kards
description:
Kiddie Cards is described on the box as "Colorful, Educational, Entertaining Cards for Children. The 55-card deck has backs in five different colors (red, orange, yellow, blue and green), while the front of each card has an illustration of what the rules call "items which surround every child in his everyday life".

The cards are clearly aimed at what the rule card calls "small fry", and are primarily educational and aimed at very young children.

The game does not come with fixed rules, and suggests that children may wish to devise their own games. The one game suggested is to deal the cards equally to the players, and have each child discard in turn. The next child may not discard unless he or she identifies the image on that card.

Alex G. Malloy (American Games: Comprehensive Collector's Guide; Krause 1999) dates this as circa 1970s, but the illustrations of household appliances and vehicles have more of a 1950s look to them.

name: Pfänder-Spiele
description:
The title of this early 19th century game translates as the Forfeit Game. It comes in two parts: a set of 47 cards and a 32-page booklet. The booklet has rules for 20 different party-style games. These include Mufti-spiel (like Simon Says), Das Klingel-Spiel (Musical Chairs), Das blinde Ruh-spiel (Blind Man’s Buff), Die stummen Spieler oder Pantomime (Charades), and a set of terrific Teutonic tongue twisters.

What these games have in common is that at least one player may or must fail, and that’s where the cards come in. The company selects one of their number to act as the warden and choose which card to inflict on each loser. Each card includes one to three challenges. Card 39, for instance, orders that the player either “have one or two persons of the opposite sex kiss your eyes” or “confess which Commandment you have sinned against most often” or “kiss the most beautiful person in the room”.

Described on the box as entertaining and funny, the booklet takes pains to assure readers that the games and forfeits include “nothing insulting, much less offensive, but only for the humorous maintenance of youth”.

The cards and booklet are printed in a pre-umlaut Fraktur script, and the cards appear to have been hand-cut, since they vary in width and length by as much as 1/8 inch, and by as much as 3/32 inch from top to bottom of a given card. The publisher was an art dealer as well as publisher based in Stuttgart in the early to mid-1800s.

name: White Lightning
description:
Prohibition has settled over the United States. Liquor is outlawed. But people still want it. And there are people who can supply it.

2-4 Players are bootleggers running whiskey from stills in the Smokey Mountains to thirsty people in towns and cities below. Each bootlegger is competing to build a bootleg empire by controlling the highest dollar value of towns and cities across 4 states in 15 turns.

Working against them are Sheriffs and Federal Revenue agents whose cars move around the board using Movement Cards and, when a bootlegger is caught, taking actions against them by using Action Cards.

Make money selling your whiskey so you can buy more cars, stills, and vehicle improvements. Each car gets a driver with a skill and cars can be upgraded to go further, carry more whiskey and protect themselves against Sheriffs and Revenuers or other bootleggers.
mechanics: Area Movement, Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Manifesto
description:
This horse racing game by John Jaques of London was a follow-up to its successful 1910 offering Minoru (named after the horse that made King Edward VII the first reigning monarch to win an Epsom Derby in 1909). Manifesto is the name of another famous horse that raced in the Aintree Grand National a record eight times between 1895 and 1904, finishing third three times and winning twice, the second time carrying a record weight of 12 stone 13 pounds. (Wikipedia, Grand National Guide)

While Minoru focused on betting the odds on horses that had different lengths to run and equal chances of advancing, Manifesto says on its box that "players win on their judgement".

There are eight horses, each running a straight 20-space track. Each turn, players must choose one of three cards for each horse: Careful, Risky, and Reckless. By playing Careful, a horse will move safely between 1 and 3 spaces on 2D6. Playing Risky means moves of 2-4 spaces, but failing to move at all on rolls of 5, 7 and 9. And Reckless offers the chance of moves from 3-5 spaces, but failure to move on 4, 6 and 8, and a fall (elimination from race) on a 10.

The odds are set in a way that the average outcome of each card is identical, so "judgment" really comes down to "How lucky do you feel?"

Described on the cover as being designed by the (unnamed) "inventor of Minoru, the box has cover art by British equestrian painter George Dervill Rowlandson.
mechanics: Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Draftcar
description:
At 200 MPH only inches separate your car from the car behind you. Anywhere else in the world and you would be cursing the driver. But this isn’t just any joy ride. This is the world championships and as frightening as it may be, he’s giving you the speed you need to win it.

Draftcar is a 2 to 10 player drafting & racing game. Use clever card play to reposition race cars and get your car in the lead.

In Racing, drafting is the term used when two or more cars drive close together at high speeds to reduce the effect of drag on their car so they can go faster.

In card games, drafting is a term used to describe players having to choose from a subset of choices and potentially leaving the other choices for other players.

name: The Holy Grail
description:
The Holy Grail is a highly strategic card game where players take turns drawing and playing cards until someone wins the game by whittling down their hand so the only card they're holding is the holy grail itself. The deck is made up of action cards that let you steal cards like the grail from other players, force your opponents to pick up multiple card and shuffle up everyone's hands to name a few.

The game gets more and more intense as each player battles it out to be the one in possession of the grail, all the time trying to work out how to get rid of the rest of their hand without the grail eluding their grasp.

name: Das große Ochsentreiben
description: The players have to herd 3 oxen (meeples) from the village (space 1) to Chief Wampo at the cave (space 53). Movement is determined by 3 dice (one for each oxen). On some spaces oxen are lost to predators or enemy tribes. If an oxen is lost, the player uses 1 die less. The player may choose which die roll to use with wich oxen, to avoid losing one. The first player who brings the most oxen to the cave wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Prosperity: Planning Your Future
description:
Prosperity: Planning Your Future looks like Monopoly on the surface, but is a much more sophisticated game intended to teach children the realities of earning a living and keeping the family solvent and safe. Each player starts by picking a profession at random, with salaries ranging from 120 pounds a month for a postman to 300 pounds a month for an actor.

Player tokens then proceed around the board with opportunities to make investments in either unit trusts (which pay triple at game end) or a house, to use hire-purchase to buy household appliances, to put money into or take it out of banks and building societies (paying 8%) or Local Council (10%), as well as to encounter Accidents or Unexpected Expenses and to buy a wide variety of Insurance Policies against such ills.

Purchasing a property requires a minimum deposit, surveyors fee and solicitors fee, as well as monthly repayments of about 1% of the mortgage amount. Passing Start provides monthly salary for the occupation less all monthly payments (rent or mortgage, insurance, hire-purchase). The winner is the first to accumulate total assets of 15,000 pounds.

This made-in-England game is undated, but the graphics point to late 1950s or early 1960s (the family father on the box is smoking a cigar and wearing a jacket with cravat). The box claims a copyright, but there is no indication of the copyright owner or publisher, with the possible exception of a small cathedral-like logo on all four sides of the box. The rules and play suggest it might have been produced by a company in the investment or insurance business.

name: Wakkawakka
description:
Wakkawakka is a turnbased two Player game. The goal is to capture as many cherries (victory points) as possible. Therefore players move their adventurer token in a pacman styled labyrinth.
But just collecting cherries would be to easy. That's why each player also has a hunter to stop the enemy adventurer. Hunters cannot collect cherries, but when they capture the enemies adventurer it is reset to its starting position.

So players have to decide how to spend their 3 move actions each turn on their hunter or adventurer token.

The first player to collect 11 points wins the game.

name: The Game of Rough Riders
description:
This 1890 game by Edgar O. Clark is part of the publisher's Tokalon series and should not be confused with the 1900 Parker Brothers game The Rough Riders, which cashed in on Teddy Roosevelt's famous charge up San Juan Hill. Edgar O. Clark describes its game in the rules as simply "illustrating the wild life in the far West".

It is a simple spin and move game, with a few special spaces (Charge, Run Away, Ditch, Halt, Thrown and Wire Fence) that provide pluses or minuses. A piece that lands on another swaps places (sending the other back), and the four corner circles are safety points where bumping is not allowed. First player back to the start wins.

name: Space Connection
description:
Space Connection is a two-player deduction game. Each player has a two-part board, with one part being used to set up their "planets" and the other for the opponent's attempts to find them.

Each player has twenty plastic planet pegs which need to be placed in exactly nine groups of contiguous pegs (abstractly representing the Solar System's planets). Each player also has pegs representing lasers and reconnaissance ships of different strengths.

The ships can be placed to investigate one space, one space plus the six adjacent spaces, or all spaces in one of the triangles the board is divided into. A ship is only returned if its space actually contains a planet peg, otherwise it remains on the opponent's board and cannot be used again. The lasers are only useful when at least two have been placed in a line, as they reveal planets in all spaces between them.

The first player to find all twenty opposing pegs is the winner.

name: Pokemon XY Mega Evolution
description: Pokemon XY Mega Evolution - ポケモンXYメガシンカボードゲーム is a board game from Takara Tomy. The players uses a spinner that gives players move points. A player then move his/her a creature on the board and read the text on the spot they land on, or move a hero to get upgrades. There are also different paths to take. First hero to the goal is the winner.

name: HELLO TAIWAN
description:
HELLO TAIWAN is a card game about KUSO(funny) Taiwan's native affairs. There are so many dumbfounding things, complex issues of history and ethnic groups in Taiwan.
We carefully designed for each character's appearance , skills and features in the game to transform serious social events into funny cardset ability.
Let's play the game with smile and enjoy it !

[Component]
Game BoardX1
CardsX200 (include Minions and Spells)

[How to play]
1. Shuffle the cards and deal 30 cards to each players as their own deck.
2. Decide which player will go first randomly.
3. Each player draw 4 random cards from their own deck.
4. Each players have their turns alternately. At the start of each playes's turn one card is drawn from their deck and added to their hand. At the first turn of each players, they have 1 Skill Point (SP) ,then at the second turn of each players, they have 2 Skill Point (SP) ,and so on.
5.During your turn, you may play any of your cards, including summoning minions, casting spells. Playing a card will consume the amount of SP stated in the top-left corner of the card. You are also able to command your minions to attack opponent's minions or player.

[Minions]
Minions remain on the board after entering play and only leave when destroyed. Minions may not attack on the turn they enter play, but may attack each turn afterward.

[Spells]
Spells are cards which change the state of play, dealing damage, healing wounds, or buffing Minions.

[Winning the game]
A player wins the game when he reduces opponent's player to zero life.

哈囉臺灣是一款本土的KUSO時事卡牌遊戲。 臺灣有太多讓人哭笑不得的事情，有太多歷史與族群等複雜的問題，在遊戲中，我們針對每­一位角色精心設計外型、技能及特性，讓嚴肅社會事件，轉化成有趣的牌組功能，就讓我們­滿懷笑容的參與，並且享受其中吧。

name: 6 Tage-Rennen mit Rundengewinn
description:
German cycling game from the late 1920s published by a company from Leipzig.

There are six riders in the game, divided into two teams. Three of the riders (black, red and yellow) have a special lap counter in their back wheel. These riders are moved with the three coloured dice on the outer lane (with roman numerals) and try to win a lap over their competitors. The game rules calls them "Tempofahrer", which might be translated as "endurance riders".

The three other riders are sprinters. They race each other on the inner lane at given intervals and compete just for some points which count only in case of a tie in the number of laps won.

There are the three coloured dice.

These three dice are thrown in turns and the riders in the outer lane advance as many fields as dice mark their colour or their teammate's (three-coloured dice would have been enough and probably better). However, if in a turn none of the dice shows your colour(s), you fall back to the red square with no lap won.

So you hope for a long run of throws with at least one of your colours to win a lap. And most often than not you get a bad throw when you have completed more than three quarters of a lap and you are very near your objective. That hurts!

Meanwhile, the sprinters wait their turn to play. At intervals (the rules are not particularly precise here) the coloured dice are put aside, the riders on the outer lane stay wherever they are, and a short sprint takes place between the three riders on the inner lane. No complicated rules here either, just throw and move, with a couple of penalty squares (2 -only reachable by a double one on the first throw- and 13). Teams whose sprinters land twice on these squares during the game (in different sprints, most probably) are penalized with one lap.

The rules state that some player or onlooker can call a sprint anytime during the game for a special price he is willing to offer (a present for the winner of that sprint). Just like the "primes" in 6-day races.

The player whose rider(s) perform best during the race by crossing the finish line first wins the game.

name: Das Dansommer Radtour-Spiel
description:
German cycling racing game, the board game is two sided, one side takes place in Denmark though since it was published by a company that also rents holiday cottages in Denmark, the other side of the board represents a fishing trip in Norway. The B-side is played with pedestrians, not with cyclists.

The game comes with 4 card board cyclists and 4 card board pedestrians.

The game is won by the player whose figure crosses the finish line first. On side A of the board the players use cyclists and race to the finish line with a role & move mechanics, side B is similar but here the players use pedestrians.

name: Tour d'Autriche 2014
description:
This is a free print-and-play game published by the cycling lobby from Austria.
It's about the Tour of Austira.
Strangely enough, the game has a French name.
It features roll & move mechanics, is playable up to 4 and has a map with the Tour of Austria track printed on.

name: Le Tour de France: La Boîte à Quiz
description:
Released by French company Marabout in their 'La Boîte à Quiz' series. This trivia style party game is about the Tour de France.

The author is French cycling journalist Jean-Paul Ollivier.

The yellow box contains 160 cards, divided in the five categories. The back of the cards is of a different colour for each category.

To give the game some "strategic" edge, there are 4 types of cards in each category.
22 (out of 32) cards in each category named after the category. Besides, there are 3 "booster" cards, 3 "accident" cards and 4 "contre la montre" (time trial) cards in each category. These cards have a different symbol in the back, making a total of 20 different card backs (5 colours, 4 symbols each).

The 22 "normal" cards give one point for a correct answer.The "booster" cards give three points, while the "accidents" deduct three points from the player in case of a wrong answer. The three categories of questions in the card are given different names for each type of card, which only adds a baroque touch to the game. In all cases the player only has to answer to one question, chosen by the opponent.

On the other hand, the time trial cards have four questions and the player must answer as many as he can in one minute, getting 1, 2, 3 or 5 points.
Winner is the player who scores the most points.

name: Cyclisme-Question
description:
Trivia style card game endorsed by the Fédération Française de Cyclisme.
It was published by a French company from Toulouse.

name: Gépat
description:
Obscure self-produced French cycling sports game.

The game was made by two guys called Gérard and Patrick (that's where the GÉPAT brand comes from), and it was an ambitious project since it comes with 4 different boards. A Time trial board, a flat coarse and 2 mountain stages.

The game has 11 plastic cyclists (including one in the yellow & mountain jersey) and is playable up to 8 (with each players one cyclist) or less (for example with 2 players each one has a team of 4 riders).

Movement in this racing game is decided by playing out cards (so no dice).

You can play a 1 day race or a stage tour with a general classification using all 4 boards.

name: Bycicleclub
description:
This game's box is an incredible German box-set that looks like a modernist piece of furniture.
The main game is a cycling board game but the box also contains a rowing and horse racing game.
The components / pieces that you play with (cyclists, horses and row boats) are made from metal.
Up to 6 players can take part and they can bet on the outcome of the race(s).
The board measures 40 x 20 cms (it is not that small after all) and it is just a 50-square-long track without any particular indication on it, except for the arrow that tells us that the riders will move clockwise.

Both the cyclists depicted on the board and the tin figurines included in the game have an unmistakable XIXth century look.

However, while the riders on the board look like racing cyclists, the tin figurines rather look like tourists.

The rules are very simple. This is a betting game in which any number of players can take part. Players do not manage a particular rider but just bet on the outcome of the race. Players must agree upon the numbers of laps, and cyclists move according to the throw of dice.

During their turn every player can move any cyclists since it is unknown who placed bets on which rider.

In a way this has similar mechanics like games as like Heimlich & Co. (hidden identity) and Reiner Knizia's classic horse racing game Winner's Circle (published by Alea) which also featured players making hidden bets during a race.
This is remarkable for an antique game from the early 20th century.

After the race is over and the riders have finished the races the players reveal their bets and he who placed the most accurate bets wins the game.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sechstage-Rennen
description:
Cycling board game published in Germany (in 1926), it's about indoor cycling and takes place on an oval track, those races are know as 6-tage rennen since they last 6 days.
It has a roll & move mechanic but overtaking is only possible in straights (which have black dots) with a higher number, the overtaken rider moves to the neighboring white dot, misses a turn, and resumes the race from the black dot.
You must reach exactly the last black point before each curve and overtaking in the curves is not allowed. The rider behind will stay behind losing any extra pips.

name: Crossing the Alps
description:
This is a simple roll and move game where each player must try to move five men "across the alps" on his playing card. Each card has a row of circles marked "5", two rows of mountain scenery, and a row of goats. Unusually, the rules are printed on the front cover of the box.

Players take turns rolling a single die. Rolls of 2, 4 and 6 count for nothing. A roll of 5 allows a man to be put on the first row. A roll of 3 allows a move directly from the first (5) row to the goat row. And a roll of 1 allows a man to move forward a single row - but once in the alps, a 3 roll is useless to him. First player to get all five men to the goat row wins.

name: Ultimae Litterae
description:
You might consider this game as Big Bang Theory meeting Happy Families in the Roaring 20s - in Latin.

This is very much a Latin educational game, and consists of a deck of 65 cards divided into 13 "books" of five cards. As the rules put it: "Each book embraces declensions and conjugation forms ending in certain letters, as, es, i, um, etc."

A book's word ending appears in capitals in the middle of each card, followed by a specific example, such as "-US Gen. Sing. 4th Dec." (genitive singular fourth declension). Partial information to the other cards in the book appear on the four corners of a card along with one or more question marks.

Play is similar to Happy Families, with players taking turns asking other players for the cards needed to complete a book. But in this game, a player must ask for a card by its full form, by filling in the question marks on a card he already holds. And to ask for the King card in each book, the player must recite correctly all of the other forms in the book! The player to collect the most books wins.

name: The 12 Towers
description:
--Introduction--

The 12 Towers is an RPG board game for 2-6 players. The objective is to take control of all. Active Towers, and/or eliminate the opposing players.
Players take the role of “Keepers”, powerful rulers that control a Tower, and its surrounding territory. Throughout the course of the game, Towers will be
gained, lost, or even destroyed. Controlling Towers will involve combat, diplomacy, and teamwork. However, it may also involve treachery and deception.

While the objectives of the game are clear, it is entirely up to the players to decide how they play the game individually. Some may be aggressive
and charge head on, while others might focus on defensive actions. In the end, when players interact, they are in complete control of their own fate.
Not only do you bring a strategy to the game, you bring your personality as well.

--Brief Overview of the game--

Players: 2-6
Game Type: PvP, RPG, Exploration, Board Control
Game Board: 32 x 32 Inch Dodecahedron (13 pieces)
Movement Style: Set space amount (Can be increased or decreased)

Game Components:
- 12 Keeper Figurines
- 12 Tower Figurines
- 12 Colored Die
- 576 Game Cards
- 6 Tracker Sheets
- 12 5x7 Tower Cards

Game Run Time:
Easy/2 Players - 30/60 Minutes
Medium/4 to 6 Players - 45/90 Minutes
Hard/8 to 12 Players - 120/180 Minutes

--Game Board--

The board for The 12 Towers uses a hexagon battle grid. Players can explore, battle, cast spells, set up walls and defensive structures, and even set traps.
There is no limitation to where you can go, or what you can do. It is important to know what the different colored spaces and regions do.
Remember, the rules are for a standard game, and players have the freedom to alter these rules and regulations to better suit their needs.

--Towers--

Each Tower in the game has a unique theme, as well as it’s own strengths and weaknesses. Remember, it is important to explore options, and try out other Towers.
You may have a favorite Tower, or discover a useful combination that can turn the tides of battle, and become an intimidating force!

Your Tower is the home of your Keeper, and it’s surrounding territories belong to you and your citizens. Whether you’re the Brutal Orc King of the Fire Tower, or the
Undead Lord of the Black Tower, your Keeper is the King of it’s territory. As you play the game, you’ll gain control, or lose Towers.
Be sure to use strategy and planning when you take over the board.

--Power--

Power is the heart of The 12 Towers. Power is a simplified number that represents everything that you are; Health, Mana, Currency, Influence, everything.
Almost everything in the game effects Power. Whether you are taking damage from weapons, or casting spells. All players begin the game with the same amount of Power.
The standard starting amount is 2000. This number is them divided between your Keeper, and your starting Tower.
This number can be adjusted to use needs, or accommodate additional players.

--Cards--

The core version of The 12 Towers contains 576 cards. There are 2 types of cards; Items, and Events. Items are cards you can equip, use, cast and break.
Event cards are primarily used to give the players an advantage, as well as set the stage for role playing, and gives life and scenery to the game.
Events are the main source of gaining more item cards.

name: Hillocks (Slim Edition)
description:
A Cyclo-Cross / mountain bike board game published in 2013 in the UK.
There are two editions of the game, named "Slim" and "Pokket". The rules for the smaller "Pokket" game are a simplified version of the already simple rules for the bigger "Slim" game.

The game uses a roll & move mechanic as the players race over a track that features mountains, to reach the finish line first, he who crosses the line first wins.

name: Worldchampionship Cycling Race Game
description:
Vintage cycling board game made in China, it has a magnetic board and comes with 4 large 6cm plastic riders with a magnet on the bottom. The game works with a roll & move mechanic and a mechanism that allows you to select a gear that determines the speed of each cyclist.
Players put bets on each, after the race has finished bets are revealed and the player who put his bet on the winning cyclist wins.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Endless Land: The Endless Dwarven Land
description:
An expansion for The Endless Land, this brings the Dwarven realm into to the mix. Adds the ability for up to 5 more players to join the game.

Includes 4 modular map boards, 5 characters, over 300 tokens, and over 30 quest cards.

name: The Endless Land: The Endless Elvish Land
description:
This expansion for The Endless Land adds the expansive Elvish realm to the game. This expansion adds up to 5 players to the game.

Includes 4 modular map boards, 5 characters, over 300 tokens, and over 30 quest cards.

name: Super Prédateur
description:
To win Super Predator, you must be the first player to host on your territory the super predator - lynx , bear, wolf or eagle - which will populate your area if all the pantry is present. So you have to plant trees and hedges, and maintain your rivers to accommodate wild animals and constitute the fauna - flora balance.

Winning condition:
The first player to have in his territory:

in his forest: a deer, a doe & a boar
in the plains: two partridges, a hare & a sparrow
in the river: a duck, a pike & a carp



If all of the above animals are present the conditions are ready to introduce a super predator (lynx, bear, wolf or eagle) in your territory, the first player to do this wins the game!


Gameplay:

In the beginning of the game each player gets a pawn, 3 event cards and an intervention card.
turns are played clockwise
on his turn a player rolls the dice and moves his pawn the corresponding number of steps. If the pawn lands on a forrest spot he may either plant or remove a tree, on an agriculture spot he puts or removes a parcel, on a fauna spot he gains or removes an animal, if the pawn lands on an event spot he may play an event card.


The moment that a player reaches the winning conditions so that he can introduce a super predator, he wins the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Riversea
description:
In Riversea the players are participating in a fishing contest.

Gameplay:
The board features two tracks, on which your pawns can move. An external track (on the 4 sides of the board) for fishing in the river and an internal track (in the center part of the board) for fishing in open sea.

Each player starts with 15.000$ cash and 15 equipment cards. During the game the players can upgrade & buy new / better equipment.

The first player to accumulate 200.000$ value in money, fish & equipment wins the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Crésus
description:
The goal of this economic game is to get as rich as possible during the 10 rounds that the games last, so that you can afford yourself to buy a private island.

Gameplay:

Each player starts with 100 million $ starting capital, a pawn and a personal player board in his color that states the possible actions.
Each round consists of 5 phases: in phase 1 an event card is revealed, in phase 2 each player choose secretely in which market he is going to be active (this is revealed simultaneously), in phase 3 each player (in turn order) may choose an open card from the center of the board, in phase 4 player can buy in the markets via a blind bidding mechanism, in phase 5 the player can sell to the markets.


The game ends after 10 rounds, he who accumulated the most money wins Crésus.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Simultaneous Action Selection, Stock Holding

name: Australian bushmen
description:
A simple Australian children's roll-and-move game produced around the time of the Second Anglo-Boer War (October 1899 - May 1902). Probably published just after Federation in 1900, the game celebrates Australia's new nationhood as well as its participation in the South African conflict, in which the various Australian Bushmen's Contingents played a major part. It follows the path of a typical Bushman, proceeding from his enlistment to training, embarkation, arrival in South Africa, and engagements with the enemy.

The game is basically a re-implementation of the traditional Game of goose, with players rolling dice and moving around a 60-space track. Most spaces have a themed text: Riding test, promoted to lieutenant, ordered to the front, taken prisoner, etc. Some of these spaces also incur bonuses or penalties (moving forward or back a number of spaces, to a particular space, or miss a turn).

The board includes coloured illustrations of bushmen rounding up cattle in the Australian outback prior to enlistment, a street parade of a Bushmen's Contingents, transport ship, field hospital, field prison, troop ship S.S. Medic, and battle scenes showing Australian prisoners guarded by Boers, and Australian troops attacking a Boer position.

name: Melbourne Cup race game
description:
Simple Australian roll-and-move race game around a 100-space oval horse race track. Unlike the real Melbourne Cup which is a straight race, the game features 4 jumps.

The board is monochrome, which suggests an early publication date. The race was first run in 1869 and annually since.

name: National yacht race
description:
Simple roll-and-move race game, with a yacht race theme. The board consists of 75 numbered spaces. Players roll dice and move along the track (which looks like the track of a tacking yacht) from the wharf to the winning post. Some spaces have bonuses and penalties.
Recorded in the National Archives of Australia as first registered and exhibited in 1912 by the National Game Company.

Close examination of the board game shows some obscure artistic freedom, with the actual date (1912) represented in the small life ring on the gameboard along with the National Game Company trademark and "K.Y.C" (K? Yacht Club). It might be suggested that the K stands for the designers surname, Christopher George King.

Several later versions titled "Yacht Race" was also produced by the National Game Company probably during the 1920s or 1930s. It is therefore listed elsewhere.

name: Yacht Race
description:
Simple roll and move race game around a 60-space track, with a yachting theme. 12 of the 60 spaces offer bonuses or penalties. Unusually, each of the 4 players has his own path, parallel to each other, but separate.

The first version of the game Pre dates the National Games trademark. W. Owen of Ballarat manufactured the Yacht Race game under his name prior to continuing production under the National label. This appears to date the first version somewhere between the late 1890's to early 1900's. An advertisement is seen in 1902 for the game.

As with many of the National Games produced, the game over the years appeared in three general forms;
1. A large hardback board with a small separate box containing the playing pieces.
2. A small boxed version containing a thin carded board and pieces. This has the National Games Logo on the box
3. A large boxed version with a thin carded board (but larger in dimensions than the small box), playing pieces but no National Games Logo on the box

Another earlier version titled "National Yacht Race" was also produced by the National Game Company in 1912 but this game has 75 numbered spaces, a different layout and a different Registered number. It is therefore listed elsewhere.

name: Tsumu Tsumu Seeds
description:
User summary
つむつむシード (Tsumu Tsumu Shido) is Tsumu Tsumu Seeds, and means picking/stacking seeds.

Hard-working elves collect sunflower seeds in preparation for the winter season. They put the seeds into the their friend hamsters' cheek pouches to bring the seeds home.

In each turn, choose a task from 5 choices. The two possible actions are to either pick and stack a specified number of seeds on a hamster's "cheek pouch" or take one of the hamsters home with seeds in its cheek pouch.

If you play the same card (choose the same task) as another player, your cards cancel out each other and neither of you can perform the task. By performing a task, you receive the corresponding number of seeds as a reward. The player who has gathered the highest number of seeds by the end of the game wins.

Publisher's summary
働き者のこびとさんたちは、冬ごもりの為にひまわりの種を集めます。
仲良しのハムスターのほおぶくろにたくさん種をつめて、お家へ運びましょう。

毎回５つの仕事の中から、やりたい仕事を選びます。
でも同じ仕事を選んでいる人がいたら、その仕事はできません。
仕事をしたら、仕事内容に応じてごほうびの種がもらえます。
ゲーム終了時に一番多くの種をもらえた人が、ゲームに勝利します。
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: The Game of Games
description:
This 1930s party game was one of a series of 30 "One shilling" games published in England by C.W. Faulkner & Co. Ltd.

The Game of Games consists of a box of trifold cardboard leaflets, with one side consisting of the cover illustration and two pages of ads, and the other with 24 questions arranged in three columns. As the brief instructions put it: "The answer to each question is the title of a well-known GAME."

Example question: What a puppy does. Answer: SNAP.

Each player would get a leaflet, and the winner would be the one to correctly answer the most questions within the agreed time.

name: The Walled City
description:
This Monopoly-style game is subtitled "Chester Attractions Trading Game", and features the many tourist draws of Chester, known as the most complete surviving walled city in the UK.

Rather than following the perimeter, the 64-space playing track winds its way around each quarter of the board in turn. There are 31 attractions, in 7 groups of four and one of three. There are two sets of cards, Lord Mayor and Town Crier, that deliver random penalties and benefits.

Landing on an unowned attraction allows its purchase. Landing on an attraction owned by another player requires paying an admission fee. There is no building, but the admission fee rises as more attractions of the same colour are bought. The fee doubles with the second property, octuples with the third and goes to 50 times the base fee for a complete set. Most money wins.

The game bears no publisher identification or copyright, and has a self-published feel, possibly a prototype. The square board comes in two segments with smooth plastic taped edges and a hinge made from two Velcro fasteners. The cards and game pieces come inside a transparent plastic purse, and the game as a whole is in a large ziplock bag.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Fifth Wing Racing
description:
A unique motor racing board game simulation based on the real life rules for the 2016 motor racing season. The first in a series with a new racing circuit planned for release each season. Up to 6 players race around the track using authentic lines of travel rather than a grid system. The racing line is the quickest route around the circuit if you can get on it and stay there. Choose to play over 3 or more laps.

Use judgement to know when to overtake, slipstream the car in front, or take an alternative line into a corner. Time your pit-stop carefully. Be prepared for random events like a change in the weather, the safety car or engine management issues. If it happens in the real world, it can happen in the game.

Comes with both Basic and Advanced rules for beginners or racing enthusiasts. Advanced rules allow for 5 weather conditions, full tyre selection and choice of driving styles.

New tracks will be based on the 21 international circuits used through the racing season and you will be able to vote on which track you want to see next. They won't be exactly to scale or the game boards will be huge but we will preserve the authentic racing lines.

Each new circuit will be a self-contained game with up-to-date rules that incorporate New Season changes (such as a return to mid-race refuelling). If the rules change mid-season (as they did with qualifying in 2016) there will be a corresponding game rules change available for download from our main website. The new playing pieces will be in new team colours.

For anyone who wants to just keep the same track there will be an update pack available with the new cars, new rules and any additional cards that are necessary.

FWR does not attempt to simulate the cockpit driving experience: we felt that was being done much better with electronic console games. Instead, it gives you the fun of competing against family and friends around a table using tactical judgements about what racing line to take, when to try to overtake, when to come into the pits, what to do when the weather changes, when to take risks and when to play safe. The racing dice that contributes to movement only has the numbers 2,3,3,3,4,4. It adds to the fun and unpredictability but is rarely critical. Luck is a factor, just as in the real world but it doesn't dominate the game.

Far more significant might be a decision about whether to try to overtake the leader on the last lap when you are on dry tyres and it's started raining...

In the advanced rules, such decisions become more important. To simulate conditions across the world's racing circuits, there are 6 different types of weather that include factors like temperature as well as rain. You will have access to the full range of dry weather tyre compounds: ultrasoft, supersoft, soft, medium and hard. Three of these will be available for any particular game. Plus, of course, there will be wet weather tyres.

There will be several ways to determine weather conditions and tyre availability at the start of the game.

In addition, in the advanced rules you can change your driving style to suit the prevailing conditions and circumstances. For example, if you have a good lead or are running low on fuel you might want to reduce risk and drive cautiously. If it's the final lap and you want to go flat out to catch the leader, you might take more risks and push the car to the limit.
All up to you!

We hope you will enjoy Fifth Wing Racing, collect the tracks and download the Championship rules in 2017 so that you can compete with each other through a season of races. Have fun!

name: Nautical Challenge
description:
On the surface, this game is a simple roll the dice, move your boat around the board, first one home wins. The catch is that each move, the player must answer a skill-testing question, with the question topic depending on the segment of the race.

There are 10 decks of question cards: General Boating Rules; Nautical Knowledge; Buoys and Markers; Sea Survival; Lights & Flags; Fire Fighting; First Aid; Sound Signals; Engineering; and Knots & Anchors. There also is a Flash Card deck of signs and objects to recognize that comes into play on certain spaces around the board.

There are some interesting accessories: there is a real rope for answering knot questions, and a real triangular bandage that must be put on another player as part of a First Aid test. Players keep score with little black Life Rings, starting with 10, losing some along the way and winning one for each correct answer. The winner is not the first home but the one with the most rings.

name: Defenders of Shalvion
description:
From the publisher:

Defenders of Shalvion is a semi-cooperative and all-vs-1 game for 3-8 players.

The various factions of the galaxy Shalvion have been fighting amongst themselves for ages. Now, however, a new threat arises, threatening to drive them all to extinction: Miasma. As Defenders of Shalvion, players will take on a role of one of 6 factions, or the villainous Miasma.

Game play begins with a card drafting phase in which most players will draw 7 cards and choose 1. They will pass the remaining cards to the left. Choose 1. And continue down until there is 1 card left. This card is added to the others to create a Miasma Deck. Then the real game begins.

During the Defender Phase, players will choose 1 card to play, with the option to boost their cards with resources. (If the card represents a player's own faction, the card may be boosted without resources.) After this action has been taken, the players will then gather resources from any planets they control, and send their ships to attack the threat.

During the Miasma Phase, 1 card is flipped. Miasma gains resources and takes an action against the players. (Miasma may also be an active player, in which, the player decides which card to play.)
Players will need to watch that Miasma does not gain too many resources and become too powerful. If Miasma survives 5 rounds, Miasma wins. If Miasma gains too many resources or defeats all factions, Miasma wins. But if the factions are able to defeat Miasma, they will gain points according to their faction's unique victory conditions. And the player with the greatest number of points wins the game.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Sheep Happens: Lords of Corruption
description: Blinded by greed and desire, the Sheperds of "Sheep-Happens Lords of Corruption" were corrupted by demonic arts. To protect their lives and ambitions, they sealed large part of their power within the herds, resulting in some sort of eternal life. The burning desire to claim for themselves the domination of the valley led them to break each other's seals, initiating the conflict that still rages. Only if you prove to be the most skilled and ruthless you can prevail upon your enemies. Remember Shepherd ... Thin is the line between victory and defeat. Win the game by destroying your opponents herds to remain the last sheperd on the field, but beware, the closer you are to Oblivion, and at the end of your kingdom, the greater the power at your disposal, and with it the devastation, that you will pour out on your enemies.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Grassland and Sheep and Wind
description:
This is a card game in which players become members of a nomadic family, performing tasks necessary for the family's livelihood. If they work together, the whole family prospers.

Each player is assigned either 1 (4-6 players) or 2 (2-3 players) family members to carry out daily tasks and generate happiness. Players are each also assigned one secret family member (which may belong to an opponent) whose happiness is added to their own total at the end.

Task cards are drawn randomly and then played one at a time to a common area. Each task rewards an amount of happiness to specific family members when assigned a family member token as a worker, but the most rewarding tasks must have prerequisite cards finished before they can be performed.

Happiness is measured in chips designed as full moons, half moons, and crescent moons. The player with the most full moon happiness chips at the end is the winner, with the remaining chips acting as tiebreakers.

name: Precedence
description:
This 1906 trick-taking card game has a deck of 54 cards divided into six suits of nine cards each. The suits are ranked by color: Purple (highest), Red, Yellow, Green, Blue and Brown (lowest). Each suit has the following cards: King (highest), Duke, Marquis, Earl, Viscount, Bishop, Baron, Baronet and Knight (lowest).

The key difference from most trick-taking games is that there is no trump suit, only relative ranks. The Purple King takes anything; the Brown Knight loses to everything; the Brown King takes any card of any suit lower than King, but loses to all the other Kings.

Each trick taken during a hand counts as two points. Each Viscount taken counts an extra two points. A game is normally to 40 points.

After the deal, each player starting to the dealer's left has an opportunity to make a Single Call. He may call a Peerage (five tricks), House of Lords (seven tricks), Royal (all the tricks) or Misere (lose all the tricks). Any player making a call then plays against all the other players. A successful Peerage scores 20 points, Misere or House of Lords 30 points, and Royal 40 points . If unsuccessful, each other player scores 10 points against Peerage, 15 against House of Lords or Misere and 20 points against Royal.

The booklet includes rules for a partnership version, a two-player version and a variant called Game of Viscounts.
publishers: Leonard Beswick Ltd., William Ritchie & Sons, Ltd.

name: Electability
description:
Think you know who should be the President?

FINALLY A CARD GAME ABOUT BECOMING

PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA.

Electability is a 2 - 6 player card game that brings the madness of US presidential politics right to you!

Based on the 2016 US Presidential Election, Electability highlights some of the craziest rules, power plays, and historic scandals of US politics.

Do you wish your candidate didn't drop out early? Do you think you can beat your friends to become the next president? ELECTABILITY!

Play as Donald Trump! Bernie Sanders! Hillary Clinton! Ted Cruz! Marco Rubio! Ben Carson! and more!

We also include presidential greats pack where we bring back some of the best presidents in US History. Also our presidential hopefuls pack, where we let you run for president as sports stars, American Leading Ladies, Talk Show Hosts, etc.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Fighting, Humor, Political
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Bug-Game
description:
This 1951 game by J.W. Drueke is played with a "Bug Box" about 4" x 5", with a clear plastic lid, red sides and a green felt bottom. Inside the box is a single D6 with a different letter on each side: B, H, L, T, E, F. The name of the game appears on the felt along with an outline of a bug that has a round body, round head, two eyes, two feelers, six legs and one tail.

Each player has a sheet with 12 small boxes, each good for one game. Players take turns shaking the box, and the letter that appears determines what part of the bug they can draw.

They must roll a B in order to begin drawing the bug, and then an H in order to draw the head. After that, they may add whatever piece of the bug corresponds to the letter on the die. First player to complete a bug drawing wins.

name: Shadows in the Weald: Elksbane
description:
Elksbane is a four-counter expansion to Shadows in the Weald appearing in the sixth issue of Yaah! Magazine. It introduces a new hero, Borr Elksbane, and his two Direwolf Hirelings.

Borr is very frail, and doesn't pack much of a punch. He's not someone that can last long on his own, and in fact is at his best when he's helping others to be at their best. He allows your Party to reposition itself and to move quickly, while his tough Direwolf Hirelings slow down the enemy. It's all about getting the most out of your Party as a whole, and that often requires a bit of finesse.

The expansion includes three new scenarios, as well as rules to use Borr in all five base game scenarios.

name: Glydor
description:
This 1931 title from All-Fair is a spin-and-move game with a twist. The 16-space spinner includes moves from 7 forward to 2 back. In addition, the players may move either the total of the two numbers at the pointer and base ends of the spinner, or the difference between them.

There is the usual-looking twisting track for movement, with some squares that have specific instructions. But the winner is not the player to get to the end of the track. Rather, the winner is the last glider to land, the one who can keep his playing piece up in the air the longest by avoiding either end of the track or a forced landing.

name: The Capture of Mr. Raffles
description:
This trick-taking card game has a deck of 54 cards. There are four "series" or suits (Trump, Star, Sun, Moon), each with cards numbered from 0 to 12. There are also two additional cards, The Detective and Mr. Raffles.

The rules show a normal process for trick-taking games: one player leads, highest card takes each trick, and any trump beats any non-trump. In this game, however, The Detective is a top trump: it may not be led, but can be played at any time unless the holder also has Mr. Raffles.

The Mr. Raffles card is automatically picked up by whoever wins the trick on which it is played, and that player in turn must play Mr. Raffles at the first opportunity (the first trick in which he does not have the lead). A hand ends whenever one player runs out of cards.

Each trick taken during a hand counts one point. Each 0 card taken or held counts 5 points, and whichever player ends up with Mr. Raffles scores 10 points. Game is to 100 points.
publishers: Holt, Folger & Howard Co., Parker Brothers

name: Dobus: de clownsneusjes
description:
Dobus: de clownsneusjes (Dobus: the clown noses) is a childrens game in which children learn to recognize shapes based on a Belgium TV series.
The game starts with 44 tiles faced down on the table. Each turn a player picks a tile. If the picture on the card has the same shape (e.g. a square) as depicted on the player's clown card the player keeps the card. Otherwise it is left face up on the table (and can be taken by another player). The game ends when a player has collected ten tiles or when four "Petunia" cards are revealed. The player who found most cards with the right symbol wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Grim Prospects
description:
Explore an abandoned mine shaft in search of lost gems and ore while being careful to avoid the previous tenant's pitfalls. Draw cards by digging (draw two) or prospecting (look at the top three and choose one) from the deck until it is depleted, trying to avoid Dynamite and Gas Leaks, sure signs of disaster.

Players may also return to their base camp in order to stash their finds for safe keeping, or throw Dynamite at other players in order to make them drop their haul. Once the deck has been depleted, players tally the value of cards in their hand and stash to determine a winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Take That

name: Captain Number
description:
Two great pirates, one called Plus and the other By, try to get the mythic treasure of mathematics. They go through epic monsters and great difficulties.
He who arrives first at the mythic island will be the great winner taking with him the treasure of maths.
And he will be, "Captain Number".

Captain Number is a game of knowledge and math, there are 2 people or 2 teams, trying to go through puzzles where one makes the math problems and the other one tries to solve it, plus answering in the course of the game, cards with questions.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Point to Point Movement

name: Bara vanligt vatten
description:
Bara vanligt vatten is a somewhat educational roll-and-move game published by the Swedish Tourist Association and printed on a large trifold sheet of stiff paper. The game is water-themed and the back of the board has three pages of related physical and environmental information.

To my knowledge playing pieces were not supplied and there is no stated player count. The rules are rudimentary and game events include the usual "lose a turn", "move X spaces forward/backward" and "take a detour" among others.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Siljanspelet
description:
This belongs to a series of promotional Monopoly clones featuring local businesses and trivia, published around 1988-1992. As in Monopoly you move around a board collecting "shares" and hope for others to land on your properties, although the specifics are slightly different. Obviously the trivia elements vary from game to game within the series, and there are also some small mechanical variations, e.g. in the composition of event cards and how rent is calculated.

Though this particular game is not branded as Kunskapsspelet - it encompasses four towns around the lake of Siljan rather than a single town - it is clearly the same design by Knut Helleland, with some others contributing trivia questions.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: XITA
description:
1. Yes, another abstract strategy game, however the smallest 4 player abstract strategy game in the world (4" x 4").
2. First objective is to win. Second objective is to not come in last.
3. Each player has a player piece ("Gamer").
4. On the Board are 13 cork pieces (1 Black in the center, 4 Red around the black, 8 Green around the Red))
5. In turn, each Gamer moves 3 spaces, or "passes".
6. A cork piece is captured when a Gamer lands on it.
7. Game ends when the Black cork is captured, or all players have passed twice in a row.
8. Most points wins

name: Troll Country
description: In Troll Country 1-4 players take on the roles of a tribe of trolls trying to thrive in a dangerous land and survive against their ancient enemies, the Elfin. The game has a modular hex board where players move their trolls around to conquer lands and build improvements. Players get resources through gathering or hunting via a "Hunt Deck." They work to appease their deities and receive boons through rituals and works. While players may squabble, the main enemy is the Elfin who take their actions as determined via a special AI die. Theme and artwork is similar to "Overlord" and "Dungeon Keeper" video games.
categories: Adventure, Civilization, Dice, Economic, Fantasy, Fighting, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Cosmos
description:
This rare 1978 title is a game of space combat played out on a huge map featuring a stylized solar system and a massive web of connecting stars within a grid of squares. Eight of the nine planets are used as bases for between two and eight players. Each player has five ships, with the objective of either eliminating an opponent's five ships or getting one of his ships onto an opponent's planet.

Ships can either fire or move in a turn but not both. Range is measured not by star links but by number of squares counted orthogonally. Combat results are Hit or Miss, with the chance of a Hit increasing as range decreases. There are nine Firing Cards of 10 cards, with the number of the deck equal to the range and to the number of Miss cards it contains. Some of the result cards also trigger events through Space Conditions cards.

The movement and combat systems interact. When a ship succeeds in hitting and eliminating another ship, it gets promoted, by a degree that varies with the difference in ranks between the two. A ship's level does not affect combat, but does determine how many stars it can move in a turn. Ship rank ranges from 1 to 12.

name: Bourse
description:
User summary:

Although credit for inspiring the Parker Brothers' 1904 hit game Pit is often given to the 1903 Gavitt's Stock Exchange (GSE), this 1903 game from Flinch Card Co. is more obviously Pit's parent.

While GSE involved the trading of railway shares, Bourse (like the later Pit) was about trading commodities. All three games use the open-outcry method of trading cards (shouting a number of cards willing to trade but not their nature), and the goal of collecting all the cards of one kind.

Bourse uses a deck of 80 cards, ten each of eight commodities: Wheat (80 points), Corn (70), Cotton (60), Oil (50), Beef (40), Pork (30), Mutton (20) and Stocks (10). There are no special cards like GSE's Fatal Telegram or Pit's Bull and Bear.

name: Super Loopers
description:
Dexterity game where two players shoot marbles at the same time through two loops (one each) trying to land them on different point values.

Each player has five color-coordinated marbles, highest score wins.

name: Island's Bounty
description:
Island's Bounty is a treasure hunting board game set on an island. Players take turns rolling their dice, and exploring the grid of hex tiles on the board. Tile locations are marked in a notepad for future reference. Object tiles can be used to to help find treasure. For example, the Map allows a player to look at two face down tiles. Also, traps can be used on opponents. For instance, the Pit causes a player to lose a turn.

When a player has deduced the locations of at least two treasure tiles, the player may then begin placing their dice on the game board. The dice do not tell the exact locations of the Treasure tiles, rather, they tell the distance. The first person to place all three of their dice on the board wins the game.

name: Der Besucher: Teil 1 – Das Haus mit dem Roten Hund
description:
From the publisher:

In this labyrinth game, players assume the role of one of three mysterious young girl being chased by a dark stranger.

Players move besides their own character and the Red Dog, her protector, and the visitors, their enemy. Here a determined run mechanism and a malignant dice cause nerve-racking situations. But in order to escape yet, the girls need your help and all your skill.

name: Stadtkatzen
description:
From the publisher (translated):
In this Pachisi-style game, players roll the dice and move their pawns in a circle. The track goes around the roofs of an old city quarter. For the four main characters of the game, this is both home and hunting ground.

The town cats hunt mice, lose them again and steal them from each other. With the luck of the dice, things move around as quickly as you can call "You 've got the mouse!" can call. In this way, the game is also fun for the youngest players.

From the publisher (German):
In dieser Variante des indischen Pachisi, Vorlage für Mensch-ärgere-dich-nicht, wird in alter Tradition gewürfelt und mit den Spielfiguren im Kreis gezogen. Der Weg führt hoch über die Dächer eines alten Häuserviertels, das für die vier Hauptpersonen des Spiels Heimat und Jagdrevier in einem ist.

Die Stadtkatzen jagen Mäuse, verlieren sie wieder und schnappen sie sich gegenseitig weg. Mit dem Würfelglück geht es dabei schneller auf und ab, als man "Hab die Maus!" rufen kann. So macht die Jagd auch den Jüngsten Spaß.

name: Die Piraten der Krakeninsel
description:
From the publisher (translated):
Here, everything revolves around gold, sea battles and ships that can be sunk. The four most notorious pirates of the seas want to get the gold that is on board the galleons.

Players move around the sea chart, which is populated gold-laden galleons and the fearsome Kraken in addition to their pirates. Next to luck with the dice, a clever tactic and a nose for the right opportunity will decide who will be the next Pirate King of Kraken Island.

From the publisher (German):
Hier dreht sich alles um Gold, Seeschlachten und Schiffe, die es zu versenken gilt. Die vier berüchtigtsten Piraten der Meere wollen an das Gold an Bord der Galeonen kommen.

Die Spieler ziehen über die Seekarte, die neben ihren Piraten auch von goldbeladenen Galeonen und dem furchterregenden Kraken bevölkert wird. Neben dem Würfelglück entscheidet auch eine geschickte Taktik und eine Nase für die richtige Gelegenheit darüber, wer der nächste Piratenkönig der Krakeninsel wird.

name: Tarántula
description:
Los pequeños exploradores avanzan por la jungla sorteando toda clase de obstáculos, en busca del cofre de oro de la la tarántula. Consigue ser el primero en alcanzar el centro del tablero con dos de tus exploradores pero... ¡ten cuidado con la tarántula, ya que podría enviarte de vuelta a casa!
__

Little explorers through the jungle dodging all sorts of obstacles, in the search of the golden casket of the tarantula. Get to be the first to reach the center of the board with two of your explorers but... beware of the tarantula, as it could send back to home!

name: Find It & Bind It: The Demon Expansion
description:
The first expansion to the game Find It & Bind It in which 2-6 players control 2 witches each as they search for the Book of Shadows.
