The Demon Expansion introduces a new Book Card: The Demon. This replaces one of the Other Book Cards and introduces new rules and mechanics for how your witches interact with the demon whilst searching for the Book of Shadows.

name: Find It & Bind It: Hexes & Relics Expansion
description:
A second expansion to the game Find It & Bind It in which 2-4 players control 2 witches each as they search for the Book of Shadows.

The Hexes & Relics expansion comes with 54 additional Spell Cards. These Spell Cards add Hexes (that you cast on others) and Relics (that you play on yourself) and other Spell Cards that add to the fun in various, devious ways.

Like the first expansion, this one also adds a new dimension and set of mechanics that augment the original game.

name: Sibe chugelrundi Söi
description:
In this reaction the game, players take on the role of small piglets and mimic the big pig in the barn. They are grunting, smacking and even scratching their backs: But only the fastest piglet gets a corncob.
Game play: One player roles the seven dice. Depending on the result the players have to do a certain action: for example, they have to grunt or they have to smack. The fastest one with the right action (the dice indicate the right action) wins the round and gets a corncob. The first player with seven corncobs wins the game.

name: The Dusty Trail
description:
The Dusty Trail is a map exploration game where adventurers defeat outlaws, shoot it out (with weapons of the old west) or they gamble with the other players to earn gold.

Players start at the train station in the middle of the old west, equipped with only a little gold to spend. Each turn, players move along the map and explore new areas by laying down a card that represents a place on the map. Exploration leads to new weapons, outlaws that block the way, gold, shoot outs, saloon brawls, cattle stampedes and more.

Enemies are fought with a simple dice mechanic. Each weapon and enemy rolls a single six sided dice, and their power varies depending on the weapon used vs the difficulty number on the outlaws card. Each victory is rewarded with a number of gold pieces.

When a player lays down the last map card reaching the end of the Dust Trail a random infamous character is drawn and must be defeated.

The game ends when the infamous character is defeated and gold is collected for their defeat. The winner is the player with the most gold. If players are tied, they must shoot it out.

name: Landpartie
description: Simple roll & move game with one die. On some spaces there are events that hinder or benefit the player. The first player to reach space 69 wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hooked on Bass
description: Hooked on Bass is a VCR board game about bass fishing. Players roll dice to move their boats around the board and fish by playing cards, rolling dice, and cross-referencing the results with their board location in a reference book that comes with the game. Players who fish successfully play the VCR tape to determine what size of fish they caught. The player who catches the highest total weight of fish during the day wins.

name: Rat Rod Race
description:
Rat Rod Race is a unique and fun new board game for all the family. It was designed to provide a more tactile and interactive experience for the players with a retro vintage style to match the theme. The game is a crossover which incorporates elements of traditional board games, card games, racing games and component building.

There are two playing boards in the game, featuring a Junkyard and a Dragstrip.

THE JUNKYARD

Players begin by stocking the junkyard board with all the parts for the Rat Rods. There are 4 disassembled vehicles whose components each have their own area. You choose where to place them.

Once the Junkyard has been stocked, players roll a dice to see who goes first and begin moving their tokens around the board, collecting all the necessary parts to build their vehicles.

There are four male and four female mechanic character tokens, allowing any combination of players. Parts must be collected in order, however players can choose which path to take to reach their favourite ones first. Depending upon which direction a player chooses to take, it will lead them to different types and styles of car parts within each category.

The aim is to get the parts you want first, before the others collect them. Different body types, different engines, blower styles and different wheel designs means loads of possible combinations.

The player that finishes their car first, takes pole position on the Dragstrip Board. As each of the other players finish, they take up the remaining positions in order. Positions on the grid determine the order of turn.

THE DRAGSTRIP

This is where the real race begins.

The highly detailed Dragstrip Board is one of the largest made, with interchangeable sections to make it as short or long as you want. It can be assembled to almost 3m in length.

The road ahead is filled with potential dangers, with an extra element where players get to place hazard cones at strategic locations to try and stop the other players from winning the race. Every time a player lands on a road hazard or cone, they draw an action card from the deck which could delay them, send them back or forward, or other unexpected outcomes.

Potential hazards along the way include potholes, radar traps, toxic chemical spills, oil slicks, loose car parts, and even quake damage. Remember too, that this is the Extraterrestrial Highway...so you never know what you might encounter during the race.

Every time a player lands on a Hazard space, they take a card from the Action deck. Sometimes it's good news, sometimes it's bad!

There are 30 different Action Cards included in the game, with a little humour thrown in, and all with a unique Retro look.

We also wanted to bring back the old school fun of a game spinner, so we've designed a custom "Speed Dial" which has multiple 10, 20 and 30 MPH markings on it. Each of these correspond with the gear you are in, 1st, 2nd, or 3rd, and players move one to three spaces accordingly.

name: Cybermythica: Loom of Fate
description:
Cybermythica: Loom of Fate is a strategy game set in the world of Cybermythica, a universe which is a kind of a hybrid between mythology and cyberpunk. Each player will lead one of four Megapolis Kronos Megacorps with varying abilities and starting units. The Goal standing before them is as bright as the glare of the Titan Helios – to do everything to make the thread of their lives the leading one in the history woven by the Loom of Fate.

This task won`t be easy when you live in Megapolis Kronos, a place ravaged by incessant conflict between two Conglomerates - Logos controlled by Zeus and Elysium controlled by his brother Hades. It’s really like being between Scylla and Charybdis. The question is: whose side are you on, which strategy will you choose? Will you support the most influential of all G.O.D.S., Almighty Zeus, or maybe the Lord of the Dead, Hades? Or perhaps you will remain neutral in this conflict? Will you be able to convince Aristoi - best of the best of the residents of Megapolis Kronos - to give you their support? Will you be able to win the hearts of Megapolis’s citizens? Maybe the path to achieve the goal goes through taking the control over Megapolis’s sectors? Or maybe you will go down in history as the one who has tamed the powerful Ephemeris from the depths of Ether, and the memory about you will last forever? One goal, many roads.

The game is divided into Cycles (turns) during which players will perform actions using the resources they control – like Aristoi, Assets, special Techne cards, support and Ambrosia tokens. They will try to take control of Megapolis Kronos Sectors to get more support to fulfill contracts for large conglomerates (Logos and Elysium). Visit the special places to get Techne cards, recruit Aristoi, acquire Assets and even tame the powerful Ephemeris. Fight the other players in duels or carry out assaults against other players’ HQs. The purpose of these actions is to gain prestige in the eyes of the residents of Megapolis Kronos. The game ends when the fate token on the Loom of Fate reaches level 11 or higher and players will receive History points for all they have done during the game. The player with the highest score wins the game.

name: Combination!
description:
This 1941 game published by Clover Games Inc. consists of 48 triangular tiles bearing different combinations of six colors on each of their three sides.

The rules say to place all the tiles face down in the center of the table. Each player initially draws six. Players then in turn draw from one to three triangles each turn until one player can form a hexagon in which all six triangles match colors on each adjoining side.

These triangles are set aside. The player who created the hexagon must then place twice the number of tiles he drew above his initial six back into the center and set aside the remainder as out of the game. Each other player returns all tiles to the center, and all players draw new hands of six and start again.

The game continues until not enough tiles are left in the center for any player to complete a hexagon, at which point the player with the most hexagons wins.

name: Nyapaato
description:
User summary
にゃぱーと (Nyapaato) is a memory game where players try to find the cats hidden in the different rooms of an apartment building composed out of the tile cards. Lay out the tile cards with the window-side facing up to create a square apartment building.

If a player finds two cats of the same pattern, he or she receives one point. However, to make things a bit more difficult, if a player flips over an room with a ghost hidden inside, the ghost will rearrange the rooms of the apartment building in order to trick the players.

Try to find all the cats in the building without running into the prankster ghosts.

When all the cats have been found, the game is over. The player who has found the most cats is the winner.

The title "Nyapaato" is a portmanteau of the Japanese onomatopoeic representation of a cat’s meow ("Nya") and the word "apaato" — a shortened version of the English borrowed word "apartment" which is commonly used in Japanese.

Publisher's summary
「にゃぱーと」は、裏面が窓の絵のタイルを正方形に並べて作った「アパート」の部屋に隠れた猫を見つけるメモリー系のゲームです。
同じ絵柄の「猫」のペアを見つけることで、１ポイントを獲得します。
しかし、ちょっとした邪魔がはいります。「オバケ」のいる部屋を開けてしまうと、オバケにイタズラされてアパートの部屋の配置が少し動かされてしまうのです。
オバケのイタズラに惑わされないで、猫たちを全て見つけてあげてください。
全ての猫を見つけ出せたらゲームが終了し、一番多くの猫を見つけた人が勝者になります。

name: The Knowledge Box
description:
This appears to be an c. 1870s card game that elaborates on the basic Authors/Go Fish mechanic (asking other players for cards that complete sets). The box features a dull-colored lithograph of Niagara Falls. The cards are not illustrated and are square with plain white backs.

The game is undated and bears no copyright, patent or company name except a small white triangle containing the initials E.I.H. This suggests an early publication by E.I. Horsman, which started as a doll manufacturer in 1865 and by the mid-1880s was having a battle with Milton Bradley over the rights to Halma and was prominently displaying patents and copyrights on its boxes.

The card deck has 48 cards divided into 12 sets of four cards each. The 12 categories are: Great Poets; Great Dramatists; Great Historians; Great Painters; Great Musical Composers; Great Philosophers; Great Astronomers; Great Naval Commanders; Great Rulers; Great Pieces of Sculpture; Great Events; and Natural Wonders.

The main rules difference from Authors is that the sets are grouped into four trios. For instance, Poets, Dramatists and Historians form one of the trios. Winning two sets of a trio is worth three points instead of two, and winning all three is worth five points. Individual sets count a single point, but the person with the largest number of sets of any kind gets a two-point bonus. Most points wins.

name: The Game of Sixty-Six
description:
This undated game from Rosebud Art Co. is a spin-and-move game with a mathematical twist that is not nearly as easy as it looks. The board consists of five concentric circles of numbers connected by paths. There are four color-coded spaces in the corners and four matching spaces numbered 66 at the center.

The number spaces range from minus 9 to plus 8. The spinner is unusual - it has 12 outcomes that include 2 x 0, 3 x 1, 2 x 2, 2 x 3, and one each of 4, 5 and 6. The rules say that after making a spin, each player must move his token that number of spaces, forwards, back or sideways.

The player must add or subtract the number in each space he passes or reaches and keep a cumulative total from one turn to the next. The winner is the first to successfully reach the 66 space of their color with a cumulative total of exactly 66.

A copy of the game from renowned collector Alex G. Malloy's estate includes a hand-written attribution of the cover art to Palmer Cox, the Canadian artist famous for his books and comics about Brownies. As Cox died in 1924, this implies an early-to-mid 1920s publication date.

name: Hidden Book Titles
description:
This title includes three series of rebus-puzzle type cards. The cards were large, about 7.25" x 4.5", with a series of images on the front and a number on the back. The back of each card also included the copyright and publication date (October 1899).

The series were sold separately, with the Series A box including 30 cards and the Series B and C boxes holding only 15 each. Each box included a sheet with all the correct answers.

The cards were sold as a competitive party game, with guests vying to see who could name the most book titles correctly as the cards were displayed. For instance, the answer to a card showing two babies playing followed by a squashed capital A was Innocents Abroad.

name: Numbersaurus
description:
Dinosaur maths game.

Move the dinosaur between the volcanoes in search of the correct numbers to make up your sums and cards. An exciting game that can be played at 2 different skill levels and which encourages children to practise their sums.

name: Retruco
description:
Retruco is described on the box as "A Game of Skill, for Winter Evenings, Playable on any Table". It also is an early example of celebrity marketing, as the box declares "Played at Warwick Castle During the Visit of H.R.H. The Prince of Wales, May 1895". The box claims "Patent No. 575".

The rules say the name is Spanish for "a recoiling" and the game consists of 9 wooden pins, 3" tall, and a wooden ring. The eight yellow pins are set up in a square and the single black pin goes in the center of the square.

Players take turns propelling the ring by pushing down from the top so that it moves forward with a reverse spin, one that brings it back toward the player if it hits a pin. A player gets three shots, plus one more for each hit. Pins are reset for each player's turn.

Hitting a pin scores 10 for those in the rank nearest to him, 20 points for those on either side of the black "king" pin, and 40 points for those in the far rank. Hitting the "king", however, wipes out his score and ends his turn. First player to reach 500 wins.

name: White Text on Black Cards
description:
White Text on Black Cards was designed from the despair and despise of seeing and being asked to play all of the variants of white text on black card games. Now when I am asked to play such games, I can play this as an alternative and in just one quick round! After that, your group can easily move onto a better game of any type -- just not these!

The game is played in one round. It begins with you laying the one black card on the table and dealing the white cards as evenly as possible to all players. Then players choose the best response to the one black card and hand the to you. As the person who started the game you get to decide which answer is the best for that moment and the player who chose it gets a point. The game is played as many times as you like and points are tallied and scored most points wins.

name: Betrayal's Tower
description:
From the publisher:
A long time ago an ancient curse was origined into The Forbidden Tower. Palia's Guardians, The Elementals, sacrificed their existence to seal up the curse inside the Tower. Over time the seal has become weaker and The Curse is about to be released. A new generation of heroes will must have to put an end to the terror that threatens the kingdom. But, everything is not as easy as it seems... Among the heroes there is a traitor who will have to get rid of the heroes and release The Curse.

Betrayal 's Tower is a team game aimed at any follower of the fantasy genre in which you will have go up through the tower floor by floor, beating the danger it hides inside. You must defeat monsters, buy powerful items, and use special abilites of each heroes to reach the top of the tower and destroy The Curse to win and avoid the end of the kingdom.

From the publisher (Spanish):
Tiempo atrás una antigua maldición se originó en la Torre Prohibida. Los guardianes de Palia, los Elementales, sacrificaron su existencia para sellarla en el interior de la Torre. Con el paso del tiempo el sello ha ido debilitándose y la Maldición está a punto de ser liberada. Será una nueva generación de héroes quienes tendrán el deber de poner fin al terror que se cierne sobre el reino. Pero no todo es tan sencillo como parece, entre los héroes hay un traidor que tratará de sabotear la misión y lograr así liberar la maldición.

Betrayal’s Tower es un juego de equipo dirigido a cualquier seguidor del género fantástico en el que tendréis que ascender por las peligrosas salas de la torre prohibida y enfrentar los peligros que aguardan. Deberéis derrotar monstruos, comprar poderosos objetos y usar las habilidades únicas de cada héroe para ganar y evitar así el fin del reino.

name: Rift
description:
Rift is an arena-battle style game that unites fast-paced action with strategic card management.

An idyllic world is just one of many in the cosmos - until the Rift appears. Manifesting as a magical tear in space-time, the Rift contains the promise of absolute power - and total destruction. Up to four immortal warriors arrive on the planet to claim the Rift as their own, even as the energy begins to tear the world apart. The storms, volcanos, and earthquakes that the Rift creates are fair game to the immortals, who use the disasters to power their attacks against each other. Only one will be left standing to claim the Rift as their own.

Rift is a streamlined dueling system, where the cards in a player's hand simultaneously represents their life total and their options. Damage taken forces a player to discard, leading to agonizing choices as the game reaches its world-shattering conclusion. The novel, unique rule-set is both quick to pick up and features near-endless strategic depth.
categories: Card Game, Environmental, Fantasy, Fighting, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Memory, Player Elimination, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: The Vampyre of Mons
description:
From the publisher:

The Vampyre of Mons is co-operative game of exploration, adventure and horror by Darkmook Paper Miniatures & Water Closet Press. Debuting at Thought Bubble 2015 in the UK and originally limited to only 30 copies for the initial print run, this is now available digitally as an RPGNow! exclusive!

Set in the dark days of the Great War, The Vampyre of Mons is designed for 1-6 players and sees heroic (and not so heroic!) British troops and their mysterious allies facing the horrors of the Vampyre Lord's castle, where the very building itself plots to aid in their demise!

Using the latest version of the Darkmook Paper Miniatures Survival Horror rules, all you need to do is print and construct the components, grab some 6 sided dice and a standard deck of playing cards and you are ready to start your adventure!
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Castle Loot
description:
From the publisher:

You are about to enter the biggest castle of the most terrifying dragon. Only the fastest but the most vigilant hero will know fame and glory. Others will probably never leave the castle alive…

Castle Loot is a competitive game in which players rely on their reflexes and some judgment to win. One of the four characters, who is greatly inspired by RPG video games, is placed in the middle of the table with all his four equipment tiles surrounding him. The torch will light his path (and allow you to steal a gem from the bag of another player), his sword will be necessary to defend himself against the dragon, his bag will store the gems found and finally, his key will open all the treasure chests that you will find.

In fact, each round, a card is revealed by placing it facing up in the middle of the four equipment tiles. Then, players rush to grab the corresponding equipment of that card.
A dragon? Grab the sword!
A treasure chest? Grab the key!
Gems? Grab the bag!
Stairs? Grab the torch!

Each equipment tile has its own specific effect when it is grabbed at the right moment. But, be careful! Some cards are disguised and contain traps or spiders on them…be quick, but stay vigilant!

name: Gates: Mana Wars
description:
From the publisher:

Gates is a competitive, turn based board game with strong aspect of deck building and managing unruly creatures. All of this in an original world of magic and heroes. The first board from the Basic Set is adjusted for two players, where they must fight over limited resources of mana and outsmart an opponent.

To cast a spell a player needs mana and a card. Every spell has its own effects, sometimes divided into few verses. So you are in control on how much mana spent and which effects you wish to unleash upon your opponent and the battlefield. Anyway, imagine a situation where your silly enemy throws a fireball in your face. What could you do? Of course, there is an interrupt option, why not. Or you could summon a creature that will cover you with its own body. Erect a wall of stones to block the missile. Or cast your own fireball and make it clash like in Dragon Ball series!

Ultimate goal of this duel is to defeat everyone foolish enough to compete with you. Unless you fight against one one the Legendary Beasts, which means you need to cooperate as a team to defeat this monstrosity.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Twizmo! Words
description:
Description from the publisher:

Twizmo! Words is all about ­finding and building words using the letters on the top of Twizmo! Word Cube and the letters on the cards. Letters on the cube can be used in any order, and as many or as few times as desired. A player is not required to use all the letters on the cube, but their word must include the letter on the card for that turn. To win, players collect the letter cards during their turns to score the most points.

Each turn starts with the flip of a letter card. The letter on the card must be used—together with any letters on the top face of the cube. There is always a designated “Player” who must guess a word of at least four letters. However, if any opponent can shout out a SEVEN letter word before Player has called a word, that opponent can take the card as his own.

Twizmo! Words contains twelve “Game Changer” cards, dealt evenly to players before each game. These cards provide players with an arsenal of “secret weapons”, which they can use to surprise their opponents at just the right time.

name: Tom and Jerry Gay Double Feature Cartoon Game
description:
This 1948 title may be the earliest board game featuring the famous cat-and-mouse duo. Published by Milton Bradley under license from Loew's Inc. (owner of MGM), it is a spin-and-move game with a twist.

Each player has both a Tom and a Jerry character, and they move in opposite directions around the board. There also is a twin spinner, one for each character. Each players spins both dials on his turn. When both spinners hit the same number, both moves are doubled. First player to get both pieces round the board wins.

The game track includes three kinds of spaces: Cat, Mouse and star. What happens when two pieces meet depends on the space. Stars are safe spots. If two Toms meet on a Mouse space or two Jerrys on a Cat, both are sent home to start over. If a Tom and a Jerry meet, then Tom goes home on a Mouse space and Jerry goes home on a Cat.

The box and rules declare that "This is a Psych Tested Game"... whatever that means.
categories: Animals, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Illustration quest
description:
One player is the storyteller for the turn and looks at the 9 Illustration cards on the table. From three of these, he/s makes up a sentence and says it out loud.

Each other player using own three markers selects the up to three Illustration cards on the table which best matches the sentence, without showing it to the others.

All Illustration are shown face up and every player has to bet upon which picture was the storyteller's.

If nobody finds any of correct card, each of the other players scores 2. Otherwise the storyteller and whoever found the correct answer score from 1 up to 3 points.

The game ends when the deck is empty or if a player scores 30 points. In either case, the player with the most points wins the game.

The base game have 180 different Illustration cards.
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Simultaneous Action Selection, Storytelling

name: Playten
description: Playten is a fun, creative game for children that will help their English vocabulary. By rolling a die and moving the pawn on the colourful snail, players try to collect all the cards that match the colour of their category card. Once a player completes his/her card, he/she must be the first player to pass the finish line on the snail in order to win.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Stubborn Pigs
description:
This tiny two-player board game consists of two cardboard pigs mounted on wooden stands, and a long unfolding paper strip (13" x 3") with horizontal lines representing 28 steps from Home to Market. A teetotum is used to advance each pig in turn, with every step including an event that cause the pig to either gain or lose additional steps.

While there is neither publisher nor date marked on the box, board or rules, the game is identified as an upcoming release by Milton Bradley in American Stationer on May 29, 1890.

name: Parley-Mutual
description:
This horse-racing game, undated but likely 1930s, uses a deck of cards to determine movement. The game contains six thick cardboard cards, each having a track of 12 holes from Start to Finish. Each track is marked with one of the suits and represents the horses "Club Foot", "Diamond Jim", "Spade Tail", and "Heart Throb".

For the basic Stake Race game, each player turns over a card, the horse of the drawn suit moves ahead one space, and the owning player must pay $1 into the stakes. First to reach the finish takes the accumulated stakes.

There are additional rules for Steeplechase, Handicap, Daily Double and Hi-Stepping races, as well as a Number-Pool game that can be added to any of them.

If more than six people play at once, a second deck of cards is required.

name: Mary and John or They Lived Happily Ever After
description:
This is a third game in the series done by Howard R. Garis for Milton Bradley along with Uncle Wiggily and Jack and Jill or Who Brought the Water. In this game, Mary and John can each start from one of four corners, merging at a central plaza after 10 spaces.

At various stops along the way to their Wedding Ring at space 150, they can encounter a Lunch Room, Movie Theater, Soda Shop, Cigar Store, Dress Maker, Cabaret, Barber, Candy Shop, Shoe Store and Dentist, each of which sends Mary and John in different directions (forward and back).

name: Pat's the Bhoy
description:
This is a ring-toss game with an 8" tall caricature cut-out of a Celtic lad held upright by two wooden blocks at the back of the box. The bottom of the box is divided into six colored squares.

The cut-out's pointed ears are worth 6 points each; his club and pipe on the sides 3 points and his hat 4 points. The squares on the board range from minus 4 to plus 5.

Although undated, the style of the artwork suggests 1930s.

name: Kreuz und quer
description:
Each player has 4 playing pieces that he has to get to the 4 home spaces of his own color. At the beginning, the playing pieces are put on the table top down and are shuffled. Then they are placed randomly on all home spaces. After the colors are dispensed among the players, the playing pieces are turned up to reveal their colors. Movement is straight in all directions, but not diagonal, any number of spaces. Jumping over other playing pieces is not permitted. The first player to get all 4 playing pieces onto his home spaces wins the game.

The game was published between 1938 and 1940.

name: If I Were President, What Would I Do?
description:
This is an unexpectedly thought-provoking game based on a very simple roll-and-move track. The box says it was produced in a limited edition and "Created by a Vietnam Marine".

After each move, the player must draw from a deck of 124 cards. Most (82) require the player to ask a question of the player to his left, and if that player answers correctly, that player moves ahead the number of spaces on the card. There also are five "fun" cards, which ask "no move or point" questions like, "If you were President, would you throw a lot of parties?"

But the key to the game is the set of 37 issue cards. These ask questions such as "If you were president, what would be your position on a national health plan?" The player asked has up to 2 minutes to answer, and all players (including the answering one) then vote. If a majority approve, the answering player moves ahead the number of spaces on the card.

While the rules are written for 2-4 players, this would probably work better for somewhat larger groups, especially within a classroom.

name: Fog of War Fantasy Wargame
description:
Fog of War Fantasy Wargame is a tabletop miniatures wargame set in a fantasy world. Two players command opposing armies of miniatures and clash in a variety of scenarios. In a basic game, victory is achieved by routing the enemy army or destroying it entirely.

It differs from the normal tabletop wargaming format by using an action point system, where a number of points are assigned to the player at the beginning of the turn by a dice roll. These actions are then used to activate army units, which can then choose from a number of actions to perform. Basic actions include moving, shooting and charging, but most units have their own unique actions, such as 'Shieldwall', which affect how they are used in the game, and command units have access to actions that affect other units, such as 'Rally'. This system adds an element of tactical depth whilst reducing the length of the game turn, making for quicker games.

A single book, called 'The Tome', is the only reference point for the game, and contains all the lore, rules, army lists and other information required to play the game.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: The Botch
description:
“In the criminal underworld, there are good days and there are bad days. Today, everyone is having a bad day.”

In The Botch, a motley collection of criminals are picking through the wreckage of a massive heist gone massively cock-eyed. There’s a fortune’s worth of diamonds flying around between the hands of even the small-timer crooks scudding around the Boss’ empire, and she’s not happy.

Meant to evoke those chaotic crime movies where everything’s going wrong, The Botch is a party game of hidden information and ridiculous messes. It’s a game about bluffing and nerve, about pulling off a con, and about grabbing the jewels and running. In The Botch, you’re going to lie, cheat and steal, and if you’re really lucky you’ll get out of this with your skin intact.

The Botch is a hidden-information bluffing game designed to keep things reasonably chaotic and make it hard for players to get an overwhelming edge through experience and memorisation. It’s a game to get people into gaming, where things going embarrassingly wrong is part of the design.

The Botch contains 5 Basic roles and 5 Basic items, which are designed to be played as an entry-level stable game. As you become more comfortable with the game you can add more roles and more items, choosing from an additional 7 Advanced roles and 7 Advanced items.

First to 10 diamonds ends the game or last alive wins.
mechanics: Memory, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Lily X Blade
description:
The many prestigious high schools of Jordan Ketch Prefecture feature countless clubs for proper young ladies. A girl can try her hand at nearly anything, from flower arranging to water polo.

What they don’t offer is swordplay – but that’s about to change.

Rules are drawn up. Blades cross in secret. And special badges now identify those girls ready to duel any place, any time…

Lily x Blade is a two-player, player-versus-player card game with simple rules and a whole lot of bluffing.

- Choose your tactics, then fool your rival so she plays right into your hands! choosing a card from you hand of 5 and revealing at the same time as your opponent.
- Capture your rival’s cards to limit her options and press the advantage. Rock paper scissors but with special abilities on some cards.
- Each duelist has a unique personality and abilities – choose your favourite and ensure her ultimate victory! First to five wins, wins!
mechanics: Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Clown-o-Winks
description:
This undated game uses a tiddly-wink mechanic, but the one disk propels five small plastic rings instead of smaller disks from a red felt mat.

The directions on the box say to prop the lid behind the base as a backboard, and flip the rings onto a target board inset in the box. The board has a central clown face worth 10 on the nose, 5 on the mouth and 2 on the face, along with four small clowns holding starts, worth 3 or 4 points.

The big points come from successfully ringing one of 12 wooden pegs supplied with the game that are pushed through small holes in the boards. Each peg ringed is worth 25 points.

name: Double Quarterback
description:
This 1949 game is subtitled "The Football Game Used by Coaches to Train Their Squads. The football field inset in the box is marked to individual yards, and has peg holes along the side to mark scores, quarters and downs. Other parts include a cardboard 10 yard marker, a plastic football and three dice.

Although each play requires a roll of the dice, with the total compared against a list of plays to determine net yards gained or lost, the key to the game lies in two sets of cards. The defensive player each play secretly chooses one of five formation cards (6-2-2-1, 6-3-2, 7-1-2-1, 8-3 or 5-3-2-1).

The offensive player then calls one of eight possible plays and turns over the top card from the 80-card play deck. Cross-referencing the play row with the defensive column provides a modifier to the die roll, as well as possible fumbles and interceptions.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Bankers & Brokers: The 3D Board Game
description:
It's a race to the top of the corporate ladder in the fast paced family game! Players must use strategy and their wits to accumulate the most money before they retire. Scheme your way to the Chairmen of the Board and then force your friends to pay your debts. But watch out, they might gang up on you and force you into early retirement! Big money, big risks and backstabbing; it's all in a day's work for big business. WILL YOU SURVIVE?

Based on the poker variant of a similar name, players compete to have the best hand, betting on each round based on their position on the 3D board. Each position limits the players hand size as well as betting minimum, with loss causing the player to incur debt. When a player reaches the chairman position, they can pass debts they incur onto lower ranked players. Highest ranked player at the end of the game, who has not been forced into retirement, wins.

name: Notakto
description:
IntroductionNotakto is a misere 3-in-a-row game for two players. It's played on the squares of a finite number of initially empty 3x3 boards. All pieces are exactly the same and are shared by both players.



DefinitionsA board is dead if it contains at least one set of three stones in a straight orthogonal or diagonal line.

A board that is not dead is alive.



PlayOn their turn, a player must place a piece on an empty square of a living board.

When all boards are dead, the player who made the last placement loses.

name: Aesop
description:
This is a late 19th Century card game in which each of the 17 pairs is composed of a card with a recap and moral from one of Aesop's fables, and another with an illustration of that fable. The odd card is a portrait of Aesop himself, and all the artwork is fantastic.

All the cards are dealt out. The player to the left of the dealer takes one card from the player to his right (the dealer in this case) and then lays down in front of him as many pairs as possible. Each player in turn repeats until all pairs have been laid.

The Aesop card may be played at any time, and has the effect of doubling the number of matches beneath it. Winner is the player with the greatest number of matched pairs at the end of the game.

The box is undated, but Alex G. Malloy, American Games: Comprehensive Collector's Guide, dates it to 1890 (p. 34. #1001).

name: S and W Happy Marriage Game
description:
In the 1930s, canned food company S&W Fine Foods was the sponsor of a popular radio program called "I Want A Divorce", and in 1938 published a promotional board game called "S and W Happy Marriage Game".

The envelope used to ship the game says the show ran on eight radio stations in the Western U.S. and ran on the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sunday evenings at 7:30 Pacific and 8:30 Mountain. The board records the copyright date as 1938.

The game itself is a simple roll-and-move with a colorful folding cardboard game board. The theme is "happy marriage" and the track moves from "Proposal" to "Golden Anniversary at space 50.

The track is littered with squares representing personal faults like Jealousy, Excess, Gossip and Gambling that push players back, as well as virtues like Loyalty and Patience that move them forward. Square 24 is named "I Want a Divorce" after the radio program and sends players back to the start.
publishers: S and W Fine Foods Inc.

name: Peanut Hunt
description:
Who grabs all peanuts first?

Dexterity game for children:
Who will be the first player collecting 4 peanut chips of different colors with his elephant trunk?

name: The Balkan Tragedy 1912-1913
description:
Description from the publisher:

The Balkan Tragedy is a one-two player game simulating the conflict in the balkans during both the first and second balkan war. This is a more traditional hex and counter War-Game and plays in 90-120 mins for each scenario. The first scenario being the first Balkan War, and the Second Balkan War being the other scenario included in the game. This game is meant to setup the background for our further exploration into the conflicts of the time period. Particularly WW1, as well as other post WW1, and inter war period conflicts. The game will feature a paper map, and units counters, and all necessary tracking counters for the game. Nations included in the game are: The Ottoman Empire, Bulgarians, Serbians, Greek, Romanian, and Montenegrin forces. This is your time to see if you can change history in the Balkans, and perhaps influence this critical region at this point in human history. Your the General now!!!

name: The Moving Picture Game
description:
This is a simple but colorful game designed by Howard R. Garis (creator of Uncle Wiggily). The box cover has an illustration of people lining up at a movie theatre box office, which shows the day's feature as a Charlie Chaplin movie. The playing board is laminated to the bottom of the box, and is set up like a theatre, with 11 rows of seats and a centre aisle.

The rules are pasted on the inside of the lid, and describe a spin-and-move effort to weave through the seats all the way to the stage. The winner gets to shake hands with the hero and heroine of the movie, who have appeared that night in person. The 131-space track includes 13 seats with hazards such as "You sat in gum, lose 1 turn" and six seats with bonuses such as "Somebody eats peanuts, go to 48".

name: Farmers' Market Rally
description:
Farmers’ Market Rally is a set collection game of seasonal local produce and high scores and is for two to four people, aged eight and above. The game is set at your local farmers’ market, where you’ve met up with some friends to search for items on your shopping list and collect anything else in season this week.

For the number of players plus two, two rows of card stacks are dealt to create farmer's stands. Players take turns picking from the dealt stands, with new cards replaced after each turn. Two rounds of stands are available with surprises waiting to be found in the back of the second-row stands after players have made their most of their first-row purchases. The game continues until one of the second-row stands has sold-out, with one turn left for the remaining players.

There are thirteen item card types and 94 total items in the deck, plus ten shopping list cards.

name: COME ON OVER!
description:
One player is in a tricky situation and is looking for a solution. The other players have to invent a story around one bizarre fact that will convince the first player to come to their country to solve the problem. If your country is chosen, you receive the situation card. Whoever collects the most cards wins the game.

Who will come up with the craziest story?
Which countries do those weird facts belong to?

Including more than a hundred surprising facts about the 28 EU countries and thousands of possibilities for fun stories, COME ON OVER! is the perfect entertaining game about Europe.

name: Tibbits
description:
Tibbits is a variation and combination of several games - but played with cubes. The cubes have A, K & Q on them (like cards) and in different colors. You try to build combinations (like 3 identical As, A-K-Q of the same color, etc.) and collect chips based on what colors and combinations you make. Ages 8 and up. There is also a colors-only version of game play for younger players.

The game is packaged in a lidded plastic dice cup and comes with 3 Tibbit Cubes, 60 chips, & instructions.

name: Shires
description:
Description from the designer:

The King has died leaving no heirs. A great election is to be held to determine the throne. As an ambitious noble you must use your diplomatic prowess, economic wit, and (if all else fails) military might to secure the votes of enough Shires to garner the crown.

Shires is an epic 4X strategy game for 3-5 players. The layout of the board, buildings, fields, and armies in each shire vary from game to game. A blend of map generation, resource management, negotiation, backstabbing, and simple combat make Shires an engaging game with an always climatic conclusion.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Empires of the Clouds
description:
Description from the designer:

Empires of the Clouds is a worker placement game for 2-4 players. Players take control of an airship company during the golden age of aviation. Each round players will upgrade their airships, research new technologies, seek out investors, woo clients, and fill their passenger manifests. At the conclusion of each round the airships take flight. Players earn points and cash by completing flights and manipulating passenger manifests.

name: What The Dub?
description:
Description from the publisher:

A hilarious team based party game, inspired by The Whisper Challenge.

The game is played with two teams, max ~16-18 players. One team will draw a total of three "Dub" cards to create a sentence. The words on the cards are completely random and can be arranged in any order (ie "Kanye West" "Spaghetti" and "Pubic Hair", etc.) to create a "Dub". Once the Dub is created, they will tell it to the other team where a player will read it to their teammate to guess, who is wearing headphones playing loud, awful music. 4 points for guessing the Dub in 90 seconds, 8 bonus points for scoring in under 45. The entire Dub must be said without interruptions to score points!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: The Wave
description:
A hand sensing, light changing, exciting modular game system complete with 5 different modes! Wave your hand over the top to activate the 5 different sections. The 5 modes are Catch Me, Join, Remember, Follow, and DJ

Catch Me: A target color will appear. The five sections will blink on and off with different color lights. Every time the target color appears, move your hand over it to score!

Join: Your goal is to connect the two like colors that appear in the set of five within a few seconds. Wave your hand from the first color to the second to paint The Wave with that color and score!

Remember: A sequence of five lights will appear. After a few seconds the sequence will shuffle itself. By waving your hand from section to section, you can exchange the positions of colors. Recreate the original sequence in time to score!

Follow: The Wave will say a target color and present you with five lights. Wave your hand over the correct one to move to the next level. Each level's difficulty increases by increasing the amount of colors you need to remember in order while decreasing the time and shuffling up the lights each time you hit a correct color!

Make Music: A free play mode where you can make your own jams! Wave your hand over a section to turn it on, triggering a music loop to play until the section is turned off. Hold your hand over a section to play an alternate loop of the same type. Combine different music loops and explore the beginnings of becoming a new DJ!

name: Fire Sale
description:
(Fire Sale is still in alpha testing / early production).

"You have stumbled upon the news that there is a fire sale going on at a bankrupt estate a few blocks away. They are selling priceless antiques off at insane prices! You gathered all the cash you could and ran to the now defunct mansion. Little did you know however that tons of people would show up, all with huge wads of cash, ready to outbid you on all these “priceless” treasures!"

Fire Sale is playable at home with 2 decks of cards, 5 dice per player, and rules (in Files section). Fire Sale is a 2-4 player game featuring auction/bidding based dice placement/manipulation and set collection. Over multiple rounds players must use their dice rolls wisely to try and buy cards from the center of the table to earn sets that they can trade in for victory points!

The first player is chosen by whoever rolls the lowest amount of the lowest die value and on each turn a player has 7 possible actions to choose from, 5 being their available "main" actions and 2 being possible free actions. These actions include the ability to buy cards (to form sets), bid on cards against your opponents, play cards from your hand, turn in cards to earn points, or discard cards to get new cards in your hand. The free actions include re-rolling and "flipping" your dice. The game requires efficient use of a player's five dice that are rolled each round, in which "opposite" faced die are very valuable, though each player has ways to influence their dice rolls in tactical ways to suit their needs.

During the game players make moves with their dice, play cards from their hand, and turn in their collected sets for points. Players can use the point "pool" wisely to gain extra points while also blocking their opponents from gaining extra points. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Deduction, Dice, Print & Play
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Memory, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Hail Caesar:  The Conquest of Gaul
description:
Hail Caesar is a game of tabletop battles with model soldiers set in the Ancients era. Pit your wits and tactics against your friends as your armies clash in combat on the tabletop.

The Conquest of Gaul starter set gives you two starter forces the barbaric Celts and the legions of Imperial Rome and the glorious Hail ­Caesar rulebook.

This boxed game is just the start of your journey to conquer all comers and write your name in the annals of history!

Hail ­Caesar - Conquest of Gaul contains:

Full-colour 192 ­page hardback Hail ­Caesar rulebook

94 multi-pose, hard plastic 28mm miniatures:

30 Imperial ­Roman Legionaries
Roman Scorpion catapult and crew
60 Celt Warriors
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Question This
description:
A light party game built around intriguing prompts for lively conversation.

Each player is dealt three cards from the deck. Cards show 1, 2, or 3 points in the bottom lefthand corner, indicating the depth or gravity of the card. A 1-point card might ask, "What's the worst advice you ever received?" A 2-point card might ask, "Is it okay to cry at work?" A 3-point card might ask, "What happens after we die?"

All players select one card and play it facedown in the center of the table. The cards are shuffled and revealed, and everyone points to the card they want to discuss (with the caveat that players are not allowed to vote for their own card). Tied votes are resolved through discussion until a player changes their vote and creates a majority.

When your card is selected, you receive the number of points shown on the chosen card. The game ends when the deck is played through, and the player with the most points wins!

name: Grandmama's Game of Riddles
description:
This first version of Grandmama's Game of Riddles was one of a series of six Grandmama games issued by McLoughlin Bros. in the 1860s.

The game comes in a small wooden box and includes 120 numbered small cards, each with a riddle question. Any number may play, with one player taking on the role of "Preceptor" (holding the rule book) and the others as "Scholars".

The rules call for at least six cards to be dealt face down to each Scholar. Each Scholar in turn picks up one of his cards. If he answers correctly, he holds it. Otherwise, the opportunity to answer moves round the table clockwise, with the first Scholar to answer the riddle correctly keeping the card. Scholar with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

name: Picture Puzzles and Pennies: Series 1
description:
This undated party game was H.P. Gibson's first entry in the field of picture-puzzle party games. Unlike similar games produced by Universal and Party Games Publishers, which usually used decks of 18 cards with single images, the Gibson Series 1 puts 2-3 drawings on each of its 12 cards, for a total of 33 images.

Assuming 4, 8 or 12 players, the cards are then dealt out evenly to players, who get 1.5 minutes to guess the answers on their card(s). When time is up, they pass their cards to the players next to them. Once the cards have made the rounds, the player with the most correct answers wins.

In addition, this title uses the backs of the puzzle cards to offer a second game, Pennies. Each card has 12 clues starting "This PENNY..." and providing a blank where the answer is a word starting with the letters P-E-N. For example, the answer to "This PENNY gets in" is "PENetrate".

name: Animal Antics or Where's My Dad
description:
This party game consists of 12 perforated sheets each of which breaks into a "Mr.", "Mrs." and "Baby" of an animal, for a total of 48 possible families.

The game is played like musical chairs and must be played by multiples of three players. The appropriate number of family member cards are distributed randomly to the players. Music starts, and players rapidly pass cards amongst one another. When the music stops, players must call out and rush to get together with the other two members of their family.

Last one to get to form a group on a chair or on the floor is eliminated. The game continues until a showdown round between the last six players, where they scramble for the available cards on the floor and assemble immediately.

name: Game of Base Ball
description:
This undated but early baseball game by Milton Bradley is a spin-and-move affair. The two players race from home plate around the bases and back to home on a field glued to the box bottom.

There are 8 spaces on each side of the diamond plus the squares for the bases. Each side has a red circle, which causes a player landing there to lose a turn. The three bases and home plate must be reached by exact spin.

Using a 4-space spinner, players must spin a 3 to start the game, but go directly to first base if they spin 4 three times before getting a 3.

There also are four hazard spaces on each track. The first, right after 2nd base, means a player is out (and starts over). The second and third, on the final leg, send the player back to third base. And the heartbreaking fourth, on the last space before winning, means the player is out at home.

name: Geography Up to Date
description:
This turn of the 20th century educational game has a deck of 48 cards. Each card has between one and four geographical features listed, including continents, countries, rivers, mountains, and cities. Under each feature name is a list of questions to which that feature is the answer.

Cards are dealt out evenly among the players. The first player chooses a question on one of his cards and asks the player to his left for an answer. If the player cannot answer, he gives up a card to the questioner, who sets it aside. The questioner then moves to the next player with the same or a different question with the same answer and continues until someone answers correctly. If no one answers, the questioner sets it aside for himself and chooses a new card. When a question is answered correctly, the questioner surrenders a card to the answerer and the questioner's turn ends.

All cards won are set aside and out of the game. When all of the cards have been claimed, the player with the most cards wins.

Alex G. Malloy in American Games: Comprehensive Collector's Guid (1999) dates this game as circa 1890s, but the deck includes two cards with questions about the "murderous revolt against Christian civilization" and the capture of Pekin by "American and allied troops", both in 1900. Another card refers to Cuba as a country rather than a Spanish colony, and the game includes an ad for the "fine new games" of The Comical Game of Who (1899) and Sir Hinkle Funnyduster (1903), with the latter providing the likely publication date of this game as well.

name: Gooffy
description:
This is a paper and pencil party game designed to be played in a large gathering, generally in tables of four with players on opposite sides acting as partners. The objective is to draw the creature shown on the score sheet. Two creatures are available, a giraffe and a penguin. The game includes 25 player sheets, each with squares for 12 drawings.

Players take turns rolling a die, with each number corresponding to a particular part of the creature's body. A roll of 6 is needed to start a drawing, and when one is rolled, both partners can draw the body. A five must be rolled next, and again allows both partners to draw the head. After that, each partner rolls only for his own drawing.

The first player to complete a drawing yells "Gooffy" and the players then tally their individual scores (one point per body part). The two highest scorers move to the next table for another round, and the game continues for as many as 12 rounds. The player with the highest total points at the end of the game wins.

The giraffe needs a tail (4), a neck (3), two ears and an eye (2) and four legs (1). The penguin needs a beak (4), one eye (3), two feet (2) and two flippers (1). Each roll only allows one of the corresponding parts to be added.

name: Club Town
description:
In Club Town, all players are town planners helping to build up a town into a thriving metropolis. Players would be competing to gain favorable building contracts, build up the city, making sound financial investments as well as making financial contribution to impress the town council and mayor.

Club Town is a unique town building game that uses trick taking as its main action selection mechanic. Heavily inspired by Hearts and Diamonds (designer: Mike Fitzgerald), each suit is will have its associated action and players will need to take stock of what has been dealt to them, plan their strategy and out-think their opponent to be the most prestigious firm in town.

In a trick, each player would play a card following the lead and the suit would determine the action a player may take and the value determines how much money or investment opportunities may be gained or spent during the action: Spades to build buildings, Hearts to gain investor prospects, Clubs to earn income and Diamonds to invest in buildings. Being the leader would allow you control what everyone may do, but watch out as someone might pair their card with Influence (Joker) card to trump yours instead.

The game ends in four rounds running the whole poker deck twice and the prestige would be gained from buildings, their own investments in buildings and having the majority in favors in the Town Hall. May you be the one who outsmarts your friends and gain the highest prestige to be declared the prime developer in town!

name: Plenty of Fish in the Sea?: Delving Deeper
description:
Description from the publisher:

With deeper water you can increase the niches your species can exploit. Seek out Sponges, take refuge in the wrecks, hide in Sea grass or co habit with a protective species. Whilst things seem to be getting easier you will also have to cope with a Fishing boat and Oil pollution, plus deeper means less oxygen and harder living standards.

Adds extra fish, tiles, new game effects for tiles and new predator options to Plenty of Fish in the Sea?

name: Deutschland's Kolonien-Spiel
description:
Deutschland's Kolonien-Spiel ("Germany's Colonies Game") is a game published in Germany around 1890, in which players move tokens around a map to visit different German colonies, paying to see the sites and learn about these places.

It's a roll and move racing game - first player to reach the China space wins.

name: HACKER-Z
description:
User summary
HACKER is a 2 player game consisting of digit cards numbered 1 through 9. Using these cards, battle with your opponent to produce the larger number in order to win. (A card’s number can be changed based on the “Big” and “Small” numbers printed at the top and bottom of each card. For example: 6⇔9, 1⇔3)
Each player has a deck composed of the same 9 cards from which they randomly discard 2 cards. The game starts with each player holding the 7 remaining cards as their hand.

The first player chooses the “Winning Conditions” (BIG WIN/SMALL WIN) and places one card face down. The second player then analyzes why the first player chose those certain winning conditions to guess the player’s card in order to place a stronger card face up.

When both cards have been placed on the table, the first player turns their card face up and the card that better fulfills the winning conditions wins the round.

Switching the role of first and second player each round, continue playing for seven rounds. The first player to accumulate four winning rounds wins the game.

Publisher's summary
「HACKER」は１～９のデジタル表記の数字の書かれたカードを使って、数字の大きさ比べで対戦する２人用ゲームです。（数字は上下を変えることで違う数字として使えます。例：6⇔9、1⇔3）
２人は同じ構成のカード９枚を持ち、その中からランダムに２枚除外した７枚を使って、７回対戦を行ないます。

先手が「勝利条件（BIG WIN / SMALL WIN)」を選んで１枚伏せて置きます、後手は「なぜ先手はその勝利条件を選んだのか」ということから先手の「数字（カード）」を推測し、それに勝てる「数字（カード）」を表向きに出します。
両者のカードがそろったら、先手のカードを表向きにして、今回の勝利条件に合ったカードを出した人が１勝します。

先手・後手を交互に行ない、７試合中の内で先に４勝した人がゲームの勝者になります。

name: Desolate Front
description:
Desolate Front is an alternate World War I card game in which myth and magic fight side by side with science and technology.

Players use soldiers, officers, heroes and other items, such as The Master of the Hunt and Frankenstein's Creature, to try to take control of the battlefield. Use the latest equipment, stalwart allies, and powerful magic to vanquish your opponent's characters and secure key areas in your advance to victory.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Fantasy, Horror, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War I

name: Demokratia
description:
Description from the publisher:

The Persians have sacked Athens and the citizens look to their leaders to rebuild their city. As a demagogue of one of the ten tribes, it is your duty to increase both their power and your influence over them. The more powerful the people is, the more new citizens will come to Athens, but they will only come to the most influential demagogue.

The player who first plays all of his or her citizens to Athens wins.

Demokratia is played in rounds divided into five phases:

1) Rhetorics: Argue, negotiate and bribe for your cause.
2) Ekklesia (Assembly): Play secret votes.
3) Archon: Play citizens to the city of Athens OR to
the Boule (Council) OR to a Monument/Rhetor.
4) Phylai: Reveal votes and distribute new citizens.
5) Ostracism: Play citizens to temporarily exile a demagogue.

The players take turns to play their citizens to Athens. During each round, the power and the influence will rise and fall.


The colors of the cast votes and the erected buildings in Athens determine the tribe power, which in turn determine how many new citizens will come to Athens.
The citizens in the Boule determine the tribe influence, which in turn determine the share of the new citizens each player will get.
The players may also claim Monuments or Rhetors, each with a unique ability to influence the democratic game.


To win Demokratia, you must not only favor your own tribes but also maintain your influence over them so that no other player grow more influential and gets the power of your effort.

Demokratia is a double majority game, where you must be the strongest in the strongest tribe. In addition, the ostracism mechanism is a double catch-up mechanism: the second player can spend a citizen to exile the first player, giving the third and the fourth player a chance to catch up.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Politeia
description:
Description from the publisher:

Politeia takes the players back to the Persian Wars. Faced with the threat of a Persian invasion, the players must cooperate to defend their civilization. However, the competition for wealth and resources is fierce, as simulated by an inventive action mechanism, and just like the Ancient Greeks, the players are likely to turn their weapons against each other instead.

The different player actions add talents from the stock to the hand and turn those talents into citizens on the board, engaging in peaceful trading or aggressive warfare. Once a player run out of stock, the player with the most citizens left on the board wins.

The game board consists of tiles representing city-states, colonies and diplomatic positions. The player markers represent either talents or citizens and control of the board is determined by area majority.

The players take turns to select actions from a common mancala style action board. They pick up the action markers in one action space and drop them one by one in the spaces of the actions they wish to take, paying a cost equal to the number of action markers already in there.

The actions can broadly be divided into four groups:

1) Acquire talents, either directly through taxes and levies or indirectly through import of resources that can later be exchanged for talents.
2) Invest talents in buildings, providing action benefits, or diplomacy, providing war benefits.
3) Turn talents into citizens, either to consolidate existing city-states or to expand to new city-states.
4) Use citizens to attack other players or defend against the Persians.

The more citizens a player gets to the board, the more talents he or she may generate but the greater the risk if the Persians invade.

The unique action mechanism allows the player to optimize action combinations while at the same time blocking other players' actions by making them more expensive. This opens up several strategic paths, spanning from slow engine building to sudden seizures of area majorities. All game elements have a historical background, making Politeia a game of traditional Euro mechanisms linked by a strong theme.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Set Collection

name: Trek: World Travel Race by Land, Sea and Air
description:
This is a roll and move game across a map of the world divided into a grid 52 spaces wide (E-W) and 33 spaces deep (N-S). There are four start spaces, two on each of the east and west edges, and travellers (wooden triangles) must use a variety of vehicles (wooden cubes and cylinders) to get to the opposite edge of the board and on the other side of the equator.

Sea squares are blue, with some light blue squares that are impassable. Land squares are green, red, yellow or purple. There are eight modes of transportation, each restricted by color: cars and trains (green); aeroplanes (green, red and cross-hatched yellow, blue or purple; horses (red); camels (yellow), porters and pack animals (purple); and vessels (blue). These are scattered across the map on designated squares at the start of the game.

Players throw three dice on their turn. The red die and one white die are normal D6, the second white die is directional (N,S,E,W, and two blanks). Travellers must be on some form of transportation to move, and the white dice determine how many squares and in which direction (blanks are player's choice). The red die is used to move empty vehicles to where the traveller can intercept them and change modes. Players must move the full amount unless it brings them to a terrain border, and must change modes if they encounter an unoccupied vehicle.

Although the game is undated, it appears to be a 1930s design, since aeroplanes can only move short distances across water (Mediterranean, Caribbean, SE Asia) and not across oceans. Also, as common in the 1930s, the game comes in a small box with a separate board.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Nautical, Racing, Trains, Travel

name: Dinner with the Mafia
description:
This is a party game with a Mafia theme that combines play-acting with a Prohibition-era trivia game. The box includes eight character cards, a deck of 48 trivia question and answer cards, party invitations and envelopes with "an offer you can't refuse", menu cards, a background booklet that includes recipes for the menu dishes and even a CD of appropriate music. The dinner allegedly takes place at Scarpato's Restaurant on Coney Island in 1931.

The character cards include Al Capone and his ardently churchgoing wife Mae, along with Meyer Lansky and his new, skinny, pregnant and naïve Italian bride Anna Citron. Each of these cards includes characteristics, background information and suggested topics to guide play: Mae is violently allergic to dust, while Anna speaks only broken English and thinks words like "mob" and "burial" are management talk from her consultant husband.

Like many party games, the primary goal is mutual amusement and there are no specific rules for winning. Clearly the person answering the most trivia questions correctly could be declared a winner of that activity, and there might be a vote on best character acting.

name: Cosmonos
description:
This is an undated space travel game from Belgium that combines roll-and-move with resource management. The board covers the solar system, and the goal is to accumulate the most money primarily by being the first to land on planets. Landing bonuses range from 100 million for the moon to 1,000 million for Pluto, and there are game end bonuses for last planet, each planet card and most planet cards.

The standard red interplanetary track includes hazards that can bump players onto a useless green track. The red track leads to yellow orbital tracks around each planet, which in turn link to white landing tracks. Players must try to hit cross-over and landing points precisely, and can be damaged or even killed if they land too fast.

On each turn, players declare their acceleration and pay the appropriate amount of fuel, from 1 tonne for 1D6 to 32 tonnes for 6D6. Players may instead spend 5 tonnes for a retro thrust (1D6-3) or 20 tonnes for a super-retro (1D6 in reverse). Players may also spend money for help from an "electronic brain" that allows movement of exactly 1 in either direction for 50 million up to 4 for 400 million.

Players can buy fuel cheaply while on a planet or at double price at any time. It also can be had for free by landing on a space station (25t) and by giving up a turn while on a planet or station (10t). Players can borrow money from the bank if necessary to buy fuel.

The rules are in Flemish and French, and while the game is undated, the box graphic looks a lot like the space ship from the Tintin graphic novels.

name: Go Go Go
description:
This undated card game has a deck of 40 cards with a motor vehicle theme. There are four suits (red, blue, green, yellow) and most of the cards have illustrations of cars, trucks, motorcycles or buses. A few cards (different in each suit) have hazards or stop signs.

The player to the left of the dealer starts by playing his lowest card of any suit. Whoever has the next highest puts it on top, with play continuing until someone plays a stop sign card or until no one can follow. Then the next player starts a different colored suit (missing a turn if he has no other color). Winner is the first to get rid of all his cards.

name: The New Game of Blockade Runner
description:
This is an early 20th Century British game loosely based on the 1904-05 Russo-Japanese war and in particular the Japanese blockade of Port Arthur in the early stages of the war.

The label on the back of the board shows ships of the period along with the Russian and Japanese flags, and has the subtitle: "A Game of Skill Without Intricate Rules".

The board does not make these rules clear, but there is a Start position at the southern end of the Yellow Sea and a web of red lines and dots leading to ports in China, Manchuria and Korea. Seven ports have their names and the word "HOME" in a white box, and there is an additional "HOME" port for Manchuria as a whole.

The board bears the words "Design Registered" and "British Manufacture" but no date, publisher, copyright or patent claim. Given that the Strait of Korea is at the east edge of the map (leaving out the neighboring Tsushima Strait where the climactic naval battle of the war occurred, this game may well have been published in 1904, during the first half of the war.

name: Ultra 7
description: Ultra 7 is a fast, fun card game with plenty of twists and turns. After being dealt 7 cards each, players take turns playing cards face up onto one of two play piles. The card being played must match the top card in terms of color, number, or suit, and the first player to rid their hand of cards wins. However, the deck also contains an abundance of special cards. For example, the Flip card requires a coin toss, the results of which determine who must draw two cards. The Trade card provides the option of trading hands with another player. The Grab card is a mad grab for spoons (one less than the number of players), with the empty-handed player required to draw two cards. The dreaded Spoiler card can be a major roadblock to winning. The unpredictability these cards bring to Ultra 7 lend it an exciting playfulness that make for a rip-roaring good time.

name: Ultra 7 Extreme
description:
The goal is to get rid of all your cards before the other players. Match the color, number, suit, or name of the card on one of the play piles in order to play a card down.

Watch out for the special cards... you may have to pick up a spoon, swap spots with another player, swap hands, pass cards, or get the dreaded SPOILER card.

name: Blackout
description:
This 1964 logic game has a mechanic similar to the later Mastermind, but is played with cards and words. There is a deck of 26 Blackout cards, each with a six-letter word on one side, and an irregular inkblot on the other side. There is a second deck of 70 game cards, each of which has a pattern of holes punched through the card.

On each turn, a player takes one of the blackout word cards and places the pattern side underneath the game card. The number of black dots showing is the number of letters in that word card that appear in the game card's word.

Using a scorecard that lists each of the 26 word cards, the player must try one word card after another to determine the six letters represented by his game card, and then work out the right order for the actual word.

The rules provide 5 variants for two players, two variants for party fun, and one for solitaire. In head-to-head play, the player who takes the most cards to succeed loses points equal to his number of turns minus the number taken by his opponent, plus a flat penalty of 3 points for losing. First player to 50 points loses the game.

name: Whack-O!
description:
This is a silly spin-and-move game where schoolboy players and their catapults must try to get from top of the First Form (average IQ) to bottom of the Fourth Form (Half-Witted) while collecting as many Black Marks, Detentions, and Whack-Os as possible.

Players may have their catapults confiscated (and must pay 3 points worth of cards to get them back in order to finish), and be delayed by being sent to Coventry, the Tuck Shop or the San. While the first player to finish gets 5 bonus points, victory is determined by number and quality of demerits, with each Whack-O worth 3 points, each Detention 2 and each Black Mark 1.

The game is based on a British comedy series that according to Wikipedia ran in black-and-white from 1956-60 and later in color from 1971-72. It featured comedy writer and actor Jimmy Edwards as "the drunken, gambling, devious, cane-swishing headmaster who tyrannised staff and children at Chiselbury public school". Series creators Frank Muir and Denis Norden are give a "by arrangement with" credit on the box cover.

While the game is undated, it features a black-and-white photo of Jimmy Edwards's face atop a cartoon body, placing it as a late 1950s publication.

name: Perks: The Government House of Cards
description:
Description from the publisher:

Do you remember the scandal when Congress members had huge overdrafts in their checking accounts and were not paying it back? Well this game lets you do it, too! The goal of the game is to overdraw your checking amount by more than your opponent(s).

Set up the game by placing the numbered cards in 11 face down stacks according to the numbers printed on them (2-12). The numbers corresponds to the following political job titles: 2 Vice President, 3 President for a Day, 4 Retiring Politician, 5 Cabinet Member, 6 Incumbent Politician, 7 House of Representatives, 8 Politician's Aid, 9 Diplomat, 10 Senator, 11 Political Appointee, and 12 White House Chief of Staff.

During their turn, players roll the dice and take a card matching the number. The cards instruct the player to record a debit (subtraction) or a credit (addition) in their check register.

The game ends when a player has a full check register page - 20 items. The winner with the highest overdraft wins!

name: ELLIPSIS
description: ELLIPSIS (…) is a party card game where players try to compare things that are not necessarily similar. In addition, players have to explain their comparisons in the form of some sort of punch line. For example, “parents are like boogers … always hanging around making you look like a fool” or “parents are like belts … supportive.” Here’s the catch, the key word revealed on the drawn card must be compared to a certain letter word. Rolling the 20 sided die will dictate the starting letter of a word. In the aforementioned example, the key word was “parents” and the letter “B” was rolled to come up with the words “boogers” and “belts”. Notice the dot dot dot (…) in the example? It’s called an ELLIPSIS. Each player will write their own witty, humorous, or even barbed punch line following the ELLIPSIS. Players earn points for guessing who said what.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Humor, Party Game

name: Energie-Spar-Spiel
description:
Energie-Spar-Spiel or the Energy Saving Game is a simple roll-and-move affair published in 1981 by the German subsidiary of electrical products maker GTE Sylvania.

The game board has a slightly spiral track of 80 spaces. There are 16 spaces along the way marked in red, each of which has a bonus or penalty linked to a good or bad energy use behaviour. Each situation and its consequences are listed in an accompanying booklet.

The board is vividly illustrated by examples of the red dot situations, from drying dishes by hand and installing fluourescent bulbs to a car slamming on the brakes at a stoplight and a topless woman "talking to Susie on the phone for two hours" while her hot bath goes cold.

The game title is in German, but it includes an English rule book.

name: Oh Peg It
description:
This is a roll and move game with two different playing pieces: pegs and circles (otherwise known as bolts and washers). There are three of each in three colors (black, white and orange. There also is a set of 40 Oh Peg It cards, each with a familiar saying that swaps out a word and replaces it with "peg", and instructions for gaining or losing spaces or points. There is a set of 200 small dried beans as scoring tokens.

A player takes either a set of pegs or one of circles, and rolls one die per turn. He may split the roll between two pieces. If a peg and circle land on the same space, both players score: the pegger (piece landing) gets two points and the player pegged gets one point. The game ends when one player reaches the end of the track with all his pieces, and the winner is the one with the most points at that time.

There are three kinds of special spaces: Double Score does just that for both players pegging on one; Oh Peg It means taking a card from the deck and following instructions; and Chastity Square means no pegging here!

The sexual allusions in this Summer of Love era game are pretty obvious throughout. Aside from the male-female pegging mechanism, the cards also include sayings like "I could have pegged all night", "We'd rather peg than fight", and "Pegging makes the heart grow fonder". A second deck of blank cards is provided for those who want to get more daring or creative.

name: Spin and Step
description:
This is an unusual spin-and-move game aimed at children between 5 and 9, and suggested for parties. It includes a spinner for each of four players and a set of 30 irregular cardboard shapes (five each of six colors).
