Instead of a board, players lay out their track ahead of time by placing the shapes like stepping stones across floors or lawns.

Players then spin as in a board game and act as the playing pieces themselves, stepping from one to the next. The rules suggest placing bonuses like lollipops for the first person landing on a step, and also say the path can be made easier or more difficult to suit the players.

name: Big Apple Spinning Game
description:
This gorgeous 1940s game from All-Metal Products Co. is indeed made entirely of metal in the form of a hollow four-inch diameter apple. A metal post is mounted on the bottom of the apple inside, and a metal platter sits on top of the post.

The platter is decorated with pictures of six different fruits: apples, bananas, grapes, pears, cherries and plums. The fruit segments are numbered 1 to 6 as well, and each segment has a small indentation near the center. There is a set of 12 cardboard tokens, two of each fruit.

Players take turns dropping a small green marble onto the spinning platter and seeing where it comes to rest. They claim a corresponding token if still available. The winner is the first to accumulate an agreed number of tokens or number of points on the tokens.

name: Stacked!
description:
Stacked! is a quick, co-op game set in a mystical vanishing library. Players must answer customer questions (using IRL library digital resources) while making sure the library doesn't fill up with unshelved books.

It was created as a tool to use during digital library workshops at Auckland Libraries.

Summary
Stacked! is a cooperative game in which the players fight against the inevitable build-up of unshelved books while trying to answer as many customer questions as possible
Stacked! is a magical vanishing library and, as such, the layout changes from day to day. During the game you're going to explore the library; answer reference questions from the customers; and prevent the returned books from piling up.
In a turn, players have a choice of x actions. Move, Explore, Shelve (books), take a reference question, or use their special ability. If a player has a reference question they must attempt to find an answer between turns.

Winning the Game
The players win or lose together. The players win when each player has at least 2 answered questions.
The players lose if the Library is too full of unshelved books (I.e. Trolley Tokens are all gone).

Stacked! can be played using your local library's digital resources (i.e. as a training tool etc) or using google to find the answers.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Exploration, Fantasy, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Battle at the Arcade
description:
Description from the publisher:

It’s dark. The streets are quiet, and all the grown-ups are at home. However deep in the city, inside a small arcade parlor, furious battle rages on. Amidst the dazzling flashes and booming beep-and-bop of the arcade machines, Champions battle each other for pride, honor, and extra lives. Joysticks are their swords and buttons their shields; their amazing game playing skill are the stuff of legend. One wrong move, and it is Game Over, man. Who will win the crown of Arcade King? Take the challenge and join the game!

Battle at the Arcade is a press-your-luck card game. A cross elements of a dice game and poker (but play without dice). Players are dealt cards from a deck, and must match them to the level’s requirement in order to earn points. However, players may also perform “Special Tricks”, swap cards and points, in order to “beat the level”. More than just luck, a deep strategic layer of choice and decision are needed to win the game. What are you waiting for, lets get the GAME ON!

FEATURES .............................................


Easy to set up, just shuffle and go.
Champion, Arcade, and Score cards are printed on Jumbo Cards, to make them easier to read.
10 different "Champions of the Arcade" to pick from. Each with their unique combination of special abilities, strength, and weakness.
Relive the glory of the golden age Arcades. 10 different Arcade games to play from, inspired by the Classics, that adds more variation to each game.
Chain your move together to score BIG. Flashy combos could be made to chain one move to another.
Easy to use Score cards, with color matching cubes, to help you keep track of your game stats.
Supports up to 4 players (more players if don’t mind using other paper to track the score. Or get another copy *smile* ).
Full of "OH YEAH!" and "Ah, COOOOME ON" Moments.
Only time for a quick game? Want to have an all night tournament? The game can be easily adjusted to fit your playing style.
A fun game for a friendly game night or the whole family.

name: Cookie Mookie
description:
Description from the publisher:
A Game of Yum Yum Dessert Grabbing and Sweet Sweet Deduction
Oh NO! The Mistress of the house is gone, and all the lights just went out! But… the door to the dessert closet was left wide open! All the yum-yum goodies are for the taken! Under the cover of darkness, the household pets are scrambling to grab their favorite desserts. But who are those rascals? It’s up to the famous De-cat-ive Furlock Holems to uncover their identities!

Cookie Mookie is a set-collection micro-game with element of mystery for 2-4 players. Players are assigned a character role, with the goal to get the highest points to win the game. However, players are encouraged to keep their goal a secret, else they can be worked against you. The game is split into 4 short phases, the Setup, the Grab, the Swap, and the Deduction.

Easy to learn, quick to play. A great game for the whole family, or the sweet lovers!



=======A short description of the game-play:

First desert cards are dealt out on the able in a grid. Each player are handed a character role. Each role have particular type of desserts that they love, which would score them bigger points, as well ones they dislike, which give the negative points. Each player then takes turn plucking cards from the grid. After each player have a certain number of cards, they then swap one card with their adjacent players. If there is detective character in game, they get to deduce other player’s role. Else the turn ends, and the score are counted up to see who is the winner.

The Strategy comes at card picking phase. Not only do you want to be mindful of what other are pick, but also what you pick, so to get the max points, but without giving yourself away. This allow you fool other during the card swapping, so go give you a card that would better benefit you, while give them a card that might reduce their score.

name: The jungle law
description:
Description from the designer:

The laws of the jungle are ruthless. Everyone is either on the run or chasing someone else. The cat chases the mouse, the mouse scares the elephant, and if the cat’s not careful it will get trampled by the elephant.
Cardgame in which you place the highest bid of a certain sort… however, if your natural enemy is amongst the other players cards, you will lose anyway

name: Secret Agents
description:
Description from the designer:

Your secret agent is on a mission. He will get assignments which he must trace all over town. And of course he must try and meet other secret agents as well, to complete the ultimate mission…
A tile game and card game in which you can walk across the tiles and also slide them in order to reach the ultimate goal and fulfill all of the assignments first.

name: Blumen für Florina
description:
Description from the designer:

Easy 3D children's game in which the packaging is part of the game.
The cow Togo Lino walks around and tries to find as many flowers as he can for his girlfriend, the sheep Florina.
Some flowers are easy to get, for others he needs the help of his friend the mole, Monty, because only he can dig a hole to the forbidden garden (the box)and get more flowers.
But beware, others might want to steal your flowers, so it is good to sometimes get the help of the little watchdog Carlito!

name: Pelle the Captain
description:
Players start with 5 sailor cards and the goal is to be the first to collect a ship crew with all 5 different types of sailors or animals to win the game.

In his turn the player draws one card and then plays one card with the picture side up so that it does not cover the other cards on the table. The player can draw the card from the top of the pack or pick up any card from the table.

name: Tobi-Sugoroku
description:
User summary
Tobi-Sugoroku is a traditional Japanese game developed from the original game Joudo-Sugoroku. Tobi means 'Jumping', and as in Joudo-Sugoroku, players move differently across the board using dice rolls and following the instructions on the squares. As with other classical Japanese games, the original designers' and illustrators are not known.

However, later Tobi-Sugoroku do not keep the Buddhist theme, and instead reflect various popular subjects (New Year, ghosts and monsters, warriors and heroes, morality). This allowed the publishers to produce beautifully illustrated prints in the Edo period, and 19C and 20C magazines to have Sugoroku games as cheap pull-outs.

The main difference between Tobi-Sugoroku and Mawari-Sugoroku is that in the former, movement is across the network of squares, whereas in the latter, movement is along a controlled path (similar to Game of Goose). Any Sugoroku game with pictures is known as E-Sugoroku (E- means 'picture').

name: Racket Wars: The Business of Mafia is Business
description:
Description from the designer:

The Racket Wars game can be played with 2 – 6 players.
It’s a 90 min game.
Racket Wars is an open world, fun, strategic and fast paced dice rolling board game based on mafia theme, where players play to take control of the city. The game play is constructed in two parts, inside map and outside map. Outer part is controlled by MAFIA BOSS, where the inner city map is played using a soldier and a car. The city map is designed in a very detailed manner to give players a fun filled strategic experience interacting with the map. The idea behind this game is accomplishing a design which is very interactive for the players. That is why we made it an open world map.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Fantasy, Mafia, Maze, Print & Play, Territory Building, Transportation
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing, Cooperative Game, Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: Vigilante
description:
Overview:
Your city is being threatened by ruthless and corrupt organizations who seek to profit off the backs of your friends and neighbors. It’s time for someone to stand up and fight back. The odds are stacked against you and your fellow justice seekers, but maybe, with the right strategy, equipment and training you can chase the Minions out of your city.

Objective:
Create a hero and go on patrol to take down the corrupt organizations and their minions that threaten your city. Beat the clock, against schemes that empower the Villain, uncovering their identity and stopping them once and for all.

Gameplay:
Vigilante is a campaign, deck construction game with a sprawling city of Schemes that you and your friends' heroes move through, playing cards and rolling dice to combat. The challenge is knowing which Schemes are most important to stop, because the ones that you fail to prevent add new abilities to the Villain and his lair. Reward cards will give you temporary upgrades and gear can be combined to unlock new equipment and weapons. Upgrade your team's base or your own vehicle? The choice is yours!
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Set Collection

name: Dobbin Derby
description:
This is a very simple but colorful mid-century horse racing game aimed at younger children. The board folds out into a long and thin track (34" x 6") that runs straight with just ten spaces from start to finish. The four horses are 5" tall cardboard pieces that slot into wooden stands.

The spinner has eight possible results. Four of them move a horse on one lane only (1-4) while the other four move horses on two lanes (1+2, 2+3, 3+4, 4+1). First horse to the finish wins.

name: Canada Kongo
description:
This undated but mid-20th century Canadian game uses a regular deck of cards and poker chips as playing pieces. It has French and English instructions printed on the inside of the box lid. The board is a large fabric mat, 30" square, with a big circle and the game name in the center. Each side has a space for one playing card and a series of circles numbered 1 through 9.

On each turn, the dealer deals one card face up to each player. The player then uses chips to cover up any combination of circles that add up to the value of the card (1 for Ace through 13 for King).

Rounds continue until one player manages to cover all nine of his circles. Any player unable to cover circles equal to his card must put a chip in the pot. When the Joker turns up, the dealer reshuffles the full deck and starts a new turn beginning with the player dealt the Joker.

The first player to cover all nine circles wins the pot. In addition, each other player must pay him the value of their remaining uncovered circles.

name: Bradley's Sentence Builder
description:
This game consists of a large number of small rectangular chips, each printed on both sides with a full word rather than a letter. The words range in length from two to eight letters. Some of the words start with capital letters, and there are some chips with endings like -ing and with punctuation marks.

The game is clearly educational in nature, flowing from Milton Bradley's devotion to that cause starting in the late 1860s. While undated, the plain box and cardboard word chips suggest 19th Century publication. The box is labelled with the address of the company's Boston office at 120 Boylston St. rather than the usual Springfield factory location.

The goal is to form coherent sentences from selections of words from the box, but absent a copy of the rules, it is not clear how word cards are picked or distributed.

name: De Puerto en Puerto
description:
Going from port to port to export Uruguayan products and purchase international products!

How to play the game?

Each player receives 8 "Shipping Manifest" cards, worth $3.000 each, and a steamboat (coloured pieces). Then, all players roll the die; the player who has the highest number is in charge of giving out the 64 "Shipping Orders" cards to other players during the game.

The "Shipping Manifest" cards correspond to the products shipped from Uruguay. The "Shipping Orders" cards correspond to the purchases done during the trip.

Two steamboats leave from Montevideo, and the two others leave from Colonia, moving with one die roll in the direction indicated by the arrows. Each arrow takes one move, and the possibility to win is equal on all routes.

When a steamboat docks at a port, the player hands over the corresponding "Shipping Manifest" card to deliver the products, taking in exchange the "Shipping Orders" card for that specific port.

In the case that a steamboat has to go back to a port because of some fog, an engine malfunction, etc. on route (see obstacle rules at the bottom right of the map), the player cannot take or deliver merchandise.

The game ends when all steamboats are back to their ports of origin. The first steamboat back to its port gains an extra $10.000. The winner is the person who made the most amount of money. The "Shipping Orders" cards are summed up, deducing the amount of all "Shipping Manifest" cards still in a player's possession (products not delivered).

Spanish box cover: Nos llevará navegando en barcos mercantes por los mares del Mundo, intercambiando los productos nacionales, por los regionales de lose países de nuestro itinerario. Además de la gran atracción de conocer los Continentes, con sus puertos, idiomas y productos, está la incógnita, ¿quién será el ganador?, porque puede llegar primero - obteniendo el primer premio de 10.000-, y no ser ganador.

name: Malifaux: Guild – Lawyer
description:
Description from the publisher:

"Objection!" The Lawyer is a support piece that inflicts damaging de-buffs, improves your models' defense against horror and doles out Hard to Wound. 32mm 'heroic' scale high quality metal cast miniature.
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Miniatures

name: Malifaux: Outcast – Lazarus
description:
Description from the publisher:

Outcast Box Set, containing one 32mm 'heroic' scale miniature made of high quality Plastic.
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Miniatures

name: Pocket Rivals Strategy Card Game
description:
Pocket Rivals Strategy Card Game first edition comes with two 9-card 'deck' teams: Monsters Vs Robots. The game is designed for 2 players and is friendly for ages 8 and up. The first player to reduce their opponent's team of 9 cards to a single card left on the playing field is the winner.

Pocket Rivals Strategy Card Game playing field is a 3 x 6 grid with room for a single card within each grid space. The board is placed between the two players who face each other across the longest edges of the board. Each of the two players has 9 cards. Each card has stats for Power, Wits, Charm, & Speed arranged on the top, Left, Right, & bottom sides respectively. Each stat is printed with a value from 1 to 4.

Starting from a random arrangement of all 18 cards on the grid, players take turns removing one another's cards via a 'challenge' mechanism that compares stats on adjacent cards.

On a given turn, players activate a single card from their team on the field. They may move that card (one space in a cardinal direction), challenge an adjacent card (removing it from the field), and use the unique 'talent' ability associated with their activated card. The player may do up to all three of these actions in a single turn in any order. Gameplay continues with the players alternating turns until one team has been reduced to a single card.

Each card features a single character. The front of the card is Gallery Mode: full color art with the character name. The back of the card is Challenge Mode: single color gradient art, character talent, and a yellow rim containing a stat for each edge of the card.

The story conceit behind the game is that each player is an Ace Tactician who has selected 9 Ally Champions from across a myriad of Pocket Dimensions to face off against 9 Rivals and a Rival Ace. First to force their foe's faction from the field finishes as First Place Ace!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Children's Game, Fantasy

name: Spin It
description:
This two-player game from Milton Bradley comes with two acorn-shaped wooden tops and a target sheet of cardboard inset in the box bottom. The sheet has 18 holes with values ranging from 5 to 100.

Players take turns spinning their tops and recording the value each time it stops. First player to 500 points wins.

The earliest version of this game has a box cover showing two children playing the game on a small table, with a rural landscape seen through the window behind them. While the game is undated, the style of the graphics and the "Bradley's Best Games" logo on the box suggests a 19th Century or early 20th Century publication date.

name: Challenger Cup Race
description:
This is a very basic yacht-racing game by All-Fair. The four tracks of 45 spaces include two bonus spaces and two hazard spaces. Moves are determined by a 1-6 spinner. First player to reach the finish line by exact spin wins. The board includes the rules and art of sailing ships, buoys, lighthouses and gulls.

There is a second spin-and-move game called Circus pasted to the inside of the box lid. This also has four tracks leading from the start to the Big Top Entrance. Each track has 36 spaces including two bonus spaces and two hazards. The board decoration includes the rules and art of a marching clown, trained seal and lion.

name: Takaroo
description:
This is an action/dexterity game played with five small wooden cubes, a 15" wooden rod, a dart made of a wooden disk with three feathers attached to one side, and a board with various shapes and targets. Wooden pegs are used to keep score along ladders of holes punched into the board.

The game is played in five rounds, each of which requires a succession of physical moves. In the first round, for instance, cubes are placed on each of four stars on the board, and the player must toss the dart in the air, pick up a cube and catch the dart all with the same hand. This is then repeated for the second cube, then the remaining two cubes, and then all four cubes at once. Finally, the dart must be tossed up and hit the blue circle in the center of the board.

Each player turn lasts until he fails to complete a required trick. When his turn comes again, he starts with the failed trick. First player to complete the requirements of all five rounds wins.

name: Rookie Fireman
description:
This 1978 educational firefighting game has a playing board, a deck of 34 Fire cards, a deck of 32 Result cards, four Patrol Piece tokens, four badge cards (Chief, Captain, Engineer and Rookie), a D6 with a fire symbol over the 1, and an unpainted lead firetruck.

The board has a white track running around the edge, and an inner pattern of six vertical and two horizontal streets, connected to the fire station in the middle. In between the streets are numbered houses, retail outlets and industrial locations.

Each player starts on a different corner of the board and rolls the die to move along the white track on the outside of the board. Each time he passes his starting station, he completes one patrol. The last player to complete his third patrol gets stuck with the Rookie badge.

Whenever a player lands on a "fire" space, he draws the top card from the Fire deck, which illustrates the cause of the fire and gives a location. The player then has four rolls of the die to move the fire engine from the station to that location to put out the fire. If he succeeds, he draws a Results card and follows directions; if not, he moves his piece back one space.

The game is said to have been designed by a firehouse in Scottsdale, Arizona, and the box shows it was distributed as an educational tool through other fire departments. (One copy has a label saying "Compliments of Roy L. Parrish, Fire Chief, Clark County Fire Dept., Nevada".)

name: Go for Gold
description:
This is a British sports quiz game published as a promotional item for Webster's Yorkshire Bitter. The board has three concentric rings of spaces (Qualifying, Bronze and Silver) with a large Gold Medal space in the middle. There is a deck of 56 cards, each with six questions and answers (one for each of six color-coded categories).

Players roll a die and must first complete a full circuit of the outer track, answering a question of the appropriate color as they land on each space. Then they must aim for a Qualify space, where they must answer a question of another player's choice from the next card in order to move to the Bronze track.

Similarly, players must move around the Bronze track before trying to move up to Silver, and around that track before trying for a Gold Medal question to win the game. The questions range from familiar ("Name all five events in the modern Olympic Pentathlon") to the obscure ("Which snooker player was able to claim pints of lager as tax-deductible?").

The game box included an opportunity to enter a real contest to win tickets to five premier sporting events in late 1987 and 1988.

name: Bones
description:
'Bones' is a party game with simple game play and lots of changing dynamics.

You play a Grim Reaper, and collect lost souls by helping them find the things that make them happy, but beware the villainous Bone Dog!

Choose a character to be your reaper, then collect and lay down your stash of Happiness Items and use them to entice other souls into your possession. Souls also have special abilities that you can take advantage of to give yourself bonuses or to mess up your opponents!

Be the first to gather enough souls and you win!
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Nukie McPooch and the Zombie Mutant Presidents
description:
Description from the designer:

Armed with a plasma rifle and a hella cool dog, Nukie McPooch is our only hope against the dead U.S. Presidents that we really shouldn't have reanimated.

As punk rocker Nukie, you engage in a constant shootout with the Zombie Mutant Presidents (ZMPs) in a bombed-out city. Move yourself and your dog, Schwartz, on a randomized battlefield grid and use the ruined walls as cover. Command Schwartz to loot the bodies of ZMPs you've wasted, videotape the ZMPs for valuable intel, and plant nukes at the ZMP hideouts so you can blow them sky-high!

Each of the 43 ZMPs has his own zombiefied portrait card, combat rating, and unique National Treasure that Schwartz can loot if he's lucky. When you've defeated them all, tally your score and read the secret ending you've earned.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Spinner 10
description:
Spinner 10 is a card game played with 2 Special Dice (numbered 1-5 + Spinner) and 100 cards (10 cards each, 1 through 10). A game of luck won by the roll of the spinner dice.

"A family card and dice game by the originators of Spinner Dominos."

Players are each dealt ten face-up cards to start. In turn, each player rolls the dice and then discards a card with the corresponding die total from their hand. A spinner counts as zero, while double spinners allows you to discard all of the cards of one value from your hand (your choice). If you roll and have no matches, you must draw a new card. When it is your turn, instead of rolling you can use the die roll of the person before you, but must roll if the previous player did not roll.

Play continues (roll dice, discard if you can, draw if you can't) until one player has successfully discarded all of their cards. Everyone totals the remaining value of the cards in front of them, adds that to their own score, and a new round begins. After ten rounds, the player with the lowest score wins.

name: Ne Vous Fachez Pas
description:
The name of this old French game means "Don't get angry", and was probably inspired by Sorry or Ludo in that four pieces must get onto a track and around the board to home. However, it seems to be a more basic game, with no slides or shortcuts.

The game has a two-sided board, with a 44-space circular track on one side for up to four players, and a 60-space circle with six outward "U"s on the reverse for up to six players. It comes with six sets of four wooden pawns (red, green, ivory, brown, purple and black) and a wooden dice cup about 4" tall.

The game is undated, but the illustration on the box suggests 1930s or earlier. The picture features two men in double-breasted suits, sitting in rattan chairs and playing the game on a table, with countryside seen through the window behind them.

The box and board declare "modèle depose", and the box has a publisher logo with a "marque déposée", but the name of the publisher does not appear. The logo has a mermaid sitting on a rock, holding up a horizontal diamond shape containing the letters "STREM" and another tiny letter or dot on each end.

name: Kodderschnauze
description:
The Berlin Slang-Memo

Yourself as Bolle amuse? No problem with the memory game Kodderschnauze!
Acquire at Aldi ne pack Schrippenpuffer or lubricates ne nice plate sandwiches with Moppelkotze, the Miefquirl turns on and off you go. Here two different word-parts have to be discovered, which together make up a typical Berlin slang - equal with High German translation.

All cards are placed with the Word face down on the table and mixed well.
The game is played in a clockwise direction.
On his turn, a player must turn over two cards. If the two cards add up to a real slang expression, the player may take the card pair and once again turn over two cards. That is until he reveals two non-matching cards. Then the next player's turn.
To win the game you have to collect the most pairs of cards.

name: Unterwegs im Weltall
description:
Joe-Mo is travelling with his spaceship through outer space. On his way he has to stop at several stations and pick up the Nasuris and robots in order to drop them off on their planets. But the spaceship is not big enought for everyone that wants to get on. Who will be the one to wait at the next station ?

The youngest player starts. You play clockwise. Twist the arrow of the UFO-board.
The section where the arrow stops shows which robot or Nasuri will be picked up by Joe-Mo. But watch out - the spaceship is very small, not all of them will fit in. Follow the rules according to the face-up cards of the players.

The first one to put all cards aside is the winner.

name: Valhalla I Am Coming!
description:
The year is 800 A.D: the dawn of the Viking Age. For the next three centuries, explorers, warriors, traders, and builders will sail from Scandinavia to stake their claims across the globe. They are bold, ruthless, and utterly fearless. You are now one of them. You and your family will make a noble name as the world burns.

' Valhalla I Am Coming!' is played in 10 turns, each turn representing roughly 30 years, or one generation. Players start with control of one Viking, but will come to control that Viking’s entire family as spouses are courted and children are born. On each turn, players will explore, fight, settle, and build their families, often confronting death or injury and winning glory for their accomplishments. The player who has accumulated the most glory at the end of the game wins.

The gameplay is straightforward, with action points being spent, skill checks being made, and tables being rolled upon. The objectives of the design are fun, collaborative storytelling, and historical understanding.
categories: Adventure, City Building, Civilization, Environmental, Exploration, Farming, Medieval, Mythology
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Player Powers

name: Ach steig mir doch aufs Dach
description:
Goal of the game is to have most roof pans in the own colour on the roof and also some ladders at the end of the game.
Therefore as often as possible enemy tiles have been included in the game, flipped and thus transformed into its own color. This mechanism is known by Othello.

If you play with 2 players, use the half of the board. If you play with 4 players, each 2 use their half of the board. It is not possible to play with 3.
Each player has a character that is moved according to the dice roll. The target field specifies what the player is allowed to make. Options are:
a) place one roof tile of his color onto the roof
b) place two roof tiles of his color onto the roof
c) miss a turn
d) draw an event card and execute it immediately
e) Interim Evaluation trigger (here ladders come into the game)
The game ends when one half of the roof is fully occupied.
Each roof tile is worth one point, each conducting one another point.
Whoever has the most points wins the game.

This was published by Ravensburger as a commercial game for Braas Systempartner

name: Monster! Incoming!
description:
Description from the designer:

Monster! Incoming! is a half-cooperative game, one in which players try to defend the city from being destroyed by a huge monster. At the same time, players also compete to earn as much fame (victory points) as possible.

During the game, players use multi-functional cards for resource collecting, attacking or researching, which also leads the monster in a particular direction at the same time. When players try to attack the monster, they can ask other players for support — but if you want to be a winner, sometimes you need to be selfish...
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Set Collection
publishers: Rolling Green Leaves Studio (滾動綠葉文創工作室)

name: Ich bin ein Star: Holt mich hier raus !
description:
The jungle camp will be placed in the middle of the table. Then a player distributes all the cards. Each player puts his cards face down in front of him on the table. In turn, the players each cover the top card of their cards stack. When revealing two cards with same two insects on the discard piles, each player tries to put his hand on the jungle camp as the first.

The first one gets two stars, the second one gets one star.
If somone acts wrong, it costs one star.
The game ends, when only one or less star is left.
The winner is, who has the most stars.
At the end, the loser rolls to see what penalty he gets.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Blondinen & Nørden
description:
Quiz game for two teams with two sets of questions, each with a separate scoring track.
Win by correctly answering 12 "blonde" questions or 7 "nerd" questions first.

Blondinen & Nørden (The Blonde & the Nerd) is an entertaining game for anyone who loves to quiz. The rules are simple and quick to learn. If you have more than two players, you play in teams. The players compete in the following six categories: Mandehørm, hønsegården, children and childish souls, oldies but goodies, modern times and (un)usable knowledge. A roll of the dice determines which category to compete in. Players choose whether they want an easy (Blonde) or a difficult (Nerd) question in this category when it's their turn. The level of difficulty they do not choose, they pass on to the opposing team. With knowledge and tactics, the players must thus try to get either Blondinebrikken or Nørdbrikken first in goal.

name: the WEIGHTing GAME
description:
the WEIGHTing GAME is a two-player strategy game where players move plastic pieces (weights) inside slots on a bar that resembles a see-saw. The game begins with 7 weights in 4 different colors with each colored weight having a specific placement location.
Each player has 4 options during their turn:

Move black to any position
Move one colored weight to a matching color location
Remove and hold a weight (except black)
Replace any number of colored weights to their matching start positions


The ultimate goal is to have the bar balance while holding no weights at the end of your turn.
The game is a blend of light strategy and physics, but an experienced player might be able to memorize enough moves/counter-moves to game the system.

name: Kitty Chaos: Get Me Outta Here Promo Card
description:
Get Me Outta Here was available at Origins Convention 2005.

Its text says:
Catapults you out of the junkyard back to start.
categories: Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game, Racing

name: Askrias
description:
Welcome to Askrias, a fantasy game which allows 1 or more players to take role as an adventurer as they delve into a 9 quest campaign in one of the many stories that happen in Askrias.

The game system is designed so it allows players to fully customize what they wish their characters to be with the modular dice and ability cards.

The main objective of each scenario is a story line which will require the players to complete the 'Core' quest. However to complete the quest they will need to travel to different locations, which may result in a safe haven, a treasure coffer or monster encounter!

Combat will be turn based and there will be no 'actual' board for enemy placement - only player placement. The monsters and players will take turn at activating and attacking each other - where the monster will always attack with random results.

At times, players will find loot as well, which will be either 'Shards' or 'Gear', which they can use to upgrade and customize the modular dice that they have, or 'Spellbooks' where it allows them to use new abilities!

In Askrias players take on the role of an adventurer (or hero) whom is on a Quest in the lands of Askrias.

Quests (as well as sub / side quests) can vary and the paths players take can change from game to game opening up a great deal of replay.

Tension is at times met in the forms of monster battles and/or player ailments in which players can venture off on side quests to remedy or even instead brave the final encounter despite such ailments.

Character creation is quite open to players creating a mix of skills and powers to suit a broad range of classic role playing archetypes and is flexible to allow players to mix and match to generate very creative characters that they may imagine or wish to play as.

Items appear in the form of Die faces allowing the player to customize their gear Dice and improve their favorite items in some fun ways.

Quests can be tailored to a particular players play group by modifying encounters, events, locations and more... providing interest for both casual play and advanced role play depending on the mix of players joining in.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Solo Sonderkarten: Geschenk, Schutz und Spielrichtung
description:
This promo expansion contains Protection, Change direction, Gift cards and two rules cards.

4 Schutzkarten (4 Protection cards) allow You to protect the against the card played by the previous player if the color fits.

2 Spielrichtung (2 Change direction cards) allow You to change direction

4 Geschenk (4 Gift cards) You may play if previous player has played card with the same color - he get them "gift" and must take 2 cards from the draw deck.

name: Bodydoodles
description: The party Game where everyone gets to tattoo and be tattooed, how will you leave your mark? Take a Doodle card, Take a Body card, and pick the player you want to ink. Players race to guess what the tattoo is and earn points for correctly guessing and drawing.

name: "Sunny Andy" Deck Derby
description:
This undated but circa 1920s game is simple dice-driven horse race played on a two-part metal track. Six metal horses and two metal hurdles are also included. The metal seems to be the selling point, since the box declares "As played on Ocean Liners", and both the box and board graphics feature ships and shipboard play of a shuffleboard-sized version of the game.

The 16-space U-shaped track has six lanes. Each horse is assigned the number on a D6 corresponding to its lane. In the standard game, each player throws three dice, with each horse moving one space for each time its die number appears.

The rules, printed on the metal board, provide for a steeplechase version, where the two metal hurdles are placed on designated spaces and require two of the three dice to show the horse's number to pass. They also provide for a "fast game" where one die determines the horse and a second die how many spaces it moves. And finally there are rules for a "slow race", where the last horse wins.

name: Meeting Engagement
description:
This is a two-player Soviet-era wargame played with plastic game pieces on a map with an 8 x 12 square grid. Each player receives 11 pieces: five soldiers, five tanks, and one missile launcher. The map graphics include a road, a railway, towns, bridges, a river, streams, swamps, lakes, woods and many contour lines, but these play no role in the game. The only relevant markings are the diagonal lines across the middle two rows, which is a neutral zone or "no-man's land".

Players may set up their pieces freely on their side of the neutral zone. They move alternately, one piece at a time, and each piece may move only a single space orthogonally.

A piece captures an enemy piece by moving next to it, but the required direction changes depending on the nature mix of pieces. Like pieces (infantry vs. infantry, tank vs. tank) can capture from any of the four directions. Infantry can only kill a tank from its side or rear. A tank can only kill infantry if the target is directly in front of it. The missile launcher may kill any one piece at any distance, but then turns into another tank.

The winner is the first player to get a piece onto his opponent's back row. The game says it is for children aged 7 to 10.

name: Biathlon
description:
This is a simple roll and move game simulating a biathlon race. The 58-space track includes spaces where players fall or break their skis, delaying progress. There also are two firing line spaces where players must pause to shoot out three targets.

This winter-sports game was published in 1980, the same year that the Soviet Union hosted the much-boycotted summer Olympics. The publishing information on the box says 20,000 copies were produced, and that the retail price of the game was 78 kopeks.

name: Spellit
description:
This party game from Dennis Productions is a simple quiz about how to spell the names of a dozen well-know composers. It consists of 12 player cards, and a key card with the answers. The box features an illustration of a piano player in formal dress at the keys of an open grand piano.

Each player card has three columns with different spellings for the same 12 composers and an answer column in which the player writes 1, 2 or 3 to reflect the column of his chosen answer. The player with the most correct answers at the end of the time limit wins.

name: Fukatsu
description:
Description from the publisher:

By the end of the 20th century, a group of people with super human powers (Fukatsu) has risen, engaging into battles to rule the world. In this game of power and conquest, terminate your opponents and gain enough glory points to become the master of the new world.

Player takes turn in Clockwise order, until one player successfully gathers 16 stars(points). On a player's turn, he takes one of the two options: (a) move his pawn one space and gather power cubes, or (b) consume power cubes to damage any targeted opposing player, which will collect stars.

I) MOVING AND COLLECTING POWER. The player MUST move one space in any of the SIX directions, and if landing on a space with a power cube, the player has three options: (a) collect 3 power cubes of the different color, (b) collect 2 power cubes of same color, (c) collect 1 power cube of any color. If the player lands on a EMPTY space, he MUST refills power cubes from the power-line by dropping ONE power cube into every empty space on the board, from TOP to BOTTOM and from LEFT to RIGHT. Optionally, before moving his pawn, the player can discard one power cube of any color in his possession, to JUMP ONE SPACE AHEAD.

II) ATTACKING and EARNING STARS. The player attacks by discarding a number of power cubes equivalent in color to another players STAR CARDS, beginning with CARD-STAR1. He may combine his power cubes together with POWER TECHNIQUES he has earned during the course of the game. If the player successfully fulfill the power cubes matching an opponent's STAR CARD, he discards those matching power cubes and the opponent will take DAMAGE based on the number of STARS in the card. A damage is taken by discarding power cubes of ANY COLOR from any of the 3 EXPERIENCE METER in the PLAYER BOARD.

JUST BEFORE (I) or (II) , the player has the option to UPGRADE any of his 3 EXPERIENCE METER on his player board. To do so, he places any number of IDENTICAL COLOR CUBES into a METER of SIMILAR COLOR. If the METER wishing to upgrade is EMPTY, then any color can be added. The EXPERIENCE METER will allow the player to Learn up to 3 POWER TECHNIQUES, as well as giving bonus actions if reaching 100%.
mechanics: Area Movement, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Treasure Hunt
description:
This party game consists of 14 player cards and a rules and solutions sheet. Each player card lists 12 riddles, and the solution to each riddle is an object that can be found in the host's house.

The rules suggest 40 minutes be allowed for players to roam the house and work out answers, and the first person to present a correct and complete card wins.

A sample riddle: "One half of me would take you right away; the other half might make a happy day." The answer is Carpet (Car + Pet).

The game is undated, but is similar to other games issued in the 1930s by PGP and UPL.

name: The Name's the Same
description:
This party game from UPL is more challenging than most. Each player is given a booklet with 36 riddles. The players must first solve the riddle and then associate the answer with one of the 36 first names listed on the back of the booklet.

For example, No. 33 is "He's learnt in Kindergarten", and the answer is Alf (from Alphabet). No. 34 is "He's heading for baldness, and the answer is Dan (from Dandruff). Some involve period references or slang. No. 26 is "He's an Army volunteer", leading to Terry from Territorial; No. 29 is "She throws him over?", leading Jill from Jilted.

The rules suggest giving players 20 to 30 minutes, after which the player with the most correct answers wins.

name: Pieksämäen Aapeli
description:
The game is basically a version of the game Afrikan tähti only with it's theme changed to the Finnish city Pieksämäki. Roll to move, find Abel Häyrinen, an influental person from Pieksämäki's history, and race to the finish. There are railways to quicken your pace, but no flights can be made as there are no airports in Pieksämäki.

Description from the back of the box:
Abel Häyrinen (1842-1895) oli valtiopäivämies, kauppias sekä maanomistaja, joka oli lähtöisin Virtasalmen Putkolasta. Hän johti Pieksämäen kuntakokouksia vuodesta 1874 aina vuoteen 1895. Häyrinen oli johtajan asemassaan tasapuolinen ja ajoi kuntalaisten asioita mm. koulutuksen, terveydenhuollon ja maanviljelyn saralla. Hän vaikutti suuresti siihen, että Savon rata kulkee Pieksämäen kautta. Abel Häyrinen lahjoitti Pieksämäen kirkonkylästä ostamansa Tienristin -tilan kunnalle. Nämä lahjoitetut maat ovat nykyisin kaupungin keskeisiä alueita.

Tutustu pelaamalla Pieksämäen historiaan ja sen entisaikojen elämään.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Sub-Space
description:
Sub-Space is a collection type game with an adult BDSM theme. Each person is a Dominant, and randomly draws a submissive card. Each submissive has 3 items that you need to put your submissive into Sub-Space (AKA Win).

Players can play items on their own turns, and can use special card to keep other players from stealing or breaking their items. Status cards can be used to swap hands, make other players miss turns, or let you take an extra turn.

There are two decks and the Box set. The box set contains both Hard and Soft decks. The difference in the decks is the aggressiveness of play and some of the artwork is a bit more pointed.

Because of the theme this game is for ages 18+.

name: Jig Jump
description:
This c. 1940s game has an unusual mechanism: competitive jig-saw!

The game consists of six similar jig-saw puzzles. The images are the same, but the piece shapes for each puzzle are different. Each of the 36-piece puzzles has a row of frogs, alternately jumping and sitting on lily pads. When completed, they measure 23.5" long by 2.5" wide.

As soon as the start signal is given, each player tries to complete his jig-saw as quickly as possible, and the first one to finish wins.

Alex G. Malloy (American Games) has a listing for "Jig Race by Arthur Dritz" (p. 79, #2988), by the same publisher, which either is his record of this game or represents another version of it.

name: Fantasy Stables: Junior Edition
description:
In the game of Fantasy Stables you're trying to make it in the horse business. Your friends will now be your rivals as you compete to see who will end up on top. The object of the game is to collect the most money in cash, horse value and bonuses. Bonuses are awarded for collecting certain groups of horses. They add another level of strategy to the game. Game play is very easy and no horse knowledge is needed to play.

Everyone begins the game with money and horses to start the fun right away. The game is over when the auction stack is out of horse cards. All the turns are cooperative but competitive to keep things lively!

Collect and show horse cards featuring fabulous pictures of real horses in 5 equestrian sports (Dressage, Driving, Western Pleasure, Western Performance, Jumping).

Add horses to your stable at public auctions where everyone can bid. Bid as high as you dare – you know the range but the horse’s actual value is kept a secret until the winning bid has been paid!
Everyone can enter the shows and choosing the right horse will give you an advantage but anyone could steal the win if luck is on their side.

The junior edition features less horses resulting in a short game as well as some other game rules geared towards a younger audience
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Polyhedron Conflict
description:
War has come again to the gaming table. Your troops are spilling out of your dice bag. It is up to you to determine the best way to deploy and support them.

But beware! Your battle plan never survives the first clash of troops.

Do you have what it takes to outmaneuver and conquer the other generals?

Polyhedron Conflict is a fast-paced card and dice game. It is a gateway game for two (2) to four (4) players ages eight (8) and up that is loosely based on the classic American card game, 'War.' The average game is about 15-30 minutes and can be taught in just a few minutes or during gameplay.

Players play from a hand of seven (7), placing one card facedown. Once all players are ready cards are revealed then they roll whatever dice their cards represent. Winner of the round is the highest score. The game winning conditions are determined before the game starts with either the person with the most cards or with the most points at the end of the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck

name: Handelsrouten: A Viking Saga
description:
Overview: Take on the role of a viking captain and steer your ship through the sea, past difficult navigable sea, ice and privateers.
Discover islands and trade goods or transporting oldest to fulfill your orders and collect gold and silver.
Upgrade your ship with different extensions and hire new viking crew members.
Furthermore be beware of your takers, who will make your journey as hard as possible.

Game-description:
The players control a viking ship. At the start of the game every player gets one ship card, some order cards and event cards.
The order cards are the goals, that every player has to accomplish to win the game! There are several kind of order cards, for example: gather goods and bring them to a specific harbor or transport a viking and so on. Every card gives a player some vicotry points and if a player has more than twelve points at the end of a round the game ends.
The game is played in clockwise direction. A player can do three actions during his turn. The actions are:
1. Catch fish (if you are on a game-tile with fish)
2. Rotate your ship one tile and move (or just move on tile)
3. Rotate your ship in the other direction
4. Lay in on a harbor
5. Gerate two silver (oversee trade, only once each turn!)

In every round the players can also bribe some independent vikings to mug another player, if the black ship catches a player.
Forthermore the players have to expand their viking ship, for example to transport more goods or to sail faster and so on.
One game turn consists of:
1. Every player do actions clockwise
2. Bribe the Freebooter
3. Every player do actions clockwise
4. Give out some goods, vikings (for transport) to the islands and their markets
At least, player can buy and use event cards to manuipulate for example the island markets, the freebooter or other player ships.

name: Watussy
description:
It is a game to "discard", so, the purpose of the game is to finish your cards before your opponents. How? Stay alert and have unbeatable reflexes to catch the opponent in "error", impose your cards and start driving to the victory.
What each player must do is to draw a card and put it public in the right place. If a player do a mistake and one of the other players see it, he can say Watussy. Now he can put all his public deck over the public deck of the other player that did the mistake.
The first player to finish his deck win the game.

name: Neuroshima Tactics: Moloch – Hybrydy 2
description:
Hybrids are blasphemous mix of human and the machine. Just their look makes you shiver. They are strong, well armed units that can be used for large variety of tasks.

This set contains 2 miniatures, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Neuroshima Tactics: Hegemonia – Punki 2
description:
Punks believe in motto "Leave and let die". They like to party, their lives are intense but short. They act in large groups, so their machine pistols can spit out rain of bullets

Punks set contains 2 punks, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Neuroshima Tactics: Mutanci Borgo – Cyborgi 2
description:
Cyborgs. Toughest of Borgo units. They have modified skeletons and muscles and augmentations that increase their stamina. That gives them superhuman ability to survive.
This set contains 2 minis, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Neuroshima Tactics: Mutanci Borgo – Szpony 2
description:
Claws. Strong and fast mutants fighting with implanted knives. Deadly in close combat. And their speed lets them to get to close combat before you say "Grenaade!"
This set contains 2 minis, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Neuroshima Tactics: Heroes – Treasure Hunter
description:
When you see your goal, nothing else matters. You press forward like a tank, forgetting about wounds, weariness and fear. You’re a treasure hunter – a broken collarbone, a pack of mutants or the fact that you haven’t had any sleep in three days won’t stop you from getting what you were send after. In your profession, you have to be ready for everything.

This set contains 1 mini, accessories set, random location card, additional game counters and rules booklet.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Kuldkarikas
description:
Biathlon-themed board game.

Goal of the game: To fi nish the race first.
Players roll die and move on the path, with some special spaces.
In shooting range player rolls the special die (with black-white dots) 5 or more times and if missed must make penalty round.

Player who finishes first is the winner.

name: Overture of Kings
description:
Description from the publisher:

Overture of Kings is a fantasy based card game for 2-6 players. It is set in a fictional world, but it uses many familiar medieval tones. The players assume the roles of the kings, and must build their armies while at the same time preventing the other kings from building theirs.
The game consists of two decks of cards; one primarily used to build your army and the other used for attacks and other actions. Overture of Kings requires strategy and planning, but there are elements that involve the luck of the draw and die rolls.
There are two player decks designed around the same rules and full games which are more complex and take longer to play. Also, there are Alliance game rules around which tournament play has evolved Included in the game are two types of optional cards that will either make the game easier for new players, extend the length of the round or both. It takes between 30 minutes to 2 hours to play a round depending on the optional cards used and the experience levels of the players.
Overture of Kings is easy to learn, family friendly and fun. There is a quick start guide to help new players understand the basics quickly as well as a full rule book for more detailed explanations of the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Adventure, Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval, Wargame
mechanics: Hand Management, Take That, Variable Phase Order

name: Tribes of Prax
description:
Players take on the role of a tribal khan from one of the five Great tribes of Prax: Sable, Impala, High Llama, Bison and Morocanth. The aim of the game is to accumulate status for your tribe. The tribe with the highest status at the end of the game is the winner. Players need to shepherd all their precious resources carefully in order to guide their tribe to victory.

Tribes of Prax is played in turns each representing a Gloranthan year. A game will consist of between 8 and 12 turns. Each year is divided into several seasons and phases.

Tribes of Prax consists of a game board depicting the are of Prax, Glorantha, Spirit Plane board, tokens for each player and couple of decks for allied spirits and random events. The game board is divided into irregular areas. A type of terrain or unique location defines each area. Players' tokens are their herds, clans, khan, heroes, warriors and shaman.

Players also have power that acts as a currency in the game. New power for each round is gained from various positions. During the game players move their tokens to different areas in the map and do various acts using power. At the same time players try to balance with invading Lunar forces (not a player role). Their acts and herd size will determine how much status they gain among the other tribes. The player with most status after predefined amount of rounds is the winner.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Abhi Ya Khabi
description: Abhi Ya Khabi was designed for people from rural and tribal India with low to mid-level literacy, and low game-literacy, and introduces them to a play environment where they have to make choices that reflect their real life. By investing money into different actions (from volunteering to building a new house) players collect ‘smiles’ in reward and protect themselves from life’s potential traps. With the aim of collecting the maximum number of smiles symbolic of the fundamental objective to maximize one’s wellbeing, players must decide their strategy and build their own path to happiness through the different items and challenges of the game. In effect, players are effectively competing against themselves to maximize their levels of personal well being (measured by money and smiles) lent itself well to creating an environment where each player (regardless of their demographic background) saw themselves as equals. After (and along with) the actual game, a discussion session is held in which participants analyze different elements of the game and then create new content to bring important social issues to their community and wider social circle.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Travel Game
description:
This five-player game was published as a free supplement in the 1908 issue of the Tsarist-era magazine “дело и потеха” (Business and Fun). The game is printed on a single 14.75" x 9" sheet of paper, with attractive color graphics representing the continents of Europe, Africa, America, Asia and Australia. (America is shown as the land of tall buildings and money.)

Despite the graphics, the game is really one of abstract strategy. The board consists of two concentric circles, with tripled lines around the circumference of each circle and across two diameters at right angles. There are nine circles (numbered 1 to 9) at the resulting intersections, with 1 at the center (Europe), 2-5 on the middle ring, and 6-9 on the outer ring (the four other continents).

The rules say to use a bowl of nuts to keep score, and players must agree beforehand on how many nuts will be required to win. They draw lots for turn order, and must place their token on a continent (the center or an outer circle). Each player in turn must move his token one space to an adjacent open circle. If no adjacent circles are open, he loses his turn.

The objective is to move one's token into the center circle as often as possible, collecting a nut each time. The first player to reach the agreed target wins.

name: Across the Atlantic
description:
This Chad Valley game is a simple roll and move affair in which up to four players race their passenger liners across the Atlantic.

All players leave from the UK (Liverpool, Bristol, Southampton and London), and have their own 75-space tracks ending in the Americas (Quebec, New York, Kingston, and Panama). Each track has four special spaces: Miss a Turn; Go Again; Back 3; and Back 5.

The three-section board has some nice graphics including scenes from Africa and South America and various incidents en route. The green player must be thankful that technology has improved since 1912: the iceberg off Newfoundland causes only a missed turn!

The board is 17" x 11.5", and has two folds, with an almost square center piece and smaller Eastern and Western side pieces.

name: Race to the North
description:
This Chad Valley title is a simple roll-and-move railway game for up to four players. There are four starting stations, and the goal is to reach the finish station by one of three tracks leading into it.

In between, various tracks criss-cross each other. Landing on a split space requires moving to the branch line, and landing on one of the intersections requires a die roll that sends the player's train in a random direction. There also is the usual sprinkling of hazard spaces that cause delays.

name: Kleiner Bär regelt den Verkehr: Teddy reist ins Bärenland
description: Roll and move game. The players start in "Bärenfried" and travel to "Bärenhausen". They start with train, car, motorcycle, horse, bike or on foot. At certain points they get on change zones, where they change their method of travel according to the result of the die. According to their method of travel they have to pass fewer or more spaces to reach the next change zone. On spaces with traffic signs, the player has to wait for a number of one to three turns. Players traveling by train are not affected by traffic signs. The first player to reach "Bärenhausen" wins the game.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Rolling For Bunnies: A Rabbit Match Dice Game
description:
Bunnies and dice: that's all. In this offshoot of Rabbit Match: The Game, players collect rabbit cards from a common tableau using two types of dice, socializing and bunny type.

Each turn players determine how many dice to commit in preparing (socializing) rabbits for adoption and how many to spend seeking appropriate adopters for the fully socialized buns. Multiple players can contribute to making a single bun friendly, but only one can get adoption credit (and points), allowing other contributors to dip into his or her dice pool.

Collect a variety (lop, lionhead, ruby, large, small) of bunnies shoot for sheer numbers, or play for victory points? Rolling for Bunnies allows for multiple strategies and contains advanced cards (such as pairs, groups) with the base set.

name: Girl Meets World
description:
Based on the Disney Channel show

Game came as one sheet of cardboard.

From the game:
All aboard the New York Subway for an underground adventure with your friends!

First, detach the game board. Then pop out and assemble the dice and the game pieces.

Roll the dice and count the circles to see where you land. Read the clue to see what happens next. If you stop on a [yellow circle], you might jump ahead or get knocked back. If you stop on a [star], you can jump to a different line on your next turn.

But if another player lands on your spot, you must go back down the line to the nearest station.

First person to Riley's house wins! Good Luck!

name: La Forme et la Couleur
description:
With three shapes (cube, cylinder, sphere) being in three colors (blue, yellow, red) you must realize, on a board of 16 vertical rods arranged in a square of 4 out of 4, the maximum combinations, and also interesting combinations.

Achieving a combination is successful in placing four pieces of the same shape - or the same color - or better still in the same shape and the same color,

On an alignment of 4 rods, in long or wide;
On the four corners of the same square.


It is also possible to do combinations by placing, on the same vertical rod, three pieces of the same shape or the same color, or better still in the same shape and the same color.
The possible combinations of this new three-dimensional game, highly original and modern, are countless.
You learn very quickly to identify the shot that will score the most points by not letting your opponent a minimum of possibilities.

name: Find the Bug! Agile
description:
You play an IT professional responsible for an agile team. Using test-driven development, you will create user stories, test other players’ user stories and integrate components to
earn victory points. The game can be used to teach agile testing but also works without its theme as an economic engine game.

You earn victory points in different categories but it is the points in your weakest category that determine the winner.

Code is represented by colored cubes and components by tiles with slots for input code and output code. The players take turns to perform one of the following tasks:

1. Program: Take code/s or exchange for victory points.
2. Model: Play one user story. The expected output is chosen by you and known to all players but the required input as per the user story is only known by you.
3. Develop: Play two input codes on Another player’s user story. If you fail, try again next turn. The other player gets codes equal to the color of the input. If you pass, you get victory points equal to the color of the output.

Once a component is developed (i.e. both input and output is known), it becomes a component that can be integrated with other components and share code with each other so that the output of one component is used as input for other components. By integrating components in this way, you get victory points equal to the color of half the output. The bigger the module, the more victory points you earn.

The challenge of Find the Bug! - Agile is to find the right code for the right user story and plan your gameplay so that the code received from your current task can be used for the
next task.

The unique mechanism of Find the Bug! - Agile is the way code flows between components, challenging the players not only to find the right code but also to plan forward so that they
have the right code at the right time.

name: Target Ball
description:
This game consists of a target board inset into the box, a 3.75" long metal spring catapult, and three wooden balls about 3/4" in diameter. Holes designed to fit the balls are cut into the cardboard target at various points.

These include a 50 point bulls-eye and four holes in each of three surrounding rings (30,20,10), plus half a dozen 10 holes and four diamonds worth 5 outside the main target. There is a "No Score" indented section in front of the target, where balls count for zero but may be re-shot. A ball that misses the box counts zero and is out of play.

Players take turns shooting the three balls, and the one with the highest total score after four rounds wins the game.

name: Game of Industries
description:
This is a late 19th Century quiz game, which the box says contains "400 Questions and Answers on the Great Industries of the United States". It consists of 100 plain cardboard cards. Each card has four questions, each followed by its answer, with a black line surrounding the text near the card's edges.

Players take two cards to start, with the remainder placed face down to form a draw deck. Each player in turn asks a question from one of his cards to the player on his left. If that player answers, he takes the card and places it in front of him. If he cannot, each other player in turn has an opportunity to answer and take the card. If no one answers correctly, the asking player gets to place it in front of himself. Whenever a card is taken, it is replaced from the draw deck, and the turn passes.

Some sample questions and answers:

What river is said to drive more mills and factories than any other river in the world? The Merrimac.
The exports of what city are ten times the value of its imports? New Orleans.
What city in New York is the largest cheese market in the Union? Utica.
For what is Troy, N.Y. noted? Collars and cuffs.

The game is undated, but Alex G. Malloy (American Games, 1999) dates it to the 1890s.

name: User Input Required
description:
User Input Required is a card game that can be played three different ways. But, before you play the game, the players themselves help craft the cards that will be used during the game.

The game can be played as either A) a drafting game, or B) a push-your-luck game, or C) a take that game. Before the game starts, players will fill in the cards that will be used during the game. Also, before the game starts, the players will also decide on the rules of engagement and how scoring will work. The limits of the game are only limited by the imagination of the players.

All 116 cards in User Input Required are dry erase and come sleeved.
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Open Drafting, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Take That

name: Trading Card Baseball
description:
This is a relatively complex die-rolling version of baseball. Pitcher rolls 1D6: 1-3 = ball; 4-6 = strike. Batter may take or swing. If he swings, rolls 1D6: matching the pitch number is a square hit; rolling an adjacent number is a weak hit.

On a hit, player rolls 3D6 for a weak hit and 4D6 for a square hit. The total indicates a location on the field, each of which is either an out or has a picture of a die with a target number from 2 to 6. The defending player rolls a D6, and if he rolls >= the target number, the player is out. If not, the batter gets at least one base. The defender rolls again, adding the result to the previous, and if the total still fails to reach the target number, the runner gets another base and a third roll is made. Batting totals of 19, 22 and 24 are home runs.

The unique feature of the game is that it is designed to be played with regular baseball trading cards, so that players can use their favorite real-life players in their line-ups and keep statistics on their performance over a season. The game includes 18 generic cards (2 for each position) that can be used as is, or customized with names.

There are additional rules for double and triple plays, sacrifice bunts, base stealing, clutch pitching and slugging.

name: Huracán
description:
The goal of the game is to avoid finishing the game with thee sunken ship token.

Each player begins with a hand of 9 cards; the rest of cards are left in a face down stack and the first one is revealed; and ship tokens are dealt (one with a sunken ship, the others with a floating ship). In a UNO-ish fashion, a player in his turn can play a card from his hand only if it matches the revealed card in color, number or action, and some cards perform actions on the ships. The game ends when a player gets rid of all his cards.

name: Beer! The Outrageously Fun Drinking Game
description:
The hilarious card game where you assign drinks, steal from others, have blackouts and even an occasional drunken hookup. Beer! also tests your knowledge with crazy categories like Types of Liquor, Cartoon Dogs, and Excuses for Not Making Love. If you win, you get to assign LOTS of drinks to the other players!

RULES

Object: To end a game with the highest cumulative number of drinks on the drink cards in your hand

Setup: Deal each player five cards. Place the rest of
the deck face down in the center of the table.

Play: A player begins a turn by either "knocking" (see below) or by playing a card After a card is played, take the appropriate action, then the player draws a replacement card. The player to the left of the dealer takes the first turn and play continues clockwise around the table. Stack the played cards in a pile face up next to the draw pile

Card Values: If you play a drink card (One, Two Three, Four, or Six Drinks), assign that number of drinks to a player. Play a Social card and everyone drinks. For Blackout, select a player to lose a turn. If you play Steal, take a card from the player of your choice. (Don't look at the other player's hand and she draws a replacement card, you do not.) For the Drunken Hookup card, you select two players who either kiss or drink three drinks each (they decide)

Category Cards: If you play a category card, select one of the categories on the card and announce it to the group. Players then take turns naming items that fit into that category. You name the first item, then continue around the table until a player either repeats an item or cannot think of anything else that fits in the category. Allow 10 seconds per turn. The person
making the mistake takes a drink

Knocking: If a player knocks instead of playing a card, that is the signal that the player wants to end the round. Each player following the knocker gets one last turn, then everyone shows their hands. Add up your cumulative drinks by counting the number of drinks on each drink card in your hand. The player with the highest number wins the round. you knock but do not win, take five penalty drinks. (Note: the round also ends if you reach the end of the deck and no one has knocked.)

Assigning Drinks: The winner hands out his drink cards to whomever he chooses. Drink the number of drinks on each card that is given to you. (lf players tie each winner assigns only three drink cards.)

name: Highest Bidder
description:
Highest Bidder is a card game for 2-5 players. Bidding is a central mechanism as players place secret bids from their hands onto point-scoring cards. Bids are placed simultaneously at the count of three and you never know which cards, how many and in which order your opponents will play.

Once bids are placed face down in front of each player, they're revealed one card at a time. Numbered "Bid Cards" add toward the value of your bid. Strategic "Effect Cards" affect your opponents.

The player with the most points once all cards have been bid on, wins.

name: Procurado: Mosquito da Dengue !
description:
Game description from the designer:

Procurado: Mosquito da Dengue is a game for up to 4 players. It is a cooperative game where the goal of the players is to eliminate all breeding sites of the mosquito Aedes aegypti or eliminate all the mosquitoes in the game. Mosquito wins all players are able to eliminate all members of a single family (There are 4 families in the game). For this the players will have to roll 3 Dice D6 and position them in only 3 of the 5 existing on the board records. The value obtained in the Dice D6, indicate how many points each disc can spin, always clockwise. With the rotation of these disks, there will always combinations of two symbols that trigger actions immediately. Are nine possible combinations of actions and players will need to know very well where to place each data in order to fulfill the goal of the game.

name: Top Flopp
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Top Flopp is a fun trick-taking card game for the whole family. For 2 - 8 players. Aged 10+.

There are three ways to start the game. Based on your cards, you decide and call whether you play: TOP, FLOPP or Chance. If you call TOP you must win each round and all other players will try to trump whereas in a FLOPP round you must lose each round and all other players will try not to trump. If you win a TOP or FLOPP you gain points but if you lose all others get points. When calling Chance you just play a card, which can be trumped or not and everyone has the chance to gain points. The player who trumped then gets to call TOP, FLOPP or Chance… The player who reached the winning amount of points (depending on the number of players) wins the game.

Playing time varies depending on the number of players or the amount of winning points you decide on. reviewers and testplayers played from 15 minutes up to 5 hours (with many rounds and special self-invented challenges for winners or losers ;-).

Reviewers and testplayers say Top Flopp is similar to Swiss/German/Austrian traditional card games like Jassen, Schnellen, Schnalzen... and is most fun with 3 or 4 players.

name: Spaß muß sein!
description:
The German title of the game Spaß muß sein! means "Fun must be!”. This is a simple card game, printed 1958. The game includes 100 cards of two types. The blue one with a ques-tion, and the red one with a answer. You have to through a card with a question. A other player has to choose answer. It’s up to you to decide if the answer is fitting or just fun.
Example: Question: “Would you like to go with me trough a forest?” Answer: “No, its to dan-gerous.”

name: The Nightmare Invader
description:
In The Nightmare Invader you play as an ordinary hotel guest with an extraordinary ability - you can enter other people's dreams. You will need that power to fight The Nightmare Invader - an evil entity who is trying to take control of all the guests by giving them terrifying nightmares.

To win the game, first you must wake up as many guests as you can before the invader drives them insane with terror. Then you will take the fight to the invader, trying to drive it out of the mind of its human host, or destroying it completely. But it will not be easy. The invader is completely alien, and uses deckbuilding to achieve its goals. Meanwhile you must use six sided dice to achieve yours.

The Invader gets the first turn. On the Invader turn you draw 3 cards from the Invader deck, each showing a different fear, such as Ghosts or Spiders. Any guests afraid of these fears become panicked. If the Invader can panic a guest 5 times before you wake them, they succumb to the will of the Invader and their card is added to the Invader deck, making it stronger.

On your turn, you roll 6 dice. Each die can be used once. If a die roll is high enough, you can use it to calm down a guest and if you calm the guest completely, they wake up and are removed from play. Dice can also be used to learn extra skills and abilities, such as removing the Invader's health, or adding distractions to the Invader deck.

It's a battle of dice versus cards. Do you have what it takes to save humanity and defeat The Nightmare Invader?
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck

name: The Bead Game Box
description:
The Bead Game Box is an innovative board game for the modern age. Combined with an online App, it gives you access to more than 100 traditional board games.

The Bead Game Box is all about creativity. You can easily share your variations of well known games using the App or you can even create and share your own games. Users also have access to Print&Play boards for games requiring specific boards.

It doesn't matter if it's Tic-Tac-Toe or The Royal Game of Ur. The Bead Game Box is suited for all kinds of games.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Ancient, Bluffing, Dice, Game System, Math, Party Game, Print & Play, Puzzle, Territory Building, Wargame
