mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Role Playing

name: Soldiers
description:
This is a WWII-era target game. The targets are cardboard soldiers that are inserted in wooden stands. The shooting mechanism is a wooden cannon powered by an elastic that shoots small wooden darts. While the box shows a twin-engine American starred airplane, the soldiers themselves are still in Napoleonic-era uniforms.

Scoring is simple: whoever knocks down the most soldiers wins.

The all cardboard and wood construction is consistent with wartime publication, and the cannon and stands are similar to the cannon version of Bomb the Navy.

name: De wakkere Oceaan-Vliegers
description:
De wakkere Oceaan-Vliegers ("The Brave Ocean Flyers") is a Dutch-language aviation-themed target game by a German publisher (Klee). It is undated, but c. 1930 judging by title's declaration of ocean-crossing as dangerous and by the artwork featuring a combination of biplanes, single-engine monoplane seaplanes and a trimotor.

The game board is a map covering Northern, Central and Western Europe and the East Coast of North America. The board is dotted with 58 small circles with the numbers 5, 10, 15 or 20. Six of these circles are bordered in red, meaning negative points for crashing; the remaining 52 are black and give positive points.

The playing pieces are cardboard planes attached to small wooden balls. The shooting mechanism is a 5"-long cardboard springboard painted with a plane taking off. It has a wooden fulcrum near one end. Players put a plane on the long end and push down on the short end to launch it. It gains or loses points based on where it lands on the board. The player gaining the most points wins.

name: It's a Knockout
description:
User summary:
No to be confused with the two European games with the same name, this is a dice game with a boxing theme. Points are scored for rolling the dice. Additional points are scored for certain combinations of dice. Rolling three 2s, 3s, 4, or 5s results in a knockdown. Three knockdowns and the scoring player wins by technical knockout, otherwise, the player who wins more rounds after a predetermined number of rounds is the victor.

name: Nachhaltige Entwicklung
description:
Nachhaltige Entwicklung combines education and fun. The game is about sustainable development (that's what the title translates to) in germany. Players act as newsmakers trying to compete for the most important topics to put in their papers.

Step 1:
At the beginning of each round there are two of the two-faced news cards on the table, showing a little headline or news story on the upside, and one of seven colors (political topics) and some symbols unseen on the backside (like social security, health, mobility, education, environment, etc.). Players can acquire those cards by blind bidding of reporter cards. They must try to match their reporter cards to the topic of the news item by assessing which political topic this story is about.

Step 2: reporter and news cards are flipped. Players can only get those cards that they have matched the symbols of. The player with the most stars gets the card. Then, every player gets their reporter cards back, regardless of success in the auction.

Step 3: Players can swap news and reporter cards with each other if they like.

Step 4: Writing an article - scoring points. This is the only phase with a set player order. The first player chooses two or more news cards of the same color (i.e. topic), then draws an event card from the event deck and reads out the instructions that fit the color of the cards chosen. He then scores points based on the event card, symbols on the news cards, and some bonus points about number of news cards or combinations of symbols. He also gets an additional reporter card.

The game ends after a set number of rounds or time, so it can be easily fit into a school lesson.

This game is a reimplementation of a Swiss game called Klartext.
publishers: hep: der Bildungsverlag (hep – the Education Publishing)

name: Pick-A-Plack
description:
This undated game combines die rolling with memory. Each player takes a bingo-like card with four numbered columns and seven rows of circles and covers each circle with a plastic disk (plack). On each card, 12 circles are blank, and the remainder have instructions such as "Pick-A-Plack"; "Others cover one blank", "Have another turn" or "Cover two blanks".

Players take turns rolling a die. On a 1-4, they may remove one plack from that column; on a 5, they must replace a plack on an open location of their choice; and on a 6, they may remove a plack from any one location. When removing a plack, they obey whatever instructions are underneath. The player who first removes all the placks on his card wins.

Despite the random element of die rolling, the key to victory is using required replacement of placks to re-cover useful spots, and remembering which of these will be most useful in each future situation.

name: Bom-Bird
description:
This undated Chad Valley title is a dexterity game using a wood and metal spring launcher, a hollow celluloid ball, and five target birds, also hollow celluloid, that balance on a wire.

The box is used as the base for the target. A cardboard cutout of a row of trees, ranging from 6" to 8" high, is inserted into two wooden holders fixed at the front of the box. Two 10" wooden poles are inserted in two other wooden blocks fixed to the box near the back, and have a string running between them. The birds are balanced on the string, and players must shoot over the trees to hit the birds. Any number of rounds may be played, with the player having the biggest bag winning.

The instructions inside the box lid show that three other versions of the game were produced: the smallest with just a cardboard backdrop, a larger square version with four poles and strings, and a huge octagonal version with eight poles in two squares at different heights, shown with 21 birds perches and more fallen.

name: Count Down: The Adventure-in-Space Game
description:
This 1966 game is based on the Apollo project aimed at putting the first man on the moon. It is a game for 2-6 players, who roll dice to move around the board while building up a full four-stage Saturn rocket and then successfully launching it.

Components include the board, 36 Astronaut (or "Condition") playing cards with period photographs, 20 yellow Chance cards, 8 green Espionage cards, 12 pink Sabotage cards, 4 plastic rockets, each in four stages, 6 wooden rocket playing pieces, money in "mios" or $millions, and 36 markers.

To do so, players must land on squares allowing them to collect research grants, buy rocket parts or "Condition" cards that fill in each player's Control Board, and collect Chance, Espionage or Sabotage cards to help their own projects or hurt their opponents. There is even a funny "Astronaut Training" space where players must get up and do 10 knee bends or pay 100 mio for being out of condition. Players may trade cards or parts by moving into another player's home area.

Once all four stages are ready and the Control Board is full, a player may attempt a final Count Down. He must roll 2D6 three times, and if he gets a cumulative total of 25 or more, he wins the game. He may roll again on succeeding turns unless of course his project is sabotaged.
publishers: E. S. Lowe Company Inc., Mondotoy Estab.

name: Kill the Bill
description:
Game description from the designer:

This is a new semi-cooperative card game of political negotiation, deception and voting in which players are politicians from the two big parties but who also try to push forward an individual hidden agenda. This game was initially designed as a game-base learning tool at the London School of Economics and Political Science to introduce students to collective decision-making, game theory and market regulation. The game scales well at different player counts and plays under 1 hour. Gamers and non-gamers alike will enjoy Kill the Bill. It rewards experienced players who manage well their hand of cards and use them in the appropriate way and at the right time. However, the game can be also thoroughly enjoyed as a party game with a strong take-that component in which negotiation and bluffing skills may compensate the lack of experience playing the tactics cards.

Overview
In Kill the Bill, players are members of a high profile Committee in the U.S. Congress who try to pass legislation benefiting both their political party and their own secret individual agenda. Each year 3 bills are discussed and voted by the Committee. The goal of the game is to become the most popular politician by the end of the fourth year (round) so to become the front-runner in the next presidential campaign.
Players obtain points by passing bills which are favorable to the interest of their party (party scoring track), or favorable to their individual agenda (agenda scoring track). Moreover players get (and lose) popularity points throughout the game as effect of the political tactics cards played. Skillful persuasion and negotiation are important to success. However, in politics things are never straightforward. A wide range of political tactics (cards) are available to players who can unexpectedly turn decisive votes in their favor. Building alliances across the party lines, having a long-term strategy in mind and showing tactical flexibility are important in "Kill the Bill" too. Players must be ready for blackmail, bribery, deception and treason. Sometimes the end justifies the means.

Turn order
Each round consist of 4 phases:
1-Preparation (new tactics cards are dealt -draft in the first year, Committee Chair is selected and bills presented)
2-Logrolling (negotiation) phase: players try to persuade each other to support or oppose certain bills
3-Political tactics phase: tactics cards are played
4-Voting phase: bills are voted and scoring tracks adjusted.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Negotiation, Party Game, Political
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That, Voting

name: ELECTION!: The Presidential Campaign Game
description:
A game of trivia, teamwork, & campaign strategy. Ages 10 and up, for 2-8 players.
ELECTION! The Presidential Campaign Game
2nd Edition
Overview:
Citizens vote to elect our president. In this game, you can lead the campaign! ELECTION! is a game of trivia, teamwork, & campaign strategy. Players compete to be the first party to claim the most electoral votes in an American Presidential election campaign. Players lead their party’s campaign for president by raising funds and purchasing Town Hall, Advertise, and Charisma cards to earn votes. Then with votes in hand, they strategically claim State's electoral votes and ensure their party's victory. Game Play:

Each turn involves three actions.
1 Roll dice
2 Buy Cards
3 Claim States
ACTION 1: Players can choose to roll the dice to raise funds. ACTION 2: They can opt to buy cards to build their campaign and earn popular votes. For example, buy a Town Hall trivia card to test your knowledge of history, State Capitals, State nicknames, and more. A correct response earns the votes. ACTION 3: With popular votes in hand, the players use them to win selected States on the score ballot.

Players may also "endorse" a teammate after their three actions. This is done by forwarding cards to a teammate's hand, pooling cards and votes to claim more States during their turn. Can the party now claim enough electoral votes to win the election?

Game progress is kept on the score ballot. The score ballot lists all 50 states and DC, and is sorted based on presidential election results from 1988 through 2008. There are states that lean red, states that lean blue, and swing states in the middle. States that lean toward the player's political party require fewer popular votes to claim. The swing states are equal for each party, and are more difficult for both. By claiming states with earned votes, players win electoral votes for their party and work toward victory. The electoral votes listed are current for the 2012, 2016, and 2020 presidential elections.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Choice Thoughts from Longfellow
description:
This 1890 game from Milton Bradley uses the Happy Families/Authors mechanism of building sets by asking for cards, but complicates strategy through a set of bonus cards.

The game consists of 95 small card slips, roughly 2.5" long by 0.5" wide. Of these, 18 contain the name of a Longfellow poem, 72 have the name of the poem and two lines from it, and five contain the names of styles of edition bindings: Tree Calf; Full Morocco; Half Morocco; Cloth; and Paper. There also are six larger reference slips with the names of all 18 poems.

Players take turns asking for a poem or selections from a poem, and when they complete a set, play it down in front of them. They also may ask for an "edition slip", and if the asked player has one, he must hand it over. If he has more than one, he chooses which to hand over.

All but the Paper slip provide a bonus that applies to all sets scored at the time it is played. Bonuses are cumulative, so a doubled pair plus two more sets then tripled equals 18 points. However, whichever player is left with the Paper slip at the end of the game cuts his total score in half. Highest net score wins.

The game is listed by Alex G. Malloy (American Games, 1999) at p. 34, #1033.

name: Legenden des Schwertes
description:
Legenden des Schwertes ("Legends of the Sword") is a strategy board game for 2-4 players at the age of 12+.

Each player takes control of a samurai family that competes for the title of the new Shogun. Players must manage their province, villages and build castles, recruit units and complete missions.

The game is aimed at all strategy fans who love the setting up and managing of a little kingdom. The uniqueness of the game is that the players are able to gain victory over a lot of different strategies and every match is unique. There will never be a game that is similar to a previous one! In addition, the game offers an exciting battle system in which players must tactically operate and not just roll dice.

Game description:

Legenden des Schwertes is a round based strategy game. At the start of the game, every player gets a set of mission cards and event cards. The mission cards are required to get victory points. The event cards can be used to manipulate combat between armies. The game is played in clockwise direction and every player has one turn per round.

The player's turn consists of five steps:
1. Receive income
2. Built and convert buildings
3. Hire units
4. Move and fight with your armies
5. End your turn and get victory points for completed missions cards

The game ends if a player has twelve or more victory points.

May the greatest strategic genius win!

name: We Were Not Cowards: Sedan 1870 & The Fall of the Second Empire
description:
We Were Not Cowards: Sedan 1870 & The Fall of the Second Empire is a grand tactical scale wargame by Ray Weiss covering the final desperate battle for Sedan in what amounted to Napoleon the III's last day in power.

The game uses Kevin Zucker's The Library of Napoleonic Battles series rules as a base and builds upon those to simulate the intricacies of military operations representing all levels of command and control. Units are at a brigade, division, squadron, or battery scale, with 1000 men per infantry Strength Point. Turns are approximately 1 hour each.

The game not only covers the somewhat hopeless historical battle, but also explores several "What if?" scenarios that explore what may have happened had Durcot retained command after MacMahon was wounded from Wimpiffen and ordered a retreat towards Paris. There are 2 other "What If?" scenarios that allow the french to respond to the Prussian encirclement which occurred a day before the actual battle.

name: Die Olympischen Spiele
description:
This is a simple roll and move game. The players start at space 1 and advance according to the die roll. The first player to reach space 60 wins the game. Every few spaces depict another olympic sports competition. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The game includes two dice, but the rules don't mention how many dice are actually used. So it probably depends if one wants to play a short or a long game.

The game was probably published 1924 or 1928.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Tricky
description:
A 2-player abstract game, designed by C. W. Cowsley and distributed by Applied Technology in 1989. The game consists of twelve top-hat shaped tokens (10 yellow numbered from 1-10, 1 red and 1 blue), the instructions, and a green cloth bag which doubles up as a double-sided game board.

One player plays as Red, the other as Blue. The object of the game is to capture the highest total of numbered yellow tokens, without your own token being captured by your opponent. The tokens are designed so that they can be easily pressed together, so that the players' red and blue tokens gradually accumulate a stack of yellow tokens underneath them as the game progresses.

The board consists of ten circles, connected by lines in a geometric pattern. There are two variant configurations, one printed on each side of the cloth bag. The game is played in two phases: firstly, each player alternately places one numbered token on a circle until all ten have been placed; secondly players take turns moving their red or blue token along the lines from circle to circle, capturing tokens as they move, until either all ten numbered tokens have been captured - or one player has blundered allowing their own token to be captured! The advantage of going first is mitigated by placing an upper limit on the first token that the starting player may capture - in the basic game, this is fixed at 6; in the advanced game this is decided by auction.

name: The New Game of Divers or Hidden Treasure
description:
This game from Parker Brothers takes a concept used by early fishing games and re-themes it to divers trying to hook sunken treasure.

The game includes a fold-out cardboard "tank" about 9" square and 6.5" high. Each wall contains a mesh-covered arch through which players can see to some extent what they are doing. There are two foot-long wooden poles, each with a string dangling from one end leading to a 2.5"-tall deep-sea diver figure with a small metal hook at its feet. The treasure consists of small cardboard rectangles, each with a metal loop projecting from the back, and the type of treasure (gold, silver, jewels) printed on the bottom with a value.

The treasures are placed value down at the bottom of the tank, and players must dangle their divers over the wall, twisting the rods to try and hook the treasures. The game can be played as a race between two people that lasts until all the treasure has been retrieved. Or it can be played by more people, with each player getting three minutes to hook as much as possible. Either way, the largest value of treasure (not number of catches) wins the game.

name: The Enchanted Tower
description:
This is a fantasy-themed roll-and-move game with a three-dimensional board. The board comes in three segments: two of these form a colorful truncated pyramid when pegged together, and the third forms a square ivy-covered stone tower that fits into the top of the pyramid.

Each side of the pyramid has 35 holes for pegs on a winding path up to the tower; each side of the tower has a further 11 holes leading to the window where the princess presumably awaits rescue.

Each player rolls a die to climb one side of the pyramid and then up the adjacent wall. There are no shortcuts up, but eight spaces have slides back down. First player to rescue the princess wins. The rules suggest a party variation, in which four "prizes" are placed in the tower, and players get to choose a prize in order of finish.

The box is not dated, but the game is listed in the 1946 Catalog of Copyright Entries.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Game of Liners and Transports
description:
This is a game of global travel and trade. It consists of six miniature ships, two different spinners, and a four-section map of the world measuring roughly 35" x 20". The map bears a variety of different routes available (Panama vs. Cape Horn, Suez vs. Cape of Good Hope, etc.) that can be sailed in either direction.

The objective is to complete a trip around the world while picking up the greatest value of cargo. Players each start with a ship in New York and spin for their initial cargo. They then announce a direction and destination, and when they arrive at that port, can add a cargo based on the chief exports of that port as listed on the board.

When leaving a port, players who spin greater than 3 move quickly but face a financial penalty (for being delayed in port). The winner is not the player who completes the round the world voyage first, but whoever finishes with the highest total value of cargo. If a ship is destroyed by landing on a storm, all cargo is lost, the player gets a spin for insurance to offset the lost, but starts again from New York.

name: ATS Gallabat: The War in East Africa 1940
description:
Gallabat: The War in East Africa 1940 is a set of 10 historical scenarios taking place around the borderlands between Kenya and Eithiopia, pitting the forces of colonial Britain and Italy against each other in fierce, early-war battles.
Besides the 10 all-new scenarios there are four 11" × 16" geomorphic boards to play them on, as well as 368 color, die-cut counters including new soldier art; all the combat counters needed to play!
Ownership of the ATS Rulebook and standard system markers are required.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: 10 Tage durch die Schweiz
description: Imagine a 10-day trip through Switzerland. During your journey you visit the cantons and lakes that have a common border. You eventually will have to ride a train, bus or a seaplane to connect two destinations. With a little luck, you will draw a card that is perfect for your trip. In the end, 10 regions and means of transport must be aligned in the right order, Simple rules that guarantee fun and entertainment for children and adults.

name: Tiny Armies
description:
Build your own army, destroy your enemies and most of all, have fun! Tiny Armies is a funny card game for 2-4 players with strategy and a bit of luck. It plays in 20-40 minutes depending on the number of players.

You draw cards to help build your army, consisting of various different units. Units are then recruited from hand, spies are potentially played and you attack enemy units to score stars.

The objective is to gain the most stars with the game ending at a pre-set number of stars. You gain stars by destroying enemy units and stealing them from other players.

name: Violetta
description: One set of 5 different colored discs for each player participating and the "Violetta" piece are placed (one piece on one space) in a random pattern on the game board. The playing pieces start on the corner spaces. Movement is determined by a die and is allowed in any direction, but not diagonal. If a playing piece gets on a space with a disc it needs next, it collects the disc. The discs may only be collected in the right order, beginning with the largest (red) and ending with the smallest (blue). The playing pieces may only enter empty spaces or spaces with the next disc they Need. When a player has collected all 5 discs, he further needs to collect "Violetta" to win the game.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Our USA: Products and Resources
description: This was an educational game from Selchow and Righter that was part of a series of at least 3 "Our USA" games. The cover states it is for ages 7 to 14. The game includes a map of the US with a winding path, a spinner, and cards corresponding to resources that could be collected along the path (e.g. Wyoming -- wood). The object is to complete a full circuit of the path.

name: Farce Card Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

Farce is an innovative new word game with an inventive step which creates new possibilities for players to outwit each other and have fun.

The inventive step in Farce divides the English Language into 3 elements (3 types of card) so that multiple cards may be combined to create new and original witty sentences. This hasn’t been done before and is an original feature of Farce.

Farce cards contain fragments of comedy which have been designed to combine with other fragments to generate new and original witty sentences. For each round of Farce each player combines up to 12 cards (comprised of the 3 elements) to make a witty sentence which they then read out to the group. Players use their own creativity to produce something uniquely funny with their cards which they then share with the group. The player who gets the most laughs wins the round.

The group decides on each round which player received the most laughs and awards a Farce Point. If there is any dispute then the dealer for that round has the final say. The dealer rotates after each round.

Farce includes 22 Wild Cards which allow players to insert the name of a fellow player into their farcical sentence, and thereby direct their sentences at each other and make fun of each other. This makes the game all about the players.

Farce is aimed at players aged 17+ as the outputs of the game can include adult humour.

The number of possible card permutations playable is virtually infinite. Players can always create something new with Farce, something original and funny which no one has ever heard before.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: Cassette Juego: Combate Espacial
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portable boardgames that were created in Spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other South American countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box. The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

Combate Espacial (Space Combat) was a spin and move game were players try to destroy the enemy spaceship as hunting the spaceship around the board. You spin to move and the first to get the enemy spaceship will be attack.

name: Cassette Juego: El Super Mago
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portable boardgames that were created in Spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other south american countries (produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box.The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

El Super Mago ("The Super Mage") was a spin and move game, where the player only has 60 minutes of air before he perishes in the depths of the sea, he must escape his bonds, and emerge victorious to prove that he is as good as the mythical Houdini, avoid the 1 on the die, you will lose time.

—user summary

name: Cassette Juego: Caza del Oso
description:
Cassette Juego was a very popular late 80´s spin and move series of portatile boardgames that were created in spain by CASA CHICO, but later was very popular in Venezuela and Peru,among other southamerican countries.(produced by Loklinka and Maxi S.A.)

The game itself was portable with shape of a 80´s old audio cassette, that come with it cassette box.The cassette was displayed in three sections. One is located in what was the function of the die, which was replaced by a rotating wheel with various numbers printed on it. The other two panels formed the board cassette. It was made ​​of metal, for small magnetic chips (usually four, but this varied depending on the game) could adhere securely and not dropped or lost. When not being used, the chips were placed in a small metal plate located on the upper right of the board.

La Caza del Oso (Bear Hunt) was a spin and move game were players try to capture a Bear. You spin to move and the first to get the Bear will be the ultimate hunter.

name: Vikings: The Board Game – Dice Tower Kickstarter 2016 Promo
description:
A set of 6 Personal Seer cards that were available as part of the Dice Tower 2016 Kickstarter campaign

Includes:
Odin's Lament
Living Well
Selling the Legend
Explorer's Bargain
A Noble's Bride
A Viking Romance

Text on the back of all the cards:
During the first year, immediately after everyone has selected their Seer Cards, discard your personal Seer Card and replace with this personal Seer Card. If playing with the First Game setup, this is done immediately prior to the first summer season. A personal Seer Card can never be discarded or exchanged for another Seer Card
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: KoonKan
description:
This card game is played with a 61-card deck. The deck has four suits (Star, Flag, Cross and Seal) each with cards numbered 1-15, along with a Koon card bearing the picture of a raccoon.

Players are dealt 10 cards each to start. On each turn, a player draws a card from the top of the remaining deck or of the discard pile, plays a set or more if he wishes, and discards a card. As in rummy, sets can be three or more of a kind or three or more of a suit in sequence.

However, in addition to laying down sets of their own, players may add cards to any set or sequence of any player on the board. The Koon card is wild and may be used in any set, but if it is played on the end of a sequence, the player holding that actual card may play it, and add the Koon to the other end of the sequence.

The object is to be the first player to empty his hand. The last card in a hand may be discarded or may be used in a set, with no discard. Other players add up the value of cards remaining in their hand and score that many points. Game winner is the one with the fewest points at the end of the agreed number of hands.

name: Jeu du Juif-Errant
description:
This mid-19th Century game is laid out like Game of Goose, with an inward spiral of 63 spaces, but it is based on the 1844 novel Le Juif-Errant (The Wandering Jew), by Eugene Sue. The starting (lower-left) corner of the board has an impage of Sue at work writing the novel. The other corners and each space on the track show a character or incident from the 1400-page book. The center of the board shows the Wandering Jew arriving in Paris, and also includes the rules.

As in Game of Goose, players make an initial ante, and may be forced to pay more into the pot as a result of landing on certain squares. The first player to reach the end of the track takes the pot.

name: UnderQuest
description:
In UnderQuest you are an adventurer setting out into a dark and grim world to make a name for yourself. Evil plagues and vile creatures lurk around every corner. Your task is to complete quests in order to build up your character by finding new loot, learning new skills, and defeating nasty foes. Doing this will allow you to embark on even tougher quests.

You will start your adventure in UnderQuest at the Lonely Troll Inn, where you will create a new character by picking a race and class, each with different skills and perks. You will then equip your adventurer with trapping and you may also hire a torch-bearer to help you on your mission. You then must choose a quest and travel to that location to begin. UnderQuest uses a unique draw three, pick one mechanic while you are exploring the huge underground world, along with a tactical dice system for combat. Each enemy feels quite different. You will find powerful weapons, armor, and items along the way to aid you in your quest. There is even a clever alchemy system that allows you to craft potions.

During your adventure you will encounter not just foes, but also treasure, campsites, traps, random encounters, and quest points. When you have to resolve a random encounter, you will get to read from over 50 random encounters in the random encounter book. These can range from strange caravans and wandering merchants to poisonous mushroom groves and snake pits! Whenever you trigger a quest point, you will read the next entry in the quest log. This allows UnderQuest to have a strong narrative to drive the storytelling aspect of the game and make each quest feel fleshed out.

Will you be able to build a lowly adventure into a mighty hero, or will your adventurer fall to the darkness that sleeps below. You can only find out by taking on the UnderQuest!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Narrative Choice / Paragraph, Push Your Luck, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: PROELIUM LOCUM
description:
Game description from the designer:

Proelium LOCUM is a strategy game in which players represent small forces of colonization to gain supremacy in the new frontiers of the human race.

In this game, players will explore a map, the board, find and collect resources to develop their settlement and power, thus winning production, military and civilian benefits. In short, a game development and supremacy.

The game starts by placing all pieces from the board as indicated in the rulebook, except the pieces with a hexagon color (red, green, blue or yellow).

Each player starts with a building of settlement, a crystal mine mining center and a builder robot UCA. In the game, players will have to manage production and spending 3 resources, crystal, flux and naquadagh.

Using flux, players can move the UCA, when a robot into a piece upside down, it will rotate the piece and threw a given scan, according to the result given the player who has explored the piece, will get one of the resources listed above. The resources will be obtained from mines in which the player has built a mining center, they will give a fixed income and sometimes variables. On the other hand the production of flux will be managed by the player, buiding generators and paying the price (in resources) of developments.

Players can build settlements, hangars, research centers, towers, mining centers and all of these developments. In the military aspect, the player can build four types of robots, all motion profile, attack, armor, etc.

Combat works with combinations of dice rolls and spending flux.

The game ends at the end of 15 rounds of play or if a player reaches 50 victory points, you can get advantage of the bonus round, small military campaigns, construction of urban centers and research upgrades and technologies.

A player can win the game in three ways, being the player with the most victory points at the end of the 15th round, the only survivor on the board or arrive first at 50 points victory.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Worker Placement

name: Cardopoly
description:
Dice? Going once, going twice... Gone!

Cardopoly Deck replaces Monopoly's dice with movement & action cards while adding speed and more fun to the classic property trading game.

Compatible with traditional Monopoly and many themed editions.

name: LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! – The Original VOL 2
description: Gameplay in LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! is team based. A player from each team will place a "Mouthis" around their lips, pulling their lips back and making pronunciation difficult. That player will then attempt to reach a few words from the card they have drawn. They may repeat themselves as often as they would like and must get their teammate(s) to correctly guess the words they are trying to pronounce within 30 seconds. Afterwards the opposing team takes a turn. The first to five or ten points wins!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! – The Naughty VOL 1
description:
The Naughty VOL 1 expansion adds 50 additional adult themed playing cards to your existing collection of LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter!

Gameplay in LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! is team based. A player from each team will place a "Mouthies" around their lips, pulling their lips back and making pronunciation difficult. That player will then attempt to reach a few words from the card they have drawn. They may repeat themselves as often as they would like and must get their teammate(s) to correctly guess the words they are trying to pronounce within 30 seconds. Afterwards the opposing team takes a turn. The first to five or ten points wins!

From the website:

When you need a reason to get together with friends and have the best night of your life, LOLZ Game! Easy, simple, and unforgettable laughs - guaranteed!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! – The Nice Santa
description:
The Nice Santa expansion adds 50 additional kid-friendly holiday themed playing cards to your existing collection of LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter!

Gameplay in LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! is team based. A player from each team will place a "Mouthies" around their lips, pulling their lips back and making pronunciation difficult. That player will then attempt to reach a few words from the card they have drawn. They may repeat themselves as often as they would like and must get their teammate(s) to correctly guess the words they are trying to pronounce within 30 seconds. Afterwards the opposing team takes a turn. The first to five or ten points wins!

From the website:

When you need a reason to get together with friends and have the best night of your life, LOLZ Game! Easy, simple, and unforgettable laughs - guaranteed!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! – The Naughty Santa
description:
The Naughty Santa expansion adds 50 additional adult holiday themed playing cards to your existing collection of LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter!

Gameplay in LOLZ: The Gift of Laughter! is team based. A player from each team will place a "Mouthies" around their lips, pulling their lips back and making pronunciation difficult. That player will then attempt to reach a few words from the card they have drawn. They may repeat themselves as often as they would like and must get their teammate(s) to correctly guess the words they are trying to pronounce within 30 seconds. Afterwards the opposing team takes a turn. The first to five or ten points wins!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: Panda Pursuit
description:
A hungry panda has escaped the zoo in search of better food and the only way to get him back is to gather the bamboo that he likes best. That's where you come in!

In Panda Pursuit, each player is a zookeeper trying to lure Panda back to his enclosure and keep him happy. You'll have to watch what he eats and make sure you stock up on his favorite bamboo to stop him from escaping again. Meanwhile, a sneaky photographer is also chasing Panda to get the perfect set of photos. Could Panda secretly want to be a star?

Each turn players will roll custom dice and apply their results to Panda and their Zookeeper or Panda and the Photographer. When Panda stops on bamboo, he eats it. When a Zookeper stops on bamboo, he collects it. And when the Photographer stops in the same row or column as Panda, he snaps a photo.

Race the other zookeepers to the best bamboo and help or hinder the photographer trying to capture Panda in a variety of poses.

Find the right combination of food and photos to keep Panda happy and home in his enclosure in Panda Pursuit.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Stock Holding

name: Outlawyered
description:
Outlawyered is a law based card game that puts players in the the suit and lawsuit of an attorney. Each player is given three clients and must do what they can to be the first to win 5 trials.

Players must use their given Briefcase cards to play various types of Evidencezxc (Ex. Expert Witness and Mistress' Testimony) and Lawyer Tools (Ex. Objections and Outlawyered cards)in order to prevail. Each round sees one player's client get sued by the deck. The player must fight off opposing players to secure their client's freedom, and a trial win. But be careful, just because you win at the trial level does not guarantee a victory at the Super Ultimate Court!!!!

To win at trial the player must keep their client's Trial Score above the designated Trial Card's Conviction Score. Evidence cards can either decrease or increase the Trial Score while Lawyer Tools can dramaticallyasd>< impact the game in various ways, including negating a strong piece of evidence or even changing out which player is on trial.

No legal experience is needed nor will any be gained by playing.

name: Wickie Odin's Spiegel
description:
Based on the popular french children series Wickie The Viking.

A set-collection game which used a curved mirror mounted on a 3d game mat. Looking at the reflection of tokens on the mirror players have to decide whether take or not the various tokens.

For 2-4 players.

name: Iron League: Black Stadium
description:
Iron League:Black Stadium is a brutal tactical game utilizing Mechs, miniatures and interactive scenery for action-packed game play.

Configure your team with giant machines called Iron Mechs with interchangeable arms and weapons and warriors: the hordes of Claws, the heavy Zimman, your mechanic to repair your mechs. You can recruit mercenaries on your team.

Use drums full of gas in your favor, use walls to protect your warriors and be careful of fire squares. Throw the enemy into the air, or throw them at burning drum. Shoot down the Iron Mech pilots and steal their mechs, or destroy them.

With 4 game Modes: Match, Death Match, Arena and Cooperative. Nuke Tracker is a Expansion full Co-op supplementary to Iron League:Black Stadium.

Match: a tactical and ferocious sports game. Your team can be repaired after each goal.

Death Match: a competitive, destructive combat, if you survive you win. If your team dies, they cannot regenerate.

Arena: Inspired by MOBA style video games, if you destroy 2 enemy black holes or steal your enemy's plasma ball, you win. If your team dies, they can regenerate.

Coop: Survive waves of attacking enemies.

The game consists of 4 teams.

Each team contains 3 Iron Mechs, 3 Claws , 1 Zimman Warrior and 1 Mechanic. Iron Mechs are controlled by pilots with special abilities, but can be taken over by any warrior (mechanics are not warriors). If a warrior takes control of an Iron Mech, he loses his abilities, armor, and special weapons. So, he becomes a pilot but with limitations. There are also 4 mercenaries that can be hired during the game.
categories: Dice, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Sports, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Action Queue, Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Simulation

name: Tangled Trails
description:
Players travel a path from the top of the board to the bottom by playing cards. Cards can also be used to impede opponents.

Cards either have a number (1-5) of squares to move in one direction, a "star" that lets a player advance to a corner or fork, a "circled star" that allows a player to move another player's piece to a star square, or an "X" that forces a player to skip a turn.

name: Mutiny: A Pirate's Jolly Game of Dice and Back-Stabbing
description:
In Mutiny: A Pirate's Jolly Game of Dice and Backstabbing, players take on the roles of 2-6 pirates, trying to horde gold while attempting to escape a steadily sinking ship. In this case, the captain may not go down with the ship, but you can bet everyone else will!

Mutiny was introduced in concept during the 2014 rpggeek.com VirtuaCon digital convention event. At that time it was called "Pirates of the Sinking Ship".

The rules for Mutiny are simple: Using five, or perhaps six, standard dice, players roll for values of 3-5, hoping to amass wealth, 6's to board the lifeboat on which the gold is stored, while attempting to avoid 1's and 2's, which sink the ship.

When the ship reaches a water level of 20 fathoms, the ship sinks, with all aboard except whichever clever pirate has snuck aboard the lifeboat and made away with the treasure.

This game also includes Rum cards, which can be spent to gain initiative to roll dice. However, when a player's number is rolled, his rum card must be spent. Therefore, all players will receive an opportunity to roll the dice (and hopefully board the lifeboat) at least once.

Mutiny is played over a course of 3 separate games. Player character abilities shift each game, and are related to numbers also used to initiate a player's turn.

1) When this player is aboard the lifeboat, 1's rolled increase the water level by 2 fathoms.

2) This player may reroll any 2's rolled during his turn.

3) This player may keep his Rum card until he chooses to spend it to take his turn.

4) This player adds 2 gold to the lifeboat whenever he rolls a 4.

5) This player acquires 1 gold for his own personal pocket whenever anyone rolls his number during turn initiation. (The gold is added to his score at game end, provided he has won at least one of the three games.)

6) This player rolls six dice, instead of 5.

May the best backstabbing mutineer win!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Player Powers

name: Pakjesavond
description: Pakjesavond is a micro game about Sinterklaas and the missing presents. Up to five players try to find the location of these presents using the powers of the Pieten (played by children in the images) and Sinterklaas himself. The player who finds most presents by the end of the game is considered to be the best helper by Sinterklaas and wins the game.

name: Het Stratégisch Spel, Of Militaire Uitspanning
description:
Wargame published in the Netherlands and Germany in 1819 for teaching military strategy. It was sold in a wooden box containing a rulebook, 2 dice, 52 rectangular wooden playing pieces representing military units, and an 18.5 inches square topographic map.

Units move from crossroad to crossroad on the point-to-point map. Terrain affects unit movement and combat, and players also need to use their mobile magazines to provide supply for their army. The goal of the game is to capture the enemy capital. A player can also win by surrounding or eliminating a large enough portion of the enemy army.

Combat is mostly deterministic with rules for how many of different types of units are required to successfully attack a position, modified by map terrain, but players under some circumstances roll the dice to resolve combats.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement
publishers: De Weduwe J. Allart en Comp

name: Flipped Off!
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Flipped Off is a tactical card game where you play a plotting Mastermind aiming to defeat your rivals and seize control of the city for yourself. You must manage your Minions - the Pirates, Ninjas, and Robots that do your bidding, play actions that can improve your situation or wreak havoc with your enemies, and use your Minions to launch attacks and hope that your rivals can’t turn the cascade of results to their own advantage.

Each player has a set of Minion cards that they can use to attack other players, and a set of Action cards in their hand that they can use to affect either their own minions, or other player's minions. The objective of the game is to use your Minions and Actions to attack the other players and reduce their health until only a single player remains.

A Minion attacks by triggering another active Minion on the board. When a Minion is triggered it has an effect - it can deal damage to players, it can heal a player, or it can add flip counters to another Minion. But be careful! Attacking a Minion can cause a chain reaction that is out of your control. Each Minion has 2 different effects on either side of its card - each time it triggers it has a different effect on the game, and then it flips to reveal the opposite side. Minions also have a limited number of flips, once they're spent they are removed from play.

Can you out-think your opponents? Can you take advantage of the Minions on the board in order to come out on top? Eliminate your rivals and seize control of the city. Or at the very least, take all your rivals out with you and have the strongest army of Minions left who can secure the city for your successor.

name: Citizen Heroes
description:
Citizen Heroes is a fully cooperative card drafting and community resource management game where players take on the roles of support personnel such as 911 Dispatcher, Field Operations, Crisis Coordinator, and Structural Engineer. Players must work together to save their city and its citizens from an imminent Disaster (such as a Flood, Earthquake, or Inferno).
Recruit First Responders, rally them, and use them to rescue citizens,  all the while ensuring that the Disaster does not destroy the city.

• Tight action economy.
• Hard decisions can have lasting effects.
• Tension escalates after every turn.
• Constantly evolving game state.
• Danger Level Track pushes the end game.
• High player interaction through a community pool of resources and card sharing.

name: Spiredice
description:
A strategic faction based die stacking and siege game. Take control of an elemental faction waging war over ancient ruins. Earn points by rebuilding ruins as high as you can; however, be wary of your adversaries who will try and knock them down with their siege engines. As seen at PAX West 2016 in the Indie Megabooth.

Each turn players perform an action to explore new territory, move or fire their siege engine, or take control of territory with their leader. Then they roll dice to build up the ancient ruins on the board. The taller a ruin is, the more points it is worth but the bigger target it is to be knocked down by an enemy siege engine. Dice knocked out of play are captured and worth points at the end of the game.

At the end of the game, whoever has the most points currently on the board wins. There are five different scoring objectives (ruin height, color matching, captured enemy dice, faction objectives, and your faction leader's control) which can all contribute to your victory.

name: Genie Express: 1001 Deliveries
description:
Welcome to the ancient and wondrous city of Jadid. Its streets are a bustling hive of activity. Traders and merchants doing business and how do tehir goods get transported? A network of flying carpet couriers deliver these goods from one location to another!

In this magical, fun game you play delivery men trying to fulfill contracts. Really? Yes, but you're not ordinary delivery men! Your delivery vehicle is a genie-powered flying carpet and you're roaring through twisting and turning city streets in a frenzied race to make the biggest profit.

Grab the most lucrative contract or be sneaky and steal one from a rival! Ram your opponents' carpets into buildings or target them with genie power-ups! Spend coin to boost your carpet's abilities and avoid the mischievous genie wandering around town!

In Genie Express: 1001 Deliveries, players move to a location on the modular board to pick up contracts and then plotting a course to the drop off location. Movement is determined by rolling a pool of special movement dice. Completing a contract gains you gold. A player wins by getting to a pre-determined amount of gold first. Players compete to pickup the limited number of contracts so you better be quick otherwise your rivals will beat you to the winning goal!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Halfling Harvest
description:
Halfling Harvest is a simple take-that set collecting came for two to four players.

Every year our Halfling friends have a little party to celebrate the end of their harvest. The last few years have been quite extravagant and the problem is, this year they have drawn the attention of the various monsters that live in the mountains around the shire with their little shin-dig.

As the Halflings drink and dance on into the night, these monsters arrive all at the same time and (as one would expect) they do not wish to share the spoils. The fight amongst them grew ugly fast and I fear that our friends will all be hauled off one by one in the impending battle.

What we need is a distraction. The sun will rise soon and the monsters will scatter, so why don't we trick them into having a contest for the Halflings. Have each group take a recipe and the first to gather all their ingredients, gets ALL the Halflings. With a little luck this will delay them long enough that the sun will come up and our little friends can make it home in one piece.
Goal of the game/objective

Players take on the persona of one of four monsters and scramble to sort through the pile of ingredients to gather what they need to complete their recipe. This is done by drawing from the pile and playing cards from your hand; laying them face up on the table in front of you. The first person to collect and play all the items in their recipe wins. Play again to delay as long as possible!

At the end, the winner of the most games can decide whether they are a friend of the Halflings in disguise and was able to delay long enough to set them free, or is the real Monster and EATS THEM...

Component list

•72 Poker sized cards, 12 Jumbo sized recipe cards, and a Rules sheet in a two piece box
•4- player cards: Ogres, Giants, Goblins, Trolls
•12- recipe cards and 68- component cards
•13- Halflings
•42- Ingredient cards:
•7 each of: Spice, Dragonberry, Mutton, Fungus, Dwarfish Eel, & Elf Bread
•9- Attack Cards:
•1 Take Two Halflings, 1 Take Two Ingredients, 1 Wild Attack, 3 Take One Halfling, 3 Take One Ingredients
•2- Wild Ingredient Cards
•2- Defend Cards

Game Play

1.At the start of each turn, if the player has any number of Halflings, they MUST play all into their recipe by laying them face up in front of them.
2.Next, the player may play any one ingredient card into their recipe if desired, by placing it face up next to the Halflings in front of them.
3. If the player has an attack card, they may then choose to play one against another player. *note: stolen items may not be put in your hand, but must be played immediately.*
4.After the attack, the player may discard any number of cards still left in their hand into the discard pile.
5.The player will then draw from the component deck into their hand back up to a limit of five cards.
6.Play continues to the left.

Notes:

-Stolen items must be played directly into the recipe
-“Wild” cards can be played in place of any ingredients, but not Halflings
-The “Wild Attack” card can steal any card, Ingredient or Halfling, and is the only card that can steal a “Wild” card.
-The “Take two Halfling” and “Take two Ingredients” attack cards may both be taken from the same player, OR may take one from two different players.
-You may play more ingredients or Halflings into your recipe then are required.

name: DIY COMPUTER
description:
Overview：
This game is about assembling mainframe. There are 6 parts to assemble the mainframe. This is a game for 4 players.

Game components:
12 red cards (computer cases)
72 blue cards (9 CPU, 9 motherboards, 9 memories, 18 GPU, 27 hard drives)
18 green cards (function cards)
Function cards
20 Change 1 component: update a hardware which has been installed.
18 Replace 2 component cards: discard 2 cards and draw 2 components cards.
6 Boom: Choose one player to uninstall 2 components on the deck expect computer case.
4 Robbery: Rob one player of one component card in hand.
1Rule book

Rules:
1.Each player is allotted three computer case cards, and each player need to choose one from three cards.
2.Player need to collect all parts of mainframe(computer case, motherboard, CPU, memories, GPU, hard drives).
3.Different computer case need different numbers of GPU and hard drives.
4.Each player only can install two hardware in one turn.
5.Each player in each turn can make a choice, one choice is draw two blue cards and one green card, the other choice is draw one green cards and one blue card.
6.Every function card should be used in the next turn,and every player only can use two function cards in one turn.
7.On the desk, the green cards need to face up 7 cards, player can decide draw facing up card, or pile. If the facing up cards are drew, the facing up cards will be supplemented.
8. Every player can trade with other players.
9.Each player must face up the cards which they decide to install on the deck. If they do this action, they can’t change them unless using function cards.
10.If one player finishes all the parts, the game still need to finish next round.
Procedures:
1.Each player will get three computer case cards, and each player must choose one of three cards.
2.Players need to use Rock Paper Scissors to decide who is the first, then the game is on a clockwise.
3.Before players draw cards, they can use only one function card.
4.Each player in each turn can make a choice, one choice is draw two blue cards and one green card, the other choice is draw one green cards and one blue card.
5.If player want to install a part, he/she need to face up the card on the desk.

Win state:
If only one player finishes installing mainframe in this round, he/she win.
If more than one players finishes installing mainframe in this round, they will compare who get higher points in the game. And the player who get higher points win.

name: Rainbow Egg
description:
The theme：On the Thanksgiving Day, a family need to vote who sings a song to celebrate this festival. Then, they write red egg, yellow egg, green egg, bad egg and rainbow egg. And if one person get the less score, this person will sing a song.

Game components:
11 cards ( 3 Red Egg cards, 3 Green Egg cards, 3 Yellow Egg cards, 1 Black Egg card, 1 Rainbow Egg card)
1 Pen
1 Blank paper
1 Rule book

The gameplay:1. Shuffling all cards and putting it on the table.
2. Each player need to pick one card place it on their forehead which each player only can see other cards and can’t see his/her own card.
3. The first player is the youngest player, then play clockwise.
4. One player is responsible for recording the votes. And the votes need to run two rounds.
5. Rainbow egg card always gets 1 score, and Black egg card can’t get any score.
6. The game need to be finished in three turns.
First turn:
The color eggs which are voted the middle time will get 2 score. The color eggs which are voted the highest time will get 1 score, and the color eggs which are lowest time can’t get any score.
Second turn:
The color eggs which are voted the highest time will get 2 score. The color eggs which are voted the lowest time will get 1 score, and the color eggs which are voted the middle time can’t get any score.
Third turn:
The color eggs which are voted the lowest time will get 2 score. The color eggs which are voted the middle time will get 1 score, and the color eggs which are voted the highest can’t get any score.

Goals:
The player who get most score will win.
The player who get least score will sing a song.

name: Bigtyme Football
description: A combination sports and gambling game where each player plays as a team owner, competes through an entire season, and attempts to make the most money. As the sales sheet states, "Follow the season schedule and win or lose millions playing football games against your friends. Your luck will also be tested by picking Safe or Risk cards when you are the Home Team."

name: Pentos: Spieleschmiede Promo Card
description:
One additional card for the German 2016 version of Pentos.
The cards are for founders on Spieleschmiede which founded the Black Pocket package. That means all three games PENTOS, ZERO and GHOSTS of Asyncron games

name: Villa Musarañas Great Race
description:
Villa Musarañas Great Race is going to start. Each school chooses a child to participate. What about you? Who are you going to run with?

OBJECTIVE OF THE GAME
Arrive at the finish line before your rivals. For this purpose you will have to overcome all kind of obstacles. First player who reaches 200 metres wins.

BOX CONTENTS
98 playing cards and 2 more cards with the rules.

CONTENTS TO PLAY
Cards, six-sided dice (take one of any other game or download an application on your smartphone browser that simulates one), notebook and pencil.

PREPARATION
The game can be played by any number of players from 2 to 6.
Write down in your notebook each one of the players in order to add the metres reached.
Divide the cards into three stacks:
1. Race (map-greens)
Overcome obstacles, dodge monsters and answer the wise men’s questions correctly to get metres in the race.
2. Equipment (open coffer-purples)
There are two kinds of objects:
Those ones that help to overcome obstacles (blues).
Those ones that are used for hindering the rest of runners (reds).
3. Runners (cup-yellows)
Each one of the runners has a physical skill (frog jump, lion strength, rabbit speed) that helps against monsters. There is also an intellectual one (language or mathematics) that helps to answer the wise men’s questions.

CARD MANAGEMENT
Shuffle the three stacks separately.
Each player chooses a runner that is put face up on the table. The discarded cards are kept.
Deal four equipment cards to each player. It is necessary to keep them out of sight. You can never have more than four equipment cards in your hand. The unused cards are put face down at one side of the table.
The race stack is put face down in the middle of the table. The race starts when putting face up the first card of the stack. When the stack has no cards left, shuffle and put face down again.

BEGINNING OF THE GAME
Roll the dice and the player with the highest score, starts playing. Each turn spins in a clockwise direction and starts showing a card of the race stack. Each card has a challenge with a score that must be overcome by rolling the dice. If you get it you get more metres or more equipment. If not, it is likely to lose metres (never under zero), equipment or the position. Each turn does not finish until each and everyone of the players try to overcome it.

STAGES IN EACH TURN
Each turn is divided into two stages:
1. Use of the equipment. You can use equipment cards only once.
2. Overcoming the challenge. In order to get it you will have to roll the dice and overcome the score of each challenge. It will be kept in mind if some equipment card has been used.
(Before starting each player’s turn, it will be also kept in mind if some equipment card has been used for hindering).

END OF THE GAME
The player who reaches 200 metres wins Villa Musarañas Great Race Cup.

name: Creation:  The land and human
description: Creation: The land and human is a strategy card battle game. In the game, players play as the god of the new world, they are competing to each others by collecting 5 kind of elements : METAL,WOOD,WATER,FIRE,EARTH. By using different combo of elements, they can play various mysterious creation card in order to destroy their rivals or increase their citizen or army. Players are able to battle directly with other players by using army card. Additionally, players can even build famous wonder by using multiple combo of elements to get stable benefit. The player who get most citizens win the game.

name: Match 3+
description:
The game consists of 15 cards. There are three colours and three shapes. The colours are Red, Blue and Yellow, and the shapes Circle, Triangle and Square. Some cards have coloured shapes, three of the cards heve colours with out shape, and three of the cards have shapes without colour.
Each of the two players gets 7 cards and the last one is put face up in the middle. In turns, the players play a card with either the same shape or the same colour as the one played last on the pile.
When the players have no valid card to play, they pass.
When both players pass, the one who passed first can start afresh, playing any card she/he chooses.
Only a card with the same shape can be played on a card with a colourless shape.
Only a card with the same colour can be played on a card with a shapeless colour.
The winner is the player who first empties his/her hand.

name: The Hobo Code
description:
Protect your Great Depression-era property from The Hole-in-the-Boot Gang, a clan of absurdly destructive hobos that has invaded your town! Use "The Hobo Code" to direct the hobos away from your poperty and towards your neighbors’ properties instead.

The Hobo Code is 2-6 player, ~30 min game of strategic hot potato if instead of one potato, there's a bunch of them and instead of potatoes, it's hobos!

The complete rules can be found here:

https://drive.google.com/open?id=156a0isQI_PN5WIrbdK3FQuBoyY...

name: Play Ball! A Baseball Game of Skill
description:
This 1930's title is a physical-dexterity baseball game. The cardboard playing field is inset in the bottom of the box and has 23 holes punched into it, each with a result ranging from Out to Home Run. A 3" wooden bat is mounted on a wooden peg beside home plate, which has a small hole in it.

The At-Bat player puts a marble on home plate, and then flicks the bat to propel the marble across the field. If the ball fails to fall into any of the holes, it is a strike, with three strikes as usual causing an out, and three outs ending the inning.

name: Pressman Action Baseball
description:
This is an action-dexterity version of baseball, with a pressed-metal field mounted inside a wooden frame. The infield and foul territory are at a higher level than the outfield. There are two foul-out holes in the higher level, and 38 holes across the lower outfield, of which 13 are outs, 1 is a double play, 12 are singles, 8 are doubles, 3 are triples, and 1 is a home run.

There is a thin springy metal loop near 2nd base that the pitching player uses to send the ball toward home plate. There is a spring-loaded 4" wooden bat that the batting player holds back and releases to strike the ball. There is a small bell behind home plate labeled "Automatic Umpire": if the batter does not swing, a pitch hitting the bell is a strike, while one missing it is a ball.

While the game is undated, the box is labeled "A Lynn Pressman Original", suggesting that it was published after her husband Jack Pressman's death in 1959.

name: Fitch's Game of Natural History
description:
This 1887 card game was designed to teach children the names and images of animals. The deck has 40 cards, each with the name and large ink drawing of an animal on top, and four small drawings and animal names underneath, forming sets of five cards to be collected. Each card also bears a number from 1 to 8 to identify the set. This is intended to allow children to call for cards even if they don't yet read well.

The game uses a "go-fish" mechanism, with five cards initially dealt to each player. Players ask for another animal from another player, get another turn if they are successful, and draw from the top of the deck if they are not. Player collecting the most sets wins.

The cover of the box notes the patent registration date of Aug. 23rd, 1887 and displays the price of 25 cents. The side of the box declares: "Natural History Made Easy and Amusing: Fun, Wit and Knowledge combined."

name: Nodes
description:
Nodes is a strategy game for two or four players. The game board is octagonal, and each space is the intersection of a horizontal, vertical, and two diagonal lines. There are thus eight lines emanating out from each space in the manner of a compass rose.

There are two types of pieces: nodes and units. Nodes are akin to the king in Chess. They only can move one space, and a player wins when they surround their opponent's node. Units are akin to pawns in chess. They are the main troops in the game and form the basis of each player's strategy. Each player has one node and eight units throughout the game.

Unlike chess, however, the placement of the nodes on the board also determines how the units can move. The lines that extend in eight directions from the space a node occupies are called "lines of communication." If a unit is located along a line of communication the unit can move, whether it's the player's node or their opponent's. If the unit moves into a space that is also along the same line as a node, it can move again. But if a unit moves out of line or starts a turn out of line, it can't move.

A player's turn involves moving as many pieces as they want as many spaces as they want in order to defend their own node and attack their opponent's node. Every turn asks the players to make strategic decisions about when to attack, when to defend, and how to do both with only eight units. At the end of a player's turn, they move their node, and the other player makes their move. The game ends when one player is unable to move their node.

name: "Ready, Aim...Draw!"
description:
Description from the publisher:

The Fast-Action Packed Drawing and Guessing Game for Outdoor Sporting Enthusiasts! "Ready, Aim...Draw!", is the zany fast-paced action game of sketching, drawing, doodling, guessing and yelling. Entertaining words and phrases from all outdoor sporting activities including fishing, hunting, camping, boating, first aid, sporting safety, wildlife, trapping, wildlife conservation and nature test and challenge the drawing skills of the Sketcher and the perceptive guessing skills of the Guessers. As Players sketch, individuals or team members attempt to guess the word or phrase with correct guesses being rewarded with points or colored poker chips. Collect all four chips and play resumes at the "Roulette Wheel" where with a little luck the player can win the game!

name: Shindig Machine: Bits & Pieces
description: A 36 Card Expansion for Shindig Machine with new artwork that expands the storytelling possibilities of the core set.

name: Diceball
description:
This rare 1937 game from obscure publisher Ray-Fair Company uses two special dice to generate its results. Both are six-sided, but are marked with specific results, each with a line and number underneath. The rules say the dice are designed to "give results almost IDENTICAL with the averages of corresponding plays in REAL BASEBALL."

The game's dice, rules and red and blue wooden player tokens came in a small box with a separate 19" square board.

name: Championship Game of Football
description:
This pocket-size wartime football game consists of a block of wood less than 5" a side that is wrapped in simulated leather. Included in a cardboard drawer in theblock are an unusual 48-space spinner, four wooden pegs and a rules sheet with results table. The board has 100 holes on the field punched diagonally between each printed 10-yard division on the field. There also are holes to mark "Yards to Gain" (1-10) and downs (1-4).

The results table is laid out in columns. The first two columns handle kick-offs and returns. The remaining six are the play call options for the offensive player: Line Plunge; End Run; Trick Play; Forward Pass; Lateral Pass; and Punt.

There are 48 rows of results, each indicating the yards gained or lost on the called play according to the result on the spinner. Field goals may be attempted within 30 yards, and succeed on spins of 1 or multiples of 5; points after touchdown score on an even number.

name: When the Levee Breaks
description:
Each player is a City Planner in New Orleans. All players must begrudgingly work together building levees to keep the city from flooding during the next big storm. During a turn, one player will be designated as the City Manager and select 3 levees for the City Planners to bid on. The levee that gets the most money, will be built. Unfortunately everyone has a different vision of the city's future and wants some districts to be destroyed for future revitalization.

In this semi-cooperative game, players will make and break promises to save and destroy the districts according to their secret goals. The game ends when the great storm comes and floods the unprotected districts. Players earn points for successfully fulfilling the their secret goals, and lose points for failure.

name: Bakumatsu Gettan Fuda
description: This is a set collection game using a deck of cards with historical figures who played important roles in the Bakumatsu period (1853-1867) on them (these cards also serve as a standard deck of cards). Each player is dealt five cards. On their turn, the player draws one card and discards one card face up in front of them, trying to build one of 43 sets, which are thematic (people from the same domain, people involved in the same incidents, etc.), require 2 to 5 cards, and are rated from one to fifty points. When a player is one card away from completing his or her set, they say "Iza! Jinjo ni!" (Roughly, "Let's fight properly), and discard their card sideways. If they see the last card they need in front of another player, they may take it and finish their set. When a player finishes their set, they say "Bakumatsu," and discard their last card. They are done. The game ends when the deck runs out, at which time the sets are scored, highest score wins and deals the next game.

name: Instant Baseball
description:
This might be described as a minimalist baseball game. It consists of a single plastic-laminated sheet which includes a small baseball diamond, a scoring box, rules of play, and a remarkably detailed results table that aims to reflect the probabilities of a wide range of plays.

The playing mechanism is a regular pack of cards, and each batting player turns over cards and records the outcomes until reaching three outs for an inning.

The table shows a specific result for each card in the deck, including contingencies such as tagging up on a fly out. The 52 cards produce 7 singles, 2.6 doubles, 1 triple and 1.4 home runs (7 of hearts = HR in innings 3, 6, 7 and 9, otherwise a double). There are 3 walks and 2 errors, while the rest are outs of various kinds.

The special situations apply to the three double play cards along with the 7 of spades and 3 of diamonds, where the outcomes vary depending on combinations of runners on base.

name: Spill the Beans
description:
This undated dexterity game consists of a pistol that shoots wooden darts, a wooden pot and post containing 8 round wooden beads (the beans), and a target area, with 13 holes valued 5 to 25, inset in the box bottom. The pot is filled with the beans and placed on top of the post, which is inserted in a hole at the front of the target area.

The rules say players should shoot from a distance of 8-10 feet, and get three shots each. When they hit the pot, it spills the beans onto the target area. Any that fall into holes count that many points. Any that remain loose are replaced in the pot for the next shot.

Winner is the first player to accumulate 250 points. Since the maximum possible score from a single round is 100, a game will last at least three rounds.

name: Run for the White House
description:
This is a Monopoly-style election game with some add-on trivia. Each player starts with $5.5 million and rolls dice to move around the 62-space track. A player landing on a state space may pay $20,000 times its electoral votes to win it. If he doesn't want to or can't pay, the state goes up for auction. And if the state is already owned, the player pays $10,000 times electoral votes into the Campaign Fund Treasure Chest. Any player landing on that space collects all money there.

There are three kinds of random event cards and spaces: National Election Commission, National Party Headquarters and Press Conference. Each may grant or cost money or votes, and may offer the opportunity to answer a trivia question from a Presidential Seal card. Each card has two questions, one of which is chosen and read by an opponent. Answering correctly provides benefits.

The first candidate to 270 electoral votes wins, but a player may win sooner if all opponents go broke. There is a time-limit elimination process for more than two players. After 60 minutes, there is a ballot, and the player with the lowest EV total drops out and returns his states to the banks. Further ballots are held each 15 minutes until the game is down to 2 players.

name: Convoy: "10-4 Truckers C.B. Game"
description:
Subtitled "The Trucker's CB Radio Game", this 1976 title is a roll-and-move affair that riffs off that era's fad around Citizen's Band radio. The game takes players around a lavishly illustrated map of the United States, with occasional dead-ends and many bear traps and other distractions along the way.

The inside of the box top has an extensive glossary of "C.B. and Trucker's Lingo", and many of these terms along with nicknames for states and cities are sprinkled across the board.

The box says the game was distributed by Priority Marketing Communications, a subsidiary of National Consumer Products Inc. based in Chicago.

name: Cyclosprint
description:
French cycling game with a disctintive 1970s flavour.

As is typical in this kind of games, it combines overambitious features with rules that are quite obvious in general, though they may feature some surprises.

This game is big (the box measures 65 x 28 cms) and heavy, specially due to the seven (!) boards included. Five of these boards are just different finishes for various stages. Another board ("parcour montagne") can be either the end of a stage or a stage in itself, while the bigger board "("parcours plaine") is the one used in mosts races.

A maximum of six players manages a team of two riders each.

The riders are seventies' Cofalus (5cms, smaller than the ones featured in later games like l'Echappée Infernale or Les Géants de la Route), and two extra riders are provided for the yellow and green jerseys.
The riders are a bit oversized for the board (which is nevertheless quite big), and there is also a trailing car (voiture balai).

Most of the time you throw two dice and move your two riders. You decide which rider you move with each dice, considering that you are not allowed to move to a field occupied by another rider, and that there are certain fields that give you advantages or disadvantages.

An interesting/unusual rule, though, is the one for the trailing car. It starts its movement when the first rider reachs km. 47, and stops at km 100 of flat stages. If there are two or three players in the game, the trailing car moves 5 fields forward in each movement. For 4 or 5 players it just moves 4 field. With 6 players, it just moves 3 fields.
