All the riders caught up by the car are out of the race, though they may take part in subsequent stages.

For mountain stages, movement rules change. Before a climb, riders have tos stop compulsorily in the "Plateforme" field before the climb (in which there can be no more than three riders at a time). Then, during climbs, to progress to the next field riders must throw exactly the number inscribed in that field. If the field ahead is blocked by another rider, you must throw the number corresponding to the first free field, to which you will move. As a result, riders tend to form pelotons in the climbs, and these pelotons disband quickly in the descents.

By the way, there is no trailing car in mountain stages.

Another unusual feature of this game are the different stage finishes. Riders have to arrive to the neutral zone (last field) and then they move onto that particular stage finishing board. What is most unusual is that every finish has different rules. For instance, in end of stage G you have game-of-goose rules, while in end of stage F you move forward with even numbers but backward with odd numbers. In the velodrome, you have to fall exactly on the finishing stage or else ride another lap. A flat stage can end with a climb, using the B' part of board B.

At the end of the game (the players can decide how many of the stages they want to play) the player who's riders score best in the general classification wins the game.

name: Cyklo
description:
This is a game made by Marco Rossi, from Genoa (Italy). It is a clever middle point between a simulation replay game and a board game. You can play it by yourself, with a lot of tables, individual characteristics for each rider and a some of dice-throwing and table checking like a replay game, but you still have a board and riders, and the game can be played by several players.

There are (or maybe I should say "there wiill be") six versions of the game, corresponding to six historical periods (one for each post WWII decade: mine is the 1966-1975 edition). There are ten teams for each historical period, plus a bonus "world championship" special set.

There are ten team (of three riders which you can chose among four fdifferent ones). That makes thirty riders, and they all take part in the race, regardless of whether there are enough players. In the (most probable) case of having less than ten players, there are rules to manage the virtual players, to take decisions for them as whern to attack and when to follow other riders, etc...

You can play the game by yourself against nine virtual teams, in which case the game is almost a replay game (thouigh you still take your decisions for one of the teams). I wonder which would be the better balance between the number of human players and the number of virtual teams for the game playability.

An individual race or stage consists of six game turns. The winner is not the first to reach a certain point in the board, but the one to ride further in these six turns.

Before the race you set up six tiles in a special window in the board , which will define the race profile. (In the case of the picture below, a mountain stage, though one starting with a "pavés" zone). You can design your own race profile, but you can also use one of the many included in the game rules. You can chose between Milano-San Remo, Gand-Velvegem, Flèche Wallonne, Gold Race, Paris-Tours, Ronde van Vlaanderen, Paris-Roubaix, Liege-Bastogne-Liege, Paris-Bruxelles, Giro di Lombardía, a World Championship, a Time Trial World Championship, as well as 10-stage long Giro d'Italia and Tour de France.

name: Vuelta Ciclista a Espana
description:
Vuelta Ciclista a España is a dice driven race game, but it has an unusual rule.
There are five teams of five riders and a car each. The riders are numbered from 1 to 5 in each team, and the winner is the first team with three riders crossing the finish line.
On their turn players throw the die five times and the first throw is for rider number 1, the second for number 2, and so on...

However, at any time a player can decide to move the team's car instead of the designated rider.

There are also positive squares, marked AV (for "AVituallamiento", that is, feeding zone). Riders falling on them have an extra throw.

There is also an intermediate sprint ("Meta Volante") which also gives an extra throw to all the riders who pass it (regardless of whether they fall on it). If the result of this extra throw makes the rider fall on a C or P square, the throw is not valid and the rider may repeat the throw.
After square 35 there is a parking place for the cars, which cannot help riders in the final part of the race even though there is a square marked P and one marked with a C.

The game also provides classification sheets in case you want to play a stage race.
All the stages are similar and the classification is a points classification, with 40 awarded to the winner of the stage, 36 points to the second and one point to the 25th rider.

name: Wer Gewinnt Prag-Berlin-Warschau?
description:
Cycling board game produced in the DDR in 1956 about the Prag-Berlin-Warschau cycling race which was known as the Peace race, also known as Der Friedensfahrt.

The race begins in Bratislava and ends in Warsaw (as did the 1953 edition of the race). The race is divided in 12 stages. The game is played with 3 dice. The first rider to reach the even stages receives 5 points, and the second receives three points. For odd stages there are only 3 poinys awarded to the first rider to pass the city and one popint for the second.

Blue points are mountain passes; the first rider to pass through that point receives three point (none for the second).

Red lines are sprints; players who fall on these play again.

Red points with letters are race incidents (fall, punctures, injures). Players who fall on these get negative points or have to wait for some turns.

The rider with more points when all have reached Warsaw is the winner of the game.

name: Inland Water Transport
description:
Inland Water Transport was produced around 1950* as a promotional piece for the transportation companies Macneill & Barry Ltd and their subsidiary Kilburn & Co Private Ltd. The companies, along with their associates the Joint Steamer Companies, were involved in the transportation of goods throughout India (and, post partition, Pakistan). The game is a simulation of this regional logistic operation, featuring elements of roll-and-move with some mitigating choices, pick up and deliver, and the acquisition of routes and ports.

In the game up to 6 players each have a steamer and a train which they can move along the waterways and railways of North East India and East Pakistan (beginning in Calcutta), with movements based on dice rolls. At each port or rail depot they can collect cargo or deliver cargo. Cargo items are unique and are to be delivered to specific destinations, with varying payments on delivery. At certain points players collect "report" cards, which function similarly to "chance" cards in Monopoly, bestowing small benefits or losses on the player. Players can also purchase ports or railways, levying charges on other players that use them. The game ends once all cargo has been delivered, with the player with the most money winning.


Publication date is an educated approximate - no date is given in the manual but historical research of dates when the involved companies were merged and subsequently changed names dates it must be between 1949 and 1956.


Designers are sadly unknown.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Jets: Erweiterung
description: Jets Erweiterung consists of six 3D jet figures for use with the Jets board game as well as a large game board.

name: Sictitious: A Novel Word Game
description: [sic]titious is a party game for adults who love word play. In the game of [sic]titious, you define just how clever or crass you want to be. We’ve loaded the deck with more than 100 humorous altered words. Just flip a card, flip the timer and come up with a definition. Players award their [sic], [sic]er and [sic]est point cards for what they think are the best (or funniest) definitions. Or, the card flipper can be judge and jury and award the word card in play for their favorite definition.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Word Game

name: I Survived New York!
description:
This is a card game based on the stress of living in the Big Apple. There is a deck of 98 cards. Of these, 19 are I Survived New York! cards, which when played in front of a player, open that player to getting stressed out. There are 34 Stress Cards, of five types: Romance, Bucks, Shelter, Nine to Five, and Why Me? There are 38 Relief cards, each of which stops a specific type of stress. There are 5 Quick Fix cards, one for each kind of stress, that both provide relief and prevent that player from receiving any more stress of that kind for the rest of the round. Finally, there are 2 Reversal cards, which of course allow a player to dump his current stress on another player.

Players receive 5 cards each to start, and each turn draw one card and either play or discard one card. They may play their cards on any player including themselves. An I Survived New York card opens a player to receiving stress, one card at a time. A Relief card "closes" a stress pile, at which point that player then adds up his accumulated stress cards and notes the total on a scorepad. All the cards in the closed pile go into the discard pile, and that player is now free of additional stress until someone opens a new stress pile with an ILNY card.

As soon as one player has reached 4,000 stress points and closed his current pile, the round ends, and all cards are returned and reshuffled. When a player accumulates more than 12,000 stress points, he burns out totally and must move to Cleveland. The last survivor wins the game, unless a player accumulates exactly 12,000 points, at which point he wins instantly and becomes Mayor of New York.

name: Chuco
description:
This is an asymmetrical abstract game of movement. The game board is a grid of squares six deep by four wide, with the four squares in the upper left excluded and replaced by the game label. The result is two columns of four squares and two of six squares, with stars at each corner numbered from 1 to 31.

The stars are connected by pathways orthogonally and along alternating diagonals, so a given star may have as few as three connections on an edge and eight in the middle of the board.

One player takes the Chuco, a single large black plastic figure, and the other player takes 12 smaller blue hunters. Pieces may move one space along any path to an empty star, but the Chuco can jump an adjacent hunter if there is an open space behind it.

The Chuco moves first, starting on star #13, third rank in the middle. The hunters start across the first two ranks and on the two edge stars on the third rank. The hunters win if they can immobilize the Chuco by surrounding it on star 27. Since doing so requires all 12 hunters, the Chuco player wins by jumping a single hunter.

name: Strategonon
description:
Miniatures wargame played on a square grid, attempting to be more realistic and less chess-like than older similar efforts, without the complexity of map-based free movement wargames. Infantry and cavalry are represented by tiny painted metal figures placed in holes drilled in wooden tiles. Figures are removed to show losses from combat, although the exact number of soldiers remaining in each unit is tracked using pencil and paper. Artillery and various supply and naval units are represented by metal or cardboard figures.

Wooden blocks are placed on the board to show heights, and players can optionally build cardboard terrain following illustrations in the rulebook to place on the board instead of just using colored cardboard tiles to represent different terrain types. The cardboard terrain is flat and placed standing along the edges of map squares so that units can still be placed in the squares.

name: Stuff the Universe
description:
Stuff the Universe is a family friendly, turn based strategy game where players explore the universe to amass the most victory points. No game is ever the same as the universe unfolds while the players explore it, the Ancients arrive based on player actions, and the difficulty of navigating the sectors is affected by the battles that occur within them.

Equip your ship with crew and weapons to safely navigate the universe, colonize new worlds, and combat aliens that get in your way. The fate of your faction is up to you; what edge will you find that leads them to victory?

name: Taskutark: Hämmastavad küsimused ja faktid. Inimene
description:
"Amazing questions and facts. Human"
Small format trivia card game.
Question in on side of the card. Answer and amazing facts another side. Who first know the correct answer get the card as a point.

name: Taskutark: Ulmelised küsimused ja faktid. Universum
description:
"Fantastical questions and facts. Universe"
Small format trivia card game.
Question in one side of the card. Answer and amazing facts another side. Who first know the correct answer get the card as a point.
The player with the most points is the winner.

name: Taskutark: Virgutavad küsimused ja faktid. Sport
description:
"Stimulating questions and facts. Sport"
Small format trivia card game.
Question in one side of the card. Answer and amazing facts another side. Who first know the correct answer get the card as a point.
The player with the most points is the winner.

name: Taskutark: Imepärased küsimused ja faktid. Putukad
description:
"Questions and facts. Bugs"
Small format trivia card game.
Question in one side of the card. Answer and amazing facts another side. Who first know the correct answer get the card as a point.
The player with the most points is the winner.

name: Taskutark: Usukatud küsimused ja faktid. Teekond
description:
"Questions and facts. Journey"
Small format trivia card game.
Question in one side of the card. Answer and amazing facts another side. Who first know the correct answer get the card as a point.
The player with the most points is the winner.

name: Taskutark: Üllatavad küsimused ja faktid. Sõidukid
description:
"Questions and facts. Vehicles"
Small format trivia card game.
Question in one side of the card. Answer and amazing facts another side. Who first know the correct answer get the card as a point.
The player with the most points is the winner.

name: SECAN: The Number Puzzle Game
description:
SECAN is an innovative number puzzle game designed to challenge your mental arithmetic and combinatorical skills. Add, subtract, multiply, or divide two adjacent number tiles to solve the puzzle. Play one-on-one or in teams of two or more in this fast-paced game of number strategy.

Easy to Play
Players choose beginner, intermediate, or advanced level. Based on the level, they randomly draw a set of tiles and arrange them in a matrix. When all teams are ready, the first of three 5-minute rounds begins. Players add, subtract, multiply, or divide numbers to solve the puzzle.

The team with the best two out of three rounds wins the game!

name: Pro Locker Baseball
description:
This undated baseball game from Fairchild seems have evolved from the company's 1946 Baseball game. This game consists of two separate decks of cards: one of 28 Pitching cards and the other of 30 Hitting/Fielding cards. Also included are a small glossy baseball diamond and scoring box, erasable crayons for marking the score and wooden discs for baserunners.

To play, the Pitching cards are shuffled and placed face down between the players. The Hitting/Fielding cards are shuffled, and each player is dealt a hand of five. The batting player must discard and replace any Pickoff card, while the fielding player must discard and replace any Error card.

For each turn, the fielding player turns over the top Pitching card, which shows either a Ball, a green Fastball, blue Curve, yellow Changeup or a red Slider. The Batting player draws a card from Hitting/Fielding deck and then must try to play a card that matches the color of the pitch. Each of these cards has a number from 1 to 4. The fielding player then draws a card from the Hitting/Fielding deck and tries to match the color of the hitting card. A color match with a number equal to or higher than the batting card is an out; if the fielding card is lower, the difference is the number of bases hit/advanced. A card that doesn't match in color counts as a zero.

The batting player may use an Error card to automatically advance the batter and all runners by one base. The fielding player may use a Pick Off card to remove a runner on base. A fielding card 2 higher than the batting card is a double play if a runner is on first; 3 higher allows a double play of any two runners.

name: Election Frenzy: the Presidential Card Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

Election Frenzy is a new card game, based on the wild world of Presidential politics. Win the game by collecting endorsements, popularity, and media points. Attack your opponents with attack ads and scandals. Manage your campaign funds and win the Presidency!

In Election Frenzy, there are 3 rounds, and each round is split into two phases.

In Phase 1, the Campaign phase, players try to build the strongest hand possible, by collecting cards in the Popularity, Endorsements, and Media categories (suits); similar to poker, Uno, and Sushi-Go.

In Phase 2, the Attack phase, players use attacking cards to either burn or steal desired cards from their opponents; similar to Go Fish, and Bang!

The winner of each suit receives 2 electoral points, while the runner up receives 1. (Example: 1st place in Popularity = 2 pts. 2nd place in Endorsements = 1 pt. 3rd place in Media = 0 pts. TOTAL = 3 pts)

After 3 rounds, the player with the most electoral points is the President!

There are some really fun nuances to the game. Each character has strengths and weaknesses, based on the real life politicians who are being parodied. For example, Hillary has a bonus each round for the Endorsements, while Donald has a bonus each round for Media.

Each character also starts the game with a fixed amount of money. Money is needed to launch attacks. There is also money scattered throughout the deck, so even if you spend all of your cash, there is still a chance to replenish your funds by drawing the right cards.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Political

name: Jiffy Pop Chef Boyardee Crunch'n Munch Home Team Baseball
description:
This is an undated promotional game by packaged food giant ConAgra that pushed three of its brands. The game comes in a 9.5" x 14" envelope, and consists of a rules sheet and two folded and perforated sheets of glossy cardboard.

One sheet is made up of the playing field, stadium and 8 player cards, while the other has 18 player cards, 16 fly ball result cards, 16 ground ball result cards, 16 batter and runner figures, two dice (one red and one blue), and assorted signs and markers. The baseball stadium, scoreboards and the dice need to be assembled after separating the pieces.

Players draft their teams from the pool of 9 red and 9 blue players. The red players are long ball hitters and use the red die; the blue players hit more ground balls and use the blue die.

For each at-bat, the batting player rolls the appropriate die, which produces ball, strike, foul, fly ball or ground ball. When the ball is hit, players take one of the fly ball or ground ball cards and follow the results, which range from home runs to double plays. The usual rules of baseball apply.

name: Sky Dynasty: Deep Space Expansion
description: The Deep Space expansion adds 38 ship cards to the game. (9 unique ships)
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Shuffle: Trumps
description:
Two rulesets are included:
"The Families" where You may ask missing cards of You set from any player if he has he must give it to You. If You have all 4 cards of set You can place them inf front of You. The winner is the one who collects the most animal families.
"The Trumps" where players take turns reading off the requested
information. Whoever has the highest value wins the other players’ cards and puts them under his pile. If someone runs out of cards the player with the most cards is the winner.
More versions come with the app.

name: A Game of Games
description:
This social card game combines a plethora of different mini games that are simple to learn but will likely lead you to laugh until you cry.

Players will take turns drawing a card that contains some form of a mini game. There are no winners for each game, just a sole loser, as life should be. The game will continue until one loser shamefully accrues a certain number of cards, at which point the player with the least cards collected will win.

Does the game have trivia? Yup. Charades? Of course. Bluffing? Obviously. Dancing? Why not. Feats of flexibility? Sure. Laughing? Guaranteed. Awkward silence? Probably will also happen. Running away and hiding until someone comes and finds you? You'll have to play the game to find out!....but the answer is yes.

name: Cantabile Blitz
description:
The Grand Dean of an ancient, abandoned Victorian Theatre has a brilliant idea to rebuild it back to its former glory. Discovering that ragtag teams of utterly horrible musicians have been sneaking in and using the theatre for practice sessions, he decides to put every last remaining bit of his fortune into organising a tournament and invites these completely untalented teams to participate. They would be challenged to perform various musical scores in an extremely short amount of time. This is deliberate just so the true talents will be quickly picked out from the rest. The winning group shall hence be personally groomed by the Grand Dean himself into a world class orchestra team, where they would properly represent the currently dysfunct Theatre and make it famous again!

You are ringleaders of your own groups of musicians, and this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to become famous. Starting from a skeleton crew of horrendous talents, you will grow in strength and ultimately evolve into a mighty orchestra fit for any world stage.

Cantabile Blitz is played in Stages, which are then broken down into Performances. Every player starts off with the same set of basic dice, each die representing a musician of one type of instrument. At the end of every performance, the Grand Dean will reward better performing groups with more cash, which in turn allows them to recruit better and more musicians into their team. This is represented by more types of dice, eventually reaching a fully fleshed out orchestra. There are no turns in this game, and the actual musical performances are in real time. As soon as a musical score even remotely resembles its original tune by any of the groups' plays, the group can quickly submit their recording to the Grand Dean. However, the group that submits the score and ends that performance does not necessarily always win that round. They do have bonus points for doing so, but other bands might have raked up more points by completing more segments in the music sheet!

name: Druid's Road
description: As a druid, players must restore Purity back into the Drachnel Forest by casting Enchantments throughout various glades. There are 8 rounds in the game also known as Sabbats from the Celtic Wheel of the Year. During a turn a Druid must build a glade of the forest and then perform actions by himself or with the help of a summoned animal. Druids must try to Enchant a Glade to earn Spirit points. Glades that have less purity than others will earn more Spirit points. Each druid that creates a Triad (3 adjacent glades with their own enchantment) will score Spirit Points. Depending on the position of The Wheel of the Year, glade enchanting may prove difficult. Certain glades are also abundant with Druidic Magick; swiping other’s enchantments, using magical bursts, or summoning forest animals for assistance, to name a few. The more the game is played, players will come up with new strategies and new ideas on how to best earn Spirit. Each game will create a random layout of the forest, never knowing which glades will be present that game. And you never know what changing events the Drachnel Forest will unleash - so be certain to store up your Mind Power to use only when needed. The druid with the most Spirit Points after one year, wins!

name: Yeti Mountain: The Three-Dimensional, Adventure Board Game
description:
Yeti Mountain is a board game for 2-4 players, inspired by the classic game, Fireball Island from the 1980's. Yeti Mountain is played on a unique 3D game board where players race against each other to be the first to capture the Idol and escape the mountain. At any time, players can use cards to hinder opponents and help themselves. But watch out! An evil Yeti controls the mountain and tries to stop the players from stealing his Idol. He rolls snowballs at players sending them back into snow pits, slowing them down.

A turn consists of rolling the die and moving that number of spaces. If a player rolls a "1" on the die, they get to roll one of the many snowballs(marbles) and try to knock over the other players.

The first player to steal the Idol from the Yeti and escape the mountain wins!
categories: Adventure, Environmental, Exploration, Fantasy, Mythology, Racing
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Holland Wielersport
description:
The game contains 12 cardboard riders with a wooden base, and there are rules for 4 different races: Sprint, Poursuit, Omnium and Madison. The first three are individual while the latter is a team race, each team being composed of two riders.

The movement of the rides is determined by the roll of two dice, and the coloured squares on the board mean:

- red squares: advance two extra squares
- yellow squares: go back two squares:
- black squares: take a chance card

The player who's riders finish the race first wins the game.

name: Walt Disney's Pinocchio Playing Card Game
description:
This game is filled with temptation cards, all attempting to make Pinocchio do wrong. But have no fear - Jiminy Cricket is on hand to guard him.

This card game consists of 35 playing cards - 11 Jiminy Cricket cards, 11 Temptation Cards and 13 Pinocchio cards. The object of the game is to hold 4 Pinocchio cards together with 1 Jiminy Cricket card.

Five cards are dealt to each player and then players discard and draw cards until the winning condition is met. Players then receive 30 points for the winning hand, 5 points for each Pinocchio card and negative 5 points for each Temptation card. Jiminy Cricket cards do not score but cancel a Temptation card. First player to 100 wins the game.

name: One Moment Please
description: You throw the dice, move forward and complete the task. Sometimes you must answer a trivial question; sometimes you need to defeat another player in a mini game, and sometimes—to accomplish a small odd assignment. If you manage to do it—you stay where you are on the field or move forward, if not you have to move back. The player who gets to finish line first wins.

name: Minibluff
description:
A very simple new trick-taking card game where the first to play lowest card at last trick wins the game and losers are penalized according to the risks taken.
Minibluff combines Agurk game rule (playing a higher card or lowest) and Backgammon double dice rule (trick winner can ask others to double round value).
Combination of this makes Minibluff unique !

name: Albert's Big League Baseball Game
description:
This undated but likely mid-20th century title has an unusual mechanism based on two midway-style spinning wheels, one red for pitching and the other green for batting.

Each wheel has four large fins in the middle that players use to spin the wheel, vertical teeth on the rim between each of the 40 wheel segments, and a flexible metal strip mounted to a post on the corner that slows the wheel and eventually comes to rest between two of the pegs. There is also a thick cardboard field and plastic pegs to mark runners, balls, strikes and outs.

The fielding player spins the pitching wheel, which includes 12 strikes, 13 balls, 6 fouls, 1 foul pop out, and 8 hits. Balls and strikes may lead to strike-outs or walks, but on any hit result, the batting player spins the red wheel. That wheel in turn has 12 ground outs, 14 fly outs, 8 singles, 3 doubles, 2 triples and 1 home run. Most results have specific consequences such as tagging up, advancing runners or double plays.

name: QB8 Words
description:
Description from the publisher:
QB8 WORDS is a new version of QB8 where the cubes have letters instead of numbers and the goal of the game is to get exactly two cubes each of all four colors AND where you then use the eight letters to make one eight letter word or two words where one of the words has at least three letters.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Hoera! Hier is Koetje-Boe
description:
This is a dairy-themed roll-and-move game published as a promotional vehicle for a large Dutch dairy cooperative, Zuidelijke Melkbedrijven (ZM). The 66-space track starts in the bottom right corner and winds in various directions toward the "ZM meadow" in the center right, where happy dairy cows graze.

Various spaces along the way offer bonuses or penalties, and of course the first of the smiling, milk-drinking children to make it to the meadow wins.

The game box and board are not dated, but the HONGS website (Historisch Overzicht Nederlandse GezelschapSpellen or Historical Overview of Dutch Boardgames) dates it to 1968.

name: Randonnée de l'âge de pierre à l'ère atomique
description:
This undated but 1950s title designed by Edmond Dujardin (creator of 1,000 Bornes) is a transportation-themed roll-and-move game. The starting space shows a running caveman, and the 73-space track leads through a history of transportation modes. The last three spaces show a "modern car" with large fins, a 1954 motor scooter and finally the Railton Special, the car driven by John Cobb that set a land speed record of 394 mph in 1947.

The track includes various spaces with penalties and benefits, and the rules include both a description and date for the forms of transportation shown in each space and a two-page history of transportation through the ages.

name: Grand circuit des jeunes
description:
This undated motoring game comes in the form of a single sheet of thin cardboard with three panels. Two of the three panels form the game board, with a network of major and minor roads dotted with numbered obstacles and traffic signals. The third panel has the rules, the descriptions for the numbered spaces, six cut-out cars and three numbered tokens that are used instead of dice.

Players can choose whichever combination of routes they wish, but must respect the rules of the road - a rough road may be shorter, for instance, but require slower movement (two tokens instead of three).

The board has an artist's signature (Schreiner), but no date or indication of publisher. The physical format suggests that it might have been an insert in a magazine.

name: Les Jeux de 20 Heures
description:
Les Jeux de 20 Heures is based on the immensely popular French television game show of the same name. The show, which ran from 1976 to 1987 on the FR3 network, mixed celebrity contestants with ordinary people from a different region of France each week.

The rules for the board game include four quiz formats used on the TV show, all based on words and sentences:

La phrase de Maitre Capello, where one contestant makes up a short sentence and the others are given clues to try to figure it out;

Si je vous dis, where contestants are given an eight-letter word and must try to come up with as many other words as possible using that word's letters only once;

L'adverbe, where players try to guess an adverb drawn at random by asking questions; and

Le mot de la fin, where one player chooses a six to eight letter secret word, and the rest try to work out that word by proposing other words and getting feedback on which letters of the proposed word are either in the right place or included elsewhere in the secret word.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Word Game

name: Dippydisk
description:
This 1960s title is a manual dexterity baseball game that can be played indoors or outdoors. The game consists of a thick cardboard baseball field with a base and support that enable it to be mounted vertically, as well as four 2" concave plastic discs stamped to look like baseballs. The field has four holes that can be punched out: three semicircles in the outfields labelled 2 Base Hit, 3 Base Hit and Home Run, and one in the infield labelled Infield Out.

The field can be set up anywhere by placing the box lid upside down and mounting the field inside it. The players must agree on how far away the Battling Line should be. The rules suggest different distances depending on age and skill, from 20 feet for adults to less than 10 feet for younger than 9 years.

Each player in turn stands on the batting line and tosses the disks underhand at the field. Hitting the field on the fly between the foul lines is a single. Going through an outfield hole scores the labelled extra-base hit. Any disk that misses the target, hits the field after bouncing, or goes through the Infield Out hole is an Out. A player keeps batting until his third out, after which he scores the number of runs batted home that inning.

Each player (any number) takes one inning as batter and then the players repeat in sequence. The winner is the player with the most total runs after nine innings.

name: Whiz Football
description:
Despite being issued by the Electric Game Co., this game is made strictly of cardboard and wood and uses no power, probably because it was published in 1945 when wartime restrictions still reserved metal and batteries for military use.

The game has a wooden frame with the cardboard playing surface mounted at the bottom except for the 3" nearest the players, where it tilts up to the top, forming a ramp. There is a football field across the far end, with peg holes each 10 yards into which is mounted a cardboard "football" wheel marked 0 to 10. This is placed and spun to show the current line of scrimmage (a 4 resting on the 20 yard line = 24).

There are five holes spaced around the board, each surrounded by results for 11 different plays. There also are small circles, each labelled with one of those plays (pass, punt, trick, end, lateral, field goal, etc.) and a yardage result. The offensive player calls the play and a wooden football player is placed on the corresponding circle on the field. The offensive player then spins a wooden top down the ramp.

If the top goes into a hole, the results are read from that hole. If the top hits the man, the result is the yardage in that circle. If it hits the man and goes into a hole, the hole result modifies the circle result. If it misses, it means no gain, missed pass or field goal, and a poor kickoff or punt. Play and scoring proceed according to normal football rules.

name: Rudeness Rulez!
description:
Rudeness Rulez is a card game designed for children. It is similar to Cards Against Humanity, but differs in that players can use multiple cards to build sentences. The subject of cards is aimed at children and uses words that children would describe as 'rude', e.g. 'booger'.

Each player has a hand of cards, each with various words on them. One player then deals a 'start' card which has the start of a sentence on it, and the other players then try and come up with the best ending using as many of their cards as possible.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Pocket Dungeon Adventures: Army of Bone
description:
An Army of Bone approaches! The King of Bones marshals his forces to appease the Bone Dragon! Hope is scarce... but can You turn the tides of war? Face the hordes by yourself or with friends, as you seek to turn the Wheel of Fate in your favor!

Pocket Dungeon Adventures allows for up to 6 players to enjoy a light and fun dungeon exploration on the go! Choose from six different and unique classes, whilst battling against the enemy hordes! With each victory climb the ladders of fame and fortune!

In Army of Bone, players have lots of options with regards to gameplay and variety. They can opt to play solo, or choose from 2 to 6 player co-operative play. Then, players can choose to tackle either a single dungeon level (out of 3 varying difficulties), or face the entire dungeon as a 3 level campaign.

During the course of play, players will "explore" the dungeon level by flipping the dungeon cards, revealing items, traps and monsters. These will be acquired or defeated, gaining Gold for the players. Gold is used to purchase upgrades, to health, skills and weapons. Combat is resolved via dice rolling and use of skills.

When the Dungeon level is cleared, the Boss is challenged to gain access to the next level in campaign, or to gain victory, in single or final level play. After the campaign or level is defeated, all players win together in co-operative play. Note: if any player falls outside of a boss battle, the party automatically forfeits. In boss battles, fallen players are revived after it's defeat, to carry on to the next round.

Pocket Dungeon Adventures - Army of Bone is the first standalone game set in the Pocket Dungeon Adventures Universe (PDAU)!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: Monopologs
description:
Monopologs was developed in the RAND Logistics Department. In it, a player or group of players manages a simple simulation of the Air Force supply system consisting of one depot and five two-wing bases, which phase in during the game. The players thus "practice" inventory management and gain insight into inventory-control problems.

The player acts as the inventory manager for the "Widget" -- a high-value depot-reparable spare part -- and makes principal decisions of inventory control that such a manager has to make in reality. Aware of the given costs and lead times for each of his actions, he initiates procurement, plans repair schedules, and sets inventory and distribution policies.

True to practical Air Force experience, the demand for the "widget" is a random variable beyond the player's control. He is given certain limited information on the basis of which he must predict demands and establish inventory levels. He makes decisions, and in time learns their consequences. The game runs through a simulated period of 31 months, at the end of which he computes his score: the total costs his actions incurred. Some of the scores of past groups are included for comparison.

Many different groups have found Monopologs highly educational. The Air Force has found it useful for giving a broader management picture to many officers, particularly those concerned with only one phase of management, such as procurement or repair. Aircraft contractors have used it to acquaint employees with their customers' problems. At RAND itself, the game has helped to orient new employees and to stimulate logistics thinking.

name: Stickin' Around
description:
This board game is based on the 1990's television cartoon series "Stickin' Around."

The box contains two games that are played one after the other.

The first is called "Mix and Match the Illustrations." In this game, players attempt to assemble complete characters by collecting the correct heads, bodies, and feet cards. The more characters collected in this game will help players in the second game.

The second game is called "Turn the board for explorations." In this game, players roll dice to advance on a board towards the goal, planet Uranus. This game is a combination of luck and skill, as the characters that you collected in the first game can allow you to affect the game, such as stealing an opponent's character, or switching positions on the game board.

name: Trick or Treat
description:
Trick or Treat is a micro card game about pressing your luck to grab as much candy as possible before too many Trick cards show up. This is a SHORT micro Print and Play game for 1 to any number of players.

Description of a turn:
1. Shuffle the deck.
2. Draw a Card
3. Keep Treat cards and return Trick cards to the deck.
REPEAT steps 2-3 until you decide to quit or you lose. Then pass to the next player.
You gain 1 point for each Treat card that you take and you lose the game when you have drawn any Trick card 3 times.
Objective: Press your luck and see who can grab more candy!

name: Derelict
description:
Description from the publisher:

In Derelict, 3-8 players are exploring an abandoned space ship. What is the purpose of the ship, and the rooms that the crew discover along the way? That is yet to be discovered. But with a bit of knowledge and some luck, you may be able to survive.

Derelict is a tile exploration, worker placement board game for 3-8 players. Players work together to explore the derelict ship and gain resources along the way. At some point in the game, the purpose of the ship becomes clear. At that point, it is everyone for themselves as they try to escape.

With dozens of scenarios, Derelict can be played again and again, and each time will be different.
categories: Exploration, Horror, Industry / Manufacturing, Maze, Science Fiction
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Enclosure, Modular Board, Team-Based Game, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: TAKARO: The Anagram Exchange Game
description:
Description from the publisher:

TAKARO is the fast-paced anagram exchange game where players earn points by using game tiles to spell words and then exchange those tiles with the other team to spell a completely new set of words.

In round 1, each team draws any combination of 10 game tiles – consonants and vowels. Teams then roll the dice and choose a designated number of additional game tiles. To boost their scores, teams may decide to select a Power Vowel tile. This tile can be used to earn 10 additional points each round if used. When the round starts, teams will spell as many words as they can within five minutes.

At the completion of round 1, teams exchange all of their game tiles with the other team. In round 2, teams must spell unique words using the other team’s game tiles. Teams may not repeat words from round 1. The highest cumulative score wins!

name: GOLPH
description: Similar to Six Card Golf. This game is played with 9 cards that start face down in 3 rows of 3. At the beginning of game play one card is upturned (any card). On your turn you can take a new card from the draw pile or one that has already been discarded. There are cards ranging from -3 to 9, a few wild cards & also a lose your turn & a reverse order card. The object of the game is to have the least amount of points. If you get 3 cards in a row (diagonal, horizontal or vertical) all 3 cards count as 0 no matter what their face value. Game ends when one player has all 9 of their cards face up.

name: Toot: The Automobile Game
description:
This is a very early automotive-themed card game. It consists of a deck of 56 cards, divided into four colored suits with card values ascending from 1 mile to 14 miles.

Each player takes a well-shuffled suit, and the first player then turns over the top card. If it is a 1 mile, he starts his "Speed Pile" and can turn over the next card. If not, he places the card in a "Delay Pile", and the turn passes. No player may have more than three Delay Piles.

Each turn, a player then has the choice of turning over the top card in his deck or adding the top card from one of his Delay Piles to his Speed Pile. Each time a card is added to the Speed Pile, the player gets another play. When a deck runs out of cards, all cards in that player's Delay Piles are shuffled together and become the new draw deck.

The first player to complete his Speed Pile in sequence from 1 to 14 wins the hand, and gets points equal to the number of cards left in the other players' hands or Delay Piles. First player to 50 points wins the game.

name: Duck Shooting
description:
This is an early but undated shooting game from Parker Brothers. It consists of an 11.5" long metal and wood spring-loaded rifle, 0.6" long wooden bullets, 9 cardboard ducks held upright by small metal stands, and a decorated platform with 9 spots for the ducks. The spots have point values: 2 x 5; 2 x 10; 2 x 15; 2 x 25; and 50.

The box lid is placed upside down on the floor. The box is inserted vertically to form a backdrop, and the target platform fits in front of that. Standing "a few feet away", players get three shots each, and score points for each duck hit equal to the value of its spot. The targets are reset after each player turn. The first player to reach 500 points over multiple rounds wins.

name: The Road to the White House
description:
This a simple area-control, card-based U.S. election game aimed at younger children. It comes in a ziplock bag with a plasticized map of the United States, 4 crayons (red, yellow, green and blue), and a deck of 56 cards (50 state cards, a Washington D.C. card and five color-coded wild cards).

Players are dealt hands of five, and start by choosing one of their cards as their home state. Each player colors that state with his crayon. Each turn thereafter, a player starts by filling his hand to 5 cards either by drawing from the remaining deck or by stealing blind from another player.

To claim additional states, players must play cards for states that are adjacent to a state they already hold. In addition to playing from their hands, players may play the top card of the discard pile at any time. Players color in states as claimed, and only discard at the end of their turn if their hand still has five cards in it.

The states are color-coded by region, and there is one wild card for each region, plus a yellow wild card good for anywhere in the country. These allow players to claim non-adjacent states within the corresponding regions. Once all states have been claimed, the player with the largest number of electoral votes wins, with number of states held is a tie-breaker.

name: Cheese
description:
Cheese is a game of observation and quick reflexes.
Each player gets a card depicting a slice of cheese. At the same time, each player tries to be the first to complete its scheme: to do this you have to quickly take the pieces on the table and place them on the card, making them fit with the pattern depicted on the card.
The player who successfully complete the scheme first, takes the 3D piece of cheese in the middle of the table: he earns the pieces of cheese taken and draws a cat card.
The cat cards are penalties to be applied in the next round. Examples: use only one hand, use only thumb and forefinger, do not bend your elbows.
When the cheese cards end, the game ends: the player who earned more pieces of cheese wins.
The rules provides various game modes, with different levels of difficulty.

name: Play Letters
description:
Play Letters contains 400 cardboard letter squares and has directions for 10 word games:
1. Anagrams: 2-6 players. Object is to create words of three or more letters.
2. Build-a-Sentence: 2-6 players. Similar to Anagrams but you create sentences and you can take words from other players if you transpose letters to form new word.
3. Scrambled Letters: Players take letters and form a word and then scramble letters in their hands to pass onto next player to unscramble and correctly guess word.
4. Word Solitaire: Take all the letters in your name (or another place or name) and rearrange to form other word(s).
5. Ghosts: 2-6 players - Object is for each player to add a letter to letters already played by preceding players without completing a word of three or more letters.
6. Heads and Tails: Similar to Ghosts except played with words of 4 or more letters.
7. Add or O-U-T: Similar to Ghosts except you want to create words of 4 or more by adding letter to previously played letters.
8. Crosswords: Players alternate in adding words to crossword layout.
9. Tell Me What: Storytelling game where player starts a story and the stops the story and selects a letter. The first player to say an appropriate word to continue the story beginning witht he letter wins it.
10. Barnyard Hunt: 8 or 10 players. Leader hides letter squares in defined area (indoors or outdoors). Everyone goes off to find letters and when all are found each player uses letters to spell out as many barnyard related items as possible. This can also be played with other categories.

name: Casper & Lazarus
description: The game Casper & Lazarus is a board game for 2-6 players. Each player moves his ghost through the mansion trying to gather the treasures of Casper. Depending on the space on which you land, you can get the various treasures, advance or otherwise retreat, and some of them indicated a punishment. In his turn each player rolls a die which will indicate the number of spaces that must move. Win the game the first player (ghost) reaches the last space with the "wonderful potion", allowing him to become human.

name: What Is Inside It
description:
What Is Inside It is a full action packed, very thrilling & very exciting card game. This game is of high intensity and mafia like situation. It is truly a Russian Roulette. It is highly enjoyable and can be played with a number of family members and friends. This is a great game if you are looking to have a great time. This is also a perfect party game as well as a source of great entertainment and joy. If you love Action, Thrill, Big Sum Of Money and Heavy Explosions then this game is a must for you.

Background Story & Synopsis :

Imagine your self in a crisis situation and in an urgent need of cash. You end up getting in front of a loan shark who is also a crime boss, asking him for a million dollars. He places 3 briefcases in front of you and asks you to "pick one and open it". He further mentions that "only one of them has the million dollars in cash, one has the trash and one has the bomb. If you end up opening the case with the cash, you walk away rich, if you open the case with the trash, you walk away with nothing but the stink and if you open up the case with the bomb then you are a roasted meat". You take a good look at all the 3 briefcases, put in front of you to choose from. They all look exactly same, they all weigh exactly same, they also feel exactly same, but the only thing in which they differ is, what they carry inside. All the briefcases are completely odorless and produce no sound upon shaking them. They are completely sealed and locked. You may only choose one briefcase and you only get to know what is inside it, by opening it right there and right then. You finally choose and grab one briefcase to open it while wondering, what is inside it ...

GAME PLAY :

What is inside it is an exhilarating and an exciting game. A number of players can play it against each other. This game of odds, chances and strategy unfolds when a number of players are confronted with a number of cards with briefcases pictures on it. To open a briefcase, the playing card is flipped upside down so that the content of that briefcase is revealed. Without knowing what is inside of each card, the players pick up and flip one card at a time, upon their turn in each round. The risk element kicks in when all the players must instinctively choose and flip a number of cards, which are to be opened one at a time upon their turns, and the content of the card is revealed. As each card is flipped or turned, the likelihood of the players having a valuable cash amount such as a million dollars in the card or something else, such as a BOMB. The pressure mounts in each round, as the number of cards are turned or flipped. The players may also come under pressure by what might be contained in their chosen card. What is inside it ? cash or bomb or something else... The players will always be curious and puzzled, but they also know that as long as they do not intentionally or accidentally open the card with a BOMB or come under attack by any other opponent player, they are fine. There are multiple variants of this game, which can be played.

description from the publisher:
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Take That, Trading

name: Enlace
description:
ENLACE is a competitive, tile-placement abstract game which emphasizes its educational aspects, mainly, the stimulation of the observation & association skills in players.

Contents

140 printed tiles

Setup

All 140 tiles are shuffled, put face down and divided between 3 stacks of tiles of any given size. Each player is given 10 tiles that should be put in front of them facing up, so other players can clearly see them.

Gameplay

The player that begins the game takes one of his tiles, puts it at the center, then takes another tile from any of the three stacks and puts it next to his tiles; the next player chooses a tile among the ones he has whose 'printed pattern shape & color' properly links/connects and puts it next to the first one placed at the center, then takes another tile from any of the three stacks and puts it next to his tiles; and so forth...

When a player has no tile to properly link the ones at the center, he'll take one from any of the stacks, if this one also doesn't match, he loses his turn.

Object / Winning

When the stacks are gone, the first player who runs out their tiles wins the game.

In the case that no player can properly link/connect their tiles, the one with less tiles wins.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: Ground Force
description:
Ground Force is a free print & play 2 player scifi high luck strategy game.

The goal is to get one of your troops in the base of the other player. Destroying all the units of the other player will also make you win the game.

Each turn the player picks a card from his deck to see which troops he can move. Sometimes he can move different type of units in the same turn.

Each time a reinforcements card is drawn new units are placed in the base. The more mines (red spaces on the board) the player occupies the more units he can place in his base that round.

Units only move horizontal or vertical, not diagonal. Combat is done by rolling dice. The attacker has to roll swords or explosions, the defender shields or explosions.

There are three types of units: troopers. saboteurs and heavy weapon units. The troopers can occupy mines, the saboteurs are fast and can sneak behind enemy lines and the heavy weapon unit can shoot from a distance.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement

name: Hyakuninisshu Karuta English Translation 1-50
description:
Hyakuninisshu English Translated Karuta is an English translated version of the Japanese original karuta using the translation of the Japanese old poems from the anthology called "Hyakuninisshu".

The game is sometimes described as intellectual martial arts. It is about listening and being extremely focused and fast, just like the Samurai with their swords. Only here you fight with cards instead. The manga and anime and now a movie called "Chihayafuru" is about this game. For those who want to play like Chihaya and her friends but can not read Japanese, this is the game you are looking for. There is a free reader app which is a companion app to this english karuta called Hyakuninisshu EN. This reader app sings the poems in English, exactly like the Japanese poems with its unique melody because the translation we use, follows the waka form of the 5-7-5-7-7 syllables.

The game is comprised of two decks of cards, the Reader deck and the Player deck. Cards in the Reader deck contain the whole poem, while cards in the Player deck contain only the second part of these poems. To begin the game, a Reader is chosen (or you may opt to use the Reader app) and the players are divided into two teams sitting on opposite sides of the table or play area. The Reader shuffles the Reader deck and the Players mix, split evenly the Player deck between the teams and place them face-up in 3-4 rows in front of them. The Reader will read the complete poem on their cards and the player that finds the matching playing card first takes that card and puts it aside. If the card taken was on your opponent's side, you must give one card from your side to your opponent. The first team that has no cards left on their side is the winner (you must get rid of all your cards first, to win).

The game is set in Japan during the Genpei war (1180-1185). In order to win the war, you need a strategy. Place the cards you are familiar with close to you (in the beginning it is normal that none of the cards are familiar). If you know what cards your opponent is familiar with, place those cards as far as possible from them inside the playing field. Since the reader or app will always read the complete poem, you do not need prior knowledge of the poems. Strategically place the playing cards in a way that you can find and take them quickly such as laying them alphabetically or categorize them under the same first words.

name: Remedy: The Card Game
description:
Remedy is a fast-paced card game for 2 to 5 players featuring humorous characters, silly graphics and easy-to-learn rules.

There are 2 decks: the white deck that contains all of the illness cards and the green deck that contains, well, everything else. You'll draw from the green deck. At the start of the game, a card from the white deck will be flipped; this is your illness card. The illness has a number and your goal is to be the first to bring that number to 0.

To do that, you can use cards like “snuggly bed” or “delicious soup” to make the illness weaker and subtract from its number.

You can also use cards like “week old burrito” or “glass of toilet water” to make the illness stronger and add to its number.

In addition to all of that, you can play various action cards like “snot shot” or “disorienting diarrhea” to throw your opponents off and give yourself an advantage.

name: Funny City
description: Αστειούπολη ("Funny City") plays like Monopoly. As the name implies, all the roads and the cards and even the artwork of the game are funny.

name: Bomber Command
description:
This WWII British game bears neither a date nor a publisher, but vivid graphics make its objective clear: fly your planes to the big X over Berlin in the center of the board and drop your bombs! The board is almost square (13.9" x 12.8") and is divided into quadrants with player bases at the corners. There are two "Bomber Stations" at opposite corners and two "Fighter Stations at the other corners, where players start their planes.

The game itself is a spin-and-move affair, with snakes-and-ladders type tracks in each quadrant leading to two shared final approach lanes to Berlin. The bomber and fighter tracks have different hazard and bonus squares. In addition to the bonus and hazard spaces, a plane landing on an occupied space must return to base.

Each player has four planes, and must fly them sequentially to Berlin, needing to spin a 6 for a plane either to take off from base or to return from Berlin.

name: Championship 3 Dimensional Baseball
description:
This is really a baseball card game, but uses a cardboard box insert, folded into a six-sided ballfield with images of cheering crowds in the stands, as justification for the 3D sales hook. Even the player pieces are flat cardboard!

The card game itself is basic: shuffle the deck and turn over the cards one at a time. Each card reveals the results of an at-bat: a hit, a walk, or an out. Players take turns revealing cards, moving runners on the board and scoring accordingly, until their third out; then the other player has his turn. As usual, the player with the most runs after nine innings wins.

While the cards are very plain and printed on thin yellow stock, they provide unusually detailed color commentary: “Third Baseman Makes a Diving One-Handed Catch of Line Drive for an Out”; or “Ground Ball to Shortstop: He Throws High and Pulls First Baseman’s Foot Off of Bag. Batter is Safe.” There are supplementary instructions on each card for what happens to any runners.

name: Deities & Demigods
description:
Description from the designer:

Play as a demigod, and show your devotion to the deities of the Greek pantheon to earn their help moving your troops around the map, doing quests, erecting buildings and monuments, and controlling cities.

The action in Deities & Demigods is driven by an Olympus deck, containing cards for Zeus, Hermes, Ares, and Hephaestus. Each round a deity from Olympus arrives, and you may either show devotion to that deity with an offering of gold, or cash in your devotion to that deity by asking them for a favor:


Zeus will advance your position on an initiative track, which brings rewards, preferential turn order, and initiative when resolving quests later in the turn.



Hermes will bestow you with gold, which you can use to show your devotion to the deities.



Ares will grant you troop movement, allowing you to add troops to the board and move them around.



Hephaestus will build you artifacts, buildings, and monuments for special effects or end game scoring.


At the end of each cycle through the Olympus deck, you'll complete quests, and add a Hera card to the deck. When Hera arrives, you must meet her demands, and if you can, you will be rewarded with victory points!

At game end, you'll score points for the quests you've completed, the buildings you've erected, the cities you control, and the deities who's favor you've earned.

name: 5 Quadrat
description:
5 Quadrat is a collection of 25 puzzles for one person and games for two or three players, all played on a 5x5 grid with various pieces (wooden discs in several colors, matches, and dice).

Most of the games are traditional games played on such a board or traditional games adapted to the board. Credit is given in the rulebook to the books that they got the games from.

Four of the games are original. One other, Harlekin, is by Hajo Bücken; the rules say it was originally published in his Arbeitsstelle für neues Spielen but it is not clear what it was called there.

name: Baseball Spin-A-Game
description:
This mechanical game is like baseball crossed with a one-eyed bandit. The key to the game is a spinning roller mounted in one end of the plastic game case. Facing a baseball diamond that slopes down toward the players are 8 windows to cover all possible running situations: No one on, man on first, second or third, first and second, first and third, second and third, and bases loaded.

For each at-bat, the batting player pulls a lever on the side of the roller, which sets it spinning. When it stops, the result of the play is read out of the window that corresponds to the current state of the field. The results can vary widely: a home run with man on third can sit right next to pop-up out with man on second.

A baseball diamond covers most of the top of the game, with peg holes to enable runners to be tracked. Normal rules of baseball apply: three outs to an inning; nine innings to a game; highest score wins.

While the game is undated, it is likely c.1960, since the box shows the publisher as Hassenfeld Brothers but also displays the Hasbro mark that was used for years prior to the company name change in 1968.

name: World-Wide Headlines: Volume Two – Historical Events
description:
This is a party game comprised of 48 cards, each of which bears the title of a fake newspaper, a real date, and a scrambled headline. Players compete to be the first to yell out the correct unscrambled headline, and the player who succeeds most often wins the game.

For instance, the Freedom Final for December 24, 1776 reads: SHWANIGOTN ROSCSES LADEEWAR IVRRE. Solution: Washington Crosses Delaware River.

The game was published in four versions: World-Wide News (Vol. 1); Historical Events (Vol. 2); Show Business (Vol. 3); and Sports Highlights (Vol. 4).

name: Das Wohnen Spielen
description: This is a game about buying furniture by the local furniture manufacturer Rolf Benz. In it players spin a spinner and move from the "Rolf Benz showroom" in the middle of the board first to one of 4 appartments to claim one. Then they move to the different furniture stores on the outer edges of the board. Each of the furniture stores carries only 1 type of furniture. A player must get each kind for his/her appartment. Getting a furniture means answering a question read by another player. If the answer is correct a piece of furniture is awarded. Then the player must spin and go back to his/her appartment to place the furniture piece. There are also "action spaces" on the board where an action card is drawn and its instructions followed (e.g. swap a piece of furniture with another player). All the questions asked in the "furniture stores" are furniture or company related.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Z Europkiem przez Europę
description:
Europek - a cheerful dragon will take you on a journey through Europe. Along the way from Strasbourg to Cracow you will visit several European countrels and learn about their culture, geography and customs.

Players take turns to roll the dice and move their pawns on a board depicting the map of Europe. If a player lands on a space with a question, they have to answer correctly or move several squares back. The first player to reach the finish is the winner.

name: Dig it Out!
description:
In Dig it Out! players impersonate truffle hunters that, together with their loyal animals, sniff and dig our precious truffles to sell them at the village for the best offer.
Players control an animal among: Ermenegildo (an Italian Griffon), Cirilla (a funny Dachshund), BraccoUbaldo (a young Bracco Pointer) and Carlotta (a hog).

The board represents Acqualagna’s square (the Capital of the truffle, a little village in the middle of Italy), surrounded by three mountains represented by layers of hexagonal tiles one on top of the others. The hidden face of each hexagon can show a truffle (white or black and of different sizes), a mouse, an event or a snake.

At the start of each turn, players receive a number of kibbles as written on the initiative card. These represent actions that animals can do: move from one hexagon to another, sniff that is secretly examine one of the adjacent hexagons or dig that is take one tile and put it on the character sheet. But take care! The work of the truffle hunters is troubled by a wild boar that can scare the animals and eat their truffles!

The game is played through 3 seasons. Every season has specific rules regarding protected mountains and legal truffles. Forest rangers monitor the player’s behavior. They are activated by a roll dice and controlled by the active player.

At any point during the game, a player can decide to move to the little square and sell his truffles for Victory Points. At the end of the three seasons, the player with the most Victory Points is elected “Truffle hunter of the year”.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Memory, Pick-up and Deliver, Simulation

name: DecaDeck
description:
DecaDeck is a 54 card deck that can be used to play variations of traditional card games as well as new, unique games.

The deck contains 45 cards with 10 suits. Each suit has 9 cards numbered from 1 to 9. Each of these 45 cards has a unique pair of the 10 suits. There are also 9 special cards with no suit that can be used for a variety of different game functions.

This combination of suits and numbers allows for some unique variants of traditional card games.

For instance:
In a poker game, the chances of a pair are higher than with a traditional deck since there are 6 copies of each number, but the chances of a flush are lower with only 9 cards in each suit.

In a trick taking game, the lead card could have 2 suits that could be followed.

In a rummy game, each suited card could fit into a number meld or 2 different suit melds.

name: Game of Zoom
description:
Game of Zoom is a spin-and-move aviation race that involves four different spinners: a Dispatcher dial for take-off and landing, a second for determining Altitude, a third called Weather which governs movement forward, and a fourth called Radio which provides good/bad news as a result of some spins of the Weather dial.

The game is based on the birth of regular passenger air service in the United States, with each player flying between coastal terminals while stopping at cities along the way. There are four color-coded routes, and each player flies one plane E-W and the other W-E along his route.

Planes have a 50/50 chance of taking off or landing when they wish to do so, and if they fail, that player's turn passes. The altitude dial then determines how far into the sky spaces above the map that the plane moves, but this is for visual impact only. Planes must take off, move forward, and land at each city on their routes. Once a player has two planes en route, the Weather or Dispatcher spin can be used for either plane. Oddly, the four routes are not equal: two have 9 cities, one has 10, and the fourth (orange) has 12.

The game is undated, but because it was manufactured by E.E. Fairchild in Rochester while being marketed under the All-Fair brand, it was certainly published in 1938 or later, and most likely, given the theme, just after WWII.

name: Gold Rush: Dead Man's Creek
description:
Its 1851, the Gold Rush has been raging for three years and Old Man Biff has kicked the bucket. His widow Betsy has decided to return to civilization and sell her land rights to the best gold digger out there!

Gold Rush: Dead Man's Creek is a fast-paced scramble to be the first player to bank 10 gold and win the rights to the gold claim.

Players roll a die and move their pawns from town to the river to pan for gold and return the gold to the bank. Watch out though, other players are looking to steal your gold or stop you any way they can by using their attack cards! Can you survive the rush?!
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: The Gigolo Club
description:
The Gigolo Club is a frivolous card game. You have to find out who is who and then seduce the ones that are fitting your goals. As you do not know anybody’s character, you start asking them questions, either you go for one person and find out everything about him/her or you just ask for a characteristic up to all players.

When you find the right one for tonight you go on to seduce him. You give your character to him and he checks if your preferences fit and your aversions do not. You can help out with action cards making you more attractive or making your partner fit to your goals.

If the sexual preferences, the taste and aversions fit, your seduction is successful.

You can use action cards to seduce someone who is not interested in you or you can use them to frustrate the seductions of another player. You get one point for each goal you reached and then you pick a new character and new goals.

The player who reaches the most goals wins.

name: Failed Pursuit: The Battle of Chantilly
description:
The battle of Chantilly at the regimental level. Old School style of civil war regimental command games. This game will have written orders/Battle Plans for each army.

Battle Plans will play an important part in the games mechanics. The Focus here is on the command and control problems a commanding general would have. Fog of war and a lack of a Helicopter viewpoint for the commanding general are also present.

Each unit will have a fighting effectiveness rather than a casualties in terms of men lost. This allows us to combine the combat and morale mechanic into one.

Part of the Ravensworth Press 60 Minutes to Victory series of games.

—description from the designer
categories: American Civil War, Print & Play, Wargame

name: The Magic Flute
description:
Description from the rules:

There is a war brewing in the heavens! After a particularly nasty fight, Sarastro and the Queen of the Night are fighting over custody of their daughter, Pamina.

Two players take on the rolls of Sarastro and the Queen of the Night, each trying to either move Pamina to their respective strongholds, or to have their respective symbols of power reach the Tower of Wisdom at the center of the board.

By using the cards in their hands, Sarastro or the Queen of the Night attempt to sway Pamina, move their symbols, or create trials which everyone much face.

This game is based on the opera The Magic Flute by Mozart.

This game tied for first place in the Girls Got Game design contest at Ares Magazine.

name: Akhefru
description:
Akhefru, a city of splendors among the ruthless sands, one of the crown jewels of the Pharaoh.

The goal is to have the most influence over the city by recruiting important people and use with efficiency their abilities

Each game consists of three rounds, during which the players will lay down cards in front of them in a pyramid-shaped tableau by drafting cards from their hands. At the end of each round there will be a scoring phase.

The player with the most victory points at the end of the game is the winner.

name: US & German Ordinance Set #1
description: This set features a number of new ordnance for use with Global War 2nd edition. This set introduces a new concept to Global War – the idea that players can spend more IPPs for advanced ordnance, which they then expend to improve their outcomes in combat. Ordnance can improve combat values, improve the ability to select targets and in some cases give units abilities they don’t have, like being able to hunt IPPs on convoy lines. But be careful – Ordnance is expensive and its cost adds up. Most of the ordnance in this set relies on players to have, or at least have started research on advanced technologies which adds additional time and cost.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Das Ärgerspiel
description: Each player has 9 pawns, which he tries to get on the center space. Movement is determined by a die. Pawns are brought into play by rolling a 6. If a pawn gets on an occupied space it is either captured or it captures the other pawn, depending on the color of the occupied space. Pawns that are captured by pawns of their own color can be brought back into play, when a 6 is rolled. The game ends when all 9 slots on the center space are occupied or if one player has no pawns left in play. Pawns on the center space are worth 5 points and captured pawns are worth 1 point. The player with the most points wins the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Regent
description:
In preparation for the apocalypse that is the 2016 election, the assorted college students at Dawn of Time Studios made a simple political card game for 3 to 5 players that explores the most interesting and prevalent topics that pervade our legislative environment: corruption, bribes, and chasing your dreams of power and influence. Not only does every card you play have grave ramifications for the world at large, it also has a sardonic quote and description that was handcrafted by people who think they are funny.

Regent is a game about dark humor and betrayal, where your expertly executed play is rewarded by an unnerving realization that the world of politics is not that far removed from the depravity of this card game.

The cornerstone of Regent is the legislative mechanic. The regent has been given two to four policies and several bribes of varying values. Choosing a policy has several motivations - you can just choose the policy that gives you the most benefit or the one that harms the other players or choose because of the wonderful lobbying of the other players (i.e., several million dollars). Although the game runs on a purely mathematical system, the social aspect is what makes this game truly tense, entertaining, and thought provoking. Each chosen policy benefits one player or another, and in the end, whoever has the most points wins the game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Team-Based Game, Variable Phase Order

name: Providence
description:
A Game of Wretling. Control in theAge of Piray.

Provdence is a game. Players compete to strife with colonists within a growng epire.

Coloists are in every sense the players in the game. Their decide the fate of your blck marketering operate in Nassau.

Comprised of an inland estate and front. A oration is part of an indeent colony opeating away from the power of Brian’s interference. Players compete to beome the most not marketeer in the hief supplier for the many piate crews of Islnd by overeeing dalings with the colonists in Nasau.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Commodity Speculation, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Alaska Double Takes
description:
Alaska Double Takes is based on matching 48 spectacular photos of unique and scenic Alaskan Images. The rules are simple, but the challenge is sophisticated enough to intrigue players of all ages!

The object of Double Takes is to find matching pairs of photos. Start by spreading the cards face down on the playing surface. The first player turns over two of the cards at random. If the pair of cards turned over (for all to see) is not a matching pair, then the player turns them face down in the same position and the next player gets a turn. If the pair forms a match, the player claims the cards and gets to turn over two more cards. Play continues until all matches are found and claimed. The winner is he player claiming the most matching pairs.

name: Human Interface: Nakamura Tower – Masamune Drones
description: NAKAMURA CORPORATION DESCRIBES THE MASAMUNE DRONE AS A RAS (RECONNAISSANCE AIRCRAFT SYSTEM). POWERED BY NAKAMURA STAGE B ENGINE IT CAN FLY UP TO 160 KM. THE MASAMUNE BECAME THE PRIMARY DRONE USED FOR RECON MISSIONS AND TO PROTECT CORPORATE FACILITIES. SMALL AND AGILE IT CAN BE EQUIPPED WITH A VARIETY TYPES OF WEAPON - BOTH DEFENSIVE AND OFFENSIVE. THE APPEARANCE OF A DRONE IS ALWAYS A SURPRISE.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Point to Point Movement

name: Human Interface: Nakamura Tower – Muramasa Drones
description:
The past few weeks have brought more interesting news on arguments and accusations between Advanced Micromachines and Nakamura Inc. Disputes and lawsuits were followed by charges of attempted theft of fiscal reports and research results. Micromachines stock share price hit a slide after a leak of data stolen by a hacker, which in turn has sprouted conspiracy theories about competition involvement. Latest Nakamuras success streak in a few sizable bids for military equipment, traditional Micromachines domain, caused some nervous reactions from Micromachines management.

A few anonymous but reliable sources claim that the secret corporation struggle to win the best workers has escalated.
